title: Panam√° legaliza el uso de Bitcoin (BTC) en todo el pa√≠s para compras y pagos
content: Panam√° ha aprobado una nueva legislaci√≥n que permite a los ciudadanos comprar, vender y aceptar Bitcoin (CRYPTO:BTC) como forma de pago legal en todo el pa√≠s. Este paso consolida su lugar como uno de ...
resumen: Panam√° ha aprobado una nueva legislaci√≥n que permite a los ciudadanos comprar, vender y aceptar Bitcoin (CRYPTO:BTC) como forma de pago legal en todo el pa√≠s. La nueva ley es una extensi√≥n del movimiento impulsado en la capital, Ciudad de Panam√°, donde recientemente se autoriz√≥ el uso de criptomonedas como Bitcoin, Ethereum (CRYPTO:ETH) y stablecoins ‚Äî como USD Coin (CRYPTO:USDC) y Tether (CRYPTO:USDT) ‚Äî para el pago de impuestos, multas y tasas municipales. El concejal Mayer Mizrachi lider√≥ este primer esfuerzo local. Las instituciones p√∫blicas deben recibir fondos en d√≥lares, as√≠ que se asociaron con un banco que recibe las criptomonedas y las convierte al instante en USD. La decisi√≥n paname√±a llega en un contexto de creciente adopci√≥n de activos digitales a nivel mundial, en parte estimulada por las pol√≠ticas pro-cripto del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, quien asumi√≥ el cargo en enero. Desde entonces, su administraci√≥n ha impulsado una reserva estrat√©gica de Bitcoin y designado un ‚Äúzar‚Äù especializado en inteligencia artificial y criptomonedas. Bitcoin alcanz√≥ recientemente los 107.000 d√≥lares, apenas un 2,51 % por debajo de su m√°ximo hist√≥rico. Seg√∫n la firma de an√°lisis en cadena Santiment, los ETF de Bitcoin recibieron 6.630 millones de d√≥lares en entradas netas durante las √∫ltimas cinco semanas.

title: La compa√±√≠a espa√±ola OHLA rehabilitar√° la Carretera Panamericana Este a su paso por Panam√°
content: Madrid, 21 may (EFE).- La constructora espa√±ola OHLA se adjudic√≥ las obras de rehabilitaci√≥n y mejora de la Carretera Panamericana Este a su paso por Panam√°, un proyecto que contempla una inversi√≥n es ...
resumen: La constructora espa√±ola OHLA se adjudic√≥ las obras de rehabilitaci√≥n y mejora de la Carretera Panamericana Este a su paso por Panam√°. El proyecto contempla una inversi√≥n estimada de 230 millones de euros (260 millones de d√≥lares). El contrato, adjudicado por la Concesionaria Ruta del Este, se extiende durante unos 246 kil√≥metros entre la Ciudad de Panam√° y Yaviza, en la provincia del Dari√©n, e incluye trabajos de pavimentaci√≥n y ampliaci√≥n de bah√≠as de descanso y paraderos. Est√° previsto que las obras arranquen el pr√≥ximo mes de junio. La Carretera Panamericana Este es un eje estrat√©gico para la conectividad de Panam√°. En su conjunto cuenta con m√°s de 750 kil√≥metros de longitud. Con este proyecto, OHLA, en la que los hermanos mexicanos Amodio son los principales accionistas, ampl√≠a su presencia en Panam√°, donde actualmente ejecuta la extensi√≥n de la l√≠nea 1 del Metro de Panam√° y desarrolla las obras de mejora y ampliaci√≥n de la planta potabilizadora de Mendoza. Con este nuevo contrato en Panam√°, el grupo OHLA eleva su cartera en Latinoam√©rica de forma significativa con 800 millones nuevos en las √∫ltimas semanas, seg√∫n su consejero delegado, Tom√°s Ruiz. Latinoam√©rica es uno de los tres principales mercados, junto a EE.UU. y Europa, para el grupo espa√±ol.

title: Costa Rica dispuesta a eliminar barreras comerciales se√±aladas por Estados Unidos
content: El gobierno de Donald Trump detall√≥ seis obst√°culos que enfrentan los exportadores estadounidenses en Costa Rica. Las autoridades ticas afirman estar dispuestas a eliminar dichas barreras.
resumen:
Costa Rica est√° dispuesta a eliminar las barreras comerciales que Estados Unidos reproch√≥ al pa√≠s en un informe de marzo anterior. Dichos obst√°culos forman parte de las negociaciones que ambos pa√≠ses iniciaron este mes, en las que el gobierno de Rodrigo Chaves busca la suspensi√≥n del arancel del 10% impuesto por Donald Trump a las exportaciones ticas.

Manuel Tovar, jerarca del Ministerio de Comercio Exterior (Comex), confirm√≥ esta informaci√≥n.

El informe de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR), del pasado 31 de marzo, reproch√≥ los obst√°culos al comercio por parte de Costa Rica.

El an√°lisis fue presentado dos d√≠as antes de que Trump firmara la orden ejecutiva que estableci√≥ un arancel ‚Äúrec√≠proco‚Äù con la tarifa del 10% para las exportaciones de Costa Rica.

El documento Estimaci√≥n Nacional de Comercio (NTE, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) describe las barreras comerciales que Estados Unidos identifica en cada uno de sus socios comerciales, as√≠ como las iniciativas para reducirlas.

Las cr√≠ticas forma parte de los temas que se abordan en la mesa t√©cnica de negociaci√≥n entre ambos pa√≠ses, instalada la semana pasada en Washington. En junio pr√≥ximo se realizar√°n dos reuniones adicionales.

El equipo negociador de Costa Rica ser√° coordinado por la viceministra del Comex, Indiana Trejos.

Las barreras comerciales se√±aladas en el informe del USTR son:

1.  Impuestos a bebidas alcoh√≥licas: Costa Rica aplica un impuesto selectivo de consumo a las bebidas alcoh√≥licas destiladas, calculado como un porcentaje de alcohol por litro, con base en tres tasas espec√≠ficas. La tasa m√°s alta se aplica a las bebidas con m√°s de un 30% de alcohol por volumen, mientras que la mayor√≠a de las bebidas producidas por la estatal F√°brica Nacional de Licores (Fanal) se encuentran por debajo de este umbral, a diferencia de muchas importadas que lo superan.
2.  Licitaciones p√∫blicas: Las empresas estadounidenses afrontan desventajas en las licitaciones p√∫blicas en Costa Rica al competir con empresas estatales costarricenses, especialmente en los sectores de tecnolog√≠as de la informaci√≥n, telecomunicaciones y seguros.
3.  Barreras sanitarias y fitosanitarias: El Ministerio de Agricultura y Ganader√≠a (MAG) de Costa Rica retrasa ocasionalmente la emisi√≥n de permisos fitosanitarios de importaci√≥n para productos sensibles durante ciertas √©pocas del a√±o, como la temporada de cosecha, lo que afecta a los exportadores estadounidenses.
4.  Apertura en mercado de papas: El mercado costarricense para las papas de mesa estadounidenses ha estado cerrado desde el 2013. Estados Unidos export√≥ aproximadamente $3,4 millones en papas para fre√≠r a Costa Rica en el 2024.
5.  Trabas a productos de origen animal: Una regulaci√≥n costarricense del 2016 exige extensos cuestionarios a ciertas instalaciones que exportan productos animales a Costa Rica, como l√°cteos, mariscos, ovejas y huevos.
6.  Propiedad intelectual: Costa Rica debe demostrar, mediante informes, la eficacia de los nuevos programas para rastrear el uso de software sin licencia del sistema de registro en l√≠nea, a fin de mejorar el control fronterizo. Adem√°s, Estados Unidos insiste en que Costa Rica debe reforzar la protecci√≥n de la propiedad intelectual para frenar la pirater√≠a en l√≠nea y agilizar los procedimientos aduaneros que buscan disuadir la entrada de productos falsificados y pirateados.

Jaime Morales, gerente de Comercio Exterior de Grant Thornton, opin√≥ que ‚Äúes dif√≠cil saber‚Äù si Estados Unidos suspender√° el arancel establecido para Costa Rica.

Juan Carlos P√©rez Herra, docente de la Escuela de Administraci√≥n P√∫blica y polit√≥logo de la Universidad de Costa Rica (UCR), manifest√≥ que las seis barreras se√±aladas a Costa Rica son negociables dentro del marco del DR-Cafta.

Fabio Salas, socio de Impuestos y Servicios Legales de Deloitte Costa Rica, a√±adi√≥ que las barreras identificadas incluyen oportunidades de mejora en la gesti√≥n aduanera.

Las negociaciones sobre el arancel fijado a los productos costarricenses y las barreras comerciales que enfrentan los exportadores estadounidenses iniciaron el pasado 15 de mayo y continuar√°n durante junio.

title: Does Trump really have a 'winning hand' internationally? | Letters
content: President Trump‚Äôs mentality is that of an isolationist casino gambler.
resumen: President Trump‚Äôs mentality is that of an isolationist casino gambler. He believes the lie he has told himself that China and the rest of the world can‚Äôt beat his "winning hand" in his self-imposed tariff war. He believes the Chinese will fold and our citizens will step up and produce the products we presently import from China as we Make America Great Again by no longer being dependent on foreign trade for our economic prosperity. With our new tariff-based economic independence, we will dictate to all other trading partners, such as Canada, Mexico, and Europe, trade deals more favorable to us than the present ones. Furthermore, our self-sufficient isolationism will enable us to exploit our environment by ignoring the threat of global warming and ‚ÄúDrill, Baby, Drill‚Äù to reduce our huge national debt. Trump told Ukrainian President Zelinsky he didn‚Äôt have the cards to win his war with Russia.

title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq stocks slide as US-China chip feud rattles trade nerves
content: US stocks pulled back on Wednesday as investors weighed a flare-up in US-China tensions over chips and assessed Target (TGT)-highlighted retail earnings for insight into the economic impact of ...
resumen: US stocks stumbled Wednesday as bond yields continued to climb, putting pressure on equities as Wall Street fretted about the ballooning US debt while Republican leaders aimed to ready President Trump's tax bill for a House vote. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) fell more than 1.9%, or about 800 points. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) slid about 1.6%, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) fell roughly 1.4%. All three major indexes moved lower after a 1 p.m. 20-year bond auction saw weak demand, and Treasury yields surged. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield (^TNX) added 11 basis points to hit 4.59%, while the 30-year Treasury yield (^TYX) added 12 basis points to 5.09%, hovering near its highest level since 2023. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) rallied to a fresh record of over $109,000 earlier in the session before reversing with the broader market. Markets are reassessing a recent rally, with the S&P 500 snapping a six-day run of gains as relief over the surprise US-China trade truce faded. Growing concern about the US deficit and ballooning debt has intensified attention on discussions around Trump's tax-and-spending bill. Wall Street is keeping a close eye on Trump's giant tax bill, as Republicans try to appease all factions of their splintered caucus. Anxieties about the budget bill and the US debt have helped push up US bond yields. The US and China have begun feuding over chips again, less than two weeks after agreeing to a temporary pause in tariff hostilities. The Trump administration's warnings against using AI chips by Huawei have undermined the recent trade talks in Geneva, China said, putting the fragile trade deal at risk and reviving worries about economic fallout. Target missed badly on quarterly earnings and cut its full-year outlook. The US dollar fell to a two-week low. Stocks were having a rather mundane day until a 1 p.m. 20-year bond auction saw weak demand and Treasury yields surged. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield (^TNX) added 11 basis points to hit 4.59%, while the 30-year Treasury yield (^TYX) added 12 basis points to 5.09%, hovering near its highest level since 2023. Stocks subsequently sold off. Interest rate-sensitive pockets of the market led the declines, with Real Estate (XLRE) falling 2.6% to lead the S&P 500 sector action. The small-cap Russell 2000 Index (^RUT) also sank about 2.6%. OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) is purchasing Jony Ive‚Äôs startup, io, for $6.5 billion in an effort to develop a new family of products that take advantage of generative AI technologies. The 10-year Treasury yield rose above 4.5%. The Russell 2000 Index (^RUT) fell nearly 2.2%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) was down 1.1%. A 1 p.m. 20-year bond auction saw weak demand, sending Treasury yields surging. The 10-year Treasury yield (^TNX) added 9 basis points to hit 4.58% while the 30-year Treasury yield (^TYX) added 10 basis points to 5.07%, hovering near its highest level since 2023. Stocks reversed as yields rose, with all three of the major indexes quickly hitting their lows on the day. Canada Goose (GOOS) stock rose nearly 30% after the luxury coat maker posted strong first quarter results. Alphabet (GOOG,GOOGL) stock led a tech rally as shares rose nearly 5%. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) rallied more than 4% to hit a new all-time high of $109,468 per coin. The S&P 500's (^GSPC) macro moment may be over. The correlation between stocks in the S&P 500 has tumbled to about 0.16. CoreWeave (CRWV) stock is ripping higher again on Wednesday. Shares were up more than 10% in early trading. Citi analyst Tyler Radke boosted his 12-month price target to $94. Target (TGT) shares fell more than 7% in early trading after the company posted earnings results that were weaker than expected and warned of a potential drag from tariffs. The 30-year Treasury yield (^TYX) rose above the closely watched 5% level on Wednesday morning. UnitedHealth Group stock (UNH) traded % lower an hour ahead of the opening bell. HSBC downgraded UnitedHealth shares to Reduce from Hold and slashed its price target by around 45% to $270. Lowe's stock (LOW) popped 2% on Wednesday after delivering earnings that beat subdued expectations. Target (TGT) stock fell over 3% premarket on Wednesday after the retailer reported first quarter results that came in shy of Wall Street's expectations. Shares of Wolfspeed (WOLF) plunged over 60% on Wednesday on the heels of a report that the semiconductor supplier is getting ready to file for bankruptcy within weeks. Traders faced a widespread outage to Bloomberg's terminal early on Wednesday morning. The dollar (DX=F) sank to a two-week low overnight Tuesday as the US's mounting debt concerns continue to impact the greenback. Oil prices jumped.

title: FMI, Banco Mundial y BID visitan Ecuador para analizar acuerdos de financiaci√≥n
content: Guayaquil (Ecuador), 21 may (EFE).- Representantes del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), del Banco Mundial y del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (BID) analizan con el Gobierno de Ecuador, en Qui ...
resumen:
Representantes del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), del Banco Mundial y del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (BID) analizan con el Gobierno de Ecuador, en Quito, avances en acuerdos de financiaci√≥n que est√°n en marcha, as√≠ como la posible implementaci√≥n de nuevos programas de cara al inicio del nuevo periodo del presidente Daniel Noboa desde el pr√≥ximo s√°bado, se√±al√≥ el Ministerio de Econom√≠a y Finanzas.

La nueva jefa de misi√≥n del FMI para Ecuador, Patrizia Tumbarello, est√° en Quito para presentarse ante las autoridades nacionales y continuar con las conversaciones para avanzar hacia la segunda revisi√≥n del Acuerdo del Servicio Ampliado que el pa√≠s mantiene con este organismo. El acuerdo, por 4.000 millones de d√≥lares, se aprob√≥ el a√±o pasado y el pa√≠s andino -que ya recibi√≥ 1.500 millones de d√≥lares- est√° a la espera de que el FMI apruebe la segunda revisi√≥n de metas para que un nuevo desembolso.

Representantes del BM est√°n en el pa√≠s con el objetivo de preparar el financiamiento del programa de apoyo presupuestario para la creaci√≥n de empleo y la resiliencia fiscal.

Delegados del BID llegaron a Ecuador para conversar sobre el financiamiento del programa de resiliencia econ√≥mica, crecimiento y productividad.

En las reuniones participan la ministra de Econom√≠a y Finanzas, Sariha Moya, y el gerente general del Banco Central, Guillermo Avell√°n, entre otros.

Moya estuvo recientemente en China para asistir al IV Foro Ministerial de China y la Comunidad de Estados de Latinoam√©rica y el Caribe (Celac), y en el marco de esa visita se reuni√≥ con bancos de ese pa√≠s para explorar nuevas oportunidades de financiaci√≥n para proyectos que generen beneficios concretos para los ecuatorianos.

Entre las instituciones financieras con las que Moya sostuvo reuniones figuran el Banco Industrial y Comercial de China (ICBC), Banco de China, Banco de Desarrollo de China (CDB), Banco de Exportaci√≥n e Importaci√≥n de China (Eximbank) y el Banco Asi√°tico de Inversi√≥n en Infraestructura (AIIB).

La ministra dio a conocer los proyectos prioritarios del Gobierno de Noboa, particularmente en el sector de energ√≠as renovables y carreteras y expres√≥ el inter√©s del pa√≠s de contar con alternativas de financiaci√≥n a trav√©s de bancos e inversionistas chinos.

content: Surinam vota el domingo para renovar su parlamento, responsable a su vez por escoger al pr√≥ximo presidente para cambiar la suerte del pa√≠s, uno de los m√°s pobres de Sudam√©rica y que ha descubierto gra ...
resumen:
Surinam vota el domingo para renovar su parlamento, responsable a su vez por escoger al pr√≥ximo presidente para cambiar la suerte del pa√≠s, uno de los m√°s pobres de Sudam√©rica y que ha descubierto grandes reservas de petr√≥leo.

Surinam es la naci√≥n m√°s peque√±a de Sudam√©rica, con 600.000 habitantes, y la √∫nica con neerland√©s como idioma oficial.

Batalla contra una alta deuda, una inflaci√≥n galopante y la pobreza que afecta a casi una de cada cinco personas.

El domingo, los surinameses escoger√°n un nuevo parlamento de 51 miembros, que en semanas deben elegir presidente y vicepresidente para los pr√≥ximos cinco a√±os.

El mandatario saliente, Chan Santokhi, est√° constitucionalmente habilitado para un segundo periodo, pero las encuestadoras no arrojan favoritos de momento, ya que ninguno de los 14 partidos aparece con ventaja clara.

Expertos indican que Surinam podr√≠a ganar miles de millones de d√≥lares en los pr√≥ximos 10 a 20 a√±os tras el descubrimiento de reservas de petr√≥leo en altamar.

El grupo franc√©s TotalEnergies anunci√≥ un proyecto de 10.500 millones de d√≥lares para explotar durante los pr√≥ximos cuatro a√±os el yacimiento petrol√≠fero de GranMorgu, en aguas profundas de Surinam, con una capacidad estimada de producci√≥n de 220.000 barriles diarios.

La producci√≥n debe comenzar en 2028, y el pa√≠s ha creado un fondo soberano similar al de Noruega para ahorrar dinero para tiempos dif√≠ciles.

Catorce organizaciones pol√≠ticas participan en las elecciones del domingo, incluidos el centrista Partido de la Reforma Progresista (VHP) de Santokhi y el Partido Nacional Democr√°tico (NDP) del exdictador luego convertido en presidente Desi Bouterse, fallecido a fines del a√±o pasado.

En la contienda tambi√©n compite el Partido de Liberaci√≥n General y Desarrollo (APOB) del vicepresidente Ronnie Brunswijk.

Santokhi entra en la carrera tras ser blanco de cr√≠ticas por sus medidas austeras y alzas en los impuestos como parte de una reestructuraci√≥n solicitada por el Fondo Monetario Internacional.

El presidente anunci√≥ recientemente el programa ¬´Regal√≠as para todos¬ª (RVI, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) para que cada ciudadano reciba un bono de 750 d√≥lares como parte de las futuras ganancias petroleras, con una tasa de inter√©s de 7%.

Surinam, un pa√≠s diverso conformado por descendientes de India, China, Pa√≠ses Bajos, Indonesia, grupos ind√≠genas y esclavos africanos, celebrar√° en noviembre su 50¬∫ aniversario de la independencia del trono neerland√©s.

Fue uno de los primeros pa√≠ses de Latinoam√©rica en sumarse en 2019 al megaproyecto chino de la Ruta de la Seda.

El secretario de Estado estadounidense, Marco Rubio, hizo escala en Surinam en marzo, en el marco de una gira latinoamericana destinada a contrarrestar la creciente influencia de China en la regi√≥n.

M√°s del 90% del pa√≠s est√° compuesto por bosques, y es uno de los pocos en el mundo con una huella de carbono negativa.

title: The great battery race: China and the U.S. compete over the future of EVs
content: The car you drive years in the future might run off a battery being invented in a lab today. Companies in China and the United States are racing to perfect and scale up next-generation technologies.
resumen: Lithium-ion batteries were invented in the United States, but China took the lead in mass-producing them. There's a race to see who will dominate the future of EV batteries. Chinese automakers are announcing newer, better batteries at a breakneck speed, including vehicles promising 5-minute "flash charge" times. More than half of new cars sold in China come with a plug. In the U.S., plug-in sales are lower and policies promoting EVs are politically divisive. The Trump administration has started the process of rolling back incentives, infrastructure and requirements encouraging them. Globally, battery-powered cars remain a crucial part of plans to reduce the catastrophic impacts of climate change. U.S. companies are still feeling intense pressure to improve their battery offerings. General Motors engineers in Detroit announced a cheaper long-range battery. Bob Galyen, a retired executive whose long career in automotive batteries spanned both GM and the Chinese battery giant CATL, says the Chinese are ahead in manufacturing technology. American labs are still coming up with new ideas. In Shanghai, cars that can pivot on the spot, operate in water, and concept cars with quadcopter rotors were on display. BYD, the world's biggest EV maker by sales and China's top brand, put on display a drone pod that attaches to the roof of a car. BYD was demonstrating "flash charging" at 1 megawatt (1,000 kW). An engineer on site said it can add two kilometers of range per second, or 400 kilometers in five minutes. BYD is planning to install 4,000 fast charging stations across China. Chinese cars are largely absent from U.S. roads. U.S. consumers can't buy any of the buzzy Chinese EVs on the market. GM's new battery chemistry is a "lithium manganese-rich," or LMR, battery, to be produced in partnership with LG Energy Solutions and deployed in vehicles starting in 2028. GM says its new battery uses a lot more manganese and less of pricey materials like nickel and cobalt. GM says the battery can store almost as much energy as today's most expensive EV batteries, but at a cost comparable to the cheapest version. GM battery engineer Andy Oury says the steps you follow determine the final product. Shriram Santhanagopalan, the company's senior manager of advanced battery cell development, pointed through a window into a sealed, humidity-controlled room featuring a waist-high silver metal device. Evelina Stoikou, with the research company BloombergNEF, says GM's recipe should translate directly into longer range. Sam Abuelsamid, a longtime auto analyst, says using more of a cheaper input like manganese can make it easier to find alternative supplies. GM has invested in a company called Element 25 that plans to build a U.S. refinery for Australian-sourced manganese. Companies around the world are racing to build batteries based on sodium or "solid-state" batteries. Kurt Kelty, GM's vice president of battery, propulsion and sustainability, says GM is talking with start-ups about their solid-state technology. In the race for new battery tech, China has an advantage. Ford is licensing some technology made by Chinese battery maker CATL for use in American-made vehicles. China has already built up its domestic battery industry and is in the process of a global expansion. Geo Taveras, an influencer from the Dominican Republic, was filming a demonstration of flash charging. Chinese EV and battery companies, like BYD, have grown quickly on the back of strong government investment and subsidies. CATL is rolling out ultra-fast-charging car batteries and launching a battery powered by sodium.

title: Precios de productos en EE.UU.: Empresas prometen trasladar costos de aranceles ¬øInmigrantes hispanos ser√°n uno de los grupos m√°s afectados?
content: Los precios de los productos en EE.UU. se incrementar√≠an por cuesti√≥n de aranceles y los consumidores ser√≠an los m√°s afectados.
resumen:
Los precios de los productos en EE.UU. se incrementar√≠an por cuesti√≥n de aranceles y los consumidores ser√≠an los m√°s afectados.
La situaci√≥n econ√≥mica en los Estados Unidos promete ingresar a un escenario que algunos consideran puede ser peor, debido a que las diferentes medidas del presidente Donald Trump han repercutido en las empresas.
El 54% de las compa√±√≠as estadounidenses encuestadas asegur√≥ que se ver√° en la obligaci√≥n de aumentar el costo de sus bienes para adaptarse a las medidas econ√≥micas implantadas por el presidente Donald Trump.
La encuesta tambi√©n involucr√≥ a empresas de pa√≠ses desarrollados como China, Reino Unido, Francia, Alemania, Singapur y Espa√±a, las cuales indicaron, en su gran mayor√≠a, que no est√°n en capacidad de absorber todo el costo por aranceles sin tener que trasladarlo al precio de sus productos.
Esta inminente subida de precios hace que el consumidor sea el principal afectado, haciendo que fen√≥menos como la inflaci√≥n puedan presentarse r√°pidamente, y la capacidad adquisitiva de diferentes familias se resentir√≠a.
Las pol√≠ticas de Donald Trump parecen encaminadas a reducir el d√©ficit fiscal, mientras que su promesa de devolver poder a la clase media se est√° quedando solo en propuesta porque este tipo de medidas no la favorecen para nada.
Los resultados de esta encuesta se producen despu√©s de los anuncios del presidente Trump de elevar los aranceles a productos chinos, lo cual ha ocasionado una guerra comercial que pone a tambalear la econom√≠a mundial.
Walmart asegur√≥ que no puede absorber los costos por la subida de aranceles sin trasladarlos a los precios de sus productos, lo cual gener√≥ la cr√≠tica de Donald Trump asegurando que esta empresa gana miles de millones de d√≥lares, muchos m√°s de los esperados, y por ello, deber√≠a hacerse cargo del costo de dichos aranceles y no cobrarlo a sus clientes.
Uno de los grupos poblacionales m√°s perjudicados con la subida de los precios es el de los inmigrantes latinos, bien sean indocumentados o legales, pues estos √∫ltimos, a pesar de su estatus en los Estados Unidos, no son tradicionalmente los que ganan m√°s dinero y un porcentaje de ellos hace parte de la poblaci√≥n m√°s empobrecida del pa√≠s.

title: Hasta finales de junio Ecuador busca cerrar negociaci√≥n con Estados Unidos por arancel del 10 %
content: Empresarios aseguran que esa negociaci√≥n es una primera fase y que la segunda ser√° empezar di√°logos para un acuerdo comercial.
resumen:
Ecuador busca cerrar la negociaci√≥n con Estados Unidos por el arancel rec√≠proco del 10 % impuesto desde el 5 de abril pasado a m√°s de 180 naciones, con el objetivo de que la tasa sea retirada en un corto plazo.
El viernes pasado, dirigentes del sector empresarial y exportador se reunieron con el ministro de Producci√≥n, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca, Luis Alberto Jaramillo, para conocer los avances de las conversaciones.
Ecuador es uno de los 19 primeros pa√≠ses que ya negocian con Estados Unidos.
Richard Salazar, director ejecutivo de la Asociaci√≥n de Comercializaci√≥n y Exportaci√≥n de Banano del Ecuador (Acorbanec), particip√≥ en la reuni√≥n.
El banano es el tercer producto de la oferta exportable de Ecuador en Estados Unidos, detr√°s del camar√≥n y el cacao.
De enero a marzo pasado los env√≠os de la fruta representaron $ 194 millones.
El Comit√© de Comercio Exterior (Comex), autoriz√≥ al Ministerio de Producci√≥n, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca para empezar negociaciones comerciales con Estados Unidos.
Bruno Leone, presidente de la C√°mara Nacional de Pesquer√≠a, tambi√©n particip√≥ en la reuni√≥n.
Estos di√°logos entre Ecuador y Estados Unidos se enmarcan en la pr√≥rroga de 90 d√≠as que dio el presidente Donald Trump para que los pa√≠ses negocien.
Estados Unidos impuso un nuevo cero, que es el 10 %, y la aspiraci√≥n de Ecuador es que en esta etapa, que termina en junio, ese 10 % vuelva a 0 %.
Antes de la tasa del 10 %, Ecuador pagaba 12 % de arancel para el at√∫n en agua y 36 % para at√∫n en aceite.
Con $ 34 millones en exportaciones, Estados Unidos es el tercer mejor destino de las conservas de at√∫n ecuatorianas en el primer trimestre del 2025.
En primer lugar est√° la Uni√≥n Europea con $ 181 millones, seguida de Latinoam√©rica con $ 77 millones.
La reuni√≥n con el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, y parte de su equipo, se realiz√≥ el 8 de abril en Washington.
Se prev√©n tres reuniones m√°s, dos de las cuales se realizar√°n en la capital estadounidense.
La disposici√≥n de retirar el arancel vendr√≠a de la Oficina del representante comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR).
Ecuador ya dio un primer paso buscando una acci√≥n de reciprocidad de Estados Unidos, al rebajar al 10 % los aranceles para los veh√≠culos importados a Ecuador desde ese pa√≠s a partir del 10 de abril pasado.
Las estrategias de Ecuador se enmarcan en las 16 limitantes que la USTR detect√≥ en Ecuador que dificultan el comercio exterior.
En la reuni√≥n con Jaramillo tambi√©n se plante√≥ la posibilidad de constituir un cuarto adjunto que permitir√° al sector productivo exportador participar en el seguimiento t√©cnico del proceso.
Esta modalidad se cre√≥ en el 2021, pero se oficializ√≥ en julio del 2022 con el Acuerdo Ministerial MPCEIP-2022-0009-A.
El cuarto adjunto genera un di√°logo directo entre el ministerio y los actores del sector productivo, a trav√©s del Comit√© Empresarial Ecuatoriano (CEE).
El sector empresarial insiste en que Ecuador debe ir a una segunda fase en busca de un acuerdo amplio.

title: Ecuador intensifica negociaciones con EE.UU. para que elimine arancel del 10% a sus exportaciones
content: Este tiempo permite a los pa√≠ses afectados negociar. Leone explica que Estados Unidos implement√≥ un nuevo ¬´cero¬ª, que es el 10%. La aspiraci√≥n de Ecuador es restaurar el 0% de arancel. Se busca ...
resumen: Ecuador intensifica negociaciones con EE.UU. para que elimine arancel del 10% a sus exportaciones. El sector exportador ecuatoriano impulsa el di√°logo con Estados Unidos para reducir barreras comerciales. El banano ecuatoriano representa el tercer producto exportable m√°s importante hacia Estados Unidos, solo detr√°s del camar√≥n y el cacao. Los env√≠os de banano alcanzaron $194 millones entre enero y marzo. El 13 de mayo, el Comit√© de Comercio Exterior autoriz√≥ al Ministerio de Producci√≥n iniciar negociaciones formales. Richard Salazar, director ejecutivo de Acorbanec, subraya el progreso logrado. El empresario particip√≥ en una reuni√≥n clave con el ministro de Producci√≥n, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca, Luis Alberto Jaramillo. Las conversaciones entre Ecuador y Estados Unidos aprovechan la pr√≥rroga de 90 d√≠as concedida por el presidente Donald Trump. Estados Unidos implement√≥ un nuevo ¬´cero¬ª, que es el 10%. La aspiraci√≥n de Ecuador es restaurar el 0% de arancel. Se busca regresar a las condiciones arancelarias anteriores antes de que termine junio. El sector pesquero del pa√≠s tambi√©n siente el impacto directo del arancel del 10%. Con $34 millones en exportaciones durante el primer trimestre de 2025, Estados Unidos es el tercer mejor destino para las conservas de at√∫n ecuatorianas. La Uni√≥n Europea lidera con $181 millones, seguida por Latinoam√©rica con $77 millones. Richard Salazar destaca la excelente predisposici√≥n de las autoridades comerciales de EE.UU. El dirigente exportador anticipa tres citas m√°s, dos de ellas en la capital estadounidense. La disposici√≥n de retirar el arancel provendr√° de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR). Ecuador ya dio un primer paso significativo buscando reciprocidad de Estados Unidos, redujo al 10% los aranceles para veh√≠culos importados desde ese pa√≠s, medida que entr√≥ en vigencia el 10 de abril. Las estrategias de Ecuador se enmarcan en 16 limitantes. La reuni√≥n con el ministro Luis Alberto Jaramillo tambi√©n plante√≥ la creaci√≥n de un ‚Äúcuarto adjunto‚Äù. El ¬´cuarto adjunto¬ª se oficializ√≥ en julio de 2022. Este mecanismo opera a trav√©s del Comit√© Empresarial Ecuatoriano (CEE). Esta modalidad ya demostr√≥ su efectividad. Adem√°s de esta primera etapa, centrada en la eliminaci√≥n del arancel del 10%, el sector empresarial ecuatoriano ya mira hacia el futuro. Bruno Leone se√±ala que la USTR ha dado se√±ales positivas. Salazar comparte esta misma visi√≥n.

title: Guyana‚Äôs army chief says Venezuelans participating in Essequibo vote risk arrest
content: Guyana is warning that anyone living in the South American country who participates in upcoming elections organized by neighboring Venezuela over a disputed region will be charged with crimes ...
resumen: Guyana‚Äôs defense chief, Brig. Gen. Omar Khan, warned that any residents who participate in upcoming elections organized by Venezuela over the disputed Essequibo region will be charged with treason and other felony crimes. The May 25 election organized by Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro is the latest step in a push to annex the Essequibo region, which Venezuela has long claimed as its own. Venezuelans living in Guyana who become involved in Sunday‚Äôs elections could also face arrest and deportation. Nearly 100,000 people of direct or indirect Venezuelan ancestry currently live in Guyana, according to Foreign Secretary Robert Persaud. The Essequibo region represents two-thirds of Guyana and is rich in gold, diamonds, timber and other natural resources. It also is located close to massive offshore oil deposits, with current production averaging some 650,000 barrels daily. On Sunday, Venezuelans will head to the polls to elect governors and lawmakers, as well as officials who would supposedly administer the Essequibo region. In 2023, Maduro threatened to annex the region by force after holding a referendum asking voters if Essequibo should be turned into a Venezuelan state. The dispute over the region began more than a century ago, when an international tribunal in 1899 drew the border between the South American neighbors. In 2018, Guyana went to the International Court of Justice and asked judges to uphold the 1899 ruling. Meanwhile, Venezuela has dismissed the border drawn more than a century ago, noting Guyana was still a British colony. The case is still pending in court while tensions between the two countries keep rising despite an emergency summit held in late 2023 to diffuse the situation. Last week, Guyana‚Äôs government reported three separate attacks from the Venezuelan side on Guyanese soldiers patrolling a border river. Earlier this year, six Guyanese soldiers were injured in a separate attack. U.S. Ambassador Nicole Theriot has dismissed Maduro‚Äôs threats.

title: Agroexportaci√≥n peruana: entre los aranceles y los desaf√≠os estructurales
content: En ‚ÄúDi√°logos‚Äù, espacio promovido por Gesti√≥n, expertos analizan c√≥mo este escenario afecta al Per√∫ y qu√© oportunidades se pueden aprovechar.
resumen:
La tensi√≥n comercial global, marcada por los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos, puso en alerta a los agroexportadores peruanos. En ‚ÄúDi√°logos‚Äù, espacio promovido por Gesti√≥n junto con la Escuela de Direcci√≥n Universidad de Piura (PAD), tres expertos analizaron el panorama para el sector.

Juan Carlos Mathews, exministro de Comercio Exterior y Turismo, se√±al√≥ que no ser√≠a conveniente para el gobierno peruano ‚Äúponerse bajo los reflectores‚Äù de una ‚Äúnegociaci√≥n‚Äù con Donald Trump. Propuso una postura agresiva pero dirigida al mercado empresarial norteamericano, invitando a compa√±√≠as estadounidenses a invertir en Per√∫ destacando los TLC con acceso a diversos mercados, la ubicaci√≥n estrat√©gica para rutas directas y fletes favorables a Asia, y la reciente Ley de Zonas Econ√≥micas Especiales (ZEE).

Juan Arrieta, director de empresas agroindustriales y miembro del Consejo Consultivo de la UDEP, precis√≥ que el impacto de la norma arancelaria var√≠a significativamente dependiendo del tipo de producto. En el caso de los productos frescos, es crucial que los gremios tengan poder de negociaci√≥n con sus pares en el mercado americano para menguar el impacto del arancel. La contraestaci√≥n representa una ventaja para algunos productos como la uva de mesa.

Manuel L√≥pez, director de la Maestr√≠a de Agronegocios del PAD, indic√≥ que el negocio de la alimentaci√≥n tiene una demanda inel√°stica. Por ahora, la palta ser√° el primer producto en enfrentar la ‚Äúprueba de fuego‚Äù con el arancel, y las negociaciones para las exportaciones de palta no estar√≠an variado.

L√≥pez consider√≥ que se tendr√≠a que pasar por una redefinici√≥n del negocio, que implica afinar aspectos como la log√≠stica y ajustes de costos. Los principales desaf√≠os que afectan los costos son la seguridad y la gesti√≥n del agua. Los proyectos de irrigaci√≥n m√°s urgentes son los de Olmos (30,000 hect√°reas afectadas) y Piura.

El mango peruano podr√≠a exportarse a 60 pa√≠ses, pero solo se dirige a 10 mercados. L√≥pez se√±al√≥ que entre diciembre y enero hay un pico de estos productos, saliendo m√°s de 300 contenedores de Paita, lo que genera una ca√≠da de precios por exceso de oferta en pocos mercados. Una soluci√≥n ser√≠a la b√∫squeda de nuevos mercados.

Mathews coincidi√≥ en la necesidad de diversificaci√≥n. En la crisis financiera de 2008-2009, ‚Äúlo que salv√≥ el crecimiento exportador del Per√∫ fue China y para micro y peque√±as empresas Am√©rica Latina‚Äù.

L√≥pez apunt√≥ que otra opci√≥n podr√≠a ser procesar parte de la producci√≥n para el mercado interno, por ejemplo, en presentaciones congeladas.

Para Arrieta, el siguiente gobierno debe tener claro que el √©xito del agro peruano se ha sustentado en el respeto a la libertad de los negocios. Otro desaf√≠o, a√±adi√≥ L√≥pez, sigue siendo c√≥mo involucrar al peque√±o agricultor en el boom agroexportador.

title: Exportaciones de Costa Rica siguen creciendo y el efecto de los aranceles de Trump a√∫n no llega. ¬øCu√°les son los productos estrella?
content: El equipo de precisi√≥n y m√©dico experiment√≥ un crecimiento de 26% (+$740 millones), consolid√°ndose como el principal sector exportador del pa√≠s, seg√∫n los datos divulgados hoy por la Promotora del ...
resumen: Las exportaciones de bienes de Costa Rica crecieron un 13% en el primer cuatrimestre del a√±o, en comparaci√≥n con el mismo periodo del 2024, alcanzando un total de $7.034 millones; es decir, $835 millones m√°s. El equipo de precisi√≥n y m√©dico experiment√≥ un crecimiento de 26% (+$740 millones), consolid√°ndose como el principal sector exportador del pa√≠s, seg√∫n los datos divulgados hoy por la Promotora del Comercio Exterior de Costa Rica (Procomer). El sector agr√≠cola tuvo una disminuci√≥n de 1% ($8 millones). La industria alimentaria aument√≥ un 2% ($14 millones). La informaci√≥n corresponde al periodo entre enero y abril de 2025. Am√©rica del Norte aument√≥ en un 20% durante el primer cuatrimestre. Representantes del Comex se reunieron con personal de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) en Washington. El ministro de Comercio Exterior, Manuel Tovar, indic√≥ que el inter√©s primordial de Costa Rica es volver a las condiciones existentes antes de la pol√≠tica del gravamen rec√≠proco de la administraci√≥n Trump. Laura L√≥pez, Gerente General de Procomer, afirm√≥ que las exportaciones de Costa Rica se mantienen robustas. Otros sectores que muestran un comportamiento positivo son el qu√≠mico farmac√©utico, que aument√≥ un 7%; el√©ctrica y electr√≥nica, con un 2%; metalmec√°nica, con 5%; pl√°stico, con un +2%, y pecuario y pesca, con un crecimiento de 7%. A nivel de productos con mayor crecimiento en el primer cuatrimestre del a√±o se destacan los dispositivos m√©dicos (+$750 millones), caf√© oro (+$65 millones), oro en bruto (+$32 millones), aceite de palma (+$19 millones), manufacturas de metal precioso (+$15 millones), frutos sin cocer congelados (+$10 millones), medicamentos (+$10 millones), leche (+$10 millones) y carne bovina (+$9 millones). En cuanto a regiones de exportaci√≥n, Am√©rica del Norte aument√≥ en un 20%, Europa un 10%, Am√©rica Central un 7%, Asia un 3% y el Caribe un 6%. Am√©rica del Sur es la √∫nica regi√≥n que decreci√≥, con $22 millones menos.

resumen: Estados Unidos y Costa Rica negocian la eliminaci√≥n de los aranceles para las exportaciones de Costa Rica a ese pa√≠s. La noticia la dio el presidente Rodrigo Chaves este mediod√≠a durante el Consejo de Gobierno, a la vez que se√±al√≥ que esto significa una prueba m√°s de la relaci√≥n de amistad, cooperaci√≥n y negocios que tienen los dos pa√≠ses. ‚ÄúLos √∫nicos pa√≠ses que Estados Unidos ha invitado a negociar para eliminar el 10 % de impuestos son India, Reino Unido, China, Jap√≥n, Vietnam, Taiw√°n, Corea del Sur y Costa Rica. Somos el √∫nico pa√≠s de Am√©rica Latina que fue incluido‚Äù, dijo Chaves. Manuel Tovar, ministro de Comercio Exterior, asever√≥ que en junio Costa Rica volver√° a tener una nueva ronda de negociaciones sobre este tema. ‚ÄúTenemos que sentirnos honrados y tranquilos de que estamos sentados en la mesa para repasar la agenda bilateral y discutir la pol√≠tica arancelaria. Queremos el acceso al mercado de Estados Unidos al amparo del TLC. Somos especiales, porque aprecian y valoran la alianza estrat√©gica que tenemos y que bajo este gobierno se ha profundizado. En el mes de junio, esperamos una segunda ronda de pl√°ticas‚Äù, dijo Tovar. La semana pasada, el gobierno de Chaves tuvo el primer encuentro con personeros de ese pa√≠s. A inicios de abril, Trump paus√≥ sus aranceles rec√≠procos por un periodo de 90 d√≠as para permitir que los pa√≠ses negocien con el Gobierno de Estados Unidos. Posteriormente, se√±al√≥ que algunos podr√≠an empezar a pagar el arancel en las pr√≥ximas semanas. Esto ha causado una incre√≠ble incertidumbre para las empresas y los consumidores alrededor del mundo, ya que la tabla de aranceles para las importaciones a Estados Unidos oscilar√≠a entre 145 % para China a un 10 % para un pa√≠s como Costa Rica.

title: Walmart aument√≥ el precio de estos cuatro productos por los aranceles
content: Los aranceles a las mercanc√≠as importadas elevan los costos de Walmart y otras cadenas minoristas, ocasionando que el precio al consumidor se incremente. Esto se evidencia en el aumento de los ...
resumen:
Walmart se ha visto afectada por los aranceles impuestos por Donald Trump. Dos tercios de sus productos los compra en Estados Unidos. Los aranceles a las mercanc√≠as importadas elevan los costos de Walmart, ocasionando que el precio al consumidor se incremente. Se prev√© un mayor incremento en junio y julio. John David Rainey, director financiero de Walmart, aclar√≥ que la magnitud de estos aumentos supera la capacidad de cualquier minorista.

Productos que han aumentado su precio:

*   Pl√°tanos: El precio ha aumentado de alrededor de 50 centavos a 54 centavos por libra en algunos casos.
*   Paltas: Se espera que los aranceles incrementen su precio.
*   Caf√©: Se espera un incremento considerable en el precio.

title: Walmart confirma alza de precios en EEUU por aranceles de Trump a importaciones
content: En medio de un panorama de tensiones comerciales reactivadas por la pol√≠tica arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump, Walmart ha decidido mover ficha: ...
resumen: Walmart comenzar√° a subir los precios de varios productos, una acci√≥n que afecta directamente a millones de consumidores en Estados Unidos. Los incrementos ya comenzaron en abril y se intensificar√°n en junio, con un enfoque inicial en productos de temporada como √∫tiles escolares. La causa, seg√∫n la compa√±√≠a, son los aranceles impuestos a las importaciones, en particular desde China, que han encarecido los costos log√≠sticos y operativos. El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, se√±al√≥ que los m√°rgenes minoristas no permiten absorber el golpe completo de los nuevos grav√°menes, incluyendo aranceles que han llegado hasta el 145% sobre ciertos productos chinos, aunque se hayan reducido temporalmente al 30% en algunos acuerdos bilaterales. Tambi√©n se han encarecido importaciones clave provenientes de pa√≠ses latinoamericanos como Colombia, Per√∫ y Costa Rica ‚Äîbananas, aguacates, caf√© y flores‚Äî. Los ingresos del primer trimestre aumentaron 2.5% interanual (65,610 millones de d√≥lares), pero las ganancias netas cayeron a 4,450 millones, comparadas con los 5,100 millones del mismo periodo en 2024. El anuncio de Walmart desat√≥ una reacci√≥n airada del presidente Trump, quien critic√≥ a la empresa por trasladar los costos a los consumidores. Trump acus√≥ a la compa√±√≠a de beneficiarse de a√±os de grandes ganancias sin mostrar solidaridad con los clientes. Analistas de Bank of America y Deutsche Bank coinciden en que Walmart est√° mejor posicionado que otros minoristas para enfrentar la tormenta, dado que solo un 15% de su mercanc√≠a proviene de China y que dos tercios de sus productos son abastecidos por proveedores nacionales. Las acciones de Walmart han subido cerca de un 8% desde abril.

title: US envoy holds ‚Äòcandid‚Äô first talks with senior Chinese official as trade tensions persist
content: New American ambassador David Perdue says he shares Trump‚Äôs priorities for ties after meeting Chinese foreign vice-minister.
resumen: Vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs Ma Zhaoxu held a ‚Äúcandid and in-depth‚Äù discussion with newly arrived US ambassador to China David Perdue on Tuesday. The meeting marked the American envoy‚Äôs first meeting with a senior Chinese official since assuming his post in Beijing last week. The two sides had a ‚Äúcandid and in-depth‚Äù exchange of views on China-US relations and important issues of mutual concern. China views and handles China-US relations in accordance with the three principles of mutual respect, peaceful coexistence and win-win cooperation proposed by Chinese President Xi Jinping, and firmly safeguards its sovereignty, security and development interests. Ma said, ‚ÄúWe hope that the US will meet China halfway to jointly promote the stable, healthy and sustainable development of China-US relations.‚Äù The meeting took place after Beijing and Washington agreed in Geneva earlier this month to temporarily reduce mutual tariffs for 90 days. Perdue, a former Republican senator from Georgia and close ally of US President Donald Trump, is expected to play a key role in trade negotiations with Beijing and in enlisting China‚Äôs cooperation in addressing the fentanyl crisis in the US.

title: US, China resume semiconductor tensions after brief truce
content: Beijing has repeatedly lashed out at Washington D.C. for warning companies against using AI chips made by national tech champion Huawei ...
resumen: The United States and China are fighting again, this time over semiconductors. Beijing has repeatedly lashed out at Washington D.C. for warning companies against using AI chips made by Huawei. It has even accused the Trump administration of ‚Äúundermining‚Äù a consensus reached at recent trade talks in Geneva, where both sides agreed to temporarily roll back tariffs and use a 90-day window to hash out a broader deal. The Trump administration imposed high tariffs on Chinese imports, with specific duties reaching up to 100% or more on certain goods like electronics, machinery, and critical materials. In retaliation, China imposed its own tariffs on U.S. products, including agricultural goods, energy products, and automobiles, raising duties to over 100% on many items. Additionally, China restricted the export of rare earth elements vital for the tech and defense sectors. On Wednesday, China‚Äôs Commerce Ministry accused the U.S. of ‚Äúabusing export controls to suppress and contain China‚Äù and engaging in what it called ‚Äútypical acts of unilateral bullying and protectionism.‚Äù This supposed escalation could further isolate Huawei from key global markets and critical technologies. With heightened tariffs and ongoing U.S. sanctions, Huawei faces supply chain disruptions, especially in accessing essential components like semiconductors and software from American companies.

title: Wall Street tumbles under the weight of rising Treasury yields and US debt worries
content: Wall Street slumped under the weight of pressure from the bond market, where Treasury yields climbed on worries about the U.S. government's spiraling debt and other concerns.
resumen: Wall Street slumped on Wednesday due to pressure from the bond market, where Treasury yields climbed on worries about the U.S. government‚Äôs spiraling debt and other concerns. The S&P 500 fell 1.6% for a second straight drop after breaking a six-day winning streak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 816 points, or 1.9%, while the Nasdaq composite sank 1.4%. The U.S. government released the results for its latest auction of 20-year bonds. The U.S. government had to pay a yield as high as 5.047% to attract enough buyers to lend it a total of $16 billion over 20 years. The 10-year Treasury yield climbed to 4.59% from 4.48% late Tuesday and from 4.01% early last month. The 30-year Treasury yield jumped back above 5%. Treasury yields have been on the rise in part because of concerns that tax cuts currently under consideration in Washington could pile trillions of more dollars onto the U.S. government‚Äôs debt. Moody‚Äôs Ratings downgraded the U.S. government‚Äôs credit rating. Target sank 5.2% after the retailer reported weaker profit and revenue than analysts expected for the start of the year. Target cut its forecast for profit over the full year. Carter‚Äôs sank 12.6% after cutting its dividend. The S&P 500 fell 95.85 points to 5,844.61. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 816.80 to 41,860.44, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 270.07 to 18,872.64.

title: Everything You Need To Know About The Trump‚Äôs Tariff War
content: The return of Donald Trump to the global political stage has been accompanied by renewed trade tensions, particularly in the form of broad and hastily implemented tariff policies. Since reassuming ...
resumen:
Donald Trump, since reassuming office, has imposed import tariffs on nearly every country in the world, particularly focusing on nations with which the United States has a trade deficit. This has created uncertainty for global trading partners and put pressure on American businesses, especially in retail and manufacturing.

Trump's plan, under "reciprocal tariffs," aims to correct what he calls unfair trade practices. In early April, a 10% tariff was imposed on all U.S. imports, with higher tariffs for countries with trade surpluses with the U.S. A 90-day pause was introduced to allow countries to propose new trade deals.

The Trump administration has decided to send official letters through Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to inform countries about specific tariffs. Trump announced this during a roundtable discussion in the United Arab Emirates, stating that nations could appeal the tariff rates, but the process remains unclear.

On May 8, the United States signed a trade agreement with the United Kingdom. On May 12, the United States and China reached an interim agreement to reduce tariffs for 90 days.

Over 190 countries are affected by Trump‚Äôs tariff threat. Global trade experts are concerned about the lack of clarity around the "reciprocal tariffs."

American businesses are feeling the effects. Retailers like Walmart, Target, and Lowe‚Äôs are struggling to balance higher costs from tariffs with competitive pricing. Walmart warned that prices will rise, and the Trump administration criticized the company. Amazon was also scrutinized. Mattel revealed it would need to raise prices, and Trump threatened a 100% tariff on Mattel products.

India is currently in trade talks with the U.S., led by Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal.

The global economy is under pressure from inflation, supply chain issues, and geopolitical tensions.

title: Tariffs, inflation and leery customers are hitting retailers in different ways
content: Retailers are trying to navigate their way through economic uncertainty in 2025. Tariffs, inflation and lingering fears of a recession have left many Americans uneasy and pulling back on spending.

title: Where the industry sits with tariffs
content: Despite recent breakthroughs with China and the United Kingdom, the nation's global trade environment is hostile and forecasts are dim.
resumen:
Key takeaways:

*   The U.S. cooled down its trade war with China, broadly reducing tariffs from 145% to 30%.
*   Duties on automobiles and metals, as well as a fee on almost all imports, still maintain a hostile environment for freight demand.
*   Industry forecasts expect tariffs to bring headwinds for haul pricing, freight demand, and overall economic activity.
*   Tariffs are one of the most significant‚Äîand unpredictable‚Äîdevelopments for the U.S. economy in 2025.
*   Trade tensions between the U.S. and China temporarily cooled down on May 12, when Trump lowered broader tariffs from roughly 145% to 30% (with many exceptions). The tariff reduction only lasts 90 days until August 12, when it would be replaced by another trade deal or further escalations.
*   Trump also reached a minor deal with the United Kingdom, reducing tariffs on some imports of automobiles, steel, and aluminum.
*   The most significant tariff policies in effect, as of late May, are:
    *   Most imports today face a baseline 10% ad valorem fee.
    *   Many automobile and auto parts imports (for passenger vehicles and light trucks) face a 25% tariff.
    *   Many aluminum and steel imports, and derivative products, face 25% tariffs.
*   Canada and China responded to the trade barriers with similar measures against U.S. exports:
    *   Canada introduced 25% tariffs on U.S. vehicles and at least $60 billion worth of other U.S. exports.
    *   China maintained a 10% baseline tariff on U.S.-origin goods and 15% tariffs on many agricultural and energy products.
*   The duties mean significant costs for U.S. companies and consumers, raising inflation and broadly reducing demand.
*   The administration could still raise duties for imports from certain countries or industries.
*   Trump‚Äôs postponement of higher ‚Äúreciprocal tariffs‚Äù was written to last 90 days, resuming on July 8.
*   Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent confirmed on May 18 that the administration may resume its reciprocal tariffs against an unspecified set of countries.
*   Notable reciprocal tariffs announced in early April included a 20% duty on imports from the European Union, 46% on Vietnam, 24% on Japan, 26% on South Korea, and more.
*   The European Union threatened significant tariffs against U.S. goods if Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariffs take effect.
*   The Trump administration may also follow its previous threats to issue tariffs on aircrafts, copper, electronics, lumber, movies, oil, pharmaceuticals, minerals, and heavy-duty trucks and truck parts.
*   Industry analysts shared negative predictions for the impacts of tariffs on freight demand and pricing.
*   DAT Freight & Analytics predicted tariffs‚Äô economic distortions will disrupt capacity and weaken carriers‚Äô pricing for at least several months.
*   FTR Transportation Intelligence in May predicted an overall negative impact from tariffs, forecasting volumes imported from Asia will decline into 2026, while truck prices will likely rise.
*   Class 8 truck demand plummeted following Trump‚Äôs early April tariff announcements, FTR noted: New truck orders in April reached their lowest counts since May 2020.
*   The Port of Los Angeles predicted a significant pullback on global trade for 2025, leading to lower import/export volumes, reduced consumer demand, and significant layoffs among both ports and retailers.
*   The industry‚Äôs largest public companies have either scrapped or reduced their earnings predictions during their first quarter earnings reports. Some companies that lowered their predictions included FedEx, Knight Swift Transportation, Volvo Group, and General Motors. Companies that gave up sharing forecasts altogether included UPS, Cummins, Ford, and more.
*   Many macroeconomic trends are projecting doom and gloom for 2025 and beyond: The Federal Reserve is making fewer rate cuts than it originally planned; the country‚Äôs credit rating fell to a historic low; and consumer confidence is at a near-record low.
*   Though uncertainty and pessimism abound, many parts of for-hire trucking remained healthy throughout April, including freight demand and spot market pricing. However, analysts from DAT and FTR warn, many of those boons may have merely come from temporary tariff disruptions, including a rush to build inventory.

title: Team of economic rivals? The eclectic adviser mix steering Trump‚Äôs trade policy.
content: Trump economic advisers range from mainstream allies to fiercely devoted friends to MAGA stalwarts. All share a strong loyalty to the president ‚Äì even when it means defending controversial policies.
resumen:
The article discusses the team of economic advisors shaping President Donald Trump's trade policy. Key figures include:

*   **Scott Bessent:** Treasury Secretary and lead trade negotiator since early April.
*   **Howard Lutnick:** Commerce Secretary and former CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald.
*   **Peter Navarro:** Special trade advisor and proponent of tariffs.
*   **Kevin Hassett:** Economist serving as director of Mr. Trump‚Äôs National Economic Council.
*   **Russell Vought:** Director of the Office of Management and Budget.
*   **Jamieson Greer:** U.S. Trade Rep.
*   **Stephen Miran:** Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers.

The article highlights the varying backgrounds and perspectives of these advisors, their loyalty to the president, and their disagreements on economic details. It also mentions the impact of tariffs, the role of the Federal Reserve, and the differing views on the U.S. dollar.

title: UK inflation rate jumps to 3.5% in April as higher household bills kick in
content: The Bank of England has previously estimated inflation to spike at 3.7% between July and September, before dropping.
resumen:
The UK inflation rate jumped to 3.5% in April, its highest level since February last year, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The increase was driven by sharp rises in household bills, energy costs, airfares, and council tax. The jump was greater than economists had predicted. The Bank of England expects inflation to peak at 3.7% between July and September before dropping back to its 2% target. The average prices of petrol and diesel fell by 3p and 3.1p respectively, while clothing and footwear costs eased off by 0.4%. Food price inflation also increased, rising by 3.4% in the year to April. The price of meat, bread, cereals, and mineral water grew. Price growth eased for vegetables, milk, cheese, and eggs. Airfares rose by 27.5% in April. Water and sewerage prices rose by 26.1% in April. Services inflation rose from 4.7% to 5.4% in the year to April.
Chancellor Rachel Reeves said she was disappointed by the figures. Mel Stride from the Tories said families are "paying the price" for Reeves's choices. The Lib Dems called for "bold action to deliver relief for millions of hard-pressed households". Tom Pugh, an economist at RSM UK, said the late Easter this year meant airplane prices and package holidays were very high. Joshua Mahony, chief market analyst at Scope Markets, said markets are worried. James Cuthbertson, a partner at Lakedown brewing company, said his brewery business will have to raise beer prices. Andy Hawthorne, chief executive of the Message Trust charity, said the number of members signing up to use their stores rose by 33% in the last 12 months. Grant Fitzner, the acting director general of the ONS, said the jump in the rate of inflation to 3.5% in the year to April was driven by higher gas and electricity bills, but also increases in air fares and water bills.

title: Mexico's US auto exports to benefit from tariff discounts, minister says

title: Mexico‚Äôs auto exports to US to face 15% tariff instead of expected 25%
content: Vehicles made in Mexico and sent to the US will pay a 15% tax rather than the original 25% previously expected.
resumen: Mexican auto exports to the US will face an average 15% tariff instead of the full 25% expected. The reduced tariff applies to vehicles that meet regional content rules under the USMCA agreement. Automakers must certify US parts in each vehicle, with approvals lasting six months. Vehicles made in Mexico and sent to the US will pay a 15% tax rather than the original 25% previously expected, Mexico‚Äôs Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard confirmed Tuesday. According to Reuters, citing Ebrard, the competing tariff rates vary only because Mexican exports that comply with the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) get preferential discounts. This discount gives Mexican automakers a big edge over their counterparts in countries that ship automobiles into the United States. Ebrard, speaking at a public event, praised the tariff rate but noted that the benefits enshrined in the trade deal are ‚Äúwhat matter.‚Äù He said it ‚Äúis a very big advantage compared to other countries that sell to the United States,‚Äù although he acknowledged Mexico would like to see zero tariffs. USMCA offers preferential treatment to exports and their granting of tariff cuts to lessen the burden of US import taxes on auto exports. The tariff dispute between the United States and its trading partners heated up in March 2025, when President Donald Trump‚Äôs government imposed a new 25% tariff on all cars not manufactured in the United States. This tariff went into effect in April 2025, raising concerns among automakers in Mexico and Canada, which rely significantly on US exports for their automotive industries. However, under the rules of the USMCA, which replaced the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), automakers from Mexico and Canada are eligible for lower tariffs. The preferred tariff reduction method entails confirming the percentage of US-made components used in each vehicle. This method allows automakers to reduce the tax from 25% to a lower rate, based on the percentage of US content in the car. According to Ebrard, if authorised by the US Department of Commerce, this certification ensures that the 25% tariff applies exclusively to the non-US portion of the vehicle, while the US-made parts remain tariff-free. Under the deal, businesses requesting cuts to tariffs will have to provide extensive declarations detailing the percentage of US content in their vehicles. The United States‚Äô authorities will look closely at the process to comply with all the requirements. If US Customs finds that companies misreported the amount of US content in their declarations, they would end up being charged retroactively with tariffs, with the full 25 per cent rate imposed on their exports. The certification only lasts for six months, and automakers will need to regularly prove that their vehicles continue to meet the certification criteria to enjoy the reduced tariff benefits. Officials in Mexico have been working closely with automakers to maximise the amount of qualifying tariff reductions automakers can access under the USMCA. Mexico is a major player in the automobile sector, being among the top car exporters to the United States. The country‚Äôs auto manufacturing sector is an important part of its economy, with several foreign automakers opening factories in Mexico to take advantage of cheaper labour costs and advantageous trade conditions. The favourable tariff reductions are a relief for Mexican automakers, who had dreaded the impact of the Trump administration‚Äôs broad tariff on non-US-made vehicles. To avoid disruptions in their supply networks and trade links, automakers pressed the US government to moderate its tariff approach. The 15% tax, while still greater than prior rates, is a more bearable burden for producers than the full 25% duty that would have been imposed without the special concessions. The USMCA is being negotiated by Mexico, Canada, and the US, with a focus on balancing economic and trade policy objectives. The automobile sector, which accounts for a significant portion of the region‚Äôs industrial and economic production, is likely to remain a popular topic in debates. Mexican automakers will, for now, operate under the USMCA umbrella to have access to its tariff reliefs during the interim. The 15% tariff gives a crucial buffer as the industry adjusts to the new trade reality and reduces the impact of the US import tax policy.

title: Ebrard: US content in Mexico-assembled vehicles cuts export tariffs by 40%
content: Economy Minister Ebrard said on Tuesday that certain Mexican-made cars are eligible for a "discount" on the 25% tariff announced by Trump in March.
resumen:
Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard said Tuesday that vehicles assembled in Mexico will face an average tariff of 15% when exported to the United States, significantly lower than the 25% duty the U.S. applies to most other foreign cars.

The tariff "discount" for Mexican auto exports to the U.S. would be 40%, on average, but could be as high as 50% ‚Äî if the vehicle has 50% U.S. content.

United States President Donald Trump announced in late March that he would impose a 25% tariff ‚Äúon all cars that are not made in the United States,‚Äù but U.S. content in vehicles assembled in Mexico was exempted from the duty, lowering the effective tariff on vehicles made in Mexico. The tariff took effect in early April.

The U.S. Department of Commerce published the ‚ÄúProcedures for Submissions‚Äù by importers of automobiles that qualify for preferential treatment under the USMCA.

Guillermo Rosales, president of the Mexican Association of Automotive Distributors, said in March that a vehicle made in Mexico for export to the United States has, on average, 40% U.S. content. The effective tariff on a vehicle assembled in Mexico with 40% U.S. content is 15%.

The U.S. Commerce Department said it was making ‚Äúthe assumption that the approximate amount of U.S. content‚Äù in vehicles made in Mexico and exported to the U.S. ‚Äúis equal to 40 percent of the value of the vehicle.‚Äù

If a car assembled in Mexico has 50% U.S. content, it will face an effective tariff rate of 12.5% when shipped to the United States. A Mexican-made car with only 30% U.S. content will face a 17.5% U.S. tariff.

The preferential treatment afforded to Mexico is the result of the frequent meetings between Mexican officials and U.S. officials, including Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer.

Mexico‚Äôs auto sector exported more than 2.6 million cars to the United States last year, according to U.S. data.

Mexican auto parts that comply with the USMCA are exempt from 25% duties imposed by the U.S on imports from most other countries in early May.

The National Auto Parts Industry reported earlier this month that 92% of the Mexican auto parts sector will not be subject to the 25% U.S. tariff as nearly all manufacturing complies with current trade rules.

Only vehicles imported to the U.S. from Mexico and Canada may be found to be eligible to apply the 25% tariff ‚Äúexclusively to the value of the non-U.S. content of the automobile.‚Äù

As of Tuesday May 20, importers of Mexican vehicles seeking preferential treatment on the U.S. content in the automobiles ‚Äúmay submit documentation, on a model line basis, identifying the type and value of U.S. content attributable to each model line imported into the United States,‚Äù according to the Commerce Department notice in the Federal Register.

The Commerce Department notice said that the commerce secretary ‚Äúmay retroactively extend this [preferential] treatment to qualifying model lines for vehicles imported on or after April 3, 2025, at his discretion,‚Äù meaning that importers could be partially reimbursed for tariffs they have already paid.

The notice said that if Customs and Border Protection ‚Äúdetermines that the declared U.S. content is overstated or inconsistent with a U.S. content figure approved by the Secretary, the [full] 25 percent tariff will apply retroactively (from April 3, 2025, to the date of the inaccurate overstatement) and prospectively.‚Äù

Adri√°n Gonz√°lez said that while U.S. automakers such as Ford and General Motors might have 40% (or higher) U.S. content in the vehicles they make in Mexico, Japanese and German manufacturers do not.

Under USMCA rules ‚Äî and before Trump imposed the new auto tariff ‚Äî a vehicle could enter the United States tariff-free provided at least 75% of the value of its content was from North America, i.e. Mexico, the U.S. and Canada.

The United States has agreed to cut its auto tariff on vehicles from the United Kingdom to 10% for 100,000 cars a year.
