title: Market movers: Stocks seeing action on Wednesday - and why
content: TJX Cos ( TJX-N -2.68% ) maintained annual forecasts and beat Wall Street expectations for first-quarter sales on Wednesday, as shoppers looking for deals to save money in the face of growing economic ...
resumen:
**On the Rise**

*   Shares of Canada Goose (GOOS-T) jumped over 19 per cent on Wednesday.
*   Canada Goose withheld from providing its fiscal 2026 forecast due to uncertainty stemming from the implementation of U.S. President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs.
*   The Toronto-based luxury retailer reported strong quarterly sales.
*   The company‚Äôs quarterly revenue rose to $384.6-million, from $358-million a year ago.
*   Analysts estimated $356.4-million, according to data compiled by LSEG.
*   Greater China revenue surged 63.1 per cent.
*   In the United States, a marketing campaign with fashion designer Haider Ackermann, which kicked off in November, aided a 15.3-per-cent rise in quarterly revenue. The country accounts for 24.3 per cent of total revenue.
*   The company‚Äôs quarterly gross margin was 71.3 per cent, compared with 65.1 per cent a year ago.

**On the decline**

*   Brookfield Corp.‚Äòs TSX-listed shares (BN-T) were lower by 3.8 percent.
*   Spain‚Äôs Bankinter has submitted a binding bid for Livensa, a student accommodation platform owned by the Canadian fund, in what would be one of the largest deals in the sector in recent years.
*   Target (TGT-N) slashed its annual sales forecast on Wednesday after posting a sharp fall in quarterly same-store sales.
*   Shares of the company were down 5.2 per cent.
*   Target said that its first-quarter performance was impacted by changes made to its diversity, equity and inclusion policies (DEI) in January.
*   Target expects a low-single digit decline in annual sales.
*   Analysts expected a 0.27-per-cent rise, according to LSEG.
*   Target previously forecast net sales growth of around 1 per cent.
*   The retailer expects annual adjusted earnings between US$7.00 and US$9.00 per share, compared to its prior forecast of US$8.80 to US$9.80.
*   Analysts were expecting US$8.40.
*   Target‚Äôs first-quarter comparable sales fell 3.8 per cent, compared to analysts‚Äô estimates of a 1.08-per-cent decline.
*   On an adjusted basis, Target reported US$1.30 per share.
*   Analysts on average were expecting US$1.61 per share.
*   Lowe‚Äôs Cos (LOW-N) slid 1.8 per cent.
*   Lowe‚Äôs reported a 1.7-per-cent drop in same-store sales for the quarter ended May 2, compared with analysts‚Äô average estimate of a 2-per-cent decline, according to data compiled by LSEG.
*   Chinese search engine giant Baidu (BIDU-Q) on Wednesday reported better-than-expected first-quarter revenue.
*   U.S.-listed shares of Baidu lost 4.3 per cent in Wednesday trading.
*   Total revenue in the first quarter rose 3 per cent to 32.45 billion yuan (US$4.50-billion), beating analysts‚Äô average estimate of 30.9 billion yuan, according to data compiled by LSEG.
*   Baidu‚Äôs online marketing business, which contributes the majority of its revenue, fell 6 per cent to 17.31 billion yuan. Analysts had estimated 17.39 billion yuan.
*   Its non-online marketing revenue reached 9.4 billion yuan, up 40 per cent year over year.
*   The company reported profit of 21.59 yuan per American Depositary Share, compared with profit of 14.91 yuan per share a year earlier.
*   Moderna (MRNA-Q) fell 7.8 per cent.
*   Palo Alto Networks (PANW-Q) forecast fourth-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates on Tuesday.
*   Shares of the Santa Clara, California-based company were down 6.8 per cent.
*   Palo Alto projected fourth-quarter revenue between US$2.49-billion and US$2.51-billion, compared with analysts‚Äô average estimate of US$2.49-billion, according to data compiled by LSEG.
*   For its fiscal 2025, Palo Alto sees revenue in the range of US$9.17-billion to US$9.19-billion, compared to its prior projection of US$9.14-billion to US$9.19-billion. Analysts expect US$9.17-billion.
*   Revenue for the third quarter, ended April 30, stood at US$2.29-billion.
*   Adjusted profit per share came in at 80 US cents, above estimates of 77 US cents apiece.
*   TJX Cos (TJX-N) maintained annual forecasts and beat Wall Street expectations for first-quarter sales on Wednesday.
*   Shares of the company were down almost 3 per cent on Wednesday.
*   TJX‚Äôs net sales were at US$13.11-billion for the quarter ended May 3, compared with analysts‚Äô average estimate of US$13.01-billion, according to data compiled by LSEG.
*   Semiconductor supplier Wolfspeed (WOLF-N) is preparing to file for bankruptcy within weeks.
*   Shares of the company fell 59.1 per cent.

title: Great Power Competition and the Global South
content: Trump and MAGA are an accelerant of great-power confrontation. It‚Äôs important to understand that the zero-sum, antagonistic ‚Äúcompetition‚Äù between China and the United States is an inter-imperial ...
resumen:
Trump and MAGA are an accelerant of great-power confrontation. The zero-sum, antagonistic ‚Äúcompetition‚Äù between China and the United States is an inter-imperial rivalry driven by structural factors. Both are mobilizing the state to capture a greater share of economic growth for sectional interests within their respective countries. In China, this process is fueled by domestic inequalities as part of a system that vastly overproduces relative to domestic demand. The surpluses that the owners of capital in China capture have to go somewhere and much of it ends up abroad in state-driven foreign policy initiatives. The U.S. economy is captured by defense-industrial interests. The trillion-dollar defense budget is a form of military Keynesianism that at once chokes off America‚Äôs economic potential and depends on the China threat to justify itself. The forces driving and sustaining Sino-U.S. rivalry are far bigger than one presidency or one man. MAGA and Trump represent forces that heighten rivalry because they exacerbate the structural drivers of rivalry. At the end of Trump‚Äôs reign, whenever that is, Sino-U.S. rivalry will be deeper and more intensified than at the start of his presidency.

Trade policy is downstream of the forces propelling geopolitical rivalry in the first place. Biden and Trump have both pursued an exclusionary economic nationalism in trade policy, but they‚Äôve done so in different ways, to the benefit of different sectional interests. Biden‚Äôs various tariffs and restrictions on trade and investment were mostly focused on green tech, advanced weapons systems, and semiconductors ‚Äì a decoupling limited to the high-value economic sectors of the future (‚Äúsmall yard, high fence‚Äù). Trump‚Äôs tariffs and restrictions on trade are taking that Biden posture to its logical conclusion, expanding the scope of decoupling and tariff walls. A firewall-trade policy does to Sino-U.S. relations, and it is quite obviously an accelerant of rivalry and a site of confrontation.

BRICS+ ‚Äì the majority of the world‚Äôs population ‚Äì is an identification that explicitly includes China, so all of these countries have an open door toward China in various ways. The complication is if they also have friendly relations with the U.S. or rely on the U.S. market as a destination for exports ‚Äì and many do. The approach that smaller countries try to take to this dilemma is to be a ‚Äúfriend to all, enemy to none.‚Äù The closest analogy is the Non-Aligned Movement during the Cold War, but more inclusive. The dilemma for these de facto nonaligned countries ‚Äì that is, those who need friendly ties to both great powers ‚Äì is that Sino-U.S. rivalry forces them to make choices that favor one side at the expense of the other and that kind of invidious choice is against the nonaligned country‚Äôs self-interest. In the extreme, this is how a country becomes a literal battleground or a sacrifice zone in Sino-U.S. conflict. In some situations, a country simply won‚Äôt have any agency. Countries that fall within the U.S. sphere of influence (like Palau, the Marshall Islands, or the Federated States of Micronesia) will be totally dependent on U.S. aid and investment and unable to access the benefits of trade relations with China. The reverse is also true ‚Äì countries who fall within a Chinese sphere of influence, like the Solomon Islands, increasingly find themselves cutoff from a United States that is literally telling countries they have to choose between the U.S. or China. The only countries who even have the capacity to resist these invidious choices on their own are those who control needed natural resources (e.g., Indonesia) or physical sites of production in global supply chains (Vietnam). Small countries caught in the great-power dilemma can exercise collective leverage if they act as a bloc ‚Äì they can be each other‚Äôs insurance policy and strategic alternative.

Trump basically redirected U.S. power toward Ukraine, the client state, to compel them to sue for peace. Russia was not asked to concede much of anything. Ukraine was never positioned to withstand a Russian onslaught so long as Russia was willing to pay the high (military and economic) price of an invasion. Applying that template to Taiwan is unpromising for Taiwan. In Ukraine and foreign policy generally, Trump is wary of allowing any place on the world map to become a sinkhole for U.S. resources. He wants to minimize costs to the U.S. and maximize the extraction of benefits for business interests in the U.S. who support him. Trump continues to support U.S. combat operations around the world ‚Äì including in losing situations like the Red Sea battle against the Houthis ‚Äì and is likely to expand them to Mexico and Latin America. Taiwan, in Trump‚Äôs perspective, exists to be traded away. The U.S. will extract what it can from Taiwan, which, at the moment, involves relocating semiconductor production and siphoning Taiwan‚Äôs public resources in the form of growing bilateral arms sales. The government in Taipei clearly doesn‚Äôt get this yet, because relocating semiconductor production is not in their interest. The arms buildup, unfortunately, is necessary as long as 1) great-power rivalry remains a defining feature of the landscape, and 2) there is no assurance that the U.S. will actually go to war to fight for Taiwan.

The existence of the BRICS+ is an example of the Global South trying to make a world beyond great-power competition. The U.S. dollar is rapidly losing its status as the world‚Äôs reserve currency because the Global South is denominating more and more of its financial transactions in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. China became the biggest bilateral lender not because it was China‚Äôs grand plan but because the Global South sought alternatives to IMF loans, which transgressed against their economic sovereignty. This is all worldmaking from below, and it really puts the limits of the great powers in perspective. The Global South is a collection of very diverse countries that do not share sufficient collective consciousness to identify their individual interests with the whole. There‚Äôs a lot of exploitation and hierarchy that goes on within South-South relations. The world that Global South countries are helping bring into existence, while more multipolar, is more autocratic and ethnonationalist. The working classes in these countries have a lot in common with the working classes in the U.S. and China. Poor and economically insecure folks are press-ganged into subordinating their interests to the interests of their rulers, often in the form of ‚Äúgreat-power competition.‚Äù A better world is one that raises the standard of living for the global working classes, not just elites who rule in their name. And there is no sign of that world on the horizon.

title: Tariff tally
content: ‚Äî Budget lines: The Liberal platform booked C$20 billion in tariff revenue in 2025-26 ‚Äî a key piece of the fiscal picture the party pitched on the campaign trail. It‚Äôs unclear where that revenue ...
resumen:
Canadian importers are still paying tariffs.

A report from Oxford Economics claimed federal relief announced in April reduced the impact of tariffs on U.S.-sourced goods to ‚Äúnearly zero.‚Äù

Conservative Leader PIERRE POILIEVRE insisted in a widely viewed X post that PM MARK CARNEY ‚Äúquietly dropped‚Äù tariffs ‚Äúwithout telling anyone.‚Äù

On April 16, Carney‚Äôs Cabinet approved six-month tariff relief for goods ‚Äúused in Canadian manufacturing, processing and food and beverage packaging, and for those used to support public health, health care, public safety, and national security objectives.‚Äù Automakers also scored limited exemptions.

Those measures were published in the Canada Gazette on May 7.

Finance Minister FRAN√áOIS-PHILIPPE CHAMPAGNE insisted that retaliatory tariffs on 70 percent of end-use goods are still in place. The total revenue haul for those tariffs remains unclear.

WILLIAM PELLERIN, a partner in McMillan‚Äôs international trade group, said that the assertion that Canada‚Äôs retaliatory tariffs have ‚Äúnearly zero‚Äù impact does not reflect the experience of many clients, who continue to incur substantial tariff costs, with real-world impacts on prices, customer relationships, jobs and investments.

Tariffs are still in effect, Pellerin said, on nearly all HVAC equipment and hot-water tanks; plumbing equipment and fixtures; sinks and showers; clothing and apparel; tires for off-road equipment (used in mining and industrial vehicles); hardwood and other wood products; overhead transmission lines; and nearly all steel and aluminum products.

The Liberal platform booked C$20 billion in tariff revenue in 2025-26.

Finance Minister FRAN√áOIS-PHILIPPE CHAMPAGNE and Bank of Canada Governor TIFF MACKLEM will convene their G7 counterparts for eight closed-door sessions on the global economy in Banff.

Champagne got the ball rolling Tuesday evening with a joint presser alongside Ukraine Finance Minister SERGII MARCHENKO.

Champagne will have a pull aside with U.S. Treasury Secretary SCOTT BESSENT.

The G7 will express a firm shared belief in the importance of a well functioning international trade investment system.

China is part of a session on ‚Äúconflict, security and resilience.‚Äù

Prime Minister MARK CARNEY is set to put on a spectacle when KING CHARLES III and QUEEN CAMILLA arrive in Ottawa.

The two-day visit will demonstrate that Canada is a sovereign nation.

When the royals land in Ottawa, Camilla will be presented with a bouquet of red and white roses.

A Canadian Armed Forces band will play as the royals are greeted by 25 members of the Royal Canadian Dragoons.

The king will receive full military honors, and Camilla will be sworn in as a member of the Privy Council.

The king is scheduled to drop the puck in a street hockey game at Lansdowne Park‚Äôs Aberdeen Plaza on Monday.

On Tuesday, the royals will parade down Wellington Street in Canada‚Äôs state landau, drawn by horses of the RCMP‚Äôs Musical Ride. They‚Äôll be escorted by 28 RCMP.

The official visit will close at the National War Memorial.

470 people have been invited to the Senate chamber to watch the speech.

The king will later meet with 50 MPs in the Senate.

Conservative Leader PIERRE POILIEVRE is not an MP.

Bloc Qu√©b√©cois Leader YVES-FRAN√áOIS BLANCHET is expected to boycott the throne speech.

The king and queen will be accompanied by two officers of the British royal household, plus a Canadian doctor.

title: Report: Tariffs cause slowdown in Q1 dealership M&A, but market still ‚Äòhistorically strong‚Äô
content: The auto dealership buy/sell market has slowed in the wake of President Trump‚Äôs tariffs, with the resulting geopolitical uncertainty and financial market vola ...
resumen: The auto dealership buy/sell market slowed in Q1 2025 due to President Trump‚Äôs tariffs, geopolitical uncertainty, and financial market volatility, according to Kerrigan Advisors‚Äô Blue Sky Report. Buy/sell activity dropped 14% year-over-year in Q1, with 94 transactions closed compared to 109 in Q1 2024. Multi-dealership transactions dropped to 20, the fewest since 2015, while single-point transactions made up 79% of all dealership sales, up from 68% in 2023. The market remains ‚Äúhistorically strong‚Äù and is on pace to total nearly 400 transactions for the year. Auto dealerships reported their first quarterly earnings increase since 2022. The seasonally adjusted annualized rate of sales was up while inventory remained tight. Dealerships reported earnings rose from $960,000 in Q1 2024 to $1.03 million this year. The Kerrigan Index of the seven publicly traded auto retailers fell 21% by mid-April. U.S. dealership acquisition spending plummeted to $154 million, a huge drop from $1.19 billion in Q1 2024. Asbury Automotive announced the $1.4 billion acquisition of Boston-based The Herb Chambers Companies. Gross profit per new vehicle stabilized in Q1 2025 at $3,478, down 2.5% from the prior two-quarter average of $3,568. Between February and March of 2025, days‚Äô supply for every franchise in the U.S. declined an average of 21%. The U.S. public dealer groups had a blue sky multiple of 6.1x in Q1 2025, down 21% from the prior quarter‚Äôs blue sky multiple of 7.7x.

title: What You Should Know About A Prospective India-US Multi-Phase Trade Deal? Explained
content: India-US trade deal is expected to be in three tranches, and will likely cover industrial goods, farm products, and some non-tariff barriers, such as quality control requirements ...
resumen:
The United States and India are in negotiations to reach a trade deal before President Donald Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariffs kick in in July. Commerce minister Piyush Goyal was on a four-day trip to Washington that ended on May 19, where he would have met US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick as part of negotiations.

The interim trade deal is expected to be in three tranches, and will likely cover areas including industrial goods, farm products, and some non-tariff barriers, such as quality control requirements.

The second stage of an India-US deal may be a broader and more detailed agreement timed for around September to November. It will likely cover the 19 areas outlined in the terms of reference agreed by the two sides in April. The timing for this part of the deal may be aligned with an expected visit by Trump to India for the Quad leaders‚Äô summit.

The final leg of the deal will likely be a comprehensive agreement that would follow once there‚Äôs approval from the US Congress, possibly concluded only next year.

Negotiation areas include:

*   **Tariff Reductions:** India is considering lowering tariffs on US products like bourbon, motorcycles, and certain agricultural goods. The US seeks greater access for its industrial and agricultural exports.
*   **Agriculture:** Discussions include market access for US farm products such as apples, tree nuts, and alfalfa hay. India aims to boost exports of shrimp, textiles, and other labour-intensive goods.
*   **Digital Trade and E-commerce:** Negotiations address data localisation requirements and the regulatory environment for digital services.
*   **Supply Chain Integration:** Both countries are exploring cooperation in critical sectors like semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, and critical minerals to build resilient supply chains.

Over the past few years, bilateral trade between India and the US has grown steadily.

A trade delegation led by Brendan Lynch, Assistant US Trade Representative for South and Central Asia, arrived in New Delhi to hold talks with Indian counterparts from March 25 to 29, 2025. This visit was aimed at finalising the first tranche of a Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) in the latter half of 2025.

This was followed by a telephonic discussion between External Affairs Minister Jaishankar and Secretary of State Rubio underscoring the critical importance of addressing the tariffs question. Both leaders agreed to advance a fair and balanced trade agreement.

In 1947, under the leadership of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, India pursued a policy of non-alignment. India received aid from the US through the PL-480 programme.

In 1991, with the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the end of Cold War, India successfully liberalised its economy. Under the leadership of Prime Minister PV Narsasimha Rao and Finance Minister Manmohan Singh, much of the protectionist frameworks were dismantled while tariffs were significantly reduced.

In February, a joint statement by President Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi committed to enhancing bilateral trade to $500 billion by 2030.

During President Trump‚Äôs first term in office (2017-2021), trade became a major area of contention. He had criticized India for imposing 12% tariffs while the US imposed 2.2% on Indian goods. This led to the Trump administration revoking India‚Äôs Generalized System Preferences (GSP) status in 2019. India retaliated by imposing its own set of tariffs on US exports of almonds and steel among other commodities.

In 2020, there was an attempt to negotiate a ‚Äúmini" trade deal. However, the deal could not take place as Trump had been voted out of the White House in the 2020 presidential election.

When PM Modi‚Äôs visited Washington in 2023 during Joe Biden‚Äôs term, no substantial trade agreement materialised.

title: Tariff tsunami hits US firms ‚Äî and your wallet could be next
content: According to a new survey by Allianz Trade, 54 per cent of US companies say they plan to hike prices to offset the rising cost of imports.
resumen:
A majority of American businesses, and 38 per cent of European and Chinese companies are preparing to raise prices in the coming months as the impact of President Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs reverberates through the global economy. According to a new survey by Allianz Trade, 54 per cent of US companies say they plan to hike prices to offset the rising cost of imports, while only a small fraction‚Äîjust 15 per cent‚Äîintend to absorb those additional expenses themselves.

A new survey by Allianz Trade paints a stark picture of global business sentiment in the wake of ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù ‚Äì the term now widely used to describe 2 April 2025, when former US President Donald Trump‚Äôs administration announced a sweeping escalation in tariffs against China.

The findings are part of a broader picture painted by Allianz‚Äôs spring survey, which canvassed around 4,500 firms across nine countries‚Äîincluding the US, China, Germany, and France‚Äîbetween March and April 2025. Globally, 38 per cent of respondents said they expect to raise prices in response to tariffs, with US and Chinese firms leading the way.

In the US, 54 per cent of firms say they will raise prices, up from 46 per cent before the tariffs.

Just 22 per cent see absorbing costs as viable ‚Äî a figure that has dropped further in the US, France and Italy since April.

Many buyers are now insisting on ‚ÄúDelivered Duty Paid‚Äù contracts, shifting customs and logistics costs onto sellers. The US remains an outlier, with ‚ÄúCost, Insurance & Freight‚Äù still dominant.

59 per cent have introduced pricing clauses that tie contract values to FX movements, allowing them to share volatility with clients and suppliers.

Before ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù, only 5 per cent of exporting companies expected a downturn in turnover. Now, 42 per cent are bracing for declines of between 2 per cent and 10 per cent over the next year. Close to 60 per cent of surveyed firms anticipate a negative impact from the new round of US-China hostilities.

Fewer than half of firms expect export growth, down from 80 per cent just weeks ago. In addition, more than a quarter (27 per cent) warn that currency volatility, in combination with higher tariffs, could force temporary production halts, while a third are planning to halt imports or offshore operations to manage rising costs.

In Germany, 45 per cent of firms now favour cost-cutting and efficiency, while Chinese companies are taking a more expansive approach: 77 per cent are channelling funds into strategic diversification and new business lines.

Half now expect payment delays exceeding seven days ‚Äî a 13-point increase post-‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù. In Italy and Poland, the figure is even more severe, with concern jumping by 23 and 26 points respectively.

Only 11 per cent of export firms now receive payments within 30 days. Larger corporations, particularly those with turnovers exceeding ‚Ç¨5 billion, are especially vulnerable, with a quarter facing payment terms over 70 days. Sectors such as retail, agriculture and manufacturing are bearing the brunt, with SMEs particularly exposed. Nearly half of all exporters expect payment defaults to rise, particularly in the US, UK and Italy.

While a temporary trade deal has cut the average US tariff on Chinese goods to 39 per cent from a previous peak of 103 per cent, this remains triple the rate in place before Trump‚Äôs return to office.

79 per cent of US firms began accelerating imports from China, especially in agriculture, machinery and metals. Now, rerouting is the preferred mitigation strategy, with 62 per cent of American firms exploring alternative shipping lanes ‚Äî aided by a nearly 50 per cent drop in freight costs since January.

One in three has already found new markets for exports and supply chains, and nearly two-thirds plan to follow suit. For US firms, the pressure is acute: 60 per cent with overseas production have already relocated, driven by heightened exposure and longer supply chains.

Even before the latest tariffs, 34 per cent of firms had shifted or planned to shift offshore production, with 59 per cent preparing for more change.

Chinese firms are increasingly distancing themselves from North America, favouring relocation to Asia-Pacific and Western Europe. Notably, all surveyed Chinese firms with North American supply chains said they intend to relocate ‚Äî up from 79 per cent before April.

Preference for relocating to Western Europe has more than doubled, from 11 per cent to 25 per cent, while interest in Latin America has risen from 9 per cent to 25 per cent. Asia-Pacific, once a prime destination, now sees reduced interest (down from 61 per cent to 34 per cent).

US firms‚Äô intention to export to China and East Asia dropped by 11 points. Chinese interest in North America plummeted from 15 per cent to just 3 per cent.

Europe is becoming a preferred trade partner for both Chinese and European exporters. Chinese firms are increasingly targeting Europe for exports, while EU-based companies are doubling their interest in South and Southeast Asia.

German firms, once eager to exit China, are showing more willingness to remain. The share planning to relocate dropped from 67 per cent to 50 per cent, with Asia-Pacific becoming the top relocation destination for those currently exposed to North America.

For Chinese firms, interest in Latin America has tripled, offering a tariff-friendly backdoor into the US. European firms, too, are showing greater interest, with perceived export opportunities in Latin America rising by 6 points.

title: China supera a Estados Unidos en popularidad global, seg√∫n encuesta mundial que incluye a Colombia
content: Entre 100 naciones estudiadas en el DPI, 85 ven a China con mejores ojos frente a 15 inclinadas por Washington.
resumen:
Un nuevo informe del √çndice de Percepci√≥n Democr√°tica (DPI) se√±ala que, entre las 100 naciones estudiadas, 85 ven a China con mejores ojos frente a las 15 que se inclinaron por Washington.

La reputaci√≥n global de Estados Unidos ha venido en ca√≠da libre desde el regreso de Donald Trump a la presidencia en enero de este a√±o.

El DPI bas√≥ sus conclusiones en entrevistas con m√°s de 110.000 personas en 100 pa√≠ses del mundo.

La imagen de Estados Unidos cay√≥ de una valoraci√≥n neta positiva del 22 por ciento en 2024 a un menos cinco (-5) por ciento en 2025, una ca√≠da neta de 27 puntos en solo cuatro meses.

Estados Unidos solo obtuvo un margen positivo en el 45 por ciento de los pa√≠ses, comparado con el 76 por ciento que registr√≥ el a√±o anterior.

La ca√≠da en la imagen de Estados Unidos ha sido especialmente pronunciada en pa√≠ses de la Uni√≥n Europea y Canad√°.

China ha mejorado su posici√≥n global, superando por primera vez a Estados Unidos en percepci√≥n positiva general, con una puntuaci√≥n neta del 14 por ciento.

Entre las 100 naciones, 85 de ellos vieron a China con mejores ojos frente a los 15 que se inclinaron por Washington.

En el caso de Colombia, la percepci√≥n neta de Estados Unidos fue 0, mientras que hubo 19 puntos favorables hacia Pek√≠n (+19).

Canad√°, con una percepci√≥n negativa del 47 por ciento, fue el pa√≠s de la regi√≥n donde m√°s oposici√≥n se registr√≥ hacia Estados Unidos, seguido por Per√∫ (-28), Ecuador (-26) y M√©xico (-24).

En Europa, la situaci√≥n fue muy similar, pero con n√∫meros negativos a√∫n m√°s agudos: Suecia (-50), Turqu√≠a (-50), Alemania (-44), Espa√±a (-42) y Noruega (-39 por ciento).

La popularidad de Estados Unidos a nivel global ya hab√≠a comenzado a caer desde el 2023 tras su apoyo incondicional a Israel en la guerra en Gaza.

Trump obtuvo la puntuaci√≥n m√°s baja entre un grupo diverso de figuras pol√≠ticas, culturales y espirituales como Elon Musk, Bill Gates, el fallecido papa Francisco, Taylor Swift y Kim Kardashian.

Trump fue superado por el presidente chino, Xi Jinping, y el presidente ruso, Vladimir Putin.

En el sondeo, solo un 27 por ciento de los encuestados expres√≥ una opini√≥n positiva del republicano frente a un 58 por ciento que lo valor√≥ de manera negativa.

Jinping obtuvo un 32 por ciento de imagen positiva frente a un 31 por ciento de imagen negativa, a su vez Putin cont√≥ con 32 por ciento que lo ven de forma positiva y un 49 por ciento negativa, respectivamente.

Luego dijo que no tendr√≠a tiempo y que, en cambio, enviar√≠a cartas a los pa√≠ses dici√©ndoles cu√°l ser√≠a su arancel final. Se avecinan plazos para cuando los aranceles podr√≠an volver a entrar en vigor: en agosto para un acuerdo con China, y en julio para los dem√°s pa√≠ses.

title: Strategic Earthquake in Europe Signals Age of Uncertainty
content: A convergence of crises‚Äîgeopolitical shifts, energy instability, and economic stagnation‚Äîmarks the end of a historical era and the beginning of a more volatile multipolar world order.
resumen: A convergence of crises‚Äîgeopolitical shifts, energy instability, and economic stagnation‚Äîmarks the end of a historical era and the beginning of a more volatile multipolar world order. Challenges include mass immigration, a potential Ukraine settlement favoring Russia, reduced U.S. security guarantees, and unsustainable fiscal models. Defence spending, energy strategy, and resource security. Populist movements are accelerating as supranational institutions lose influence. Geopolitically, the events of the first half of 2025 strongly indicate that seismic change is coming to Europe. Europe‚Äôs leaders face a number of serious and pressing dilemmas. A number of major shaping factors have converged at precisely the same time, a kind of ‚Äògreat conjunction‚Äô that signals the close of a number of historical cycles and patterns. One epoch has ended and another is about to begin. The heightened sense of volatility will bring great risk to investors even as it also presents rich opportunities. The globalist order is in decline, and a new nationalist-centric order is taking its place. The events of the last year, particularly those surrounding the election of US President Donald Trump, caught many people, including governments, off-guard. This transformation heralds the emergence of a multipolar world and the disintegration of the ‚Äòrules-based order‚Äô which has predominated since the end of World War Two. Many of the supranational organisations that have for so long provided the framework through which modern governance and trade take place appear to be cracking up. This includes the UN and the WTO, as well as more regionally-focused entities like the EU and NATO. European governments face a number of major dilemmas. Their strategic choices will have major ramifications for the continent for many years to come. The most explosive factor in domestic politics, particularly in Western Europe, is the question of mass immigration. The significant rise of populist and nationalist parties across the continent is directly tied to mass immigration. Europe‚Äôs governments face dual prospects of a) a post-war settlement in Ukraine in which Russia obtains its strategic and territorial objectives, and b) a US pivot away from NATO and Europe and towards the Far East. The realization that Europe can no longer rely on the US for military protection, whilst not increasing its own defence spending to 5% of national government budgets has sparked a marked change in defence policies across the continent. Many governments have announced intentions to increase defence spending. Europe‚Äôs economic malaise has been universally noted. Europe‚Äôs economies have been struggling ever since the 2008 financial crisis. Within the EU, the top-heavy bureaucratic structure and mass of extensive regulations have made the prospect of imminent recovery rather remote. Germany had been the motor that kept the EU economy going, yet its own economy has fared very badly in recent years under the impact of the Russia-Ukraine war and increasingly stringent Green regulations. Europe‚Äôs lack of competitiveness is notable in a number of domains. The innovation and investment dilemma has become readily apparent with French President Emmanuel Macron publicly recognising that the stifling regulatory space had prompted a vast exodus of talent and capital to fresher pastures such as the US, the UAE, and parts of the Far East. Energy strategy is another area in which governments will have to reassess their options. The war in Ukraine revealed the extent to which governments like Germany had become dependent on Russian gas. The commitment to radical Net Zero targets, made in a context within which climate politics was ascendant, will have a sharp impact on industrial output. The Green Party in German enjoyed less support in 2025 than it did in 2021, losing 33 seats. The new coalition government of Chancellor Merz has made major concessions to the Greens including the promise of devoting ‚Ç¨50bn of a new (borrowed) ‚Ç¨500bn special fund to climate protection. The recent electricity blackouts in Portugal, Spain and parts of France underlined the fragility of the current energy framework. The power cuts in parts of Western Europe once again highlight one of the major drawbacks to hyper-globalisation‚Äîthe reliance on highly complex but fragile systems. The Red Sea crisis, the result of Yemen-based Houthi rebel activity, and a major source of risk in an area through which 30% of the world‚Äôs container shipping normally passes. As the world moves away from hyper-globalisation to a more regionally-based order, supply chains will likely be revised so as to mitigate the level of risk present during a period of great geopolitical instability. As the ‚Äòrules-based order‚Äô wanes there will likely be a return to a much more ‚Äòcut and thrust‚Äô modus operandi as far as state power projection goes. Globally, there will be a number of key strategic regions of interest, reminiscent of the various ‚ÄòGreat Games‚Äô of the nineteenth century, such as the Anglo-Russian ‚ÄòGreat Game‚Äô in Central Asia or the ‚ÄòScramble for Africa‚Äô. The completion of the International North South Transport Corridor (INSTC) has provided significant strategic advantage to Russia. Central Asia is becoming a highly important region economically-speaking, not least due to the presence of Rare Earth Elements (REEs). Both the Arctic and Antarctic will be of keen interest to the great powers of the 21st century as well as to those with geographical proximity. President Trump‚Äôs repeated comments vis-√†-vis Greenland, currently an autonomous territory within the Kingdom of Denmark, are indicative of a number of American strategic objectives. Greenland possesses some of the world‚Äôs largest reserves, including yttrium, scandium, neodymium, and dysprosium. Continental Europe‚Äôs prospects in this field are an important point of exploration. While Europe currently does not produce any REEs, various deposits have been located across the continent, from Norway and Sweden to Greece. These factors are only some of the wider strategic concerns with which European governments will have to grapple over this coming transformative period. The powerful rise of populism and nationalism looks set to grow stronger. The present interim period brings with it a sped-up political cycle that sees many national governments at present quite unstable.

title: The case for a North American Customs Union
content: Many of the assumptions underlying the conventional wisdom about globalization in the early 2000s have been upended in ...
resumen:
In recent years, assumptions about globalization have been upended. The COVID-19 pandemic exposed the vulnerability of supply chains and the world‚Äôs overreliance on China. The US and other Western countries have experienced a decline in manufacturing activity and employment. China has emerged as a global technology leader, with firms like Huawei, DJI, CATL, and BYD dominating strategic sectors. In 2024, electric cars accounted for nearly half of all car sales in China, compared to roughly 10% in the US.

US President Donald Trump‚Äôs response to China‚Äôs economic rise has been to build a tariff wall. On April 2, Trump announced a minimum 10% tariff on all US imports and ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs on almost all trading partners. China retaliated immediately, and global financial markets swooned. The US and China have since agreed to a mutual temporary reduction of tariffs to 10% for 90 days.

The Trump administration faces the challenge of addressing unfair trade practices, intellectual-property violations, and America‚Äôs reliance on Chinese goods. China produces around 52% of the world‚Äôs cement, controls more than 80% of solar-panel manufacturing, and has the capacity to build nearly 40 million internal-combustion vehicles annually. Chinese exports to emerging markets have more than doubled since 2017. China‚Äôs national savings are 44% of GDP.

The Trump administration should pursue a deal with China that focuses on shifting China‚Äôs industrial capacity toward domestic demand. The US would be better off creating a North American customs union with Mexico and Canada that adopts a common external tariff. A recent study by Pedro Noyola and Jamie Serra Puche outlined the benefits of replacing the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) with a customs union. Such a shift would eliminate the inefficiencies of rules-of-origin checks within North America, lower transaction costs, and establish the region as a single economic zone. The combination of Mexico‚Äôs workforce and geography, America‚Äôs technology, capital, and productive capacity, and Canada‚Äôs energy and raw materials would make the bloc an attractive location for global supply chains.

The USMCA, which replaced the original 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement, aimed to discourage additional US automotive investment in Canada and Mexico by raising the local-content requirement for vehicles from 62.5% to 75%. Regional integration deepened as automakers restructured supply chains. US tariffs on Chinese goods accelerated nearshoring to Mexico. In the first three quarters of 2024 alone, Chinese direct investment in Mexico‚Äôs automotive sector surged by more than 86%, reaching $3.5 billion. Over the past three years, the number of Chinese companies in Mexican industrial parks has doubled.

A North American customs union, with a common external tariff and unified trade policy, would help address asymmetries and strengthen oversight of third-country supply chains. The three North American countries would do well to approach the first mandated review of the USMCA in 2026 with an eye toward this goal.

title: Colombia debe aprovechar la guerra comercial entre China y EE. UU.
content: En la guerra comercial entre China y EE. UU., Colombia y Latinoam√©rica deben aprovechar para impulsar integraci√≥n regional e industrializaci√≥n estrat√©gica.
resumen:
El autor, Di√≥genes Rosero Durango, profesor universitario, historiador econ√≥mico y experto en temas de desarrollo y democracia, analiza la guerra comercial entre China y EE. UU. y c√≥mo Colombia podr√≠a aprovecharla.

El autor menciona que una guerra comercial no beneficia a nadie, especialmente a econom√≠as medianas o peque√±as como las latinoamericanas, y que ya se siente el aumento de la inflaci√≥n internacional y la volatilidad de las monedas, incluyendo la devaluaci√≥n del peso colombiano en 2025.

El autor se pregunta si Colombia y Latinoam√©rica pueden aprovechar esta situaci√≥n. Se√±ala precedentes hist√≥ricos, como el reemplazo de la inactividad industrial europea por manufacturas de Jap√≥n y Am√©rica Latina a finales del siglo XIX, y el desarrollo de Corea despu√©s de la Segunda Guerra Mundial.

El autor considera inevitable el despegue de China como l√≠der econ√≥mico y los choques con sus competidores. Menciona que Trump intenta proteger a EE. UU. en la fase final de la supremac√≠a china, olvidando a sus socios comerciales tradicionales.

El autor propone que Colombia consolide una pol√≠tica de estado, incluyendo la comisi√≥n de relaciones internacionales. Tambi√©n sugiere actuar como bloque, retomando la agenda de integraci√≥n regional.

El autor destaca la necesidad de un liderazgo que aglutine y convenza, y de consolidar una agenda de temas estrat√©gicos como narcotr√°fico, medio ambiente, desigualdad y reindustrializaci√≥n.

El autor observa que Colombia y Brasil se acercan a China, mientras que Panam√° parece ceder ante el pragmatismo estadounidense. Concluye que acercarse a China puede convenir, pero advierte sobre los riesgos y la importancia de llenar los vac√≠os que deja EE. UU. en Europa y la regi√≥n de forma prudente y estrat√©gica.

title: A Tech Hub‚Äôs Plan to Upgrade for the A.I. Age Runs Into Trump‚Äôs Tariffs
content: A crucial cog in the global semiconductor industry, Malaysia aims to build high-end chips. It will have to contend with President Trump‚Äôs trade policy first.
resumen:
American companies started opening manufacturing facilities in Malaysia‚Äôs Penang State over five decades ago. The partnership has created tens of thousands of jobs and been a lucrative industry for Malaysia, which has become a crucial cog in the global tech manufacturing industry. It is one of the biggest sources of semiconductors exported to the United States, sending billions of dollars of components used in laptops, phones, cars, toys and medical devices.

Malaysia is caught in the cross-hairs of President Trump‚Äôs tariffs. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim acknowledged on Wednesday that Malaysia relies heavily on the United States for trade and investment. He said he could not accept what he described as Washington‚Äôs tendency to dictate which side other nations should pick, a reference to Mr. Trump‚Äôs trade war with China.

Last year, Mr. Anwar set an ambitious goal to prepare Malaysia to build high-tech chips used in A.I. He laid out a decadelong, multibillion-dollar plan to move Malaysia from assembling and testing semiconductors into chip design and cutting-edge manufacturing, akin to Taiwan.

Last month, his administration imposed a 24 percent levy on all Malaysian exports to the United States. Those tariffs were soon put on hold. The two countries are in negotiations ‚Äî the status of which is unclear ‚Äî but all Malaysian goods are subject to a 10 percent base-line tariff Mr. Trump has imposed.

The president has said that he is also considering a blanket levy of at least 25 percent on all semiconductor imports.

Last year, the Austrian tech giant AT&S opened a factory in Malaysia in Kedah State, near Penang, making next-generation chips for AMD.

About 65 percent of Malaysia‚Äôs electrical and electronics exports are produced by American companies operating there, government data shows.

Last year, Malaysia exported $16.2 billion worth of chips to the United States, accounting for close to 20 percent of all U.S. semiconductor imports, according to Reuters.

In March, Malaysia said that it would pay the British firm Arm Holdings $250 million over a decade to help build a local semiconductor design sector. It hopes to develop up to 10 homegrown chip-design firms that can bring in a combined revenue of $20 billion a year.

Malaysia has also attracted an investment from the A.I. chip darling Nvidia, which is working with YTL, a Malaysian conglomerate, to develop A.I. infrastructure.

France, Australia and Japan are among other recent investors in chip-design operations in Malaysia.

title: China corteja a Am√©rica Latina
content: N√∫meros de la Red ALC-China muestran que la Inversi√≥n Extranjera Directa (IED) de China en Am√©rica Latina pas√≥ de ser casi cero en el 2000 a promediar 12.5 mil millones de d√≥lares anuales desde el 201 ...
resumen:
El encuentro China-CELAC celebrado en Pek√≠n acapar√≥ buena atenci√≥n por lo mucho que la geopol√≠tica tiene en juego. Por vez primera, fueron los mandatarios de Brasil, Chile y Colombia y no los ministros del exterior quienes encabezaron un foro que busca contrarrestar los intereses econ√≥micos de Estados Unidos y diversificar las cartas de Am√©rica Latina. El Presidente chino, Xi Jinping, declar√≥ que "la intimidaci√≥n y la coerci√≥n s√≥lo conducen al aislamiento", en referencia al proteccionismo que enarbola Donald Trump. Tras unos d√≠as de intenso cortejo chino a la regi√≥n, cabe destacar cinco puntos clave.

En primer lugar, China est√° dispuesta a fortalecer sus lazos con los gobiernos de Am√©rica Latina. Xi y Lula firmaron m√°s de 30 acuerdos para la inversi√≥n china en Brasil, incluyendo infraestructura y miner√≠a. El Banco Central de Brasil y el Banco Popular de China tambi√©n firmaron una l√≠nea de intercambio de 157 mil millones de reales (~28 mil mdd). Colombia firm√≥ un acuerdo de cooperaci√≥n sobre la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta de China. China tambi√©n prometi√≥ una nueva l√≠nea de cr√©dito por 9 mil 200 millones de d√≥lares a CELAC y exent√≥ por un a√±o el requisito de visa para ciudadanos de Argentina, Brasil, Chile, Per√∫ y Uruguay.

En segundo sitio, es previsible que el intercambio comercial genere nuevas tensiones con los Estados Unidos. Las exportaciones de Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe a China pasaron de s√≥lo 14 mil millones de d√≥lares en el 2004 a 194 mil mdd en 2023, crecimiento cuyo m√∫ltiplo de 14 veces es atribuible en un 65 por ciento a s√≥lo cuatro bienes: hierro, cobre, soya y petr√≥leo. En cuanto a las importaciones, pasaron de 28 mil millones de d√≥lares a casi 300 mil mdd impulsadas por la manufactura. Washington enfrentar√° dificultades para conseguir materia prima a descuento y nuevos mercados para sus productos e inversiones en la medida que China le haga sombra en la regi√≥n.

El tercer punto es que correlaciones de fuerza desfavorables al interior y un intenso calendario electoral podr√≠an descarrilar lo ganado en Sudam√©rica. En Chile, Colombia y Brasil existe una alta probabilidad de que los partidos de derecha ganen las pr√≥ximas elecciones. Un desconocimiento de los acuerdos firmados hoy con la econom√≠a m√°s grande del mundo por paridad de poder adquisitivo es impensable por temor a represalias.

En cuarto lugar, la Administraci√≥n Trump buscar√° contrarrestar la creciente influencia china. Estados Unidos considera cada vez m√°s a Pek√≠n como un rival estrat√©gico en Am√©rica Latina. En el 2017, la Estrategia de Seguridad Nacional (NSS) nombr√≥ por primera vez el intento de China de atraer a pa√≠ses latinoamericanos a su √≥rbita mediante inversiones y pr√©stamos. En el 2020, el Marco Estrat√©gico para el Hemisferio Occidental enfatiz√≥ que las Am√©ricas son cruciales para la seguridad nacional, la paz y la prosperidad de Estados Unidos y alert√≥ sobre la dependencia tecnol√≥gica regional y la exportaci√≥n de materias primas a China. La agenda de Trump en el Canal de Panam√°, las amenazas de aranceles a M√©xico y la obstaculizaci√≥n de la l√≠nea cambiaria entre China y Argentina delatan los miedos de Washington.

Por √∫ltimo, M√©xico podr√≠a quedar fuera del nuevo orden comercial si juega mal sus cartas. N√∫meros de la Red ALC-China muestran que la Inversi√≥n Extranjera Directa (IED) de China en Am√©rica Latina pas√≥ de ser casi cero en el 2000 a promediar 12.5 mil millones de d√≥lares anuales desde el 2010. Brasil, Per√∫ y Argentina captan m√°s IED china que M√©xico. Si Washington presiona al vecino para endurecer su oposici√≥n a China, es probable que los bienes y capitales procedentes de Asia caigan a√∫n m√°s que lo trazado en el Plan M√©xico. Podr√≠a conllevar riesgos sectoriales. Al crecer la dominancia tecnol√≥gica de China, entonces la competitividad de fabricantes con problemas como Nissan, Volkswagen o las Tres Grandes de Detroit podr√≠a situar a M√©xico en un escenario de desindustrializaci√≥n prematura por geopol√≠tica adversa.

title: El papel de los diferentes mercados en la producci√≥n y exportaci√≥n de cereza
content: Turqu√≠a es el mayor productor de cereza a nivel mundial y Chile el mayor exportador, convirti√©ndose en aliados m√°s que en competidores, puesto que sus temporadas no coinciden ...
resumen:
Turqu√≠a es el mayor productor de cereza a nivel mundial y Chile el mayor exportador.
Se prev√© que la producci√≥n turca de cereza descienda en 48.000 toneladas hasta un total de 900.000 toneladas.
Turqu√≠a se ha posicionado como el mayor productor y uno de los principales exportadores de cerezas a nivel mundial, con mercados clave en Europa, Rusia y los pa√≠ses √°rabes.
Se espera que la producci√≥n mundial de cerezas frescas para esta temporada aumente ligeramente, alcanzando los 5 millones de toneladas.
Los principales importadores de cerezas del mundo son China, Rusia, la Uni√≥n Europea, Canad√° y Estados Unidos, mientras que los principales exportadores son Chile, Turqu√≠a, Estados Unidos y Uzbekist√°n.
Se prev√© que las exportaciones turcas se mantengan en torno a las 85.000 toneladas, seg√∫n los datos del USDA.
Chile es el cuarto productor mundial de cerezas, pero el mayor exportador.
La temporada de cerezas en Turqu√≠a comienza en mayo y se extiende hasta septiembre.
En Chile, la temporada empieza en octubre-noviembre y llega hasta febrero aproximadamente.
Chile, seg√∫n USDA, es el cuarto productor mundial de cerezas, pero el mayor exportador, con vol√∫menes de exportaci√≥n aproximadamente cinco veces superiores a los de Turqu√≠a.
En la √∫ltima d√©cada, la superficie cosechada y la producci√≥n de cerezas en Chile casi se han cuadruplicado, mientras que el consumo interno s√≥lo se ha duplicado.
La primera estimaci√≥n del Comit√© de Cerezas de Frutas de Chile plantea que se enviar√°n al mundo en esta temporada 131.587.007 de cajas de cerezas de 5 kilos, equivalentes a 657.935 toneladas.
De la temporada 2019-2020 a la temporada 2023-2024, las importaciones de cerezas de China se dispararon con creces y pasaron de 230.000 toneladas a 388.000 toneladas.
Las exportaciones de cerezas frescas de Chile se han cuadruplicado en la √∫ltima d√©cada, con aproximadamente el 90% de estos env√≠os destinados a China.
Durante la temporada 2023-2024 se calcula que las exportaciones de Chile a China representaron aproximadamente la mitad del comercio mundial de cerezas, estimado en m√°s de 375.000 toneladas.
Se prev√© que las exportaciones mundiales de cerezas alcancen las 759.000 toneladas.
Se estima que la producci√≥n y las importaciones de China aumenten a 850.000 y 415.000 toneladas, respectivamente.
Se prev√© que la producci√≥n total de cerezas en China aumente en 50.000 toneladas hasta alcanzar las 850.000 toneladas.
Las importaciones crecer√°n un 7%, cifrando las 415.000 toneladas, indica el USDA.
En la temporada 2023-24, la producci√≥n de cerezas frescas de China alcanz√≥ un total de 800.000 toneladas.
La producci√≥n de cerezas de la Uni√≥n Europea se ha limitado a unas 715.000 toneladas, y ello supone un aumento de 10.000 toneladas.
El consumo de cerezas de la Uni√≥n Europea se ha m√°s que duplicado en los √∫ltimos seis a√±os y se espera que alcance los 1,3 millones de toneladas en la temporada 2024-2025.
Se estima que las importaciones para esta temporada aumenten ligeramente, alcanzando 60.000 toneladas, mientras que las exportaciones se prev√© que aumenten en 3.000 toneladas, totalizando 15.000 toneladas.
Se prev√© que la producci√≥n estadounidense de cerezas aumente en 13.000 toneladas, alcanzando un total de 413.000 toneladas.
Se estima que las exportaciones de EEUU aumenten ligeramente a 85.000 toneladas, mientras que las importaciones se mantendr√°n estables en 20.000 toneladas.

title: Tremendistas, propelentes, expectantes
content: Los tremendistas y agoreros recurren a todo tipo de intimidaciones tratando de opacar con ello sus sesgos confirmatorios: ‚Äú¬°Se ha lanzado una bomba nuclear!‚Äù; ‚Äú¬°Ha estallado la madre de todas las ...
resumen:
Martes, 20 de Mayo de 2025.

Frente a los aranceles de Trump hay dos visiones: la de los catastrofistas, alarmistas y milenaristas, o la de los exploradores, visionarios y pioneros de nuevos mercados y oportunidades.

Los tremendistas y agoreros recurren a todo tipo de intimidaciones.

Los entusiastas y vitalistas emprenden pesquisas creativas para crear nuevos escenarios de intercambio, repotenciar sus destrezas competitivas y superar a los rivales.

Brasil, Australia, Vietnam, Israel, Tailandia, o Taiw√°n son ejemplos de esta tendencia propelente.

Hay una conducta intermedia a la que llamar√≠amos ‚Äúde los expectantes‚Äù.

Se trata de aquellos pa√≠ses como Corea del Norte, Cuba, Bielorrusia, y la propia Rusia, que ya han sido sometidos por los EE.UU. a severas sanciones.

El a√±o pasado los Estados Unidos importaron desde Rusia fertilizantes y platino por unos 3 mil millones de d√≥lares.

Trump no clasifica a los gobiernos entre ‚Äúamigos‚Äù o ‚Äúenemigos‚Äù, sino que ve en todo Estado un competidor con el que es posible llegar a acuerdos o, en su defecto, a confrontaciones.

La Casa Blanca les est√° planteando a sus principales antagonistas en el sistema internacional un escenario de di√°logo y transformaci√≥n de conflictos.

title: Colombia y la Ruta de la Seda: ¬ødecisi√≥n estrat√©gica o apuesta riesgosa?
content: China ha utilizado la Ruta de la Seda como un instrumento para expandir su influencia econ√≥mica y diplom√°tica en regiones estrat√©gicas. En Am√©rica Latina, m√°s de 20 pa√≠ses ya han firmado acuerdos simi ...
resumen: El Gobierno colombiano suscribi√≥ un acuerdo para ingresar a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta, promovida por China. China ha utilizado la Ruta de la Seda para expandir su influencia econ√≥mica y diplom√°tica. M√°s de 20 pa√≠ses de Am√©rica Latina han firmado acuerdos similares y algunos como Panam√° decidieron retirarse. Para los defensores de la Ruta, esto podr√≠a representar oportunidades en financiamiento para obras p√∫blicas, diversificaci√≥n de exportaciones y transferencia tecnol√≥gica. El ingreso a la Ruta de la Seda podr√≠a significar la profundizaci√≥n del desbalance comercial con China, que ronda los USD 12.400 millones, y generar acuerdos para que este pa√≠s administre la infraestructura estrat√©gica que eventualmente financie y licite en Colombia, como ocurre con el puerto de Chancay en Per√∫, bajo el control de la naviera china COSCO. Estados Unidos observa con preocupaci√≥n la creciente penetraci√≥n china en la regi√≥n y ha enviado amenazas de represalia. Estados Unidos tiene suspendidos por 90 d√≠as los aranceles rec√≠procos, mientras negocia acuerdos bilaterales con los pa√≠ses afectados.

title: South Africa's president heads to the White House. Can he charm Trump?
content: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa heads to the White House today for conciliatory talks with one of his country's most persistent critics: President Trump.
resumen: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa met with President Trump in the Oval Office on Wednesday. Trump repeated false claims of a "white genocide" in South Africa and ordered the lights dimmed to play videos he said supported his allegation. Ramaphosa attempted to correct Trump. Trump asked why Julius Malema wasn't arrested. Trump played a video that he said was of "a burial site" of murdered white farmers. Trump showed the press copies of articles, claiming they proved white farmers were being murdered. Ramaphosa's agriculture minister, John Steenhuisen, and business mogul Johann Rupert, also tried to explain the facts for Trump. In the last quarter of 2024, there were 12 murders linked to farming communities. Fifty-nine white Afrikaner South Africans who were granted refugee status by the Trump administration arrived in the U.S. last week. Trump said white farmers were having their land taken. Trump cut aid to South Africa in February, his top officials have snubbed G20 events South Africa is hosting this year and the U.S. expelled South Africa's ambassador. The U.S. administration is also angry that Pretoria has taken Israel to the International Court of Justice in The Hague over its war in Gaza. Trump's South African-born adviser, Elon Musk, was also present at the meeting. Ramaphosa offered Trump a turn on the green at the G20 summit in Johannesburg in November. Ernie Els and Retief Goosen were brought to Wednesday's Oval Office meeting.

title: 47 days of the 47th US president tariff-ying the world: How Donald Trump's tariffs are reshaping the global economy
content: Donald Trump ... tariffs are fuelling a ‚Äúloss of investor confidence‚Äù and weakening demand, with implications for jobs and GDP. APEC‚Äôs forecast for regional growth has dropped to 2.6% for ...
resumen:
Donald Trump's return to the White House has triggered global economic turmoil through aggressive tariffs and trade recalibrations. These measures have strained diplomatic ties, disrupted supply chains, and rattled financial markets.

It has been forty-seven days since the 47th US President sent the global economy into a turmoil. On April 2, Donald Trump announced his sweeping tariff hikes, regional trade recalibrations, on he what he called the 'liberation day'. Trump√¢¬Ä¬ôs √¢¬Ä¬úeconomic nationalism√¢¬Ä¬ù has reawakened tensions last seen during his first term only this time, the stakes appear even higher.

Trump's aggressive use of tariffs justified as "reciprocal" measures to correct unfair trade practices has rocked global supply chains, strained diplomatic ties, and rattled financial markets.

Some countries faced a universal 10% tariff, others were subjected to higher import duties. Products from China faced a combined import duty of 104%. Russia, Vietnam (46% tariff), Taiwan (32%), and India (26%) were also affected. South Korea and Japan are facing 25% and 24% tariffs, respectively, while countries like Australia, the United Kingdom, and Brazil face a baseline tariff of 10%.

On April 9, Trump announced he suspended his reciprocal tariffs for the next 90 days, setting a universal tariff rate of 10%, for all countries barring China.

The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) warned that trade in the region is approaching stagnation. APEC√¢¬Ä¬ôs report shows export growth plummeting from 5.7% in 2024 to just 0.4% this year. Imports are nearly flat. APEC√¢¬Ä¬ôs forecast for regional growth has dropped to 2.6% for 2025, down from 3.3% earlier projected.

Walmart said last week it would be forced to raise prices due to tariff-related costs. Scott Bessent spoke with Walmart CEO Doug McMillon, who reportedly agreed to absorb some costs.

The S&P 500 initially plummeted by up to 15% following the tariff declaration. However, a subsequent 90-day pause in tariffs and a provisional US-China trade agreement spurred a robust rebound. By mid-May, the index had not only recouped its losses but also posted a year-to-date gain of 0.1%.

After the tariff announcement BSE Sensex faced headwinds, however India's stock market became the first among global economies to recover from Trump's trade shock.

Japan's Nikkei 225 index has experienced notable declines, dropping from a high of 34,609 on 10 April to approximately 33,740 in early May. This represents a decrease of about 2.5%.

Nearly 60% of firms expect negative impacts, with just under half forecasting positive export growth, down from 80% pre-announcement. One-third of companies have already found new export or supply markets, with two-thirds planning to follow suit. Payment delays are rising, with fewer firms being paid within 30 days and longer terms hitting smaller exporters hardest. Nearly half of firms fear increased non-payment risk.

In South Korea, officials are trying to stabilise trade cooperation amid the turbulence.

Many nations are now pivoting toward regional deals in response to the United States' retreat from globalism.

The White House insists its plan is delivering results.

Heidi Shierholz of the Economic Policy Institute says there√¢¬Ä¬ôs no broad constituency demanding tariffs at this scale. Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers said the measures are likely √¢¬Ä¬úto create fewer good-paying jobs√¢¬Ä¬ù.

Thousands of federal employees have been laid off, unions are under pressure, and minimum wages for contractors have been cut. Higher production costs due to tariffs are pushing up prices.

title: Investors Are Jittery as G.O.P. Bill Threatens to Swell Deficit
content: Investors burned by President Trump‚Äôs trade fight now have to contend with a spending megabill that risks swelling the federal deficit.
resumen: America‚Äôs swelling federal deficit is unnerving global investors. As President Trump‚Äôs trade war continues, global investors are fretting about America‚Äôs rocky finances while congressional Republicans negotiate a spending megabill that could add $3.3 trillion to the deficit over the next decade. House Republicans, holding a tiny majority, are aiming for a floor vote this week. Trump, whose promised tax cuts hinge on the bill‚Äôs passage, is heading to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to try to get lawmakers onboard. Investors are wary of the fiscal risk. The prospect of adding significantly to the federal deficit has given the normally rock-solid market for U.S. government debt a roller coaster feel lately. Monday saw a rapid sell-off in 30-year Treasury bonds, in which yields jumped to their highest level since 2023 after Moody‚Äôs cut America‚Äôs triple-A credit rating on Friday. Monday‚Äôs wild market swings may indicate ‚Äúthe slow moving trend of overseas investors selling Treasuries but domestic investors increasing their holdings,‚Äù Jim Reid, a Deutsche Bank strategist, wrote in a research note on Tuesday. Torsten Slok, chief economist at Apollo Global Management, sees a similar course. Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase called out investors, saying they were suffering from ‚Äúan extraordinary amount of complacency.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúI think credit today is a bad risk.‚Äù John Williams, the New York Fed president, and Raphael Bostic, the Atlanta Fed president, said on Monday that they were in no rush to cut interest rates, citing uncertainty around growth and inflation. Home Depot on Tuesday reported disappointing first-quarter sales, but Richard McPhail, its C.F.O., told CNBC that the company would stick to its full-year guidance and that it was not feeling pressure to raise prices. 23andMe agreed to sell itself for $256 million. The biotech company Regeneron reached a deal to buy the genetic testing company out of bankruptcy protection. Paramount executives told Wendy McMahon, who has led its news division since 2023, that they wanted her to step down. Paramount is in talks to settle a defamation lawsuit by President Trump, an outcome favored by its controlling shareholder, Shari Redstone; CNN‚Äôs Jake Tapper reports that Paramount could pay up to $50 million. Sixteen Democrats joined most Republicans in approving the GENIUS Act, which would create a rules framework for so-called stablecoins. SPACs are back. A team affiliated with Trump Media took Renatus Tactical Acquisition Corp I public on Wednesday and raised $210 million. Cantor Equity Partners II, where Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick‚Äôs son Brandon is the C.E.O., went public on May 1 and raised $240 million. In 2021, 613 SPACs were floated on the stock market, raising $163 billion. Paul Atkins, the current head of the S.E.C., generally favors a lighter touch to regulations. Investors in the SPAC and the merged company, Trump Media & Technology Group, which trades under the symbol DJT, have seen huge swings. The stock rose as high as $92 in early 2022 and now trades around $25. The potential cost: a new Boeing 747-8, the jet being offered by Qatar, costs $400 million. The cost of retrofits would be at least $1 billion. White House officials initially assumed that the Qatari plane would need just a paint job and a few other upgrades, and be ready for service within the year, but bringing the jet up to Air Force One standards would take years, potentially past 2027. Lori Torman, the C.E.O. and founder of StickyJ Medical ID and Thoughtful Impressions in Seminole, Fla., has two online stores and employs 10 people and generates about $1.5 million in annual sales. She was charged a 159 percent tariff on a shipment of stainless items. Her customs charge was over $5,400. She plans to initiate a small price increase of between $2 and $5 on most items. She has observed a 30 percent drop in year-over-year sales since the beginning of April. Shares in the giant Chinese battery maker CATL soared 16 percent in the company‚Äôs Hong Kong trading debut. Nippon Steel reportedly plans to invest up to $14 billion in U.S. Steel‚Äôs operations. UBS is using A.I. to create deepfake-like avatars of its analysts to ‚Äúspeak‚Äù to clients. Tesla gave its C.F.O., Vaibhav Taneja, $139 million last year.

title: Australian central bank cuts interest rates amid global economic turmoil
content: The Reserve Bank board statement referred to ‚Äúthe heightened level of uncertainty‚Äù in the world economy and said it had ‚Äúconsidered a severe downside scenario.‚Äù ...
resumen: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) board cut its official cash rate by 25 basis points for the second time in three months, reducing the rate to 3.85 percent, down 50 points overall from 4.35 percent. This decision reflects growing concern about the impact of the Trump administration‚Äôs trade war. The decision will have only a marginal effect on home mortgage payments and rents. A household with a $750,000 mortgage could see their minimum monthly repayments fall by $228 a month as a result of the two rate cuts. The RBA‚Äôs decision was overshadowed by global economic turmoil generated by the US Trump administration‚Äôs trade war, particularly against China. The board used the word ‚Äúuncertain‚Äù 134 times in its statement. The board considered a severe downside scenario. The RBA stated that ‚ÄúGeopolitical uncertainties also remain pronounced. These developments are expected to have an adverse effect on global economic activity, particularly if households and firms delay expenditure pending greater clarity on the outlook. This has also contributed to a weaker outlook for growth, employment and inflation in Australia.‚Äù The RBA governor Michelle Bullock described the situation over the past few months as a ‚Äúroller coaster‚Äù and ‚Äúunpredictable.‚Äù There was a risk of a recession in Australia. One of the scenarios in the board‚Äôs statement estimates that unemployment could jump to 6 percent, which would mean about 900,000 out of work, if the US-China trade conflict worsened. The RBA downgraded its key economic forecasts, lowering its projections for growth in exports, business investment and household consumption, and slashed its forecasts for US economic activity. China accounted for 37 percent of all exports in 2024. Japan, South Korea and India together took 24 percent of the exports last year. The United States is the largest foreign investor in Australia, with its investment stock reaching $1.17 trillion in 2023, accounting for a quarter of the total of $4.7 trillion invested in Australia at the end of 2023. Stephen Miller wrote that the upending of the global trade system occasioned by the Trump administration‚Äôs tariff agenda will constitute severe headwinds for the global economy. Interest rates on US Treasury bonds are soaring. Moody‚Äôs rating agency joined other agencies in stripping the US government of its AAA credit ranking. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation‚Äôs chief business correspondent Ian Verrender warned: ‚ÄúBond markets are now openly questioning America‚Äôs place in the global financial system and remain unconvinced about Washington‚Äôs ability or commitment to strike a lasting peace in its trade wars.‚Äù Australia‚Äôs major banks are among the biggest institutional borrowers in the world, tapping global markets for about $30 billion to $40 billion every year. S&P Global warned that Australia‚Äôs AAA credit rating could be at risk due to mounting government budget deficits unless the Albanese government cut social spending. According to the RBA‚Äôs calculations, ‚Äúthe combined drag from higher interest rates, lower gross mixed income (mainly small business income) and tax has reduced disposable income by 5 percentage points since December 2019.‚Äù The official Wages Price Index rose 3.4 percent over the 12 months to the March 2025 quarter. The RBA‚Äôs core inflation rate has eased to 2.9 percent. Living costs for employee households rose 3.4 percent over the 12 months to March, and by an annual rate of 4.4 percent during the March 2025 quarter. In April, the official jobless rate remained 4.1 percent. Employment vacancies fell 9.3 percent over the preceding year. An estimated 621,000 people were counted as unemployed, seasonally adjusted, but the number of job vacancies had fallen to 328,900. For workers aged 15 to 24, the official youth unemployment rate remained more than twice as high at 8.9 percent.

content: Los ministros de Econom√≠a de los pa√≠ses del G7 se re√∫nen en Canad√° a partir del martes con Ucrania como invitado a la mesa, donde la guerra con Rusia monopolizar√° buena parte del encuentro, as√≠ como l ...

title: Aranceles de EE. UU. generar√≠an presi√≥n moderada sobre el tipo de cambio y leve afectaci√≥n en exportaciones costarricenses
content: La reciente imposici√≥n de aranceles por parte del gobierno de los Estados Unidos ha generado diversas reacciones a nivel internacional y en el caso de Costa Rica, aunque el impacto directo a√∫n es ...
resumen:
La reciente imposici√≥n de aranceles por parte del gobierno de los Estados Unidos podr√≠a generar efectos en distintas variables macroecon√≥micas en Costa Rica si estas medidas se mantienen durante un per√≠odo prolongado.

Rolando Sabor√≠o Jim√©nez, coordinador de la C√°tedra de Estad√≠stica de la Universidad Estatal a Distancia (UNED), expuso una valoraci√≥n preliminar sobre los posibles impactos que estas pol√≠ticas arancelarias podr√≠an tener sobre la econom√≠a costarricense, si se mantienen durante la administraci√≥n de Trump.

Existe un alto nivel de incertidumbre, ‚Äúno est√° claro si estas medidas se sostendr√°n, si ser√°n modificadas o incluso eliminadas a cambio de concesiones en otras √°reas‚Äù.

Tampoco se puede descartar un aumento de los aranceles seg√∫n las valoraciones estrat√©gicas de la administraci√≥n estadounidense.

Si los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos se mantienen durante toda la administraci√≥n, se anticipa una presi√≥n moderada al alza en el tipo de cambio, debido a una posible reducci√≥n en las exportaciones y en la llegada de inversi√≥n extranjera directa.

No se prev√© un impacto directo sobre las tasas de inter√©s en Costa Rica, podr√≠an presentarse efectos indirectos seg√∫n la reacci√≥n de las tasas estadounidenses.

El profesional universitario estim√≥ una afectaci√≥n moderada en el crecimiento econ√≥mico por la p√©rdida de competitividad de ciertos productos, aunque un escenario m√°s adverso ‚Äîcomo la relocalizaci√≥n de empresas hacia M√©xico‚Äî parece poco probable.

‚ÄúEl turismo y la inflaci√≥n no deber√≠an presentar impactos significativos, salvo que el contexto internacional se deteriore o se agraven las tensiones diplom√°ticas‚Äù, indic√≥ Sabor√≠o Jim√©nez.

Tipo de cambio: De mantenerse los aranceles durante toda la administraci√≥n, se prev√© una presi√≥n moderada al alza en el tipo de cambio, es decir, una depreciaci√≥n del col√≥n frente al d√≥lar. Esta situaci√≥n estar√≠a relacionada con una posible reducci√≥n en la compra de productos costarricenses por parte de Estados Unidos, as√≠ como con menores incentivos para la llegada de Inversi√≥n Extranjera Directa (IED), lo cual disminuir√≠a la oferta de divisas en el sistema financiero nacional.

M√°s all√° de los aranceles, ya se observan signos de debilitamiento en la llegada de turistas al pa√≠s, lo que podr√≠a estar vinculado a una p√©rdida de competitividad por la fuerte apreciaci√≥n reciente del col√≥n, un fen√≥meno que podr√≠a revertirse parcialmente en los pr√≥ximos a√±os.

Tasas de inter√©s locales: Los aranceles por s√≠ solos no tendr√≠an un impacto directo sobre las tasas en Costa Rica; sin embargo, cualquier cambio podr√≠a presentarse de forma indirecta, dependiendo de c√≥mo los aranceles afecten las tasas de inter√©s en los Estados Unidos.

‚ÄúEl efecto depender√° del equilibrio entre las presiones inflacionarias generadas por los aranceles y el impacto que estas medidas tengan sobre la econom√≠a real estadounidense, especialmente en variables como el empleo y la producci√≥n‚Äù, detall√≥.

Crecimiento econ√≥mico: Sabor√≠o advirti√≥ sobre un posible efecto moderadamente negativo, principalmente por la afectaci√≥n en las exportaciones costarricenses hacia Estados Unidos, como resultado de un incremento en los precios debido a los nuevos aranceles.

Un escenario m√°s adverso se presentar√≠a si las empresas extranjeras instaladas en Costa Rica, particularmente las del sector de dispositivos m√©dicos, consideraran trasladar sus operaciones a M√©xico para aprovechar los beneficios arancelarios del tratado USMCA (Tratado entre M√©xico, Estados Unidos y Canad√°).

‚ÄúSin embargo, este escenario parece poco probable por ahora, ya que implicar√≠a una duplicaci√≥n de inversiones en el corto plazo, adem√°s de asumir el riesgo de que la siguiente administraci√≥n estadounidense revierta esas decisiones dentro de cuatro a√±os‚Äù, aclar√≥.

Exportaciones: La implementaci√≥n de aranceles podr√≠a reducir la competitividad de ciertos productos costarricenses en el mercado estadounidense, afectando de forma moderada su volumen y dinamismo.

Turismo: El flujo de visitantes estadounidenses hacia Costa Rica no deber√≠a verse afectado directamente por los aranceles, a menos que la situaci√≥n escale y se generen tensiones diplom√°ticas u otras medidas restrictivas que afecten la percepci√≥n del destino costarricense.

Inflaci√≥n: Los efectos de los aranceles no deber√≠an ser significativos sobre el nivel general de precios en Costa Rica.

title: El precio del Bitcoin volvi√≥ a escalar y se acerca a nuevos m√°ximos: los motivos
content: Luego de tocar en marzo un piso debajo de USD 80.000, la principal criptomoneda inici√≥ un camino de recuperaci√≥n y super√≥ otra vez los USD 106.000, muy cerca de su r√©cord ...
