title: There‚Äôs some good news for Trump‚Äôs approval rating, latest poll shows
content: The latest Morning Consult poll showed 48% of voters approving of Trump‚Äôs job performance‚Äîhis highest approval rating Morning Consult has recorded since mid-March. The poll showed that half of the ...
resumen: President Donald Trump‚Äôs approval rating ticked up following his Middle East trip last week, a new poll showed. The latest Morning Consult poll showed 48% of voters approving of Trump‚Äôs job performance‚Äîhis highest approval rating Morning Consult has recorded since mid-March. The poll showed that half of the voters still disapproved of Trump‚Äôs job performance, but that dropped two percentage points since last week. According to the poll, Trump‚Äôs approval ratings on foreign policy and his handling of trade also improved. The poll found that voters are ‚Äúevenly divided over Trump‚Äôs handling of trade.‚Äù The poll found that Trump‚Äôs strongest policy area continues to be immigration, where 53% of voters approve of his handling of it. He continued to receive low marks on the economy, with 47% of voters disapproving of how he is handling it. Morning Consult‚Äôs Eli Yokley also explained that last week, Trump also received his ‚Äúbest news week‚Äù since February. The latest poll was conducted May 16-19 among 2,208 registered U.S. voters. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. The latest Harvard CAPS/Harris poll showed that 46% approved of how Trump is handling the economy, which is up from the 43% who said the same last month. Another 43% said they approved of how Trump is dealing with inflation, which is up two percentage points from last month. A recent Reuters/Ipsos poll, released Tuesday, found Trump‚Äôs approval rating ticked up two percentage points since the poll was conducted late last month. The poll found that 44% of respondents said they approved of Trump‚Äôs job performance, while 52% say they disapproved. The Quantus Insights poll showed a virtual tie, with 48.2% of respondents saying they approve of Trump while 48.3% said they disapprove. According to Reuters, former President Joe Biden had a 55% approval rating at a similar point in his presidency.

title: Pres. Trump lobbies House Republicans
content: President Donald Trump tries to blame Democrats as support for this "big, beautiful bill" faces tough questions on Capitol Hill.
resumen: President Donald Trump headed to Capitol Hill Tuesday with a stern message to House Republicans to stay in line and support his multi-trillion tax and spending bill. President Donald Trump turned up the pressure, telling wavering House Republicans to support what he calls his ‚Äúbig, beautiful bill‚Äù or face the political consequences. Behind closed doors, the president told the House Republican Conference that they all must unite behind his multi-trillion dollar budget bill. White House sources say the President warned that any Republican who doesn‚Äôt back the bill could face a primary opponent. ‚ÄúYou have a couple that will grandstand, but I think even the grandstand is look, the alternative is a 68% tax increase. And you can blame the Democrats for that. And 1 or 2 grandstanding. We only have one issue, but we have tremendous support.‚Äù The president urged fiscal conservatives to give up their push to expand Medicaid cuts and some moderate Republicans to drop their efforts to raise the cap on state and local tax deductions. The president‚Äôs bill would extend tax cuts due to expire in December, boost border spending, and repeal much of President Biden‚Äôs Inflation Reduction Act. Democrats are unified in opposition to the legislation. That includes Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer who continues to criticize the President‚Äôs trade tariffs policy. On the floor of the Senate, Minority Senator Chuck Schumer (D- N.Y.) said, ‚ÄúFor someone who fancies himself a shrewd businessman, Donald Trump doesn‚Äôt seem to understand the pain his trade war has created for businesses.‚Äù Despite the President‚Äôs arm twisting, his Capitol Hill visit appeared to fail to sway some key Republicans from more liberal states and conservatives who want steeper cuts to the federal budget deficit. Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) has a very narrow majority in the House. The House Rules Committee has called a meeting for the unusual time of 1am ET Wednesday.

title: Trump Scolded Companies for Raising Prices. Do They Have a Choice?
content: Economists say companies generally have to pass along the cost of tariffs. But populists on the left and right say the president may have a point.
resumen:
El presidente Trump se quej√≥ el s√°bado de que Walmart deber√≠a "dejar de culpar a los aranceles" por los inminentes aumentos de precios.

El a√±o pasado, el presidente Joseph R. Biden Jr. cit√≥ la "avaricia corporativa" como la raz√≥n por la que los estadounidenses pagaban m√°s por la gasolina, los alimentos y el alquiler, al tiempo que desviaba las cr√≠ticas de que sus pol√≠ticas hab√≠an empeorado la inflaci√≥n.

Michael Strain, economista del American Enterprise Institute, dijo que en ambos casos, el presidente comete un error de pol√≠tica, lo que lleva a un aumento de los precios al consumidor, y el presidente culpa a las empresas.

Los aranceles del Sr. Trump, que se fijan en el 30 por ciento sobre las importaciones chinas hasta mediados de agosto, tendr√°n efectos en toda la econom√≠a, ya sea empujando los precios al alza para los consumidores o, si las empresas absorben algunos de los costos, reduciendo las ganancias para las empresas. Esas respuestas podr√≠an impulsar la inflaci√≥n, frenar el crecimiento y aumentar el desempleo.

Elizabeth Wilkins, presidenta del Roosevelt Institute, dijo que la idea b√°sica de que las empresas tienen m√°s poder de fijaci√≥n de precios de lo que se cree es algo que se debe interrogar.

El Sr. Trump sugiri√≥ que Walmart usara sus miles de millones en ganancias del a√±o pasado, "mucho m√°s de lo esperado", para proteger a los consumidores contra los aumentos de precios.

Chad Syverson, economista de la Universidad de Chicago, dijo que el tama√±o de las ganancias de una empresa tiene poco efecto en su decisi√≥n de aumentar los precios. La mayor√≠a de las empresas quieren preservar sus ganancias, ya sean grandes o peque√±as, porque no hacerlo incurrir√≠a en la ira de sus propietarios o accionistas, algunos de los cuales son fondos de pensiones e inversores a peque√±a escala.

Alexander MacKay, economista de la Universidad de Virginia, dijo que si, en algunos casos, las empresas aumentan los precios incluso m√°s que el aumento de sus costos, eso no refleja necesariamente un comportamiento nefasto. Puede reflejar el hecho de que los consumidores ya no se sienten tan desanimados por los aumentos de precios.

Jared Bernstein, que se desempe√±√≥ como principal economista de la Casa Blanca del Sr. Biden, dijo que muchos consumidores durante la pandemia estaban menos disuadidos de lo habitual por los aumentos de precios porque estaban inundados de una serie de inyecciones de efectivo del gobierno.

Oren Cass, ex asistente de pol√≠tica republicano, dijo que una gran empresa como Walmart ten√≠a mucha m√°s influencia sobre sus precios de lo que dejaba ver.

John David Rainey, director financiero de Walmart, dijo que la empresa estaba "bien equipada" para navegar por los aumentos de precios del 2 o 3 por ciento, pero no por un arancel del 30 por ciento, la tasa actual sobre los bienes de China. El Sr. Rainey agreg√≥ que Walmart de hecho absorber√≠a algunos de los aumentos de costos.

Nick Iacovella, vicepresidente ejecutivo de la Coalici√≥n para una Am√©rica Pr√≥spera, se√±al√≥ una l√≥gica dudosa en la fijaci√≥n de precios por parte de las empresas: un fabricante de autom√≥viles gritar√° sobre la necesidad de aumentar los precios cuando los costos aumenten, pero cuando un fabricante de autom√≥viles aprovecha un acuerdo comercial para trasladar la producci√≥n a M√©xico, rara vez traslada los ahorros a los consumidores.

Ms. Wilkins, del Roosevelt Institute, argument√≥ que las grandes empresas no solo aumentaban los precios cuando sus costos aumentaban, o cuando los compradores se mostraban dispuestos a pagar m√°s. Dijo que las empresas a veces explotaban las preocupaciones generalizadas sobre la inflaci√≥n para manipular los precios.

Dr. MacKay, el economista de la Universidad de Virginia, concedi√≥ que este tipo de coordinaci√≥n era posible. Se√±al√≥ un estudio reciente que argumentaba que los ejecutivos de la industria a√©rea se han coordinado eficazmente para reducir los asientos en las rutas competitivas telegrafiando sus intenciones durante las llamadas de ganancias.

Noam Scheiber es un reportero del Times que cubre a los trabajadores de cuello blanco, centr√°ndose en temas como la remuneraci√≥n, la inteligencia artificial, la movilidad descendente y la discriminaci√≥n.

title: What Trump‚Äôs Phone Call With Putin Reveals About His View of the World
content: The two leaders talked for more than two hours‚Äîand they probably didn't spend much of it discussing the prospects for peace.
resumen: Presidents Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin talked Monday for more than two hours but made not an inch of progress toward ending the Russia‚ÄìUkraine war. Trump said afterward that he believes Putin wants peace. Trump wants the war to end quickly only so that the U.S. and Russia can resume good relations‚Äîand if this means Ukraine‚Äôs surrender, so be it. Trump hailed the ‚Äútone and spirit‚Äù of their conversation as ‚Äúexcellent.‚Äù Putin, in a formal statement, deemed the talk ‚Äúfrank and useful.‚Äù Trump has called for an ‚Äúimmediate ceasefire.‚Äù Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky endorsed the idea. Putin never has. Earlier on Monday, several European leaders urged Trump to renew the demand during his conversation with Putin. Trump ignored their plea. Putin continued to insist that prior to a ceasefire, the two combatants must address the war‚Äôs ‚Äúroot causes‚Äù‚Äîwhich, in Putin‚Äôs mind, amount to the very existence of Ukraine as a sovereign state with its own language, culture, and aspirations to align with Europe. Trump didn‚Äôt challenge Putin on this point. He also told reporters that he would not impose sanctions or any other punishment on Russia, regardless of Putin‚Äôs actions. He said that Russia and Ukraine would have to hold negotiations on their own. Trump is acknowledging that Putin, not Zelensky, is the one resisting a ceasefire‚Äîyet if Russia stays on that course, the U.S. won‚Äôt step up its support for Ukraine; instead, Trump will simply pull out. Trump has said that without firm U.S. support, Russia will win the war. The day before the much-anticipated phone call, Russia slammed Ukraine with one of the largest drone attacks since the war began‚Äîyet Trump didn‚Äôt so much as mention it in their talk. The two leaders talked for more than two hours about trade. Russia wants to do largescale TRADE with the United States when this catastrophic ‚Äúbloodbath‚Äù is over, and Trump agrees. There is a tremendous opportunity for Russia to create massive amounts of jobs and wealth. Its potential is UNLIMITED. Ukraine too ‚Äúcan be a great beneficiary on Trade, in the process of rebuilding its Country‚Äù. To the extent a coherent foreign policy is emerging in Trump‚Äôs second term as president, it is centered around three goals: trade, the promotion of ‚Äúgreat-power politics,‚Äù and peace at any price in order to promote the first two.

title: US importers race to create bonded warehouses amid Trump tariffs
content: Companies importing goods into the United States from China are rushing to convert warehouses into facilities that are exempt from President Donald Trump's tariffs until they are ready to sell the ...
resumen: Companies importing goods into the United States from China are rushing to convert warehouses into facilities that are exempt from President Donald Trump's tariffs until they are ready to sell the merchandise. The U.S. has more than 1,700 bonded warehouses, facilities where imported goods can be held without immediate payment of customs duties such as tariffs, currently 30% for shipments from China. Such fees are only paid when the goods leave the bonded warehouse. The rush to bond U.S. warehouses for goods ranging from clothing to auto parts is a bet for some that raised U.S. tariffs will be only a short-term policy by the Trump administration. Due to Trump's tariff war, many of these bonded warehouses are now at full capacity, and prices for space in them have skyrocketed, four industry sources told Reuters, prompting companies to apply to U.S. Customs and Border Protection to expand bonded space. Utah-based fulfillment firm LVK Logistics is in the process of making one of its warehouses bonded "in response to the tariffs," CEO Maggie Barnett told Reuters, adding she expects the process to take three to four months. Chris Rogers, who manages the supply chain research team at consultancy S&P Global Market Intelligence, said, "It involves money and it takes time, but if you are a big company and expect tariffs are going to remain elevated for an extended period, you can convert (existing) spaces into bonded warehousing." Chris Huwaldt, vice president of solutions at WarehouseQuote, a logistics research firm, said other companies and logistics firms are seeing their applications with the CBP backlogged in some cases by over six months. Last year, the process would have taken a couple of months. Huwaldt said getting storage space certified as bonded "could cost thousands of dollars or it could cost six figures," depending on the state the warehouse is based in, the financial status of the company and the additional security measures required by the CBP for a specific location. Trump's on-again, off-again tariff policy - which pushed duties on Chinese goods to as much as 145% in April before lowering them - makes the flexibility afforded by bonded warehouses appealing to companies. Cindy Allen, shipping consultant at Trade Force Multiplier and a former FedEx Logistics executive, said, "A lot of companies importing from China - not just China-based, but U.S. importers as well - are taking advantage of bonded warehouses to assist with cash flow." The CBP said it has noticed an increased interest in the use of bonded warehouses for continued compliance with new regulations and executive orders. In early 2024, bonded storage space was rented at approximately twice the cost of standard storage rates, but since the start of 2025, it has risen to four times the price to rent non-bonded space, according to WarehouseQuote data. Allen said, "This rush to bonded warehouses to ease cash flow is unprecedented." During the first Trump administration, many companies simply accepted the levies on China. Vladimir Durshpek, cofounder of Venice, Florida-based warehousing and storage company CargoNest, said he is weighing adding a third bonded warehouse to his assets until U.S. tariff negotiations are completed. Fremont, California-based storage company DCL Logistics has not made definitive plans for bonded space because "it's unclear if the demand will stay this high," Chief Revenue Officer Brian Tu said. Jacob Roseburrough, director of marketing at WarehouseQuote, said, "By the time a lot of warehouses would be able to achieve bonded status right now, these additional tariffs might be gone, and the demand for bonded space might not be there."

title: China‚Äôs smartphone exports to US crash to 14-year low amid trade war
content: The decline in smartphone export reflects a dramatic fallout from escalating trade tensions and renewed tariff threats.
resumen: China‚Äôs smartphone exports to the US have plunged to their lowest level since 2011. In April 2025, China‚Äôs mobile phone shipments to the US plummeted 72 per cent year-on-year to $688.5 million, the lowest monthly figure since June 2011, according to China‚Äôs General Administration of Customs, as reported by Bloomberg and Trade Data Monitor. This collapse outpaced the 21 per cent overall drop in Chinese exports to the US in the same period. Smartphones led the decline in export value in April 2025, with a month-on-month drop of $1.8 billion. The Trump administration has imposed tariffs of up to 145 per cent on select Chinese goods, including mobile phones and electronics. In 2024, US-China bilateral trade totaled $690 billion. Apple Inc. is accelerating its shift of iPhone production to India. According to China‚Äôs General Administration of Customs, the value of smartphone component exports from China to India has roughly quadrupled over the past year. India now hosts Apple‚Äôs largest iPhone production base outside of China.

title: Tariffs trigger price hikes: Shoes, clothing and toys to get more expensive this summer
content: Skyrocketing prices might not be top of mind this spring. But many economists warn that consumers should get ready to pay more as soon as summer.
resumen: Consumers can expect big price spikes on clothing and shoes this year. The consumer price index rose year-over-year by 2.3% in April. Consumers should get ready to pay more for some things as soon as summer. Some shoppers might want to keep an eye on Memorial Day sales. Spikes in shoe prices could get people talking. Shoe prices are expected to be 15% higher and apparel prices are expected to be 14% higher in the short run, according to the Budget Lab. The report issued May 12 estimated the effects of all U.S. tariffs and foreign retaliation implemented in 2025 through May 12. Overall, we could see an average per-household consumer loss of $2,800, the Budget Lab reported, as a result of higher tariffs. The price level from all 2025 tariffs rises by 1.7% in the short run. Exactly when we'll pay higher prices on individual items will vary. Hallmark acknowledged that it "made the necessary decision to adjust pricing on select imported products from our gift and ornament collections that are impacted by the current economic climate." On May 15, Walmart said it would have to start raising prices on many goods later in May and June to address higher costs associated with tariffs. The price of bananas at Walmart rose to 54 cents a pound, up from 50 cents, thanks to higher tariffs. The Budget Lab analyzed the May 12 tariff rates as if they stayed in effect in perpetuity. As of May 12, the U.S. and China agreed to a reduction in tariffs for 90 days as negotiations continue. The May 12 changes to the China rate alone reduce the negative economic impact of all 2025 tariffs to date by 40%, according to the Budget Lab. U.S. consumers still face an overall average effective tariff rate of 17.8%, the highest since 1934, according to the estimates from the Budget Lab. Without the lower China tariffs ‚àí but with a trade deal between the United States and the United Kingdom and newly proposed auto rebates ‚àí the average effective tariff rate would have been 27.6%. Consumers could have a bit of calculating to do when it comes to how much they might be willing to buy early and how willing they might be to hold off shopping. It is substantially uncertain where China tariffs in particular are going to end up over the summer. If there are significant tariffs on China still in place this summer, it‚Äôs highly likely they will put upward pressure on apparel and electronics prices for back-to-school shopping. Consumers could experience sticker shock when they shop for a long list of items. Price tags on many goods will start reflecting the impact of tariffs by June and July. Consumers probably will see price increases on clothing and apparel; footwear; toys and games; and small electrical appliances, including microwaves, toasters and mixers. Price hikes might also be expected for household items for bathrooms, including items made of plastic; children's car seats and strollers; and some types of furniture. Percentage increases in the double-digit range seem probable for items like toys, car seats and strollers. The Toy Association, which has more than 900 members, is urging the U.S. government to grant a reprieve from tariffs on toys imported from China. The New York Post ran a Page One cover May 1 declaring: "Skimp on the Barbie." As of May 13, a 10% tariff on goods entering the United States is to stay in place. Inflation isn't bad now. Prices fell on some items in April, including airline tickets and used cars and trucks. PNC Chief Economist Gus Faucher noted in his report that consumers saw little indication in the April CPI report of tariffs causing higher goods prices. Tariffs are likely to drive prices and inflation up over the next few months. Diane Swonk, KPMG's chief economist, noted in a report: "This could be the last benign inflation report for a while." Major footwear manufacturer Wolverine Worldwide stated in its earnings report that it would not provide a full-year 2025 outlook as a result of "uncertainty around tariffs and related macro-economic conditions." Wolverine Worldwide shoe brands include Merrell, Saucony, Hush Puppies, Chaco and Stride Rite. The recent de-escalation with China to lower tariffs from 145% to 30% for 90 days is welcome news, according to an economic outlook issued May 13 by KPMG. The KPMG report indicated that the Federal Reserve "is not expected to cut rates until December due to a bout of stagflation, a period of rising inflation coupled with escalating unemployment." Charles Ballard, professor of economics emeritus at Michigan State University, said uncertainty is just off the charts. Baby strollers, baby car seats, cell phones, laptops and toys, are some of the items that face the greatest uncertainty.

title: Global retailers' tariff strategy risks spreading pain beyond US consumer
content: Global retailers including sandal maker Birkenstock and jeweller Pandora are looking at spreading the cost of U.S. tariffs by raising prices across markets to avoid big hikes in the United States that ...
resumen:
Global retailers including sandal maker Birkenstock and jeweller Pandora are looking at spreading the cost of U.S. tariffs by raising prices across markets to avoid big hikes in the United States that could hurt sales.

Birkenstock's chief financial officer said last week that a "low-single-digit" price increase globally would be enough to offset the U.S. tariff impact.

Pandora CEO Alexander Lacik said the Danish company is debating whether to raise prices globally or more in the U.S., its biggest market.

Markus Goller, partner at consultancy Simon Kucher in Bonn, Germany, said that a manufacturer from outside of the U.S. might increase prices slightly in the U.S., and slightly in Europe, and in other markets.

U.S. President Donald Trump has imposed a blanket tariff of 10% on all global imports and is threatening higher so-called "reciprocal" tariffs on its trading partners.

When U.S. behemoth Walmart said it would have to raise prices in response to tariffs, Trump ordered the world's biggest retailer via social media to 'eat the tariffs'.

Jean-Pierre Dub√©, professor of marketing at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, said that retailers don't want to be accused by the White House of raising prices purely because of U.S. tariffs, so if they can demonstrate that their prices are going up everywhere then... it's kind of a shield.

Jason Miller, professor of supply chain management at Michigan State University, said that retailers could raise prices on certain products or in certain markets where consumers are less price-sensitive, and use that to subsidise other products or countries where price hikes would hurt sales more.

Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey raised the issue of "global companies that don't make that distinction [on tariff rates] and just say, we're going to impose a pricing solution which goes right across the world irrespective of those differences."

In the euro zone, inflation was finally gliding towards the European Central Bank's 2% target.

European companies surveyed by the European Central Bank (ECB) in late March said price growth in the retail sector was subdued.

Trump unveiled his tariff policy on April 2, and later hiked tariffs on Chinese goods to 145%.

The U.S. tariffs on China - lowered last week to 30% - have allowed some European retailers to source goods more cheaply than before.

Martino Pessina, CEO of Takko Fashion, which sells clothes in 17 European countries, said suppliers in China had offered lower prices as U.S. retailers cancelled orders from factories there, and shipping costs also fell.

Adidas CEO Bjorn Gulden told investors after reporting results late last month that there is no reason to raise prices outside the U.S. because of the tariffs.

ECB executive board member Isabel Schnabel has said the euro zone's inflation rate may initially dip below the central bank's 2% target, but that tariffs might prove inflationary further down the road.

Hal Singer, professor of economics at the University of Utah, warned that some could take advantage of tariffs to raise prices by more than rising costs, boosting their profits similarly to the inflation surge of 2021-2022 during the pandemic.

U.S. consumers' 12-month inflation expectations jumped in April to 6.7%, the highest reading since 1981.

Miller said that if people are expecting inflation, it gives firms a little bit more room to raise prices.

title: Is Walmart raising prices? What MA shoppers should know about Trump tariff price increases
content: Prices at Walmart will likely start going up later this month due to President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs, executives said on May 15.
resumen:
Prices at Walmart will likely start going up later this month due to President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs, executives said on May 15.

Many items sold at Walmart, like food, toys, clothing, electronics and back to school items, are expected to increase in price.

In Massachusetts, there are 27 Walmart Supercenters and 21 discount stores located across the state.

Prices at Walmart will likely start going up later this month due to President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs, executives said on May 15.

"We will do our best to keep our prices as low as possible but given the magnitude of the tariffs, even at the reduced levels announced this week, we aren't able to absorb all the pressure given the reality of narrow retail margins," CEO Doug McMillon said in a statement.

U.S. shoppers will start to see prices rise at the end of May and certainly in June, Walmart's Chief Financial Officer John David Rainey said in a CNBC interview.

While Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said retail giant Walmart "will be absorbing" the impact of tariffs on CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúState of the Union‚Äù Sunday, he also said that some costs "may get passed on to consumers."

Tariffs are taxes on foreign goods shipments to the U.S. They are paid by importers: in this case, American manufacturers or retailers. The cost is typically passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices.

Many items sold at Walmart, like food, toys, clothing, electronics and back-to-school goods, are expected to increase in price.

McMIllan said in an earnings call that ‚Äúfood inflation is very much on our mind,‚Äù according to CNN. The company said that already, the price of bananas at Walmart has risen four cents a pound because of higher tariffs.

According to The Budget Lab at Yale, a non-partisan policy research center, consumers can expect to see 15% higher shoe prices and 14% higher apparel prices in the short run, with the rates going up in the long run. Their May 12 report estimates the effects of all U.S. tariffs and foreign retaliation implemented through May 12, including the currently lower tariff rates on China.

The U.S. also imports a large volume of toys, baby gear and electronics from China, meaning that prices are likely to go up on those items. Mattel, the maker of Barbie, said that it planned to raise prices on its toys because of the tariffs. (Barbie is sold at Walmart.)

Trump too acknowledged that some toys might get more expensive, saying in an interview with ABC in early May that "maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls," and that "maybe the two dolls will cost a couple bucks more than they would normally."

Seasonal products, like back-to-school gear, could also get more costly as those purchases can‚Äôt be delayed.

‚ÄúIf there are significant tariffs on China still in place this summer, it‚Äôs highly likely they will put upward pressure on apparel and electronics prices for back-to-school shopping," Ernie Tedeschi, director of economics at The Budget Lab at Yale University, told the Detroit Free Press.

It‚Äôs still unclear exactly when and where the price hikes will hit, especially as tariff rates are still in flux. But The Budget Lab‚Äôs report predicts an average per household consumer loss of $2,800.

In Massachusetts, there are 27 Walmart Supercenters and 21 discount stores located across the state.

Some Supercenter locations include Fall River, Leominster, Plymouth, Tewksbury, Walpole and Worcester.

title: Actividad econ√≥mica en el pa√≠s perfila estancamiento
content: La econom√≠a mexicana se estanc√≥ en los √∫ltimos meses y apunta a un mayor debilitamiento, afectada principalmente por la contracci√≥n en la actividad industrial. En marzo registr√≥ un crecimiento anual ...
resumen:
La econom√≠a mexicana se estanc√≥ en los √∫ltimos meses y apunta a un mayor debilitamiento, afectada principalmente por la contracci√≥n en la actividad industrial.

En marzo registr√≥ un crecimiento anual de apenas 0.2 por ciento y de 0.7 por ciento en abril, medida con el Indicador Oportuno de la Actividad Econ√≥mica (IOAE).

Las actividades secundarias registraron una ca√≠da anual del 1.3 por ciento en marzo y del 0.80 por ciento en abril. En tanto, las actividades terciarias avanzaron 1.1 por ciento anual en marzo y 1.5 por ciento en abril.

A tasa mensual, tras un avance de 1.0 en febrero, el IOAE subi√≥ 0.2 por ciento en marzo, y report√≥ un nulo crecimiento en abril, de acuerdo con los registros del Inegi.

Para analistas de Banamex, de materializarse estos resultados, el crecimiento del PIB en el primer trimestre habr√≠a sido de 0.2 por ciento trimestral.

Julio Santaella, expresidente del INEGI, indic√≥ que ‚Äúcon el resultado obtenido en el bimestre, la actividad econ√≥mica regresa a su senda de estancamiento, lo cual deja ver que el efecto de febrero fue inusitado‚Äù.

Arturo Vieyra, economista en jefe de grupo Coppel, mencion√≥ que entre los factores clave que han impedido un mejor desempe√±o de la econom√≠a est√°n las amenazas arancelarias del presidente Donald Trump, que han inhibido la inversi√≥n, pero, adem√°s, la debilidad en el PIB de Estados Unidos.

El PIB en EU tuvo una contracci√≥n del 0.3 por ciento en el primer trimestre de este a√±o, respecto al trimestre anterior, y a esto a√±adimos que la pol√≠tica fiscal en M√©xico es restrictiva, con un ajuste en el gasto que se ubic√≥ 8.4 por ciento por debajo para el presupuesto de este periodo.

Para el resto del a√±o se espera una persistencia en la debilidad econ√≥mica, y estim√≥ un crecimiento del 0.1 por ciento anual.

De acuerdo con Gabriela Siller, directora de an√°lisis econ√≥mico de Grupo Financiero Base, los datos del IOAE sugieren que la econom√≠a seguir√≠a mostrando signos de reducci√≥n en abril y los pr√≥ximos meses.

Se√±al√≥ que se estima un crecimiento de cero por ciento para todo el a√±o, en un escenario central; de 0.5 por ciento en un escenario optimista y una ca√≠da de 1.0 por ciento en el escenario pesimista.

Para Jorge Pe√±a, catedr√°tico de la Facultad de Econom√≠a de la UNAM, los resultados de marzo y abril evidencian la fragilidad de la situaci√≥n econ√≥mica.

Aunque el sector servicios muestra resiliencia, es probable que no sea suficiente para contrarrestar el mal desempe√±o de la industria.

Andres Abadia, economista en jefe para Latinoam√©rica de Pantheon Macroeconomics, advirti√≥ que los segmentos clave de la industria siguen con un bajo dinamismo.

El sector de la construcci√≥n no tiene impulso, la miner√≠a est√° limitada en su desarrollo, y aunque los servicios crecen, ya no es suficiente para compensar el mal comportamiento del sector secundario.

title: The commodities feed: Trump-Putin call yields little progress
content: Oil prices remain steady as the market digests the Trump-Putin call, which appears to have resulted in no significant breakthroughs.
resumen:
Oil prices remain steady as the market digests the Trump-Putin call, which appears to have resulted in no significant breakthroughs.
The scheduled call between President Trump and President Putin doesn‚Äôt appear to have led to any significant breakthroughs.

The USDA‚Äôs weekly US crop progress report for the week ending 18 May shows domestic corn plantings stood at 78% complete.
US soybean plantings are 66% completed as of 18 May.

Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) corn prices are likely to remain largely under pressure.

title: IMEF: Econom√≠a mexicana se contraer√≠a en el segundo trimestre por efecto gusano barrenador
content: Es muy probable que la econom√≠a mexicana se contraiga en el segundo trimestre de 2025, adem√°s de que contin√∫a la expectativa de que la actividad econ√≥mica caiga este a√±o por factores como la elecci√≥n ...
resumen:
El Instituto Mexicano Ejecutivo de Finanzas (IMEF) advirti√≥ que es muy probable que la econom√≠a mexicana se contraiga en el segundo trimestre de 2025.

El IMEF alert√≥ que situaciones recientes como el cierre de las fronteras de Estados Unidos a las exportaciones mexicanas de ganado vivo por la propagaci√≥n del gusano barrenador o el impuesto de 5% a las remesas que busca aprobar el Congreso estadounidense deterioran las expectativas de crecimiento para M√©xico.

V√≠ctor Herrera, presidente del Comit√© Nacional de Estudios Econ√≥micos del IMEF, dijo que est√° por verse el impacto real sobre el crecimiento de la econom√≠a mexicana de los aranceles y la ca√≠da de las exportaciones en el segundo trimestre del 2025.

Herrera dijo: "Esperamos que caigamos en terreno negativo en este segundo trimestre. No sabemos si en alg√∫n momento dado se va a poder llamar oficialmente una recesi√≥n porque hay ciertas condiciones que se tienen para que se pueda denominar una recesi√≥n como son duraci√≥n, profundidad y extensi√≥n, pero un crecimiento negativo es un crecimiento negativo y ya los efectos los estamos sintiendo hoy".

Por cada d√≠a que las fronteras estadounidenses se mantengan cerradas a las exportaciones mexicanas de ganado vivo por el gusano barrenador, se tendr√≠a un impacto de m√°s de 3 millones de d√≥lares diarios para los exportadores mexicanos.

El cierre de la frontera por la propagaci√≥n del gusano barrenador representa un ‚Äúimpacto importante‚Äù para los exportadores de carne en M√©xico, y tambi√©n para Estados Unidos.

Las exportaciones totales de carne a Estados Unidos (ya sea en ganado vivo o en cortes) son de m√°s de 3,500 millones de d√≥lares al a√±o, y que poco menos de la mitad de esa cifra es lo que se estar√≠a viendo afectado por el cierre de las fronteras.

Gabriela Guti√©rrez, presidenta nacional del IMEF, asegur√≥ que de aprobarse en el Congreso estadounidense la iniciativa para gravar en 5% el env√≠o de remesas, se ‚Äúreconfigurar√° el mercado de remesas que se ha desarrollado en Estados Unidos‚Äù.

Las remesas representan el 24% del PIB de El Salvador y m√°s del 3% del PIB de India y M√©xico.

Las remesas representan del 10 al 14% del PIB estatal de Oaxaca, Zacatecas, Michoac√°n, Guerrero y Chiapas.

Es muy probable que de aprobarse la iniciativa, el env√≠o de remesas continuar√≠a por v√≠as alternas no tradicionales como los encomenderos o las criptomonedas, lo que elevar√≠a los costos y el riesgo de esto env√≠os.

El volumen de remesas enviadas desde los Estados Unidos se reducir√° en los pr√≥ximos meses por la persecuci√≥n a los migrantes ilegales.

El IMEF asegur√≥ que su encuesta de mayo refleja un pesimismo persistente entre los economistas consultados, quienes recortaron su expectativa de crecimiento para M√©xico de 0.2 a 0.1% en 2025.

En la encuesta, 16 encuestados (37% de la muestra) esperan un crecimiento negativo en comparaci√≥n de los nueve registrados en abril.

title: India‚Äôs stock market rated above Japan and China by more fund managers: survey
content: Fund managers are confident that India will benefit more from the US-China trade war, according to the Bank of America Securities survey.
resumen: Seg√∫n una encuesta de Bank of America Securities, India ha sido calificada como la principal opci√≥n de mercado de valores en Asia por los administradores de fondos de riqueza. Aproximadamente el 42 por ciento de los administradores de fondos tienen una posici√≥n de sobreponderaci√≥n en las acciones indias, por delante de Jap√≥n con el 39 por ciento y China con solo el 6 por ciento. La encuesta, publicada el 13 de mayo, recopil√≥ informaci√≥n de 109 panelistas que gestionan un total combinado de 234 mil millones de d√≥lares estadounidenses en activos, quienes respondieron preguntas del banco entre el 2 y el 8 de mayo. El informe cita a los estrategas de Bank of America, diciendo que "India emerge como el mercado m√°s favorecido, percibido como un probable beneficiario de las realineaciones de la cadena de suministro tras los efectos de los aranceles".

resumen:
**TRANSPORTES FERROVIARIO:** El pleno del Congreso debate este martes, a iniciativa del PP, reprobar al ministro de Transportes, √ìscar Puente, por la atenci√≥n que recibieron los pasajeros en las estaciones de tren durante el apag√≥n del pasado 28 de abril. title: Costa Rica sostuvo primera reuni√≥n en Estados Unidos para negociar arancel impuesto por Trump
content: Las pl√°ticas se realizaron por iniciativa de la administraci√≥n Trump. ‚ÄúCosta Rica fue invitada por los Estados Unidos a participar en esta misi√≥n t√©cnica gracias a las consistentes relaciones de la ...
resumen:
El gobierno de Costa Rica sostuvo reuniones con representantes de la administraci√≥n de Donald Trump para suspender la tarifa arancelaria del 10% impuesta por Estados Unidos desde el pasado 5 de abril.

Las reuniones se realizaron el 15 y 16 de mayo.

El Ministerio de Comercio Exterior (Comex) inform√≥ que se llev√≥ a cabo la primera reuni√≥n con funcionarios de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR).

Manuel Tovar, jerarca del Ministerio de Comercio Exterior (Comex), recalc√≥ que el objetivo del di√°logo es lograr la suspensi√≥n del arancel del 10%.

El acuerdo comercial DR-Cafta, vigente para Costa Rica desde 2009, establece el intercambio de bienes con Estados Unidos sin aranceles.

Las pl√°ticas bilaterales entre ambos pa√≠ses se realizaron por iniciativa de la administraci√≥n Trump.

Las negociaciones continuar√°n en dos rondas m√°s programadas para junio.

El equipo negociador de Costa Rica ser√° coordinado por la viceministra del Comex, Indiana Trejos.

En 2024, Costa Rica export√≥ bienes a Estados Unidos por un total de $9.411,9 millones, lo que representa el 47% de los $19.900 millones destinados al mercado exterior.

Se exportan m√°s de 1.100 productos con montos superiores a los $200.

La naci√≥n norteamericana aport√≥ el 70% del flujo de inversi√≥n extranjera en 2024, equivalente a $3.047,5 millones, de acuerdo a datos del Banco Central de Costa Rica (BCCR).

El pasado 2 de abril el presidente Trump anunci√≥ el establecimiento de aranceles rec√≠procos a los productos costarricenses que son exportados hacia Estados Unidos.

En total fueron afectados 175 pa√≠ses.

El 12 de mayo, Estados Unidos y China acordaron una tregua comercial, que suspende la mayor√≠a de aranceles por 90 d√≠as.

A inicios de abril el presidente Rodrigo Chaves asegur√≥ que ‚Äúno es catastr√≥fico‚Äù que Trump, impusiera la tarifa a Costa Rica.

Estados Unidos es el principal socio comercial de Costa Rica y el origen del 70% del flujo de inversi√≥n directa.

title: ONDA dice 50 % de productos gravados por EE. UU. a RD pertenecen a propiedad intelectual
content: SANTO DOMINGO.- Ante decenas de entusiastas educadores, creadores y estudiantes, el director general de la Oficina Nacional de Derecho de Autor (ONDA), licenciado Jos√© Rub√©n Gonell Cosme, revel√≥ que m ...
resumen:
El director general de la Oficina Nacional de Derecho de Autor (ONDA), licenciado Jos√© Rub√©n Gonell Cosme, revel√≥ que m√°s del 50 % de los productos gravados por el gobierno de Estados Unidos con un arancel del 10 % a la Rep√∫blica Dominicana est√°n relacionados con la propiedad intelectual.

El presidente Donald Trump ha anunciado aranceles de 10 % para todos los pa√≠ses socios de Estados Unidos, incluyendo un 100 % a las pel√≠culas y producciones audiovisuales extranjeras.

Gonell Cosme expres√≥: ‚ÄúPuedo decirles que m√°s del 50 % de las solicitudes arancelarias que est√° haciendo Estados Unidos a la Rep√∫blica Dominicana tienen que ver con propiedad intelectual‚Äù.

La ONDA est√° implementando actualmente un equipo de trabajo en conjunto con la Procuradur√≠a General de la Rep√∫blica y el Instituto Dominicano de las Telecomunicaciones (INDOTEL) para combatir la pirater√≠a digital en todas sus formas.

En los √∫ltimos tres a√±os, la ONDA ha registrado m√°s de 20 mil obras art√≠sticas, cient√≠ficas y literarias.

En lo que va del a√±o se han registrado m√°s de cinco mil obras art√≠sticas, cient√≠ficas y literarias.

La gesti√≥n de Gonell Cosme al frente de la ONDA, iniciada en agosto de 2020, ha obtenido grandes logros en beneficio de los creativos y del pa√≠s.

La Facultad de Ciencias Jur√≠dicas y Pol√≠ticas de la Universidad Aut√≥noma de Santo Domingo (UASD) realiz√≥ el pasado fin de semana el ‚ÄúForo Acad√©mico de Propiedad Intelectual UASD-2025‚Äù.

En el foro participaron el Ministerio de Industria, Comercio y Mipymes (MICM), la ONDA, INDOTEL, la Asociaci√≥n Dominicana de Propiedad Intelectual (ADOPI), la Oficina Nacional de la Propiedad Industrial (ONAPI) y el Programa de Medicamentos Esenciales (PROMESE/CAL).

En el panel ‚ÄúUna mirada a la propiedad intelectual desde la academia, docentes y funcionarios gubernamentales‚Äù participaron la jueza del Tribunal Constitucional y experta en propiedad intelectual Army Ferreira; el decano de la Facultad de Ciencias Econ√≥micas y Sociales de la UASD, Antonio Ciriaco Cruz; el director de la ONDA, Jos√© Rub√©n Gonell Cosme; la procuradora general adjunta, Isis de la Cruz, y el procurador de la Corte de Apelaci√≥n, Jonathan Bar√≥.

title: Ron Johnson ya es embajador de EU en M√©xico; Sheinbaum recibi√≥ sus cartas credenciales
content: Sheinbaum recibi√≥ las credenciales del embajador Ron Johnson, representante de Trump, junto a otros cuatro diplom√°ticos, expresando su deseo de mantener buenas relaciones con EU ...
resumen:
La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum recibi√≥ el lunes en Palacio Nacional las cartas credenciales de cinco nuevos embajadores en M√©xico, entre ellos Ronald Johnson, representante de la administraci√≥n Trump. Los diplom√°ticos realizaron la entrega formal de la documentaci√≥n oficial que los acredita como representantes de sus naciones en M√©xico.

Se recibieron las cartas credenciales de los embajadores de Rep√∫blica Argelina Democr√°tica y Popular, Messaoud Mehila; Rep√∫blica Dominicana, Juan Bol√≠var D√≠az Santana; Rep√∫blica de Colombia, Carlos Fernando Garc√≠a Manosalva; y Rep√∫blica Eslovaca, Milan Cig√°n.

Sheinbaum ha expresado su intenci√≥n de establecer una buena relaci√≥n binacional.

El embajador Johnson arrib√≥ a suelo mexicano el pasado jueves y fue recibido al d√≠a siguiente por el canciller Juan Ram√≥n de la Fuente.

Ron Johnson comparti√≥ un primer mensaje como embajador en funciones, en donde envi√≥ saludos al pueblo de M√©xico, tambi√©n de parte de su esposa Alina. Asegur√≥ que ambos esperan conocer a√∫n m√°s de M√©xico, ‚Äúsu cultura y a muchos de ustedes‚Äù, y agreg√≥ en espa√±ol: ‚ÄúEs un honor representar a nuestro presidente Donald Trump y al pueblo estadounidense‚Äù.

Johnson inform√≥: ‚ÄúNac√≠ en un pueblo de Alabama y he dedicado mi vida a servir a mi pa√≠s y a servir a la causa, para la libertad del mundo. De mis padres aprend√≠ la importancia de la familia, trabajar duro y el respeto a Dios y a los otros. Los valores que compartimos con ustedes nos han guiado, a m√≠, a mi esposa Alina, a nuestros cuatro hijos y a nuestros nietos‚Äù.

Johnson asent√≥: ‚ÄúNuestra relaci√≥n con ustedes, con M√©xico, es de gran importancia. No hay otra en el mundo que tenga un mayor impacto en las vidas de nuestros pueblos. Somos m√°s que socios: somos vecinos y amigos‚Äù. Compartimos nuestra integraci√≥n econ√≥mica y lazos culturales. Estoy aqu√≠ para trabajar juntos, con la presidenta Sheinbaum y su equipo, temas de inter√©s como la seguridad, la frontera y la migraci√≥n.

Mencion√≥: ‚ÄúLas muchas llamadas entre nuestros presidentes reflejan la importancia de nuestra relaci√≥n y prioridades compartidas. La colaboraci√≥n entre nuestros pa√≠ses va a mejorar las vidas de nuestros pueblos. Me siento optimista por trabajar juntos por el bienestar, la seguridad y la prosperidad de nuestras naciones‚Äù.

title: El hambre aguda golpe√≥ a 295 millones de personas en 2024, advierte un informe
content: El hambre aguda golpe√≥ a 295 millones de personas de 53 pa√≠ses en 2024, un r√©cord, sobre todo a causa de los conflictos, y las perspectivas para 2025 no son muy alentadoras debido la disminuci√≥n de la ...
resumen:
En 2024, el hambre aguda golpe√≥ a 295 millones de personas de 53 pa√≠ses, un r√©cord, principalmente debido a los conflictos. Las perspectivas para 2025 no son alentadoras debido a la disminuci√≥n de la ayuda internacional, seg√∫n un informe publicado el 19 de mayo de 2025.

El empeoramiento de la situaci√≥n en √°reas como Sud√°n, Birmania o Gaza eclips√≥ los avances en Afganist√°n o Kenia, seg√∫n el reporte anual de la Red Mundial contra las Crisis Alimentarias, integrada por la UE, el Banco Mundial y agencias de la ONU.

De los 295,3 millones de personas (el 22,6% de la poblaci√≥n analizada), 1,9 millones estaban al borde de la hambruna, algo nunca visto desde 2016. La mayor parte de esa poblaci√≥n en situaci√≥n extrema se encontraba en Sud√°n y en la Franja de Gaza, y en menor medida en Mal√≠ y en Hait√≠.

Los conflictos y la violencia fueron el primer factor de crisis alimentaria en 2024, para 140 millones de personas en 20 pa√≠ses. En otros 18 pa√≠ses, los episodios clim√°ticos extremos provocados por el cambio clim√°tico causaron desastres agr√≠colas.

Para 2025, el informe advierte que la intensificaci√≥n de los enfrentamientos, las tensiones geopol√≠ticas, la incertidumbre econ√≥mica y los cortes de financiaci√≥n y ayudas est√°n "incrementando la inseguridad alimentaria en algunos pa√≠ses", como la Rep√∫blica Democr√°tica del Congo o Hait√≠.

El informe tambi√©n advierte que "choques econ√≥micos" como los aumentos de aranceles o el debilitamiento del d√≥lar pueden provocar un repunte de los precios de los alimentos y perturbar las cadenas de suministro.

La financiaci√≥n general de la ayuda va en declive, sobre todo con la retirada a principios de 2025 de Estados Unidos. La financiaci√≥n vinculada a la alimentaci√≥n podr√≠a disminuir un 45% y la ayuda de la que se benefician al menos 14 millones de ni√±os est√° "en peligro".

El secretario general de la ONU, Antonio Guterres, denunci√≥ que "el hambre y la malnutrici√≥n se extienden m√°s r√°pidamente que nuestra capacidad de respuesta, mientras que un tercio de los alimentos del mundo se pierde o se desperdicia".

Rein Paulsen, director de la oficina de emergencias y de resiliencia en la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas para la Alimentaci√≥n y la Agricultura (FAO), cit√≥ los avances en Afganist√°n, donde en 2024 hab√≠a tres millones de personas menos en situaci√≥n de inseguridad alimentaria que tres a√±os antes.

resumen: Representantes del Ministerio de Comercio Exterior de Costa Rica (COMEX) sostuvieron la semana pasada la primera reuni√≥n oficial con la administraci√≥n del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump para discutir la reciente imposici√≥n de aranceles a las exportaciones costarricenses. title: Ren: Trump and Xi tone down senseless trade war
content: The U.S. and China are calling a 90-day truce in their trade war, temporarily lowering tariffs on each other from eye-wateringly high levels.
resumen: The U.S. and China are calling a 90-day truce in their trade war, temporarily lowering tariffs on each other. U.S. levies on most Chinese imports will be reduced to 30 percent from 145 percent, while the 125 percent Chinese duties on United States goods will drop to 10 percent. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said last week after negotiations in Geneva, ‚ÄúNeither side wants to decouple.‚Äù About 16 million jobs could be at risk thanks to Trump‚Äôs tariffs, according to estimates from Goldman Sachs Group Inc. The government‚Äôs unemployment insurance covers about 244 million. In the first quarter ‚Äî even before Trump ignited his second trade war ‚Äî payouts to the jobless rose by a whopping 22.4 percent to 46.5 billion yuan ($6.4 billion). Last year, the number of ride-hailing drivers jumped by 27 percent to 38 million, while their compensation fell. In the United States, small businesses account for almost 80 percent of job openings.

resumen:
El transporte mar√≠timo navega entre la incertidumbre generada por la pol√≠tica comercial del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, lo que se ha traducido en una ca√≠da de hasta el 50% del precio de los fletes en 2025, pese al respiro tras el primer pacto de aranceles entre Estados Unidos y China.

El coste medio de cada TEU -contenedor est√°ndar de 20 pies- empez√≥ el a√±o en 2.505 d√≥lares por unidad, un precio que empez√≥ a descender hasta los 1,293 d√≥lares para la semana del 21 de marzo.

El puerto de Los √Ångeles hab√≠a sufrido una ca√≠da de hasta el 35% del tr√°fico de buques en las √∫ltimas dos semanas.

El pasado viernes 9 de mayo ning√∫n buque de carga hab√≠a salido de China con mercanc√≠as hacia los dos principales puertos de la costa oeste norteamericana durante las doce horas anteriores.

La tregua arancelaria de 90 d√≠as que suspende los altos grav√°menes para dejarlos en un 30% para las exportaciones chinas y un 10% para las estadounidenses parece haber calmado tambi√©n al mar.

content: Tegucigalpa, 19 may (EFE).- Honduras recibi√≥ este lunes a 38 migrantes, incluidos 19 menores, que retornaron voluntariamente desde Estados Unidos bajo un programa de autodeportaci√≥n que cubre el viaje ...
resumen: Honduras recibi√≥ el 19 de mayo de 2025 a 38 migrantes, incluidos 19 menores, que retornaron voluntariamente desde Estados Unidos. El retorno se realiz√≥ bajo un programa de autodeportaci√≥n que cubre el viaje y un estipendio adicional de 1.000 d√≥lares. El grupo de hondure√±os regres√≥ en un vuelo ch√°rter que aterriz√≥ en el Aeropuerto Internacional Jos√© Ram√≥n Villeda Morales, ubicado en La Lima, en el departamento de Cort√©s. Los hondure√±os hicieron uso del programa de asistencia de viajes que Estados Unidos ofrece a los migrantes indocumentados para facilitar el regreso a sus pa√≠ses y les otorga 1.000 d√≥lares. Las asistencias se canalizan a trav√©s de la aplicaci√≥n CBP Home. El pago de la retribuci√≥n se realizar√° a los beneficiarios ¬´una vez est√© confirmado el regreso a su pa√≠s de origen¬ª, seg√∫n el Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS). Los migrantes irregulares que expresen su decisi√≥n de autodeportarse voluntariamente a trav√©s de CBP Home ya no estar√°n en lo alto de la lista del Servicio de Inmigraci√≥n y Control de Aduanas (ICE) para sus redadas, ¬´siempre que demuestren que est√°n logrando avances significativos en la finalizaci√≥n de dicha salida¬ª. Kevin Antonio, uno de los 38 hondure√±os que se acogieron al programa de retorno voluntario, dijo que despu√©s de cinco a√±os en Estados Unidos opt√≥ por autodeportarse para reunirse con su madre en Honduras. De los 38 migrantes, 19 son adultos y 19 menores de edad. A trav√©s del programa social ¬´Hermano, hermana, vuelve a casa¬ª, los hondure√±os deportados recibir√°n en principio 100 d√≥lares, un bono para la adquisici√≥n de alimentos y luego otros 1.000 d√≥lares para que puedan emprender alguna actividad econ√≥mica. Seg√∫n cifras oficiales, alrededor de 1,8 millones de hondure√±os, entre residentes legales e indocumentados viven en Estados Unidos, y 261.651 tienen orden de deportaci√≥n. Con la llegada de estos 38 migrantes, las autoridades estadounidenses han retornado a m√°s de 14.000 hondure√±os en lo que va de 2025.

title: Tariffs live updates: Bessent says tariffs may return to 'reciprocal' levels if deals aren't made
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warned on Sunday that tariff rates will go back to "reciprocal" levels if countries do not make trade deals with the US during the 90-day pause. ‚ÄúPresident Trump has ...
resumen:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warned on Sunday that tariff rates will go back to "reciprocal" levels if countries do not make trade deals with the US during the 90-day pause. He highlighted the 18 key partners with whom the US is prioritizing trade deals.

Bessent said Walmart‚Äôs (WMT) price hike warning was a ‚Äúworst case scenario‚Äù after speaking with CEO Doug McMillon.

President Trump told Walmart to "eat the tariffs" instead of raising prices. Trump said Walmart made BILLIONS OF DOLLARS last year.

Walmart (WMT) said that rising costs from tariffs could lead to higher prices for shoppers as early as this month.

Trump said Friday that the US will set tariff rates for its trading partners within the next few weeks. He said his administration cannot negotiate trade deals with all countries at once due to limited capacity.

Trump renewed his criticism of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on Saturday. Trump said the Federal Reserve should cut rates "sooner, rather than later."

The EU has warned that tariff uncertainty is pushing euro-area inflation below the European Central Bank‚Äôs target for next year.

South Africa's President Ramaphosa will discuss business ties with Elon Musk during a Washington visit to improve US relations. A proposal could offer Tesla (TSLA) favourable import tariffs in exchange for building EV charging stations in South Africa.

Diageo plans $500M in cost savings by 2028, lowers tariff impact view.

China‚Äôs factory output slowed in April but remained resilient.

The US effective tariff rate has moved lower over the past month. At 14.4%, the effective US tariff rate is nearly back to its pre-"Liberation Day" level.

Trump said in a social media post the U.S. Federal Reserve should cut rates "sooner, rather than later." Trump also criticized the head of the central bank, Jerome Powell.

Walmart (WMT) execs signaled tariff-driven price hikes that are poised to begin later this month.

Walmart CEO Doug McMillon met with the president in late April to discuss tariff implications. Walmart made a case to remove tariffs on China altogether.

President Donald Trump said on Friday that he'll decide on tariff rates for US trading partners in the next few weeks.

Japan is pushing for full removal of Trump‚Äôs 25% car tariffs.

content: Ciudad de M√©xico.- La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum recibi√≥ este lunes las cartas credenciales que acreditan a Ronald Johnson como el nuevo Embajador de Estados Unidos en M√©xico. El representante del ...
resumen: La presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum recibi√≥ este lunes las cartas credenciales que acreditan a Ronald Johnson como el nuevo Embajador de Estados Unidos en M√©xico. El representante del Gobierno de Donald Trump arrib√≥ a Palacio Nacional por la calle Correo Mayor, en una camioneta blindada con placas diplom√°ticas. Ingres√≥ al recinto para participar en la ceremonia protocolaria, realizada en el despacho presidencial. El encuentro entre Sheinbaum y Johnson se registra en medio de las tensiones con el Gobierno de Estados Unidos. La visita de Johnson pr√°cticamente pone fin a la pausa que hab√≠a mantenido el Gobierno mexicano, desde la √∫ltima etapa del sexenio de Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador, con la Embajada estadounidense, entonces encabezada por Ken Salazar. Ronald Douglas Johnson es un diplom√°tico estadounidense que se desempe√±√≥ como Embajador de Estados Unidos en El Salvador, entre 2019 y 2021, durante el primer mandato de Trump. Se retir√≥ como coronel del Ej√©rcito de los Estados Unidos despu√©s de m√°s de tres d√©cadas de servicio y trabaj√≥ como enlace de ciencia y tecnolog√≠a de la Agencia Central de Inteligencia (CIA), con el Comando de Operaciones Especiales de los Estados Unidos en Tampa, Florida. El 10 de diciembre del a√±o pasado, Trump lo nomin√≥ como Embajador de Estados Unidos en M√©xico, pero fue hasta el 12 de febrero cuando su nominaci√≥n fue enviada al Senado. El 9 de abril fue confirmado por el Senado, con 49 votos a favor y 46 en contra. El 13 de abril rindi√≥ protesta para el cargo, ante el vicepresidente J. D. Vance. En su audiencia ante los legisladores el Johnson no descart√≥ la posibilidad de realizar acciones militares en suelo mexicano contra los c√°rteles de la droga. Este d√≠a, la presidenta tambi√©n recibe las cartas credenciales de los embajadores de la Rep√∫blica Argelina Democr√°tica Popular, Messaoud Mehila; Rep√∫blica Dominicana, Juan Bol√≠var D√≠az Santana; Rep√∫blica de Colombia, Carlos Fernando Garc√≠a Manosalva, y Rep√∫blica Eslovaca, Milan Cig√°n.

title: Recibe CSP cartas credenciales de embajador de EU
content: El encuentro entre Sheinbaum y Johnson se registra en medio de las tensiones con el Gobierno de Estados Unidos ...
resumen: La Presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum recibi√≥ este lunes las cartas credenciales que acreditan a Ronald Johnson como el nuevo Embajador de Estados Unidos en M√©xico. El encuentro entre Sheinbaum y Johnson se registra en medio de las tensiones con el Gobierno de Estados Unidos. Ronald Johnson arrib√≥ a Palacio Nacional por la calle Correo Mayor, en una camioneta blindada con placas diplom√°ticas. El encuentro se concreta tras diversas exigencias para la entrega de agua del R√≠o Bravo y amagos que han obligado a M√©xico a frenar la migraci√≥n hacia el norte y aceptar deportados extranjeros. La visita de Johnson pr√°cticamente pone fin a la pausa que hab√≠a mantenido el Gobierno mexicano, desde la √∫ltima etapa del sexenio de Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador, con la Embajada estadounidense, entonces encabezada por Ken Salazar. Ronald Douglas Johnson es un diplom√°tico estadounidense que se desempe√±√≥ como Embajador de Estados Unidos en El Salvador, entre 2019 y 2021, durante el primer mandato de Trump. Se retir√≥ como Coronel del Ej√©rcito de los Estados Unidos despu√©s de m√°s de tres d√©cadas de servicio y trabaj√≥ como enlace de ciencia y tecnolog√≠a de la Agencia Central de Inteligencia (CIA), con el Comando de Operaciones Especiales de los Estados Unidos en Tampa, Florida. El 10 de diciembre del a√±o pasado, Trump lo nomin√≥ como Embajador de Estados Unidos en M√©xico, pero fue hasta el 12 de febrero cuando su nominaci√≥n fue enviada al Senado. El 9 de abril fue confirmado por el Senado, con 49 votos a favor y 46 en contra. El 13 de abril rindi√≥ protesta para el cargo, ante el vicepresidente J. D. Vance. En su audiencia ante los legisladores el Johnson no descart√≥ la posibilidad de realizar acciones militares en suelo mexicano contra los c√°rteles de la droga. Este d√≠a, la Presidenta tambi√©n recibe las cartas credenciales de los embajadores de la Rep√∫blica Argelina Democr√°tica Popular, Messaoud Mehila; Rep√∫blica Dominicana, Juan Bol√≠var D√≠az Santana; Rep√∫blica de Colombia, Carlos Fernando Garc√≠a Manosalva, y Rep√∫blica Eslovaca, Milan Cig√°n. Las cartas credenciales son documentos emitidos por un Jefe de Estado o Gobierno que acreditan a un individuo, generalmente un diplom√°tico, como representante oficial de su pa√≠s en el extranjero. El representante entrega las copias de estilo de las cartas credenciales al Ministro de Relaciones Exteriores y luego presenta las cartas credenciales originales al jefe de Estado, en este caso, a la Presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum. Una vez aceptadas las cartas credenciales, el Embajador adquiere estatus diplom√°tico oficial, para ejercer sus funciones.

title: Major supermarket chain on alert: ‚ÄúBetween it and China they should ‚Äòeat the tariffs,‚Äô and not charge valued customers anything‚Äù
content: President Donald Trump threatened Walmart on social media after the retailer said that it would have to raise prices due to the Trump‚Äôs tariffs.
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Walmart on social media after the retailer said that it would have to raise prices due to the Trump‚Äôs tariffs.

Walmart CEO Doug McMillon said during an earnings call last week, ‚ÄúWe can control what we can control.‚Äù ‚ÄúEven at the reduced levels, the higher tariffs will result in higher prices.‚Äù

The company‚Äôs Chief Financial Officer John David Rainey said that customers could expect to see higher prices by the end of the month ‚Äúand then certainly much more in June.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre wired for everyday low prices, but the magnitude of these increases is more than any retailer can absorb,‚Äù Rainey said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more than any supplier can absorb.‚Äù

Trump posted on his social media platform Truth Social, ‚ÄúWalmart should STOP trying to blame Tariffs as the reason for raising prices throughout the chain,‚Äù Trump posted. ‚ÄúWalmart made BILLIONS OF DOLLARS last year, far more than expected. Between Walmart and China they should, as is said, ‚ÄúEAT THE TARIFFS,‚Äù and not charge valued customers ANYTHING.‚Äù He ended his post with a not-so-veiled threat: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be watching, and so will your customers!!!‚Äù

Imports of autos, certain auto parts, aluminum, and steel are taxed at 25%.

Trump also imposed a 10% tariff across the board on most nations during his 2 April ‚ÄòLiberation Day‚Äô announcement along with additional ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs. He eventually paused the latter levies for 90 days after the financial markets had a meltdown.

Trump left in place even higher tariffs on imports from the US‚Äôs three largest trading partners Mexico, Canada and China. Many goods from the first two face a 25% tax and goods from China will now be taxed at 30%. That‚Äôs down from 145% after the US and China agreed to ratchet down the escalating tension as both sides became worried about the effect that the tariffs were having on trade. The lower level will be in place for 90 days while the two economic superpowers try to work things out.

title: Trade War Fails To End Civilization
content: Trump's surprise US-China tariff rollback triggered a powerful relief rally, with the Nasdaq gaining its best week since January. Click here for a detailed analysis.
resumen: Trump's surprise US-China tariff rollback triggered a powerful relief rally, with the Nasdaq gaining 7% for its best week since January. AI stocks, led by Nvidia and AMD, surged on major Saudi deals, reinforcing the thesis that 'AI is the new oil' for market leadership. Despite lingering inflation and tariff risks, markets shrugged off macro worries, with retail investors rewarded for buying the dip. The week closed with risk appetite restored, gold slumping, and the S&P nearing record highs. On May 8, the president summoned investors to load up, just ahead of a US-China trade deal.

title: Nigeria‚Äôs soybeans seen gaining from China‚Äôs import shift
content: This makes Nigeria‚Äôs soybeans relatively cheaper than China‚Äôs, presenting an opportunity for the nation‚Äôs agro-based exporters to ...
resumen:
Amid global trade tensions and China‚Äôs tariff on U.S. agro imports, new insights point to Nigeria as a potential alternative to the world‚Äôs largest soybean importer.

The US and China recently agreed to reduce tariffs on most goods after an escalating trade tension triggered by Donald Trump. The US agreed to slash tariffs on Chinese goods to 30 percent from 145 percent, while China lowered its levies on American imports to 10 percent from 125 percent. This makes Nigeria‚Äôs soybeans relatively cheaper than China‚Äôs, presenting an opportunity for the nation‚Äôs agro-based exporters to sell cheaper product to US consumers. China has also taken a decison to diversify away from the US market, leaving an opportunity open for Nigerian exporters.

Fimile Toks, an analyst, highlighted the global implications of the U.S.-China trade rift. ‚ÄúIn 2024, the U.S. exported $12.4 billion of soybeans to China. If Nigeria can ramp up output and secure even a fraction of that market, the ripple effects could transform rural farming economies nationwide,‚Äù he noted. ‚ÄúNations build wealth through strategic exports,‚Äù Toks added. ‚ÄúLook at Brazil‚Äîit overtook the US in soybean exports within five years by following a clear national strategy. Nigeria has the potential to do the same, with the right focus and leadership,‚Äù he further explained.

Frederick Ukula, agro-processing manager at Ecobasic Seed Company Limited, underscored the strong profit potential of soybean farming. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a highly profitable venture,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSoybeans are in constant demand for feed, food, and oil. They‚Äôre easy to grow, have high-yielding seed varieties, and there are varieties less prone to shattering, making them a smart choice for farmers,‚Äù he noted.

Kaduna-based farmer Abdoulmalik Maisango shared similar optimism, calling soybeans ‚Äòa silent millionaire maker.‚Äô He explained, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a key ingredient in animal feed and soy milk, with high demand from agro-industries. With good agronomic practices and improved seeds, farmers can harvest two to four tons per hectare and make up to N2.8 million in profit,‚Äù he added. Maisango also highlighted its affordability and soil-friendly nature. ‚ÄúA ton of soybeans currently sells between $350 and $565. Plus, it doesn‚Äôt need much fertilizer‚Äîbeing a legume. It naturally enriches the soil,‚Äù he noted.

Ayodele Uwala, national president of the Soybeans Stakeholders Coalition of Nigeria, emphasised the crop‚Äôs versatility and value-added potential. ‚ÄúOver 70 percent of food sauces in Nigeria contain soybeans,‚Äù he noted in an exclusive interview with BusinessDay. ‚ÄúCottage industries are thriving by processing soybeans into soy milk, cheese, fortified bread, and even local favorites like ‚Äòmoin moin.‚Äô It‚Äôs not just a crop‚Äîit‚Äôs a catalyst for agro-industrial growth,‚Äù he added.

Soybean continues to rank among Nigeria‚Äôs top agricultural exports, fuelled by strong demand from major international markets like China, Nepal, Pakistan, and Turkey. In 2023, Nigeria exported soybeans worth N148.2 billion‚Äîa remarkable 561 percent jump from N22.42 billion in 2022, according to BusinessDay research. The Nigerian Export Promotion Council (NEPC) attributes this dramatic rise to improved local production, driven by competitive farm-gate prices and surging global demand. ‚ÄúSoybean has become one of Nigeria‚Äôs most promising non-oil exports,‚Äù the NEPC noted in a recent report.

According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) report, Nigeria produced 1.1 million metric tons of soybeans in 2022, making it the second-largest producer in Africa after South Africa. It further projects steady growth, with production expected to reach 1.5 million metric tons by 2026, at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 1.1 percent between 2024 and 2028.

Meanwhile, data from the World Economic Database underscore the growing importance of global soybean trade. China‚Äôs net soybean grain imports have skyrocketed‚Äîfrom just 20 percent of global share in 1997 to a commanding 80 percent by 2019. ‚ÄúThis shift in China‚Äôs demand presents a strategic opening for Nigeria,‚Äù said a trade analyst at the Nigerian Export Promotion Council. ‚ÄúIf we continue to scale production and strengthen our export infrastructure, Nigeria could capture a meaningful share of this expanding market.‚Äù

Uwala pointed out several critical challenges hindering soybean production, including limited access to quality seeds, lack of essential inputs like fertilizers, particularly Single Super Phosphate (SSP), and the unavailability of Soybean Inoculant (NoduMax). He noted a serious gap in mechanisation, with no harvesters or threshers available to support both small- and medium-scale farmers. Other farmers also highlighted price volatility as a recurring challenge, a common issue with grain markets. They emphasised that fluctuating prices make it difficult to plan and sustain consistent profitability in soybean production. Ukula also pointed to insecurity and a lack of awareness among rural farmers about the availability of improved soybean varieties as a major challenge. ‚ÄúInsecurity disrupts farming operations, while limited knowledge of high-yield, resilient seed options prevent farmers from maximising their productivity,‚Äù he noted.

The global soybean market was valued at $193.10 billion in 2023 and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 4.4 percent between 2024 and 2030, according to Grand view Research. In the same year, Nigeria exported $201 million worth of soybeans, ranking as the 12th largest exporter out of 142 countries worldwide, according to data from the Observatory of Economic Complexity. Soybeans also emerged as Nigeria‚Äôs 14th most exported product among 3,364 export categories. Key export destinations included India ($126 million), Pakistan ($40.8 million), Canada ($9.24 million), Nepal ($8.78 million), and Turkey ($5.05 million), underscoring Nigeria‚Äôs growing relevance in the global soybean trade.

title: Britain agrees trade and defense reset with European Union
content: Britain agreed the most significant reset of ties with the EU since Brexit, removing some trade barriers and collaborating on defense.
resumen: Britain agreed the most significant reset of ties with the European Union since Brexit on Monday, removing some trade barriers and collaborating on defense to help grow its economy and boost security on the continent. Prime Minister Keir Starmer has bet that securing smoother access to Europe for UK visitors and trade will drown out the cries of "betrayal" from Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage when he agrees to closer EU alignment at a summit in London. The deal contains political risk for Starmer as it touches on sensitive issues including fishing rights, and many of the agreements will require further negotiation. The reset follows U.S. President Donald Trump's upending of the post-war global order, which has forced governments around the world to rethink ties on trade, defence and security, and brought Starmer closer to France's Emmanuel Macron and other European leaders. Economists said the reset with the UK's biggest trading partner could have a larger impact on its sluggish economy than recent deals with India and the U.S., but its refusal to rejoin the EU's single market or customs union will limit that. Starmer said on X: "It's time to look forward ‚Äî to move on from the stale old political fights and to find common sense, practical solutions that improve the lives of British people." At the heart of the reset is a defence and security pact that will let Britain be part of any joint procurement, but further agreement will be needed for British companies including BAE BAES.L, Rolls Royce RR.L and Babcock BAB.Lto take part in a 150 billion euro ($167 billion) programme to rearm Europe. On fishing, British and EU vessels will have access to each other's waters for 12 years - removing one of the UK's strongest hands in any future talks - in return for a permanent reduction in paperwork and border checks that has prevented many small food producers from exporting to Europe. Britain should also get access to faster e-gates for UK travellers at EU airports. In return, it has agreed to the outline of a limited youth mobility scheme, with the details to be hammered out in the future, and it is discussing participation in the Erasmus+ student exchange programme. Starmer is due to meet with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Antonio Costa to sign the deal on Monday morning, after the two sides agreed the final details in the middle of the night. Britain's vote to leave the EU in a historic referendum in 2016 revealed a country that was badly divided over everything from migration and sovereignty of power to culture and trade. Polls show a majority of Britons now regret the vote although they do not want to rejoin. Farage, who campaigned for Brexit for decades, leads opinion polls in Britain, giving Starmer limited room for manoeuvre. The prime minister and French President Emmanuel Macron have struck up a solid relationship over their support for Ukraine, and Starmer was not tainted with the Brexit rows that went before, helping to improve sentiment. Trump's unpredictable tariff programme has also prompted governments to try to strike new trade deals to seek new export economies. Britain struck a full trade deal with India earlier this month and secured some tariff relief from the U.S., while the EU is seeking to forge trade deals with India and deepen partnerships with Canada, Australia, Japan and Singapore. Rather than seek a full return to a pillar of the EU like the single market, Starmer sought to negotiate better market access in some areas - a move that is often rejected by the EU as "cherry picking" of EU benefits without the obligations of membership. Removing red tape on food trade will require Britain to accept EU oversight on standards, but Starmer is likely to argue that it is worth it to help lower the cost of food. Agreeing a longer-term fishing rights deal will also be opposed by the industry, by Farage, and by the opposition Conservative Party who negotiated the original Brexit deal and who labelled Monday's event as the "surrender summit".

title: The US and China called a truce on tariffs, but is the battleground expanding?
content: Analysts say Trump is looking to tighten tech restrictions, and this time Beijing has a better ‚Äòtoolkit‚Äô to counter ‚Äòlong-arm jurisdiction‚Äô.
resumen:
Despu√©s de que China y Estados Unidos acordaron una tregua temporal en la guerra comercial durante las conversaciones en Ginebra la semana pasada, las tensiones han vuelto a estallar, lo que pone en duda cualquier desescalada duradera.

Poco despu√©s de que se llegara al acuerdo para suspender los aranceles durante 90 d√≠as, Estados Unidos impuso una prohibici√≥n global a los chips Ascend AI de la empresa china Huawei Technologies por presuntas violaciones de control de exportaciones y preocupaciones de seguridad nacional.

Beijing acus√≥ entonces a Washington de "jurisdicci√≥n de brazo largo" y de "bloquear y reprimir maliciosamente los productos de chips chinos y la industria de la IA sin justificaci√≥n". El portavoz del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores, Lin Jian, inst√≥ a Estados Unidos a detener las "pr√°cticas proteccionistas y de acoso unilateral" y a "detener su supresi√≥n infundada de las empresas tecnol√≥gicas chinas y la industria de la IA".

Seg√∫n los analistas, la √∫ltima prohibici√≥n de los chips Huawei, cruciales para los esfuerzos de Beijing por desarrollar sus propios semiconductores avanzados e inteligencia artificial, indica que el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump busca expandir el campo de batalla m√°s all√° de los aranceles y endurecer las restricciones tecnol√≥gicas a China.

Pero Beijing no solo est√° jugando a la defensiva. Los analistas dicen que China ahora est√° mejor preparada y contrarresta activamente las restricciones estadounidenses, incluso con sus propios controles de exportaci√≥n y autosuficiencia para garantizar que no est√© a merced de otro pa√≠s.

Zhao Minghao, profesor del Instituto de Estudios Internacionales de la Universidad Fudan en Shanghai, dijo que la represi√≥n estadounidense contra los chips Huawei fue "significativa", ya que reflejaba las crecientes preocupaciones de Washington sobre el progreso del gigante tecnol√≥gico.
