title: Canadians Fear Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Will Create a ‚ÄòGhost Town‚Äô in Ontario
content: President Trump‚Äôs tariffs on auto parts are already causing job losses in Windsor, Ontario, the heart of an industry that makes components for vehicles bound for the United States.
resumen: Pauline Ridley and Colleen Barrette, union officials, said that Windsor, Ontario, would be a ‚Äúghost town‚Äù without auto-parts makers. President Trump‚Äôs tariff war against Canada has unleashed widespread anxiety in Windsor, the country‚Äôs auto-making capital. There are roughly 100 smaller auto-parts plants in Windsor and the surrounding county that employ some 9,000 workers. About 5,400 people work for the three auto factories in Windsor. Many parts makers are small businesses without the financial cushion that auto giants can lean on to soften the blow from the 25 percent tariffs Mr. Trump applied to imported autos and some auto parts. At KB components, where Ms. Ridley is the union chairwoman, about 100 people are currently laid off, leaving nearly 400 workers at the company‚Äôs three plants in Windsor molding plastic parts for Toyota, Ford and the electric vehicle makers Rivian and Lucid. Flavio Volpe, the president of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers‚Äô Association, estimates that upward of 12,000 parts workers have been laid off and, in some cases, recalled since the start of U.S. tariffs. Ms. Ridley said, ‚ÄúThis is, like, utter chaos that Trump started.‚Äù In 1904, Henry Ford formed a partnership with a wagon works maker in Windsor to establish the Ford Motor Company of Canada. The sprawling Windsor Engine plant opened in 1923. Ms. Ridley‚Äôs father made industrial patterns that were used to cast metal auto parts. Her son had worked at a German-owned plastic parts plant in Leamington, Ontario. After the U.S. tariffs went into effect, he was laid off. Magna International, an automotive parts company founded by Frank Stronach, became a global behemoth, with $43 billion in sales. Stratus Plastics employs about 36 people. Colby Wu, co-owner of Stratus Plastics, said the biggest challenge was the ever-shifting nature of Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs and uncertainty over their longevity. Mr. Wu said, ‚ÄúThe worst thing in today‚Äôs situation is the fact that we don‚Äôt know what direction he‚Äôs going to go.‚Äù Stefan Andersson, the chief executive of KB Components, said the firm was still planning to proceed with upgrades to the factory‚Äôs molding machines. The two women were part of a union group that physically blocked a truck from moving machinery from a local family-owned stamping plant across the bridge that connects Windsor to Detroit. The company, Titan Tool & Die, relies on dies or molds owned by larger parts companies or automakers, some of which can cost millions of dollars, to stamp or mold parts. A court ordered the union to stop blocking the trucks, and the machinery is now in Michigan.

content: With a war in Ukraine and the U.S. rethinking alliances, Britain and the European Union may need each other more than they thought. They're holding their first summit since Brexit Monday.
resumen:
Five years after Brexit, Britain and the EU announced fresh ties.

Britain and the European Union held their first summit since Brexit.

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer welcomed top EU officials to London, including European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

Polls show a majority of Britons now believe it was wrong for the United Kingdom to leave the EU.

Britain and the EU already have tariff-free trade, according to their 2020 breakup agreement.

At the summit, they worked out extending the EU fishing industry's access to British waters for another 12 years, permitting British students and 20-somethings to work short-term jobs in the EU and vice versa, and opening up access for British travelers to use electronic passport gates at European airports.

The British government will remain outside the EU's single market trading bloc.

Britain will continue to sign its own trade deals. It recently struck a deal for relief of U.S. tariffs on British steel, aluminum and most cars. It also signed a comprehensive trade deal with India this month.

When Britain was part of the EU, anyone from other member states could live and work freely in the U.K.

A far-right anti-immigrant party called Reform U.K., led by Nigel Farage, made big gains in England's local elections last month.

Starmer, whose center-left Labour Party has a large majority in the U.K. Parliament, has adopted some of Farage's populist language on immigration.

Officials also discussed cooperation on climate policy, carbon markets ‚Äî and even music. Elton John has been lobbying for less red tape for British musicians who go on tour in Europe.

title: Tariffs As Hidden Taxes: Was Amazon Right About Price Disclosures?
content: Robert Goulder comments on whether tariffs are hidden taxes that should be routinely disclosed to retail consumers.
resumen:
Several weeks ago, the author suggested the creation of a national tariff-payer advocate. This officeholder would have responsibilities that parallel those of the national taxpayer advocate within the IRS, but in the tariff context. The officeholder would be supported by a professional staff and function as an independent actor.

Amazon was poised to unveil a new feature in how it displays prices, showing how much Trump‚Äôs tariffs are adding to the price of each product, right next to the product‚Äôs total listed price.

The impetus for Amazon‚Äôs move was a policy change the Trump administration had announced a few weeks earlier. Trump eliminated the long-standing de minimis rule for international parcels with a declared value not exceeding $800. Previously, these shipments were exempt from duties. On April 2 the White House announced that, going forward (effective May 2), de minimis items sent through the international postal network would be subject to a duty equal to the lesser of a 30 percent tariff on the declared value or $25 per item.

Amazon found itself needing to adapt to the removal of the de minimis exemption ‚Äî thus, the proposed change in how the company would display prices.

By way of example, consider a hypothetical listing of an imported espresso machine normally priced at $100. With Trump‚Äôs rescission of the de minimis exemption, the listing might read as follows: ‚ÄúPrice: $125 ‚Äî excluding local sales tax, including $25 tariff.‚Äù

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt, joined by U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, lashed out against Amazon during a morning briefing with reporters. She labeled Amazon‚Äôs move a ‚Äúhostile and political act.‚Äù She went further, accusing Amazon of inappropriate bias, noting that the company proposed no similar pricing disclosure to reflect the rise of inflation that occurred during the Biden administration.

Within a few hours of Leavitt‚Äôs remarks, Trump phoned Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos to urge Bezos to reverse course on the price disclosure. Bezos accommodated the request. Tim Doyle, a spokesperson for Amazon, later explained the situation as follows: The team that runs our ultra-low-cost Amazon Haul store considered the idea of listing import charges on certain products. This was never approved and is not going to happen.

Trump and Bezos have a peculiar relationship. Bezos is the second wealthiest man in the world (behind Elon Musk and ahead of Mark Zuckerberg), with an estimated net worth of $220 billion. Trump frequently criticized Bezos during his first term. Last year, with the presidential election fast approaching, Bezos seems to have made goodwill gestures toward Trump. Bezos did not contribute to Trump‚Äôs campaign ahead of the election, but he did donate a cool $1 million to Trump‚Äôs inauguration fund. Bezos dined with Trump at Mar-a-Lago in December 2024 and was in the Capitol rotunda when Trump was inaugurated on January 20.

The late congressman Phil Crane said the ‚Äúworst tax imaginable‚Äù is a hidden tax.

Temu has chosen to be transparent about embedded U.S. tariff costs ‚Äî a direct consequence of Trump‚Äôs termination of the de minimis exemption. Temu has adopted the identical disclosure practice that Amazon considered before backing down under pressure from the White House.

title: EU Cuts 2025 Eurozone Growth Forecast Over Trump Tariffs
content: The EU on Monday sharply cut its eurozone economic growth forecast for 2025 because of global trade tensions sparked by US President Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs.
resumen: This photograph taken in Paris on April 8, 2025 shows a globe with a USA flag with the inscription ‚Äútariffs‚Äù planted on it as the global economy has been rocked since sweeping 10 percent US tariffs took effect over the weekend, triggering a dramatic market sell-off worldwide and sparking recession fears. The EU on Monday sharply cut its eurozone economic growth forecast for 2025 because of global trade tensions sparked by US President Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs. The European Commission said the 20-country single currency area‚Äôs economy should grow 0.9 per cent in 2025 ‚Äî down from a previous forecast of 1.3 per cent ‚Äî due to ‚Äúa weakening global trade outlook and higher trade policy uncertainty‚Äù. The EU also lowered its prediction for eurozone growth in 2026 to 1.4 per cent, down from 1.6 per cent expected in November last year, AFP reports. Trump has hit the European Union and others with 25-per cent levies on steel, aluminium and auto imports, and the bloc faces sweeping additional tariffs unless it reaches a deal with Washington. The US leader announced a 20 per cent levy on most EU goods in April, along with higher duties on dozens of other nations. That measure has since been frozen until July to allow negotiations, but Trump has kept a ‚Äúbaseline‚Äù 10 per cent tariff on imports from around the world, including the 27-country EU. The EU also said Germany, the bloc‚Äôs biggest economy, would not grow at all in 2025, a significantly sharp reduction from the 0.7 per cent predicted last year. The EU also pointed to the US-China trade war, during which the two sides hiked levies on each other‚Äôs goods before slashing them in a temporary de-escalation. The commission said it expected inflation in the 20-country single currency area to ease to 2.1 per cent, unchanged from the previous prediction and very close to the European Central Bank‚Äôs (ECB) two-per-cent target. Inflation among the 20 members of the eurozone has slowed down sharply from the double-digit highs seen in late 2022 and sat at 2.2 per cent in April. The EU cut its 2026 inflation forecast to 1.7 per cent, from 1.9 per cent.

title: G7 finance leaders seek unity on non-tariff issues in Canada, face US resistance on trade policy
content: G7 finance officials meeting in Banff amid US tariff pressure US won‚Äôt sign G7 statement unless it aligns with Trump priorities G7 seen uniting around Ukraine, IMF and ...
resumen:
G7 finance leaders will meet in Banff, Canada.
The meeting will set the stage for the G7 leaders‚Äô summit in June in Kananaskis.
Finance leaders from the Group of Seven industrialised democracies will strive for unity on non-tariff issues.
The US may have trouble reaching consensus with a Trump administration intent on pushing allies to serve US interests.
The other six G7 members are Japan, Britain, Germany, France, Italy and host Canada.
The other six G7 members want to keep the powerful Western policy alliance from fracturing over US President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs and reversals on climate change, global tax cooperation and Ukraine.
A source briefed on US positions in the talks said that any consensus needed to align with Trump administration priorities.
US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will join fellow G7 finance ministers and central bank governors for the Tuesday-to-Thursday meeting.
Japan, Germany, France and Italy all face a potential doubling of reciprocal US duties to 20 per cent or more in early July.
Britain negotiated a limited trade deal that leaves it saddled with 10 per cent US tariffs on most goods, and host Canada is still struggling with Trump‚Äôs separate 25 per cent duty on many exports.
Charles Lichfield, deputy director of the Atlantic Council‚Äôs GeoEconomics Center in Washington, said that ministers from the other six countries will likely try to tactfully remind Bessent that they are the closest US allies and that it is difficult for them to meet Washington‚Äôs demands that they exert economic pressure on China while facing US coercion themselves.
Bessent will push the countries to address imbalances and non-market practices, including in their own economies, and counteract China‚Äôs state-driven economic model.
Bessent is widely seen as a moderating influence on Trump‚Äôs trade agenda.
Mark Sobel, a former US Treasury and International Monetary Fund official who is US chairman of OMFIF, an independent financial policy think tank, said G7 ministers will ‚Äúencourage him to push for more moderate administration policies on trade.‚Äù
A draft communique has been prepared already and that Canada was pushing to achieve a consensus to show that G7 countries were standing together on a range of issues.
These are expected to include a broad statement of support for Ukraine in its struggle against Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion, with Ukrainian Finance Minister Serhii Marchenko in attendance.
The EU is readying a new package of sanctions to increase pressure on Moscow.
Trump announced after a call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday that Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks would begin immediately.
The US source on the G7 meeting said Bessent was leaving all sanctions options open to increase pressure on Russia to bring an end to the war.
Another area for common ground is likely to be on support for the International Monetary Fund and World Bank after Bessent reaffirmed US backing for the institutions in April.
Other issues on which agreements can be reached include cooperation to fight money laundering and other financial crimes, and Bessent‚Äôs call for stronger reliance on the private sector to drive growth.
Language on climate change is expected to be a source of discord.
Suzanne Clark, CEO of the US Chamber of Commerce, said ‚ÄúMy crystal ball is so murky now, I can‚Äôt really see the future very well.‚Äù

title: The ongoing oil price tensions
content: OPEC+ oil war impacts global economy, India's oil imports, and geopolitical dynamics, analyzed by expert Mahesh Sachdev.
resumen: Global oil demand is approaching a plateau, with the International Energy Agency (IEA) expecting it to grow only by 0.73% in 2025 despite sharply lower prices. The IEA predicted that global oil consumption would peak before 2030. On May 3, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries Plus (OPEC+) decided to go ahead with a collective output increase of 4,11,000 barrels per day (bpd) from June. This was the third month in a row that the oil cartel decided to raise crude production, undoing the 9,60,000 bpd or nearly half of the 2.2 million bpd ‚Äúvoluntary‚Äù output cuts eight of its members undertook in 2023. There are hints that the full 2.2 million bpd cut would be unwound by October 2025. The Brent crude price plummeted by almost 2% to $60.23/barrel, then recovered to $65/barrel. OPEC+ aimed for triple dollar mark. OPEC+ decided to reverse its tactic from reducing supplies to raising production. OPEC+ took a collective production cut of five million bpd, nearly 10% of its total pre-pandemic output. A further ‚Äúvoluntary‚Äù cut of 2.2 million bpd was taken by eight members. Saudi Arabia, OPEC+‚Äôs largest producer, which took nearly three million bpd or 40% of the total production cuts, got increasingly infuriated by endemic OPEC+ overproducers, such as Kazakhstan, Iraq, the UAE and Nigeria. Saudi Arabia prefers stable and moderately high oil prices. Saudi Arabia‚Äôs average production fell below nine million bpd in 2024, its lowest level since 2011. The oil market is more fragmented with large flocks of freelancing producers. Crude exports by major oil producers such as Russia, Iran and Venezuela are currently hobbled by U.S. economic sanctions. The S&P Global agency lowered its global GDP forecasts to 2.2% for 2025 and 2.4% for 2026. The World Trade Organization recently predicted a 0.2% annual decline in world trade in 2025. India, the world‚Äôs third-largest crude importer, shelled out $137 billion in 2024-25 for crude. India‚Äôs crude demand rose by 3.2%. A U.S. study last year predicted that in 2025, nearly a quarter of global crude consumption growth would come from India. A one-dollar decline in oil price yielding an annual saving of roughly $1.5 billion for India. The Gulf economies sustain over nine million of our expatriates, whose annual remittances are estimated at over $50 billion. Mahesh Sachdev, retired Indian Ambassador, focusses on the Arab world and oil issues.

title: New poll reveals a major shift on Trump‚Äôs economy
content: The latest Harvard CAPS/Harris poll showed that for the first time since July 2021, a majority of voters believe that the U.S. economy is strong. The poll showed that 51% of voters said it‚Äôs strong, ...
resumen: A new poll showed that sentiments about the economy are shifting under President Donald Trump. The latest Harvard CAPS/Harris poll showed that for the first time since July 2021, a majority of voters believe that the U.S. economy is strong. The poll showed that 51% of voters said it‚Äôs strong, while 49% said it is weak. In April, just 46% of voters said the U.S. economy was strong and 54% said it was weak. Just 46% approved of how he is handling the economy in the latest poll, which is up from the 43% who said the same last month. Another 43% said they approved of how Trump is dealing with inflation, which is up two percentage points from last month. Just 42% approving of Trump‚Äôs stances on the issues of tariffs and his trade policy. Overall, just 39% of voters said that the economy is headed in the right direction. This is a slight increase from the 37% who said the same in April. Overall, 47% of voters approve of Trump‚Äôs job as president. This is a slight downturn from last month, when 48% said they approved. The poll was conducted among 1,903 registered voters on May 14-15. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.2 percentage points. A recent Reuters/Ipsos poll, released Tuesday, found Trump‚Äôs approval rating ticked up two percentage points since the poll was conducted late last month. The poll found that 44% of respondents said they approved of Trump‚Äôs job performance, while 52% say they disapproved. The Quantus Insights poll showed a virtual tie, with 48.2% of respondents saying they approve of Trump while 48.3% said they disapprove.

title: EUR/USD: Euro remains calm near 1.1200 level on a poor agenda's day
content: The single European currency has started the week in a calm trading tone, maintaining the levels of the previous days near the level of 1.12, with investors remaining cautious and avoiding big bets.
resumen: The single European currency has started the week in a calm trading tone, maintaining the levels of the previous days near the level of 1.12, with investors remaining cautious and avoiding big bets. Friday's announcement of the University of Michigan's survey on consumer confidence in the United States disappointed, causing the US dollar to come under temporary pressure. The previous week was clearly in favor of the US dollar, with the European currency coming under pressure and sliding almost 200 basis points, approaching the critical level of 1.10. The dollar's shine was mainly enhanced by developments regarding the trade war and the interim agreement between the United States and China, which brought great optimism to the markets, simultaneously strengthening both the US dollar and international stock markets. President Donald Trump's controversial personality and his ability to surprise and change the facts from day to day have created significant uncertainty among investors, and although the change in policy has brought some stability, favoring financial markets and the US dollar, the clouds have not completely cleared. US government debt securities remain at high levels that could not be fully justified by the current levels of Fed interest rates. The 10-year bonds moving above the 4.50 level. The exchange rate not having any strong direction at the moment, the European currency since it climbed to its high of 1.1575 has again come under mild doubt but on the other hand the American currency after the very good correction is struggling to continue to shine. The range of variation will remain between the levels 1.11 and 1.16 for the near future.

title: 5 years since Brexit, are Britain and the EU getting back together?
content: With a war in Ukraine and the U.S. rethinking alliances, Britain and the European Union may need each other more than they thought. They're holding their first summit since Brexit Monday.
resumen:
Five years after Brexit, Britain and the EU announced fresh ties.

The first summit since Brexit was held with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and top EU officials, including European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

The summit addressed extending the EU fishing industry's access to British waters for another 12 years, permitting British students and 20-somethings to work short-term jobs in the EU and vice versa, and opening up access for British travelers to use electronic passport gates at European airports.

The British government will remain outside the EU's single market trading bloc and will continue to sign its own trade deals.

A far-right anti-immigrant party called Reform U.K., led by Nigel Farage, made big gains in England's local elections last month.

Under a new deal, EU boats will be able to fish in the U.K. until 2038.

Officials also discussed cooperation on climate policy, carbon markets.

Britain will now be able to access an EU defense loan program worth $170 billion.

title: Singapore construction sector sees fallout from US tariffs amid trade war truce
content: Singapore‚Äôs construction sector is starting to see some fallout from US President Donald Trump‚Äôs global tariffs, with firms here grappling with uncertainty over pricing and supply of raw materials, ...
resumen:
Singapore‚Äôs construction sector is starting to see some fallout from US President Donald Trump‚Äôs global tariffs, with firms here grappling with uncertainty over pricing and supply of raw materials, according to local industry associations.

Analysts are mixed on the tariffs‚Äô impact on construction materials costs in Singapore, even as the temporary truce reduces the risks of acute global supply chain disruptions.

New US tariffs on steel and aluminium are tightening global supply chains, and Singapore is starting to feel the strain.

Mills in China and India are fully booked for the next six to seven months as US buyers stockpile materials, limiting availability in Asia, and driving up costs.

On May 12, the US and China agreed to suspend part of their tariffs on their respective exports for 90 days.

The 25 per cent sector-specific tariffs on steel, aluminium, automobiles and auto parts announced in March and April remain in place, albeit with rebates for vehicles assembled in the US and a partial exemption for the UK.

The 10 per cent universal tariffs announced on ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù are also still in place.

Tariff uncertainty has wreaked havoc on aluminium prices, which jumped from US$2,449.90 per tonne in September 2024 to a peak of US$2,658.30 per tonne in March 2025, before dropping to US$2,371.60 per tonne in April.

Some building materials manufacturers here have seen higher aluminium costs and longer lead times.

For major projects, a 5 to 10 per cent increase in material costs could add millions of dollars in costs to budgets. Delays in delivery and unpredictable pricing are also disrupting timelines. Materials like facades and fittings, which rely heavily on aluminium, are especially affected.

The local construction industry has not been too badly hit by the tariffs on steel so far. However, if global steel prices increase due to redirected demand and tighter supply, we may start to feel the effects over the next three to six months.

Sector-specific tariffs on steel and aluminium have the potential to raise costs for Singapore‚Äôs construction sector.

The 90-day truce may provide a ‚Äútemporary window of stability‚Äù in global pricing, even though volatility remains a concern over the long term.

The actual cost impact in Singapore will still depend on how long-term supply arrangements and market sentiment adjust.

The construction ecosystem remains vulnerable to any re-escalation of trade tensions, and contractors must remain vigilant about project timelines and materials availability in the second half of 2025.

Short-term supply re-directions are possible as Chinese exporters seek to re-route goods to markets in the region, such as Asean.

Chinese exporters are doing so for two reasons: to tap burgeoning construction demand in the region, and also because their goods could gain access to US markets at lower tariff rates if the final processing was done at a third-party country such as Indonesia before being exported to the US.

The tariffs could benefit the construction sector in the Asia-Pacific as raw materials may get cheaper in the near term.

The tariffs on steel and aluminium ‚Äì and potential retaliatory action from the European Union ‚Äì are expected to push up construction costs in the US and the EU, and slow the construction pipeline.

The Asia-Pacific, which currently has fewer tariffs in place and a significant construction pipeline of over 230 million sq ft of office space, is a likely destination for this surplus. This could lead to short-term price deflation in raw materials here.

Raw material costs are only one component of overall development costs.

Rising shipping fees, local labour and land costs continue to influence project viability.

Mr Benjamin Lim, Singapore Manufacturing Federation‚Äôs (SMF) industry group chairman for building products and construction materials.

Lee Kay Chai, Singapore Contractors Association (Scal) president.

Dr Dominic Brown, Cushman & Wakefield‚Äôs head of international research.

title: Will Trump‚Äôs trade curbs skip the Middle East?
content: President Donald Trump's new AI deals with Gulf nations is fueling optimism in the global tech sector that the Middle East may be spared from looming U.S. chip controls.
resumen:
The global tech sector sees the Trump administration‚Äôs multibillion-dollar AI deals between U.S. and Gulf firms as a signal the Middle East could be spared as its Commerce Department moves toward tightening chip controls on China.

One corporate representative for a major industry group said the Middle East AI chip deals that the President and his staff have made are important to the AI diffusion conversation.

The White House last week said Trump secured more than $2 trillion in investment agreements in the region, including nearly $150 billion between Saudi Arabia and American defense contractors, an order by the Qatari government for 160 Boeing planes and a $60 billion partnership between American energy companies and Abu Dhabi‚Äôs state-run oil firm.

The Trump administration begins to revise the Biden-era AI Diffusion Rule, which it decided to officially block last week over concerns that the policy would adversely harm domestic industry.

The rule would have imposed country-specific caps on sales of advanced chips ‚Äî including strict curbs on countries in the Middle East.

Trump‚Äôs Commerce Department is now preparing to replace the Biden-era measure with its own curbs on chips.

Information Technology Industry Council President and CEO Jason Oxman said the Trump Administration should develop its new approach with robust stakeholder engagement and provide direction and certainty in the interim period. The trade group ITI counts Amazon, Apple, Intel and Nvidia as members.

Sam Winter‚ÄëLevy, a fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the Trump administration could be less resistant than the Biden administration was to giving away large volumes of advanced chips to countries, including the UAE and Saudi Arabia, that retain ties with China in the AI domain.

David Sacks, Trump‚Äôs AI czar and a former venture capitalist, was reportedly part of high-level negotiations between the U.S. and Emirati firm G42 for a deal that would send hundreds of thousands of high-end chips to the UAE.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent suggested the administration could impose some tariffs by region, ahead of a looming July 9 deadline for the return of so-called reciprocal tariffs.

Trump told reporters that while ‚Äú150 countries‚Äù were seeking to make deals with the U.S., it was ‚Äúnot possible to meet the number of people that want to see us.‚Äù

U.S. trading partners should expect individual letters from Bessent and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick ‚Äúat a certain point over the next two to three weeks,‚Äù in which they would be ‚Äútelling people what they will be paying to do business in the United States.‚Äù

The administration plans to impose a specific tariff level after July, while other deals will be negotiated ‚Äúin due course.‚Äù

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) attacked the economic logic of Trump‚Äôs aggressive tariff strategy.

The Commerce Department is weighing changes to how it calculates duty rates.

The administration is seeking input on possible alternatives to ‚ÄúCohen‚Äôs d,‚Äù which is a statistical measure the department uses in antidumping and countervailing duty investigations.

Commerce is asking for stakeholders to file public comments by May 30.

title: Euro Zone Bond Yields Dip Amid U.S. Trade Tensions
content: Euro zone government bond yields turned negative as investors sought safer assets due to growing doubts over a U.S.-China trade-war truce. The U.S. Treasury yields eased after initial gains, while ...
resumen: Euro zone government bond yields turned negative this week as investors sought refuge in safer assets, prompted by doubts regarding a U.S.-China trade-war truce. Initially, both euro zone and U.S. yields rose, fueled by rising fears over the fiscal implications of a U.S. tax bill. Concerns intensified following Moody's downgrade of U.S. credit rating, causing longer-dated Treasury yields to reach an 18-month peak. However, Germany's 10-year yield‚Äîthe euro zone benchmark‚Äîfell in afternoon trading as China's demand for the U.S. to address its chip export curbs spooked markets. Despite some recovery in bond prices, volatility persisted as investors digested news of potential Federal Reserve rate adjustments and European fiscal policies. Markets priced in adjustments to European Central Bank rates amidst expectations of military-related debt mutualisation across the euro area.

title: Trump Berates Companies for Warning About Tariff Price Increases
content: The president recently attacked Walmart, saying it should ‚Äúeat‚Äù the costs rather than pass them on to customers.
resumen:
President Trump is telling some of the nation‚Äôs largest companies that they should eat the cost of his tariffs.

The United States has imposed a 10 percent tariff on nearly every nation since the spring, with steeper duties reserved for specific products and countries, including a minimum 30 percent tax on Chinese imports.

Walmart might have to increase prices soon. Doug McMillon, the chief executive, said on Walmart‚Äôs latest earnings call last week that it probably would not be able to ‚Äúabsorb all the pressure‚Äù from the president‚Äôs tariffs for much longer.

In response, the president demanded in a post on social media on Saturday that Walmart ‚ÄúEAT THE TARIFFS,‚Äù rather than pass any new costs on to customers. He argued that Walmart had generated billions of dollars in profit last year, so it could afford to shoulder any added expenses.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù that Walmart would, in fact, ‚Äúeat some of the tariffs,‚Äù noting that he had spoken with Mr. McMillon over the weekend.

The law requires that companies be forthcoming with shareholders about the financial risks they face.

Mr. McMillon‚Äôs call with Mr. Bessent had been scheduled before the president‚Äôs threat, and the chief executive made no new commitments about pricing, said a person familiar with the matter.

Molly Blakeman, a spokeswoman for Walmart, said in a statement: ‚ÄúWe have always worked to keep our prices as low as possible, and we won‚Äôt stop.‚Äù

The administration has completed an early framework for an agreement with Britain, and it has worked with China to mutually lower the punishing tit-for-tat tariffs that essentially halted trade between the world‚Äôs largest economies.

Mr. Trump has threatened repeatedly to restore the much larger ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs that he announced in early April. Those levies were suspended for 90 days to give other nations time to reach trade deals with the United States.

Financial markets tumbled anew amid concerns about the president‚Äôs agenda and its effects on the country‚Äôs fiscal future.

Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, pointed to that data in a statement on Monday, stressing that the administration‚Äôs policies are working. He said the United States ‚Äúhas the leverage to make our trading partners ultimately bear the cost of tariffs.‚Äù

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, told reporters earlier Monday. He said any tariff-related price increases, if they occurred, were not a sign of inflation but a ‚Äúone-time‚Äù effect.

Companies including Lowe‚Äôs and Home Depot will report their latest earnings this week.

Gregory Daco, chief economist for the consulting firm EY-Parthenon, said that there was an ‚Äúincreasing likelihood they‚Äôre going to pass on at least part‚Äù of the higher costs to consumers.

When a disputed report surfaced in April that Amazon would begin displaying tariff-related costs on its widely popular marketplace, the Trump administration accused the e-commerce giant of a ‚Äúhostile and political‚Äù act. Mr. Trump later spoke with Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, and the company denied that the policy was going into effect.

The president took aim at Mattel, which had warned that it might raise the price of its popular toys, including Barbies, as a result of tariffs. Mr. Trump threatened to impose a 100 percent tariff on Mattel‚Äôs products.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs push to limit what companies can charge their customers is also a sharp deviation from the 2024 campaign, when he attacked Vice President Kamala Harris after she embraced a federal ban on price gouging by grocery stores and food suppliers.

Mr. Trump also turned his attention to Ford Motor when it appeared poised to raise prices on some of its vehicles on the heels of a report to investors showing it would face $1.5 billion in tariff costs this year.

Mr. Trump said at a White House event this month in response to a question about the public‚Äôs patience for price increases: ‚ÄúTariffs are the most misunderstood thing maybe in any form of business.‚Äù

He maintained that those costs would not fall on to consumers. ‚ÄúOftentimes, the country picks them up. Oftentimes, the company picks it up,‚Äù Mr. Trump continued. ‚ÄúThe people don‚Äôt pick it up, OK? The people don‚Äôt pick it up.‚Äù

title: How the Trade War Shaped a Chinese Battery Giant‚Äôs Hong Kong Debut
content: Shares of the company, CATL, surged in their first day of trading. Onshore U.S. investors were blocked from buying its stock as a ‚Äúdecoupling‚Äù of finance continued.
resumen:
Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd., or CATL, started selling shares for the first time in Hong Kong on Tuesday, surging 16 percent. It was the world‚Äôs biggest stock listing so far this year, according to the data provider Dealogic.

Tensions between China and the United States pushed CATL to ban U.S. onshore investors from its share sale, the first outside of the Chinese mainland, where it is listed in the city of Shenzhen.

CATL has found itself caught in the crossfire as Washington and Beijing have lobbed sanctions, blacklists and tariffs at each other. It was labeled a Chinese military company by the Pentagon. U.S. lawmakers called on its Wall Street bankers to back out of the Hong Kong listing. And it has been hit with tariffs on the batteries it makes.

The CATL Hong Kong stock sale marks a dramatic reversal from a decade ago when Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, elicited cheers from traders as it went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014. The company raised $21.8 billion.

CATL raised $4.6 billion ahead of its secondary listing in Hong Kong. The stock was sold for $263 Hong Kong dollars a share, or about $33.62 U.S. dollars. Its biggest investors include Kuwait‚Äôs sovereign wealth fund, the Chinese firm Hillhouse Capital Management Group and Oaktree Capital Management, the American asset management firm.

CATL moved to hive off American investors ahead of the listing as tensions between the United States and China spiked. It said last week that it had changed the share sale to what is known as a Reg S offering, which prevents the sale of stock to onshore U.S. investors and exempts it from having to make certain regulatory filings in the United States.

CATL said that geopolitical tensions are among the risk factors to its business. ‚ÄúWe face risks associated with changes in trade policies or tariff regulations,‚Äù it said in a regulatory filing.

In response to the Pentagon‚Äôs designation of the company as having both military and commercial technology, CATL said that it had ‚Äúnever engaged in any military-related businesses or activities‚Äù and had ‚Äúproactively engaged with the Department of Defense to address the false designation.‚Äù

Some 10 percent of American investors would have probably invested in its stock if not prevented from doing so, said Victor Shih, a specialist in Chinese finance at the University of California, San Diego.

title: Trump‚Äôs tariffs may mean Walmart shoppers pay more, his treasury chief acknowledges
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged Sunday that Walmart, the largest US retailer, may pass along some of the costs from President Trump‚Äôs tariffs to its shoppers through higher prices.
resumen: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged that Walmart may pass along some of the costs from President Trump‚Äôs tariffs to its shoppers through higher prices. Bessent described his call with Walmart CEO Doug McMillon a day after Trump warned Walmart to avoid raising prices from the tariffs and vowed to keep a close watch on what it does. Bessent pushed back against inflation concerns, praised the uncertainty caused by Trump as a negotiating tactic for trade talks, and dismissed the downgrade Friday of US government debt by Moody‚Äôs Ratings. Bessent said he spoke Saturday with McMillon, stressing in two news show interviews that what he thought really mattered for Walmart customers was the decline in gasoline prices, which is averaging roughly $3.18 a gallon. Bessent said on CNN, ‚ÄúWalmart will be absorbing some of the tariffs, some may get passed on to consumers.‚Äù In a social media post on Saturday morning, Trump said Walmart should not charge its customers more money to offset the new tariff costs. Bessent said Walmart on its earnings call on Thursday had been obligated under federal regulations ‚Äúto give the worst-case scenario so that they‚Äôre not sued.‚Äù Walmart‚Äôs chief financial officer, John David Rainey, said Thursday, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre wired to keep prices low, but there‚Äôs a limit to what we can bear, or any retailer for that matter.‚Äù Bessent maintained that the ratings downgrade was a ‚Äúlagging indicator‚Äù as the financial markets had already priced in the costs of a total federal debt of roughly $36 trillion. The tax plan being pushed by Trump would add more roughly $3.3 trillion to deficits over the next decade, including a $600 billion increase in 2027 alone, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. The Trump administration is still trying to determine rates with roughly 40 major trading partners before a July deadline. It‚Äôs also in the early stages of a 90-day negotiation with China, after agreed a week ago to reset tariffs on that country from 145 percent to 30 percent so that talks can proceed. Bessent said any worries about tariffs by small business owners most likely reflected the higher rate previously being charged on China. Bessent said, ‚ÄúStrategic uncertainty is a negotiating tactic.‚Äù Bessent appeared on NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù and CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúState of the Union.‚Äù

title: China retaliates with up to 75pc tariffs on engineering plastic from US, EU, Japan, Taiwan amid trade tensions
content: China on Sunday announced anti-dumping duties as high as 74.9 per cent on imports of POM copolymers, a type of engineering plastic, from the United States, ...
resumen:
China announced anti-dumping duties on imports of POM copolymers from the United States, the European Union, Japan and Taiwan.

The commerce ministry‚Äôs findings conclude a probe launched in May 2024.

POM copolymers can partially replace metals such as copper and zinc and have various applications including in auto parts, electronics and medical equipment.

Initial investigations had determined that dumping was taking place, and implemented preliminary anti-dumping measures in the form of a deposit starting from January 24.

The highest anti-dumping rates of 74.9 per cent were levied on imports from the United States, while European shipments will face 34.5 per cent duties.

China slapped 35.5 per cent duties on Japanese imports, except for Asahi Kasei Corp, which received a company-specific rate of 24.5 per cent.

General duties of 32.6 per cent were placed on imports from Taiwan, while Formosa Plastics received a 4 per cent tariff and Polyplastics Taiwan 3.8 per cent.

title: Por: Dennis Falvy // Aun con 300%: empresas de EEUU en china ok
content: Se se√±ala que aunque EE.UU. suba los aranceles al 300%, miles de empresas seguir√°n produciendo en China. ¬øLa raz√≥n? Un ecosistema industrial tan eficiente que pa√≠ses como Ecuador est√°n, literalmente, ...
resumen: Aunque EE.UU. suba los aranceles al 300%, miles de empresas seguir√°n produciendo en China. Un ecosistema industrial es tan eficiente que pa√≠ses como Ecuador est√°n, literalmente, a d√©cadas (y cientos de miles de millones de d√≥lares) de distancia. Trump convirti√≥ el d√©ficit comercial en enemigo p√∫blico. Las f√°bricas no regresan a Ohio, ni a Detroit, ni a ninguna ciudad estadounidense. Miles de empresas estadounidenses siguen produciendo en China por ‚Äúeficiencia‚Äù. Adri√°n D√≠az Marro, empresario con a√±os de experiencia en China dice que la mayor√≠a no conoce el tema de la China. Las empresas simplemente absorben el costo, trasladan parte al consumidor, o buscan alternativas en Vietnam o M√©xico. Irse de China del todo, incluso con un arancel del 300%, sigue siendo mala idea. Se trata de un ecosistema industrial que funciona como un organismo vivo, afinado, gigantesco. El mito de que China es ‚Äúmano de obra barata‚Äù ya no tiene sentido. Los salarios en las ciudades industriales son comparables a los de Europa del Este. China sigue liderando porque tiene una cadena de valor integrada, √°gil y monumental. Foxconn, en Zhengzhou, ensambla 500.000 iPhones al d√≠a. Tiene 300.000 empleados y una red de proveedores alrededor del edificio. La log√≠stica es tan perfecta que si un puerto se detiene, hay rutas alternas ya listas. Replicar esto en EE.UU. no es solo costoso; es inviable a corto plazo. No hay t√©cnicos suficientes, no hay proveedores cercanos, no hay incentivos estatales. Seg√∫n el Boston Consulting Group, recrear ese ecosistema le costar√≠a a EE.UU entre $1,5 y $2,5 billones de d√≥lares y requerir√≠a entre 15 y 25 a√±os. El absurdo del proteccionismo es que termina castigando a las propias empresas estadounidenses. Seg√∫n datos del propio gobierno, el 40% de lo que EE.UU. importa de China son productos fabricados por empresas estadounidenses que operan all√° porque all√° funciona todo mejor. Nike, Apple, Tesla o General Motors no producen en China por ideolog√≠a. Lo hacen porque es el √∫nico lugar donde sus cadenas de suministro son tan r√°pidas, eficientes y confiables que pueden competir globalmente. Penalizarlos por eso solo encarece sus productos‚Ä¶ para el consumidor estadounidense. China necesita exportar, y EE.UU. necesita financiar su d√©ficit. Sin esa din√°mica, el sistema financiero global se desbalancea. Trump insiste en que EE.UU. ‚Äúpierde dinero‚Äù con China. EE.UU. compra productos chinos baratos y eficientes, lo que reduce sus costos de vida. China compra deuda estadounidense, invierte en bonos del Tesoro y financia el propio d√©ficit de Washington. China no acumula d√≥lares en una caja fuerte. Los reinvierte en EE.UU., asegurando tasas de inter√©s bajas, cr√©dito accesible y estabilidad para el d√≥lar. La guerra comercial de Trump es como intentar frenar un tren de alta velocidad lanz√°ndole piedras. China sigue siendo la gran f√°brica del mundo no por salarios bajos, sino por hacer funcionar la econom√≠a real como un reloj suizo a escala continental.

title: A rajatabla: El aporte del sector monetario
content: Por Ori√≥n Mej√≠a.- No se exagera si se afirma que la estabilidad y crecimiento de la econom√≠a se sustentan en las pol√≠ticas monetarias asumidas por el Ba ...
resumen:
La estabilidad y crecimiento de la econom√≠a se sustentan en las pol√≠ticas monetarias asumidas por el Banco Central y la Junta Monetaria que garantizan tambi√©n el control de inflaci√≥n a trav√©s de oportunas inyecciones de liquidez y reducciones de la tasa de Pol√≠tica Monetaria (TPM).

El banco emisor asumi√≥ en 2023 un programa encaminado a alcanzar la meta de inflaci√≥n de 4%+-1%, con la reducci√≥n de la TPM, de 8.50% hasta 7.0%, en tanto que la Junta Monetaria aprob√≥ en 2023 un programa de expansi√≥n de liquidez, equivalente al 3% del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB), equivalente a 205 mil millones de pesos.

En 2024, las autoridades monetarias autorizaron una inyecci√≥n de liquidez a la econom√≠a de 175 mil millones de pesos, lo que permiti√≥ que el PIB cerrara en ese a√±o en un 5.0%, en cumplimiento de las metas de inflaci√≥n y estabilidad cambiaria, con una reducci√≥n de 275 puntos b√°sicos en la tasa de inter√©s de referencia.

El sector financiero exhibe gran fortaleza en t√©rminos de liquidez, rentabilidad y expansi√≥n del cr√©dito porque supo regentear los niveles de liquidez facilitados por el banco emisor desde la crisis sanitaria derivada de la pandemia del COVID 19, al punto que a marzo de este a√±o sus activos netos ascendieron a RD$3.9 billones, para un crecimiento interanual de 10.5%.

En enero y febrero de este a√±o, la econom√≠a apenas creci√≥ en 1.7% en t√©rmino interanual, pero en marzo, tuvo una expansi√≥n de 4.5%, lo que permiti√≥ que el trimestre cerrara con un promedio de 2,7%, en perspectivas de alcanzar a finales de 2025, un nivel superior al 4.0%.

La expansi√≥n del cr√©dito bancario, de un 17.5% interanual ha incidido en el crecimiento de sectores como construcci√≥n, manufactura, agropecuaria y exportaci√≥n, aunque tambi√©n la econom√≠a recibe el ox√≠geno de m√°s de 43 mil millones de d√≥lares que ingresan a trav√©s de turismo, remesas, inversiones, exportaciones y zonas francas.

El endeudamiento p√∫blico que al 31 de marzo se ubic√≥ en US$59,600.8 millones (47.1% del PIB), d√©ficit fiscal (3.0%) y baja inversi√≥n de capital (2.2%), sectores que el gobierno deber√≠a gestionar con mayor cuidado, para evitar da√±os irreversibles a la econom√≠a.

Los presidentes Leonel Fern√°ndez, Danilo Medina y Luis Abinader acertaron al nombrar y confirmar a H√©ctor Valdez Albizu, en la gobernaci√≥n del Banco Central.

title: Scott Bessent says Trump will raise tariffs again on any nation that doesn't negotiate in 'good faith'
content: Treasury Secretary Bessent told NBC that if nations don't want to negotiate with the US, then their tariffs will "spring back to the April 2nd level." ...
resumen:
Scott Bessent said on Sunday that Donald Trump could raise tariff rates again for certain nations.
"This means that they're not negotiating in good faith," Bessent told NBC's Kristen Welker.
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Sunday during an NBC interview that President Donald Trump will raise tariff rates again for nations that don't negotiate trade deals with the United States in "good faith."
During an interview on "Meet the Press," Bessent pointed to the higher tariffs imposed on myriad countries after Trump's April "Liberation Day" speech as a consequence of any failed talks.
"I think that it would be the April 2nd level," Bessent replied when asked by host Kristen Welker about the tariff rates some nations may face by the administration.
"Some countries were at 10%, some were substantially higher," he said. "The negotiating leverage that President Trump is talking about here is if you don't want to negotiate, then it will spring back to the April 2nd level."
Bessent also addressed Trump's remarks on Friday, when the president said nations may receive a letter from the administration outlining their effective tariff rate if talks are being held without sincerity.
"This means that they're not negotiating in good faith," Bessent said. "They are going to get a letter saying, 'Here is the rate.' So I expect that everyone would come and negotiate in good faith."
After Trump's "Liberation Day" speech, which sent global markets reeling, the president issued a 90-day pause on the higher "reciprocal" tariff rates that he sought to impose on numerous nations.
Instead, most countries have been subject to a baseline 10% tariff rate while they conduct their respective trade discussions with the US.
A notable exception has been China.
The US in April raised tariff rates on Chinese goods to a high of 145%.
Last week, the US temporarily cut the tariff rate on Chinese goods to 30% as the two countries continue to engage in high-level trade talks.
China also lowered its levies on US goods from 125% to 10%.
Earlier in May, the Trump administration announced a trade framework with the UK, with the US rescinding tariffs on British steel and automobiles and US farmers gaining increased market access in the UK.

title: El canciller paname√±o afirma que varios pa√≠ses reconocen que el Canal es de Panam√°
content: Ciudad de Panam√°, 18 may (EFE).- El canciller paname√±o, Javier Mart√≠nez-Acha, dijo este domingo que pa√≠ses como Portugal, Ghana o Argentina "entienden la realidad" de Panam√° y "reconocen, sin ninguna ...
resumen:
El canciller paname√±o, Javier Mart√≠nez-Acha, dijo este domingo que pa√≠ses como Portugal, Ghana o Argentina ¬´entienden la realidad¬ª de Panam√° y ¬´reconocen, sin ninguna duda¬ª, su soberan√≠a sobre el Canal.

Mart√≠nez-Acha aprovech√≥ su presencia en la entronizaci√≥n del papa Le√≥n XIV para ¬´saludar al primer ministro de Canad√°, Mark Carney, y al presidente de Paraguay, Santiago Pe√±a¬ª, y conversar ¬´con los ministros de Relaciones Exteriores de Portugal, Paulo Rangel; Ghana, Samuel Okudzeto Ablakwa; Argentina, Gerardo Werthein; Chile, Alberto van Klaveren, y Costa Rica, Arnoldo Tinoco¬ª.

Mart√≠nez-Acha declar√≥ que intercambiaron opiniones con jefes de Estado, primeros ministros y cancilleres, quienes est√°n en sinton√≠a con Panam√° y su causa y que expresaron una gran solidaridad con su pa√≠s porque entienden perfectamente su realidad y reconocen, sin ninguna duda, que el Canal es suyo.

El Canal de Panam√° ha estado en los √∫ltimos meses en el centro de una diatriba de Trump, que afirma que lo recuperar√° para EE.UU. por la influencia en la v√≠a de China, un extremo que ha negado reiteradamente el presidente paname√±o, Jos√© Ra√∫l Mulino.

EE.UU. construy√≥ a inicios del siglo XX el Canal y lo oper√≥ por m√°s de 80 a√±os, hasta su traspaso a Panam√° hace 25 a√±os, tal como lo establecieron los Tratados Torrijos-Carter de 1977.

La v√≠a se rige por un Tratado de Neutralidad que est√° vigente desde octubre de 1979 y que han suscrito unos 40 pa√≠ses.

Estados Unidos es el principal usuario del paso navegable de 82 kil√≥metros, con m√°s del 70 % de la carga que lo cruza saliendo o con destino a ese pa√≠s. Le siguen China y Jap√≥n.

Las carteras de seguridad de Panam√° y EE.UU. firmaron recientemente unos acuerdos que han sido objeto de controversia en el pa√≠s centroamericano porque ampl√≠an la presencia temporal y rotativa de personas castrense estadounidense.

Los cr√≠ticos afirman que los convenios violan el Tratado de Neutralidad, y han activado recursos ante el Supremo paname√±o para anularlos.

La Administraci√≥n de Mulino niega esa denuncia alegando que no se contempla el establecimiento de bases militares estadounidenses en el pa√≠s.

En Panam√°, un pa√≠s que solo cuenta con polic√≠as especializadas pues aboli√≥ su Ej√©rcito en 1990 tras la invasi√≥n de Estados Unidos en diciembre de 1989, no existen bases militares de EE.UU. en raz√≥n de los Tratados Torrijos-Carter de 1977.

Los acuerdos con EE.UU. ¬´refuerzan la capacidad de lucha¬ª de Panam√° ¬´en temas de delitos internacionales como narcotr√°fico, lavado de dinero, ciberterrorismo, etc.¬ª, ha dicho Mulino.

title: Utah economy, job creation lead the nation but aren‚Äôt safe from federal policies‚Äô impact
content: Utah‚Äôs rates on unemployment and job growth are surpassing national averages this year and the state has kept its top spot in economic outlook ranking. But, amid tariffs, and a dropping consumer ...
resumen: Utah‚Äôs rates on unemployment and job growth are surpassing national averages this year and the state has kept its top spot in economic outlook ranking. The state‚Äôs economy is outperforming other states, with jobs growing 2.1%, almost doubling the 1.2% national average. Utah also has some of the lowest unemployment rates, 3.1%, while that number remained unchanged at 4.2% nationally, according to a report from the Utah Department of Workforce Services released on Friday. ‚ÄúLabor market indicators remain robust, with broad job expansions across industries and a low unemployment rate,‚Äù Ben Crabb, chief economist with the department, said in a statement. The top private sector industries adding jobs to the state are education and health services, followed by construction and manufacturing. Nearly half of the state‚Äôs jobs are in Salt Lake County, and 1 in 4 jobs are in Salt Lake City, according to Kem C. Gardner Policy Institute data shared by Natalie Gochnour, the institute‚Äôs director, to the Salt Lake City Council on Tuesday. Utah also led the nation in gross domestic product growth in 2024 with 4.5%, compared to a 2.8% national average, and earned other top spots in the country, including one of the highest household incomes with cost of living adjustments, and the lowest poverty rate. Estimates indicate that there may be a recession during the last half of 2025, with the country‚Äôs gross domestic product falling 0.9% during the third quarter and 1.1% during the fourth quarter. The probability of a recession among most economists is somewhere in the 45% to 60% rate, according to Gochnour. The free fall of consumer sentiment in the country is already happening. A decline of job growth in leisure and hospitality is also felt in the state. That industry shrank by 400 jobs in the last year, the second-largest private sector decline after the trade, transportation and utilities industry, which experienced the loss of 2,300 jobs. The forecast for international visitation as of March is a 9.4% decline, according to Tourism Economics, an Oxford Economics research company. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints‚Äô remodeled Temple Square is expected to attract millions of visitors in 2027.

title: Tariffs Will Likely Lead To Price Increases, Bessent Says
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent conceded on Sunday that President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs could increase prices for consumers. Walmart CEO Doug ...
resumen:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent conceded on Sunday that President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs could increase prices for consumers.

Walmart CEO Doug McMillon announced on a Thursday earnings call that the company would raise its prices due to the tariffs after recording a slip in first-quarter profits, despite strong quarterly sales and a bump in operating profit.

During a Sunday appearance on ‚ÄúState of the Union,‚Äù Bessent said he spoke to McMillon, who told him that Walmart would potentially pass tariff-related costs on to American shoppers.

Bessent said Walmart will be absorbing some of the tariffs, and some may get passed on to consumers.

Bessent said inflation is down, and the administration has gotten gasoline prices down, and service prices are down.

Trump demanded that Walmart not pass on tariff-related costs to consumers in a Saturday post on Truth Social.

Republican Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul said Sunday on ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù that increased costs from tariffs are an inevitability.

Bessent said on ‚ÄúState of the Union‚Äù Sunday that he believed the Trump administration ‚Äúwill do a lot of regional deals,‚Äù meaning setting different tariff rates for different regions, including Central America and certain parts of Africa, according to Axios.

The treasury secretary also noted that the Trump administration is currently prioritizing ‚Äúthe 18 important trading relationships.‚Äù

Following trade negotiations in Geneva, Switzerland, the U.S. and China have temporarily dropped their tariffs on one another significantly.

China had previously endeavored to make inroads in Vietnam, Malaysia and Europe, following Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariff rollout in early April.

Trump on Friday asserted that his administration will soon tell certain countries in a letter what their tariff rates will be, Fortune reported.

A Reuters/Ipsos poll published April 23 showed that just 37% of respondents approved of the president‚Äôs management of the economy.

Political analyst Mark Halperin, former Democratic strategist Dan Turrentine and former White House press secretary Sean Spicer argued on May 5 that Democrats were failing to capitalize on what they viewed as poor political rhetoric by the president.
