title: Mark Carney talks about the difference his government plans to make for Canadians
content: Vassy Kapelos spoke this week with Carney about his plans for the Canadian economy, becoming an energy superpower, whether he will keep Bill C-69 and the emissions cap and renegotiating USMCA.
resumen:
Vassy Kapelos spoke with Prime Minister Mark Carney about his promise to Canadians.

Carney stated that Canada is in a crisis, the biggest in generations, due to American tariffs and changes in the global economy. He emphasized the need for big changes, focusing on affordability and increasing GDP per capita and productivity.

Carney mentioned that being an energy superpower involves both clean and conventional energies, including oil and gas, and using Canadian resources to displace imports. He also highlighted the importance of nuclear, hydro, and carbon capture and storage. He stated that building one pipeline alone wouldn't make Canada an energy superpower.

Carney said he would build a pipeline if consensus exists and that he has experience in major energy projects. He mentioned billions of dollars of financing for Indigenous partners and the importance of Canada's low risk, low cost, and low carbon approach.

Carney stated that he is interested in results regarding Bill C-69 and emissions caps and that they will rely on provincial environmental assessments.

Carney mentioned speaking with Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre and Regina-Qu‚ÄôAppelle MP Andrew Scheer.

Carney said that the relationship with the U.S. has changed and that the global economy is changing.

Carney stated that USMCA is an advantage and that they intend to make the most of their advantages in these negotiations.

title: Europe warned to change fast or become a ‚Äòshock absorber‚Äô of US-China trade war
content: Senior European Union officials are breathing a sigh of relief over a US-China tariff deal that may delay a diversion of Chinese exports to Europe. But they have been warned that the bloc must reform ...
resumen: Senior European Union officials are relieved over a US-China tariff deal that may delay a diversion of Chinese exports to Europe, but they have been warned that the bloc must reform quickly or become a ‚Äúshock absorber‚Äù of global trade imbalances. The climbdown in superpower tensions following talks in Geneva last weekend has led to a mutual reduction in tariffs. Economists said that the deal does not meaningfully change a bleak outlook for Europe if it fails to quickly adapt to Washington‚Äôs efforts to reorder trade with China and the rest of the world. Michael Pettis, a finance professor at Peking University, said that without deeper political integration and better coordination of fiscal and industrial policies, the ambition of Europe becoming a ‚Äúthird pole‚Äù in a bipolar world dominated by the US and China risks remaining a slogan rather than a strategy. Pettis added that Europe might become a shock absorber, forced to adjust to the choices of others without shaping the outcomes. The US currently represents nearly half of global deficits, and with the UK and Canada they together comprise roughly two-thirds of all deficits. Pettis believed that the US would put pressure on others to reduce their deficits. Pettis, also affiliated with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said that either global surpluses must come down, or some other part of the world must run the large deficits needed to balance global surpluses, and for all practical purposes this mostly means Europe. European governments viewed the Sino-American deal as possibly buying them time on what is anticipated to be a wave of diverted Chinese exports to EU ports. Michal Baranowski, Poland‚Äôs deputy minister for development and technology, said that the US-China agreement was ‚Äúa good first step‚Äù and that with US-China tensions de-escalating, Europe is less likely to see trade diversion. Observers have warned that this development must not distract the EU from the significant internal reform required to survive in a harsh new world order. The bloc is divided on areas of industrial policies that may afford it better financial means to compete with the US and China. New German Chancellor Friedrich Merz appeared last week to rule out EU-wide joint borrowing. Luis Garicano of the London School of Economics and a former member of the European Parliament urged the EU to shift its focus to reducing barriers within its own 27-member bloc rather than chase free-trade agreements. Garicano wrote that the hidden cost of trading goods inside the EU is the equivalent of a 45 per cent tariff, and for services, the figure climbs to 110 per cent. The EU is expected to adopt a multipronged approach of trying to cut trade deals with partners including India and the Mercosur group of South America as it also negotiates directly with the economic superpowers themselves. Talks with the US continue, with trade chief Maros Sefcovic speaking with US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick by phone on Wednesday. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said this week that the US and Europe may be a bit slower. Brussels officials are awaiting the first assessments of a task force set up to monitor the impact of Trump‚Äôs tariffs on trade flows. Customs statistics suggest that circumstances may have changed even in the short window in which the US and China maintained mutual tariffs north of 120 per cent. Chinese trade data for April showed declines in Chinese shipments to the US and big jumps in shipments to Europe. A 21 per cent drop in China‚Äôs shipments to the US was mirrored by a 20.44 per cent leap in China‚Äôs shipments to Germany. In April, China‚Äôs EU imports fell 16.46 per cent. Bloomberg reported that China‚Äôs trade surplus with the EU reached a record US$90 billion in the first four months of 2025. Brussels seeks to convince Beijing to take action that would address the potential trade diversion and China‚Äôs manufacturing overcapacity. Marjut Hannonen, head of trade for the EU delegation in China, said that the overcapacity problem is huge, growing, massive and goes across the sectors, and that China is just doubling down on more manufacturing capacity. Talks between French and Chinese ministers this week failed to yield a deal that would see tariffs lifted on France‚Äôs cognac imports, French Finance Minister Eric Lombard said. Yanmei Xie, an independent analyst of China‚Äôs political economy based in Barcelona, said that the EU‚Äôs efforts to get Beijing to change were likely doomed to failure. Xie said that overcapacity is a feature not a bug in the Chinese model of techno-industrial upgrade through relentless manufacturing scaling.

title: Japanese Yen and Aussie Dollar Forecasts: China Stats and Trade Headlines in Focus
content: AUD/USD outlook tied to China‚Äôs economic health and RBA bets. Weak data or trade war flare-ups could push the Aussie toward key support levels.
resumen:
Japan‚Äôs Tertiary Index drop may hit Q1 GDP, weakening BoJ rate hike bets and weighing on the Yen.
AUD/USD hinges on China data and US-China trade news; weak numbers may drive Aussie below key support.
A 0.25% RBA rate cut is 96% priced; markets expect three cuts by year-end.
Economists forecast the Tertiary Industry Index to drop 0.2% month-on-month in March after holding steady in February.
The tertiary sector contributes roughly 70% to Japan‚Äôs GDP.
Later in Monday‚Äôs session, Fed speakers will influence sentiment toward the Fed rate path and US dollar appetite.
The Fed‚Äôs Bostic, Williams, and Jefferson are on the calendar to speak.
Rising support for a Q3 Fed rate cut would weaken US dollar demand, sending USD/JPY toward the May 6 low of 142.350.
Calls to delay Fed rate cuts on labor market resilience and tariff uncertainties could drive USD/JPY above the 50-day EMA toward the 149.358 resistance level.
Bearish USD/JPY Scenario: Escalating trade tensions, stronger Japan data, or dovish Fed chatter may drag USD/JPY below 142.5.
Bullish USD/JPY Scenario: Easing trade tensions, weak Japan data, or hawkish Fed rhetoric may support a move above the 50-day EMA toward 149.358.
On May 19, China‚Äôs economic data will dictate AUD/USD trends amid ongoing US-China trade developments.
Key stats, including retail sales, unemployment, and industrial production, could reflect the effects of US tariffs on manufacturing, the labor market, and domestic consumption.
Weaker-than-expected data could signal weakened demand, impacting Aussie trade terms as China accounts for one-third of Australian exports.
Australia has a trade-to-GDP ratio above 50%.
Bearish Aussie dollar Scenario: Escalating US-China tensions, weak China data, or dovish RBA rhetoric may send AUD/USD toward the $0.63623 support level and the 50-day EMA.
Bullish Aussie dollar Scenario: Easing US-China trade tensions, upbeat China data, Beijing stimulus, or hawkish RBA signals could drive the pair above the 200-day EMA toward the May 14 high of $0.65008.
Markets are pricing in three RBA rate cuts.
Shane Oliver, AMP‚Äôs Head of Investment Strategy and Chief Economist, stated: ‚ÄúThe Australian money market post the jobs data has priced in a 96% probability of a 0.25% RBA rate cut on Tuesday with three 0.25% rate cuts priced in by year end.‚Äù.
Hawkish Fed signals could widen the US-Aussie interest rate differential in favor of the US dollar.
A less dovish Fed stance may send AUD/USD toward the $0.63623 support level and the 50-day EMA.
Support for a Q3 2025 Fed rate cut may narrow the rate differential.
A more dovish Fed could drive AUD/USD above the 200-day EMA toward $0.65144.
Key Market Drivers to Watch Today:
USD/JPY: US-Japan trade talks, services sector data, and BoJ commentary.
USD/JPY and AUD/USD: Fed forward guidance and global trade headlines.
AUD/USD: US-China trade developments, China data, RBA signals, and Beijing stimulus-related news.

title: Gold may see pullback in the near term amid growing signs of easing US-China trade tensions
content: Gold prices saw a significant pullback at the start of April after reports confirmed that precious metals were excluded from President Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariffs. Additionally, Federal Reserve Chair ...
resumen:
Gold may see a pullback in the near term amid growing signs of easing US-China trade tensions.

Gold prices saw a significant pullback at the start of April after reports confirmed that precious metals were excluded from President Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariffs.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell adopted a hawkish stance, warning that tariff-driven inflation could dampen economic growth and delay any potential rate cuts.

Gold briefly dropped to $2,970 but rebounded strongly, driven by a collapsing U.S. dollar, which fell to a 35-month low of 99.01, and China‚Äôs imposition of aggressive 125% retaliatory tariffs.

In April 2025, COMEX gold futures surged over 18% from their monthly low to an all-time high of more than $3,509 per ounce in late April.

The rally lost momentum in the final week as gold prices corrected sharply to below $3,210 amid easing geopolitical tensions and a rebound in the U.S. dollar.

COMEX gold closed April with a 4.5% gain, marking its fourth consecutive monthly rise.

MCX gold futures also rose over 14.5% from April lows but ended 5% higher for the month after retreating from all-time highs of ‚Çπ99,558 per 10 grams to around ‚Çπ94,600.

Gold prices faced another setback in the second week of May, hovering near a one-month low, weighed down by improved global risk sentiment and reduced safe-haven demand following significant progress in U.S.-China trade negotiations.

Both nations agreed to temporarily lower tariffs on each other‚Äôs goods for 90 days, with the U.S. reducing the combined tariff rate on Chinese imports to 30% from 145%, and China lowering its levies on U.S. imports to 10% from 125%.

The Federal Reserve‚Äôs hawkish comments added to the bearish momentum. Chair Jerome Powell highlighted rising inflationary pressures and risks in the labor market, ruling out any preemptive rate cuts due to trade-related uncertainties.

Gold is currently trading near $3,230 per ounce.

Markets are now pricing in only 50 basis points of easing this year, with a 50% probability of a 25 basis point cut in September, which could limit gold‚Äôs upside.

Hedge funds have begun unwinding long positions, with CFTC data showing net long futures and options at a 14-month low.

A stronger dollar and higher Treasury yields have also weighed on bullion.

Further signs of easing U.S.-China trade tensions, following the U.S. announcement of plans to lower the "de minimis" tariff threshold for low-value Chinese shipments to 30%, are likely to keep gold prices under pressure in the near term.

Technically, COMEX gold has key support at $3,170, with a broader demand zone between $3,050‚Äì$3,090. A breakdown below $3,050 could expose $2,900. On the upside, sustained strength above $3,320 and a breakout beyond $3,450 could target $3,700.

On MCX, ‚Çπ91,500 is crucial support, with resistance at ‚Çπ94,800 and ‚Çπ97,900, beyond which gold could rally towards ‚Çπ1,03,800.

COMEX silver futures settled 5% lower in April, near $32.80 per ounce, despite recovering over 19% from an eight-month low of $27.50.

COMEX silver futures have been trading in a narrow range of $31.8‚Äì$33.5 per ounce so far in May, following a 5% decline in April despite a strong 19% rebound from an eight-month low of $27.50.

Currently, Comex silver trades below $33 per ounce.

title: Trade tensions remain on edge
content: After the US announced on April 9 it would temporarily suspend tariff hikes on several countries for 90 days, the global trade sector breathed a sigh of relief.
resumen: Trade tensions remain on edge despite China reaching an agreement with the US to pause tariffs for 90 days. After the US announced on April 9 it would temporarily suspend tariff hikes on several countries for 90 days, the global trade sector breathed a sigh of relief. Yet trade tensions remain elevated even after China reached an interim agreement with the US on May 12 to pause tariffs for a period of 90 days for further negotiations to take place. Negotiations with other countries have progressed, as the UK recently concluded a vague trade deal with the US, while Japan completed two rounds of negotiations. However, on Friday US President Donald Trump said the country will not negotiate on tariffs with most nations, instead sending letters to them detailing tariff rates. Thailand has registered slower progress, sparking concerns in the business community as the timeline regarding its tariff suspension is elapsing. With China set to benefit from the 90-day pause, Thailand may find itself at a competitive disadvantage if its negotiations are not concluded promptly. Dhanakorn Kasetrsuwan, chairman of the Thai National Shippers' Council (TNSC), said the US-China agreement to pause their reciprocal tariffs for 90 days has created an advantageous window for China that's about a month longer than many other countries. The TNSC urged the government to swiftly negotiate with the US to maintain tariff benefits and collaborate with the private sector to initiate strategies to counteract potential challenges. Temporary price adjustments in key markets should also be considered, he said. While analysts assess China's negotiations as being difficult, Mr Dhanakorn said Beijing may leverage this period to secure a special deal extending the tariff pause, gaining advantages for particular products, or establishing government-to-government agreements. He said Thailand could be affected in two ways. On the negative side, China might quickly enter markets with lower prices, especially Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar and Vietnam, along with the Middle East and Africa -- areas Thailand is focusing on. On the positive side, if any agreements help ease trade tensions, Thailand could experience indirect benefits through lower shipping costs and a strengthened supply chain, although these advantages may be limited, said Mr Dhanakorn. Thailand must monitor the trade stances of China and the US because their decisions can significantly influence the global market, he said. The government should also introduce measures to help stabilise Thai businesses, said Mr Dhanakorn. Moreover, the role of commercial diplomats should be strengthened to ensure detailed information is available to the private sector, allowing for quick adaptations to any shifts in the situation, he said. Kriengkrai Thiennukul, chairman of the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI), said the US-China agreement to pause tariffs should not be considered a signal their trade conflict will stop. The world's two largest economies have competed with each other for years, taking turns adjusting tariffs on each other's imports. The conflict is unlikely to be easily resolved, meaning Thailand should brace for potentially unpleasant impacts to its economy, said Mr Kriengkrai. The global economy continues to be uncertain, with manufacturers in many countries affected by the US's reciprocal tariff policy. The FTI warned the government about an influx of goods from China and other countries into Asia, including Thailand, following the announcement of the US reciprocal tariffs on many countries. The 90-day pause provides an opportunity for the Thai government to push for new measures to better protect local industries, said Mr Kriengkrai. The Joint Standing Committee on Commerce, Industry and Banking earlier called on the government to enforce legal measures against the influx of low-cost Chinese products into the Thai market, which is expected to intensify this year. Current measures are inadequate to protect manufacturers in the country, the committee said. Among the efforts already implemented by the government are the Customs Department's imposition of the 7% value-added tax on imports valued less than 1,500 baht, seeking to decelerate their sales, and the Thai Industrial Standard Institute's more frequent inspections of products listed on online platforms. Local manufacturers are not only concerned about the impact of harsh US tariffs on Thai exports, but also reduced sales if the country is flooded with Chinese imports, according to the FTI. Chinese goods are 20-40% less expensive than Thai goods, said ML Peekthong Thongyai, vice-chairman of the FTI, referring to an FTI poll. Roughly 45% of 540 executives and members of the FTI said this price gap was noticeable when Thai and Chinese products were compared, while 21.1% said Chinese imports were only 10-20% cheaper. Chinese entrepreneurs have the advantage of lower costs and better technology, said ML Peekthong. Poj Aramwattananont, chairman of the Thai Chamber of Commerce, said the recent trade discussions between the US and China offer promise for constructive negotiations that could benefit other nations. He said the Thai government should pursue negotiations with the US, and the chamber submitted a proposal to the administration it considers to be appropriate and advantageous. However, Mr Poj said any proposal concerning tariff reductions must safeguard Thailand's agricultural sector. He said several major Thai companies, including Banpu Plc and Thai Union Plc, are eager to explore investment opportunities in the US. Mr Dhanakorn of the TNSC agreed the US-China trade dialogue is a positive development. He said he anticipates reduced trade tensions in the short term, as both countries are motivated by the desire to maintain economic stability and ease global tensions. Yet Mr Dhanakorn said the conditions governing these negotiations must be monitored. In the meantime, he said Thailand should broaden its export markets, especially in Southeast Asia, the Middle East and India, to reduce dependence on primary markets. Furthermore, the country must work on enhancing its competitiveness by adopting technology for production, implementing environmental, social and governance practices, and elevating product standards to international levels, said Mr Dhanakorn. The TNSC supports negotiations for an Asean-US FTA, said Mr Dhanakorn. While Asean has an FTA with China, it lacks a similar agreement with other significant consumer markets such as the US. Thienprasit Chaiyapatranun, president of the Thai Hotels Association, said the 90-day tariff pause between the US and China offers short-term relief for the global market and the tourism industry. He said the pause may signal greater opportunities for all countries to negotiate trade deals to benefit their economies. While the pause is temporary, Mr Thienprasit said it offers optimism to prospective travellers planning overseas trips this year, including the Chinese market, as well as foreign visitors from both leisure and business segments. As a consequence, Thailand's stagnant inbound market can expect some uplift, he said. Since Trump's initial announcement of the tariff hikes in April, some people have delayed their travel plans, concerned about the economic impact and awaiting clearer developments in the trade war, said Mr Thienprasit. Although most business and meeting events have continued as scheduled, there were fewer foreign attendees than expected due to tighter budgets for overseas trips by companies wary of economic uncertainty, he said. Mr Thienprasit suggested during this period, Thailand should continue to promote itself as a welcoming tourism destination, with attractive sites and events, while also focusing on restoring safety, the country's image and tourist confidence. Fitch Ratings said the joint statement on

title: South-East Asian countries need to navigate shifting trade patterns
content: AS the United States and Europe have sought to loosen their economic ties with China in recent years, Beijing has focused on expanding its export markets across the "Global South", particularly in ...
resumen: As the United States and Europe have sought to loosen their economic ties with China in recent years, Beijing has focused on expanding its export markets across the ‚ÄúGlobal South‚Äù, particularly in South-East Asia. This could create significant economic risks as the region‚Äôs manufacturers struggle to compete. Beijing‚Äôs exports to America seem destined to continue falling, as do those to the European Union (EU). The EU has been seeking to ‚Äúde-risk‚Äù from Chinese imports and supply chains, particularly when it comes to electric vehicles (EVs), batteries and solar power equipment. China‚Äôs exports to the United States and the EU have already been declining steadily for years. In 2018, almost 20% of China‚Äôs exports were to the United States. By 2024, this was down to 14.7%. The proportion of exports to the EU also declined, from 17% to 14.4% during this period. China has been reducing its export dependence on all developed economies, including Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. Instead, the manufacturing powerhouse has been expanding ties with the ‚ÄúGlobal South‚Äù, particularly Asean. In fact, 16.4% of China‚Äôs exports went to Asean in 2024. China‚Äôs focus on Asean accelerated after the 2018 trade war that started during US President Donald Trump‚Äôs first term. Vietnam‚Äôs incremental exports to the United States matched its incremental imports from China almost exactly in the first few years after the beginning of the previous Trump trade spat. The Trump administration originally slapped staggeringly high ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs on Asean economies on April 2, partly to hinder this export re-routing. Several South-East Asian governments have begun to crack down on violations of ‚Äúcountry of origin‚Äù rules by their exporters. Chinese exports to Asean economies are currently mostly intermediate goods that are re-processed and exported, but that is starting to change as more finished goods are ending up in Asia‚Äôs domestic markets. These Asean imports of low-priced finished goods from China, many sold through eCommerce platforms, have already become a bugbear for local manufacturers, particularly in Indonesia and Thailand. In Indonesia, as imports of Chinese clothing have risen in recent years, the country‚Äôs own textile sector has laid off workers, including 80,000 in 2024, with 280,000 more estimated to be at risk in 2025. In Thailand, more than 100 factories, mostly small and medium-sized enterprises, closed down every month from 2021 to 2024. According to independent think tank K- Research, these factories were mostly manufacturing furniture, electronics, garments, automotive and steel. Chinese foreign direct investment is also surging in Asean, particularly in the ‚ÄúNew Three‚Äù sectors: EVs, batteries and solar energy. Chinese automaker BYD commissioned a 150,000-unit EV factory in Thailand in July 2024, and Chinese battery maker CATL announced a US$5.8bil investment in Indonesia‚Äôs nickel sector in 2023, though that was recently scaled back by half. While these investments have created jobs and helped Asean‚Äôs integration into global supply chains, they have also disrupted local supply chains. In Thailand, oversupply of EVs has led to price wars and production cuts in the country‚Äôs traditional auto market, resulting in the closure of a dozen of the country‚Äôs auto parts manufacturers. Manufacturing seems to be stagnating across the region. Manufacturing purchasing managers indices are currently in the contractionary zone and on a steadily declining path in all the large Asean economies. China‚Äôs Asean trade partners will need to navigate today‚Äôs ever-shifting trade and investment landscape with great care and trepidation.

title: La estrategia comercial con China no existe
content: Los √∫ltimos presidentes han tenido a China como un reto comercial, pero las pol√≠ticas son cortoplacistas y carecen de una estrategia a largo plazo en la ...
resumen:
La estrategia comercial con China no existe.

Los √∫ltimos presidentes han tenido a China como un reto comercial, pero las pol√≠ticas son cortoplacistas y carecen de una estrategia a largo plazo en la que ganen las exportaciones.

El presidente Petro ha cometido un error de c√°lculo diplom√°tico y comercial al correr a los cuarteles chinos tras el incidente de los aranceles con Estados Unidos durante la Semana Santa pasada, pero m√°s se ha equivocado cuando en medio todos esos afanes no ha preparado una estrategia a largo plazo con la segunda econom√≠a del mundo y f√°brica global.

Los pa√≠ses que mejor negocian con China en la regi√≥n son Brasil, Chile y Per√∫, econom√≠as que hoy cuentan con China como su primer socio comercial. Brasil pas√≥ de vender unos US$1.000 millones a comienzo del siglo XXI a m√°s de US$130.000 millones el a√±o pasado.

China ha desarrollado cientos de grandes compa√±√≠as p√∫blicas como Huawei, Xiomi, BYD, TikTok, Lenovo, Alibaba.

China no negocia con discursos ideol√≥gicos como en la Guerra Fr√≠a.

La visita de Petro a ese pa√≠s careci√≥ de un trabajo t√©cnico anterior, no se llevaron propuestas a largo plazo, y mucho menos, fueron empresarios interesados en exportar o importar.

Brillaron por su ausencia los empresarios interesados; m√°s cafeteros, floricultores, manufactureros, textileros y hasta importadores de carros y motos.

El memorando de entendimiento para la adhesi√≥n a la nueva ruta de la seda no deja de ser un canto a la bandera y as√≠ lo entendieron los chinos que a rengl√≥n seguido no le quitaron la visa a los colombianos interesados en hacer negocios con China.

Estados Unidos no dej√≥ que Petro se bajara del avi√≥n presidencial y sentenci√≥ que no avalar√° cr√©ditos de multilaterales para obras de infraestructura desarrolladas por constructoras chinas.

Las relaciones comerciales con Estados Unidos y China no deben ser excluyentes como un principio de comercio nacional, eso se debe tener como pilar fundamental por una pol√≠tica de estado, pero nos olvidamos que no hay ni ministro de Comercio Exterior en medio de esta situaci√≥n.

title: Trump critica a Walmart por aumento de precios, vinculado a aranceles de su administraci√≥n

resumen: El ministro de Desarrollo Econ√≥mico (SDE), Fredis Cerrato, manifest√≥ que se sigue haciendo an√°lisis para lograr un Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) entre Honduras y CHINA. title: El ‚Äúcomplejo de dios‚Äù de Trump y sus pol√≠ticas ego√≠stas
content: La autora Roya Pour Bagher se√±ala que: La implementaci√≥n de pol√≠ticas ego√≠stas no es un fen√≥meno aislado de Donald Trump; es m√°s bien la naturaleza del Estado de ese pa√≠s, el mismo sistema fundado en ...
resumen:
La autora Roya Pour Bagher se√±ala que la implementaci√≥n de pol√≠ticas ego√≠stas no es un fen√≥meno aislado de Donald Trump; es m√°s bien la naturaleza del Estado de ese pa√≠s, el mismo sistema fundado en el genocidio de los ind√≠genas estadounidenses.

El 3 de mayo, en la cuenta Truth Social de Donald Trump y en las redes sociales oficiales de la Casa Blanca, se present√≥ como papa usando IA. Aproximadamente una semana antes, Trump hab√≠a expresado su deseo de ser papa.

Las recientes acciones de Trump recuerdan al expresidente estadounidense George W. Bush. Algunos informes indican que Bush afirm√≥ en privado haber recibido instrucciones divinas para invadir Irak y Afganist√°n. Bush dijo: "Me impulsa una misi√≥n de Dios". Dios me dec√≠a: "George, ve y lucha contra estos terroristas en Afganist√°n". Y lo hac√≠a. Y luego Dios me dec√≠a: "George, ve y acaba con la tiran√≠a en Irak". Y lo hac√≠a.

Esta ret√≥rica grandilocuente ayuda a justificar pol√≠ticas ego√≠stas y refuerza el dominio de las √©lites sobre los principios democr√°ticos.

La reciente introducci√≥n de una lista de exenciones arancelarias que impact√≥ a muchos es un ejemplo de las maniobras pol√≠ticas ego√≠stas de Trump. El prop√≥sito de los aranceles supuestamente era el logro de los objetivos econ√≥micos de "Estados Unidos Primero". Sin embargo, algunos de los elementos de la lista de exenciones de Trump se basaron en criterios ambiguos y, m√°s notablemente, parecen proteger industrias en las que residen los intereses de su c√≠rculo m√°s cercano.

Uno de los art√≠culos exentos es un termopl√°stico utilizado en la fabricaci√≥n de botellas de pl√°stico, lo que beneficia enormemente a Reyes Holdings. Los propietarios de esta empresa han contribuido millones a causas republicanas.

Trump public√≥ en Truth Social: "¬°Este es un gran momento para comprar!", horas antes de anunciar la pausa de 90 d√≠as en los aranceles. En el Despacho Oval, presumi√≥ de que sus amigos multimillonarios hab√≠an ganado grandes sumas de dinero gracias a esa decisi√≥n: ¬°Gan√≥ dos mil 500 millones de d√≥lares y 900 millones! ¬°No est√° nada mal!.

Las acusaciones de manipulaci√≥n del mercado y uso de informaci√≥n privilegiada se multiplicaron, y los senadores exigieron que se prohibieran esas pr√°cticas, as√≠ como la divulgaci√≥n de las transacciones realizadas esos d√≠as.

Trump promovi√≥ la hidroxicloroquina como tratamiento durante la pandemia de la covid-19, lo que provoc√≥ un aumento en el valor de las acciones de las empresas vinculadas al f√°rmaco. Las investigaciones tambi√©n revelaron v√≠nculos entre Trump y sus donantes con los fabricantes del medicamento. El f√°rmaco en cuesti√≥n nunca demostr√≥ su eficacia en el tratamiento de la covid-19, se ha asociado con efectos secundarios graves y podr√≠a haber contribuido a miles de muertes.

En diciembre de 2019, Trump fue sometido a un juicio pol√≠tico por retener ayuda militar a Ucrania. Un resumen de una llamada telef√≥nica revel√≥ que Trump intentaba presionar para que se investigara a su rival pol√≠tico, el hijo de Biden. En enero de 2021, fue sometido a un nuevo juicio pol√≠tico por acusaciones de fraude electoral e incitaci√≥n a los disturbios del Capitolio.

El complejo de dios de Trump y sus pol√≠ticas ego√≠stas se enmarcan en la estructura de dominaci√≥n clasista del gobierno estadounidense. El gobierno federal estadounidense est√° fuertemente influenciado por una intrincada red de √©lites que controlan los recursos econ√≥micos y las instituciones pol√≠ticas. Estas √©lites suelen tener la capacidad de formular pol√≠ticas que favorecen sus intereses.

Existen informes que sugieren que la administraci√≥n de Obama pudo haber filtrado selectivamente informaci√≥n clasificada en 2012, conocida como la "Lista de Asesinatos", para presentarlo como un l√≠der fuerte en seguridad nacional y as√≠ impulsar su campa√±a de reelecci√≥n. En 1972, un grupo vinculado al equipo del presidente Nixon irrumpi√≥ en la sede del Comit√© Nacional Dem√≥crata en el Hotel Watergate para apoyar su campa√±a de reelecci√≥n. El esc√°ndalo Watergate oblig√≥ a Nixon a dimitir. En 1921, la administraci√≥n del presidente Harding estuvo involucrada en el esc√°ndalo conocido como "Teapot Dome ", por la explotaci√≥n de recursos naturales en terrenos p√∫blicos.

El gobierno estadounidense implementa sus pol√≠ticas bajo la apariencia de un complejo de salvador, con la ayuda de la √©lite que lo manipula en el escenario de la democracia estadounidense.

title: How global millionaires are using the golden visa to buy their American Dream
content: The US Golden Visa is an attractive option for people around the globe. It combines the promise of opportunity, education, and security, making it one of the most powerful draws for wealthy individual ...
resumen:
The US Golden Visa, specifically the EB-5 Immigrant Investor Visa, is a popular option for wealthy individuals seeking US residency. It offers a direct path to permanent residency (Green Card) through investment in projects that create jobs and stimulate the US economy.

The EB-5 program is attractive because it provides a relatively fast way for investors and their families to secure permanent residency and potentially US citizenship. It also provides access to world-class education and employment opportunities. Children of EB-5 investors can attend public schools and may be eligible for in-state tuition at top universities. Unlike many other visa categories, EB-5 does not require a US sponsor.

The EB-5 visa requires an investment of $800,000 in a Targeted Employment Area (TEA) or $1.05 million elsewhere into a new business that creates at least 10 full-time US jobs. The program covers the investor, spouse, and unmarried children under 21, with eligibility for US citizenship after five years of residency.

The process involves choosing a qualifying investment, selecting direct or regional center investment, filing Form I-526E (or I-526), awaiting USCIS approval, applying for a visa or adjusting status, receiving a conditional Green Card (2 years), filing Form I-829 (Remove Conditions), and optionally applying for US citizenship after 5 years.

US Green Card holders enjoy easier access to several countries.

The EB-5 visa grants conditional permanent residency, and investors must prove that their investment has created at least 10 full-time jobs for US workers and that the investment is sustained. After two years, investors must file Form I-829 to remove the conditions on their green card.

To apply for US citizenship, one must meet the residency requirements: a 5-year period of continuous residence in the US as a Green Card holder, during which you cannot stay outside the US for more than 6 months at a time. You must also be physically present in the US for at least 30 months of the five years.

As a US Green Card holder, you are considered a tax resident and must report and pay taxes on worldwide income.

The US Gold Card Visa, a proposed immigration initiative, is designed to provide affluent foreign nationals with a fast-tracked route to US permanent residency and eventual citizenship in return for a $5 million investment. The EB-5 is based on economic contribution and job creation, whereas the Gold Card would be based purely on financial payment.

title: Dos Momentos Claves ‚Äì Matices y Contradicciones
content: En este mes de mayo se han celebrado dos momentos de trascendental importancia en la evoluci√≥n del mundo hacia relaciones internacionales.
resumen:
En mayo se celebraron dos eventos de importancia: el 9 de mayo en Mosc√∫, el 80 Aniversario de la Victoria sobre el nazismo en 1945 y el 13 de mayo en Beijing, la Cuarta Reuni√≥n Ministerial del Foro China CELAC. Ambos eventos marcaron momentos claves en la creaci√≥n del nuevo orden mundial.

El 80 Aniversario de la Victoria de la Uni√≥n Sovi√©tica en la Gran Guerra Patri√≥tica fue un tema central, destacando el sacrificio de los pueblos sovi√©ticos. A la celebraci√≥n asistieron los presidentes Xi Jinping de China, Lula da Silva de Brasil y jefes de gobierno o Estado de Abjasia, Armenia, Burkina Faso, Bielorrusia, Bosnia y Herzegovina, Congo, Cuba, Egipto, Etiop√≠a, Guinea Bissau, Guinea Ecuatorial, Kazajst√°n, Kirguist√°n, Laos, Mongolia, Myanmar, Osetia del Sur, Palestina, Serbia, Eslovaquia, Rep√∫blica Sprska, Turkmenist√°n, Uzbekist√°n, Venezuela, Vietnam y Zimbabue. India, Nicaragua y Sud√°frica enviaron delegaciones de alto nivel. Azerbaiy√°n envi√≥ una unidad militar. Tambi√©n estuvieron presentes secretarios generales de la Organizaci√≥n de Cooperaci√≥n de Shanghai, la Confederaci√≥n de Estados Independientes, La Organizaci√≥n del Tratado de Seguridad Colectiva, la Uni√≥n Econ√≥mica Eurasi√°tica, la Organizaci√≥n de Cooperaci√≥n Isl√°mica, la Comisi√≥n de la Uni√≥n Africana y la presidenta del Nuevo Banco para el Desarrollo. El presidente Putin se reuni√≥ con m√°s de la mitad de los l√≠deres presentes, incluyendo a Xi Jinping, Nicol√°s Maduro, Miguel D√≠az-Canel y Lula da Silva.

La Cuarta Reuni√≥n Ministerial del Foro China CELAC en Beijing fue un reconocimiento de la realidad por las naciones de Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe. Se proyectaron los dilemas provocados por el enfrentamiento entre las pol√≠ticas neoliberales occidentales y el socialismo. El Foro elabor√≥ un Plan de Acci√≥n para fomentar la cooperaci√≥n entre China y los pa√≠ses de la CELAC en √°reas importantes durante el per√≠odo 2025-2027. China se comprometi√≥ a trabajar en conjunto con los pa√≠ses de Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe para promover la seguridad humana en Hait√≠. Se anunci√≥ una coordinaci√≥n para la COP 30 sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico en Brasil en noviembre y para la Segunda Conferencia Internacional sobre Reforma Agraria y Desarrollo Rural en Colombia en febrero 2026. Wang Yi, Ministro de Asuntos Exteriores de China, se reuni√≥ con varios Cancilleres, incluyendo el de M√©xico y Bolivia. El presidente de la junta directiva del Congreso Nacional Popular de China, Zhao Leji, se reuni√≥ con los presidentes del Parlamento Latinoamericano y Caribe√±o y del Parlamento Centroamericano.

title: Trade war truce isn‚Äôt cause for complacency
content: Despite a temporary tariff ceasefire between the United States and China, Asian economies need to strengthen RCEP as a response to a trade war that is likely to grind on ...
resumen: The temporary tariff reduction between the United States and China has been likened to a ceasefire in an ongoing trade war, but the long-term stability of the agreement remains uncertain and inflationary effects persist. US tariffs on Chinese imports have been reset at a baseline rate of 30 per cent, down from a peak of 145 per cent, and have fallen from 125 per cent to 10 per cent on the Chinese side. The US numbers remain higher for key exports like steel, aluminium and electric vehicles, while China continues to impose elevated tariffs on American agricultural products and semiconductors. The White House was finally spooked by the potential political consequences of chaos in financial markets, inflation spikes and empty shelves that loomed if the China tariffs remained at their peak. Trump‚Äôs approval rating is hovering in the low 40s. The fact not recognised well enough by the White House was that in this trade war China had escalation dominance. Even if the 30 per cent baseline agreed to in Geneva sticks, it‚Äôs hard to see which of the competing (and indeed contradictory) rationales for the tariffs offered by the Trump administration is actually being served. Many analysts say it won‚Äôt be high enough to make many Chinese manufactured goods uncompetitive in US markets, though it is probably high enough to have inflationary effects. The rest of Asia has to be prepared for the US‚ÄìChina trade war to grind on, with cycles of thaws and flare-ups, based on the long-term Trumpist goal of decoupling. The United States will continue to politicise trade ‚Äî accusing many Southeast Asian economies in particular of being sites for ‚ÄòChina-washing‚Äô manufactured exports, ignoring the complexities of regional economies‚Äô participation in China-centred value chains. A core goal of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) agreement was to put ASEAN in the driving seat of a framework to enable the deepening of genuinely trans-regional value chains. RCEP‚Äôs as-yet relatively modest requirements of its members and the breadth of its membership are two sides of the same coin. Because it excludes potential spoilers like Russia, India and the United States, ‚ÄòRCEP-based processes are less likely to be undermined by geopolitical splits and differences of perceived economic interest of the kind that affect other regional platforms such as the East Asia Summit, or bedevil the G20 process globally‚Äô. RCEP has important potential as a platform for consolidating the political consensus in favour of East Asia‚Äôs continued integration and managing any disagreements ‚Äî regardless of whatever attacks on that project emanate from the United States. Top of the to-do list for ASEAN governments ‚Äî to whose long-term development strategies RCEP is attuned and who badly need to reaffirm, through concrete action, ASEAN‚Äôs much-vaunted centrality ‚Äî is to use the rest of Malaysia‚Äôs 2025 chair year to put political capital and bureaucratic energy towards rescuing RCEP from going to waste in managing the crisis that the world now faces.

title: Comex da luz verde para que Ecuador inicie negociaciones comerciales con EE. UU.
content: El Comit√© de Comercio Exterior emiti√≥ un dictamen favorable para empezar di√°logos de cara a la firma de un acuerdo marco sobre comercio rec√≠proco.
resumen:
El Comit√© de Comercio Exterior (Comex) emiti√≥ un dictamen favorable para que el Ministerio de Producci√≥n, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca (MPCEIP) empiece negociaciones comerciales con Estados Unidos.

A trav√©s de la resoluci√≥n 005-2025, del 13 de mayo, el pleno del Comex emiti√≥ un dictamen favorable previo para que el Ministerio de Producci√≥n ‚Äúinicie las negociaciones‚Äù entre Ecuador y Estados Unidos, ‚Äúencaminadas a la suscripci√≥n de un acuerdo marco sobre comercio rec√≠proco y de futuros instrumentos para su plena implementaci√≥n‚Äù.

Las negociaciones deber√°n desarrollarse en cumplimiento de la Constituci√≥n, disposiciones de la Organizaci√≥n Mundial de Comercio (OMC) y las normativas vigentes en el pa√≠s.

El documento fue suscrito por Alexia Alc√≠var, presidenta encargada del Comit√© de Comercio Exterior.

En los considerandos de la resoluci√≥n se indica que la negociaci√≥n y suscripci√≥n de un acuerdo marco de aranceles rec√≠procos entre Ecuador y EE. UU. ‚Äúpermitir√° fortalecer los v√≠nculos comerciales, econ√≥micos y pol√≠ticos entre ambos pa√≠ses‚Äù.

El pleno del Comex, en una sesi√≥n del 13 de mayo, conoci√≥ y aprob√≥ un informe t√©cnico para el inicio de negociaciones con Washington ‚Äúpara la suscripci√≥n de un acuerdo comercial‚Äù.

El informe fue presentado por el Ministerio de Producci√≥n y recomienda que se emita el dictamen favorable para que empiecen las conversaciones comerciales antes de la firma de un acuerdo marco de comercio rec√≠proco.

El prop√≥sito es ‚Äúmantener y ampliar las relaciones comerciales bilaterales con el objetivo de buscar el inicio de las negociaciones encaminadas a la suscripci√≥n de un acuerdo comercial amplio entre Ecuador y Estados Unidos‚Äù.

Estados Unidos es el principal socio comercial de Ecuador.

En el primer trimestre de 2025 la balanza comercial no petrolera con ese pa√≠s (incluyendo a Puerto Rico) dej√≥ un saldo positivo de $ 1.050 millones, con exportaciones por $ 1.761 millones y $ 711 millones en importaciones, seg√∫n el Banco Central del Ecuador (BCE).

Los exportadores ecuatorianos han planteado por a√±os la necesidad de buscar un acuerdo comercial con Washington.

En un reporte de la Federaci√≥n Ecuatoriana de Exportadores (Fedexpor), publicado el 15 de mayo, Xavier Rosero, presidente del gremio, expone que con Estados Unidos hay que ser ‚Äúser r√°pidos, pero estrat√©gicos‚Äù.

Se debe aprovechar la ‚Äúventana de negociaciones‚Äù que abri√≥ el gobierno de Trump con la pausa de 90 d√≠as que orden√≥ para implementaci√≥n de aranceles adicionales al resto de pa√≠ses.

El fin es conseguir que Ecuador sea uno de los pa√≠ses que logre un entendimiento comercial para desmontar la sobretasa del 10 %, plantea Rosero.

‚ÄúEse desaf√≠o debe complementarse con planteamientos claros que permitan abrir puertas hacia una negociaci√≥n definitiva de un acuerdo comercial completo que elimine los aranceles que nuestros competidores dejaron de enfrentar hace 20 a√±os por sus acuerdos comerciales con los Estados Unidos‚Äù, enfatiza el presidente de Fedexpor.

title: Donald Trump exige a Walmart que "se coma los aranceles" ante posibles subidas de precios
content: "Walmart deber√≠a dejar de culpar a los aranceles como motivo para subir precios en toda la cadena", escribi√≥ Trump en su red social, Truth Social.
resumen:
Donald Trump critic√≥ a Walmart por sugerir subidas de precios tras el aumento de las tarifas arancelarias, exigiendo que "se coma los aranceles" en lugar de trasladar el costo a los consumidores.

Trump escribi√≥ en Truth Social: "Walmart deber√≠a DEJAR de culpar a los aranceles como motivo para subir precios en toda la cadena".

Trump calcul√≥: "Walmart gan√≥ MILES DE MILLONES DE D√ìLARES el a√±o pasado, mucho m√°s de lo esperado".

Inst√≥ a Walmart a que se "COMA LOS ARANCELES" y mantenga los precios bajos.

Trump public√≥: "Estar√© vigilando, al igual que vuestros consumidores".

Walmart tiene m√°s de 4.000 tiendas a nivel nacional.

El jefe ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, dijo este jueves que los nuevos aranceles les obligar√° a empezar a subir los precios.

McMillon prometi√≥: "Haremos el m√°ximo esfuerzo para mantener nuestros precios tan bajos como sea posible", pero advirti√≥ de que la compa√±√≠a no ser√° capaz de "absorber toda la presi√≥n" impuesta por los aranceles.

La portavoz de Walmart, Molly Blakeman, expres√≥ mediante un comunicado: "Siempre hemos trabajado para mantener nuestros precios lo m√°s bajos posible y no dejaremos de hacerlo".

Blakeman se√±al√≥: "Mantendremos los precios tan bajos como podamos, el tiempo que sea posible, dada la realidad de los estrechos m√°rgenes del sector minorista".

Seg√∫n el director financiero de la compa√±√≠a, John David Rainey, una tercera parte de los productos que distribuye Walmart proceden de otros pa√≠ses.

Muchos otros establecimientos minoristas, como Target o Best Buy, alertaron sobre potenciales subidas en los precios dadas las elevadas tarifas arancelarias.

title: China aprovecha tensiones con EE.UU. para acercarse a sus antiguos aliados
content: En medio de una intensa guerra comercial impulsada por el expresidente estadounidense Donald Trump, China ha aprovechado el descontento global para estrechar lazos con los tradicionales aliados de Est ...
resumen:
En medio de una intensa guerra comercial impulsada por el expresidente estadounidense Donald Trump, China ha aprovechado el descontento global para estrechar lazos con los tradicionales aliados de Estados Unidos, como la Uni√≥n Europea, Jap√≥n, Corea del Sur y pa√≠ses de Am√©rica Latina.

Tras una escalada arancelaria sin precedentes ‚Äîque llev√≥ los impuestos a importaciones chinas hasta 145%‚Äî, Washington ha perdido credibilidad entre sus socios internacionales. En contraste, Pek√≠n ha reforzado su imagen como defensor del comercio multilateral y de un orden econ√≥mico abierto, justo e inclusivo.

China ha realizado acercamientos estrat√©gicos: conversaciones directas con l√≠deres europeos, visitas oficiales de alto nivel y compromisos conjuntos para fortalecer la cooperaci√≥n comercial y diplom√°tica. L√≠deres como Pedro S√°nchez (Espa√±a), Lula da Silva (Brasil), Gustavo Petro (Colombia) y Gabriel Boric (Chile) han reafirmado su relaci√≥n con China, pese a las presiones de EE.UU.

Adem√°s, en el Indo-Pac√≠fico, China ha intensificado su presencia mediante proyectos de infraestructura y la promoci√≥n de la unidad regional frente al proteccionismo estadounidense. La reuni√≥n del 4 de mayo en Italia entre pa√≠ses del Sudeste Asi√°tico y China reforz√≥ esta postura, marcando una mayor integraci√≥n econ√≥mica.

Incluso en contextos adversos, como las sanciones a Rusia, China ha profundizado su alianza con Mosc√∫, incrementando sus importaciones de gas ruso y colaborando en proyectos tecnol√≥gicos, como una futura central nuclear en la Luna.

Aunque EE.UU. intent√≥ una tregua comercial de 90 d√≠as para reducir tensiones, analistas prev√©n que la incertidumbre se mantenga. A pesar de los aranceles, China ha resistido econ√≥micamente, y se espera un repunte de exportaciones mientras persista la ambig√ºedad sobre un acuerdo comercial duradero.

China, seg√∫n expertos, se posiciona como el nuevo referente global ante el repliegue y la imprevisibilidad de Washington, ganando terreno tanto pol√≠tica como econ√≥micamente en regiones clave.

title: Analysis: Trump‚Äôs truce with China on tariffs comes at a cost to U.S. credibility
content: U.S.-China trade talks in Geneva resulted in a temporary slash of tariff rates, but the ripple effect of this tit-for-tat escalation won‚Äôt disappear anytime soon.
resumen: The trade talks in Geneva between the United States and China yielded greater-than-expected de-escalation in the ongoing trade war, but it won‚Äôt be so easy to undo the damage this skirmish has done to U.S. trade credibility and the role of the dollar on the global stage. The two sides agreed to a point-for-point mutual reduction in their respective tariff rates for an initial period of 90 days, bringing rates down to near the same levels that prevailed before the tit-for-tat escalation. This reduction of 115 percentage points lowers the U.S. tariff rate on Chinese imports to 30 percent and 10 percent on U.S. goods flowing the other way. The deal extends to China the same treatment that the Trump administration already granted to other countries on April 9 when it announced a pause to the implementation of ‚Äúreciprocal tariffs.‚Äù Chinese goods are still subject to the universal 10 percent tariff on all U.S. imports in addition to certain sectoral tariffs, which brings the effective tariff rate on Chinese goods to around 40 percent ‚Äî still significantly higher than a year ago. This de-escalation in the trade war has already provided relief to financial markets. U.S. imports from China are likely to surge during the next three months as businesses and retailers stock up on Chinese goods. This stockpiling activity means greater demand for logistical services, resulting in higher container shipping costs and freight costs, which will add to inflationary pressures in the United States. The 90-day tariff reprieve on Chinese goods completes the Trump administration‚Äôs walk back of its reciprocal tariff policy ‚Äî the signature part of the April 2 (‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù) announcement ‚Äî but it‚Äôs too late to undo the long-term harm already caused. The dollar has weakened significantly against major currencies like the euro and the yen, which will result in less purchasing power of U.S. households and higher everyday costs. Foreign investors in U.S. financial markets have also been burned by the precipitous decline of the dollar. At the end of last year, investors held an all-time high of $16 trillion in U.S. equities, or 18 percent of the whole stock market. Now, they will not be as eager to park their capital in the United States. This could bring higher volatility in U.S. bond and stock markets. Chinese officials described the joint statement from the Geneva talks as ‚Äúan important step to resolve differences through equal dialogue and consultation.‚Äù The prohibitively high retaliatory tariffs amounted to a mutual trade embargo that lasted for 39 days. A back-of-the-envelope calculation shows that it takes about 34 days for Chinese exports to reach U.S. consumers and the factories that use Chinese imports as industrial inputs. It takes about 15 to 20 days for goods loaded in containers to reach the United States‚Äô West Coast via ships from Chinese coastal ports. Once there, it then requires a week of unloading, inspection, and custom clearance, and then a second week for nationwide rail or truck distribution to reach cities on the East Coast. Estimating a lean inventory level of about one month means that the price effects of tariffs were scheduled to become evident starting this summer. For China, the lesson learned is that the Trump administration isn‚Äôt willing to ignore the domestic pressure applied by American businesses. Their supply chains are still dependent on China, which means that their Achilles Heel is inventory logistics. In April, while direct trade with the United States plunged, Chinese exports surged to Southeast Asian countries. Washington and Beijing have bought themselves three months to figure out what each side wants and what it must have. The current ninety-day pause will probably be extended as the two sides edge closer to a comprehensive deal, but a further reduction in tariff rates seems unlikely. Beijing can live with a differential rate on Chinese goods that is only 20 percent higher than the rest of the world. The Trump administration will likely shift its focus to consolidating its position within the Western trade bloc by striking deals with Europe and Japan. The typical trade deal of substance takes about 18 months to negotiate. Chinese small businesses ‚Äî the backbone of Chinese exports ‚Äî will not halt export to wait for the two governments reach a trade deal. They will continue to expand markets and manufacture facilities overseas in places where they can sell products for higher margins and further cut costs wherever possible.

title: Were Trump tariffs lifted on China? How tariffs affect Massachusetts depending on country‚Ä¨
content: President Donald Trump announced that China and US had agreed to pause escalating tariffs for 90 days. Massachusetts has its own imports and exports.
resumen:
President Donald Trump on May 12 announced that the U.S. and China had agreed to lower the escalating tariff rates on trade for the next 90 days.
Chinese imports will face a 30% tariff in total, down from 145% on most goods.
The Chinese government agreed to reduce their retaliatory tariffs down to 10% from the previously set 125%.
The rates are expected to go into place by May 14, and the news sent the U.S. stock market soaring.
Trump has made tariffs a key point in his presidency, issuing reciprocal tariffs on a selection of countries to target what he considers to be unfair trading practices.
Those were also paused in April, and most imports are now taxed at 10%.
Tariffs are taxes on foreign goods shipments to the U.S.
They are paid by importers: in this case, American manufacturers or retailers.
The cost is typically passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices.
Reciprocal tariffs are the tariff rate ‚Äúnecessary to balance bilateral trade deficits between the U.S. and each of its trading partners,‚Äù according to the U.S. Trade Representative.
Trump had imposed tariffs on goods from China in his first term, too.
A timeline by nonpartisan tax policy nonprofit the Tax Foundation, those tariff orders in 2018 and 2019 show a similar on-again, off-again pattern.
President Joe Biden kept many of Trump's tariffs in place, and even increased on targeted items such as Chinese electric vehicles and syringes.
Those have stayed in place as Trump has added steeper rates on top of it.
At one point, the White House released a figure indicating that tariffs on Chinese imports were up to 245% on some goods with the new tariffs and Biden administration tariffs together.
The deal announced May 12 only applies to the reciprocal tariffs, meaning earlier announced tariffs are still in place.
The U.S. exported $144 billion worth of products to China in 2024, according to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative.
Of that $144 billion, $125 billion were products grown, produced or manufactured in the U.S. (the rest being foreign goods re-exported to China).
These are the top 10 types of products the U.S. exported to China, according to domestically produced export data from the U.S. International Trade Commission:
Mineral fuel and oil: $13.38 billion, 11% of total exports to China
Grains, seeds and fruits: $13.35 billion, 11% of total exports to China
Electrical machinery and TV parts: $11.49 billion, 9% of total exports to China
Nuclear reactor parts and mechanical appliances: $10.47 billion, 8% of total exports to China
Aircraft parts: $10.2 billion, 8% of total exports to China
Optical and photographic parts: $8.92 billion, 7% of total exports to China
Plastics: $7.17 billion, 6% of total exports to China
Vehicle parts and accessories: $6.14 billion, 5% of total exports to China
Pharmaceutical products: $4.99 billion, 4% of total exports to China
Organic chemicals: $3.88 billion, 3% of total exports to China
According to the Observatory of Economic Complexity, Massachusetts exported $34.9 billion in 2024, making it the 19th-largest exporter state in the United States.
As of February 2025, the top exports of Massachusetts were gold ($490 million), vaccines, blood, antisera, toxins and cultures ($178 million), medical instruments ($175 million), centrifuges ($116 million), and machines and apparatuses used for things like semiconductors ($116 million.)
Massachusetts‚Äô top export, gold, goes mostly to China.
But China isn't the top export destination for Massachusetts in total; instead, it's the United Kingdom at $451 million.
Massachusetts‚Äô top export destinations are:
United Kingdom ($451 miillion)
Mexico ($269 million)
Canada ($211 million)
China ($193 million)
Germany ($151 million)
In 2024, the U.S. imported $438 billion worth of goods from China, according to Office of the U.S. Trade Representative.
These are the top 10 types of products the U.S. imported from China, according to data from the U.S. International Trade Commission:
Electrical machinery and TV parts: $124.97 billion, 28% of total imports from China
Nuclear reactor parts and mechanical appliances: $82 billion, 18% of total imports from China
Toys, games and sports equipment: $30.03 billion, 7% of imports from China
Plastics: $19.29 billion, 4% of total imports from China
Furniture, lamps and pre-fabricated buildings: $18.52, 4% of total imports from China
Vehicles: $16.85 billion, 4% of total imports from China
Iron and steel: $11.98 billion, 3% of total imports from China
Optical and photographic parts: $11.88 billion, 3% of total imports from China
Clothing: $9.99 billion, 2% of total imports from China
Shoes: $9.78 billion, 2% of total imports from China
According to the Observatory of Economic Complexity, Massachusetts imported $42.2 billion, making it the 17th-largest importer in the United States.
As of February 2025, the top imports of Massachusetts were other precious metal products ($576M), refined petroleum ($330M), medical instruments ($230M), orthopedic appliances ($166M), and petroleum gas($158M).
Massachusetts imports mostly from Canada, at $924 million.
Massachusetts imports the most from:
Canada ($924M)
Switzerland ($537M)
Mexico ($341M)
China ($248M)
Germany ($210M)

content: President Trump wants Walmart to keep prices down despite tariffs. It could hit the large retailer on the top line.
resumen: Hay un rumor de que Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN) planeaba mostrar el efecto de los aranceles en los precios de los art√≠culos vendidos en su sitio. El rumor contin√∫a que el presidente Trump no deseaba que Amazon mostrara que sus aranceles perjudicaban a los consumidores. En el sitio de redes sociales Truth Social public√≥: "EAT THE TARIFFS", "Estar√© observando, y tambi√©n lo har√°n sus clientes". Trump dijo que Walmart gan√≥ "BILLONES DE D√ìLARES". En realidad, Walmart opera con los m√°rgenes m√°s estrechos. En el trimestre m√°s recientemente reportado, tuvo un ingreso operativo de $7.1 mil millones y unos ingresos de $168 mil millones, lo que sit√∫a su margen en poco m√°s del 4%. Los aranceles chinos podr√≠an reducir ese margen. Los inversores esperan que los ingresos operativos y los ingresos contin√∫en creciendo, y eso fue ciertamente cierto en el trimestre m√°s recientemente reportado. Los ingresos aumentaron un 4% y los ingresos operativos un 3%. El minorista m√°s grande de Estados Unidos dijo que el futuro era brillante. "De cara al futuro, la Compa√±√≠a emite una gu√≠a para el segundo trimestre con unas ventas netas que se espera que aumenten entre un 3.5% y un 4.5% en moneda constante ("cc"). La perspectiva de la Compa√±√≠a para el a√±o fiscal 2026 se mantiene sin cambios con respecto a la gu√≠a anterior". Los aranceles podr√≠an hacer saltar por los aires esas cifras. Las acciones de Walmart han tenido una trayectoria extraordinaria. Han subido un 52% en el √∫ltimo a√±o, mientras que el S&P 500 solo. Ese a√±o se desaceler√≥ en lo que va del a√±o. El precio de las acciones de Walmart ha subido un 9% durante ese per√≠odo, mientras que el S&P se mantiene plano. Muchos inversores est√°n negociando con Walmart bajo la suposici√≥n de que su gu√≠a es precisa. Los aranceles pueden socavar esa suposici√≥n. Si los precios suben en muchos art√≠culos, los consumidores pueden reducir sus compras, erosionar los ingresos de Walmart y, en lugar de crecer, la l√≠nea superior de Walmart podr√≠a reducirse, al igual que el precio de sus acciones.

title: Empresarios temen rezago si otros pa√≠ses logran reducir aranceles del 10% impuestos por Trump
content: La Cencit plantea agenda conjunta para mitigar barreras no arancelarias, mientras el Gobierno se prepara para reuni√≥n clave con la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) ...
resumen:
Empresarios temen rezago si otros pa√≠ses logran reducir aranceles del 10% impuestos por Trump.
La Cencit plantea agenda conjunta para mitigar barreras no arancelarias, mientras el Gobierno se prepara para reuni√≥n clave con la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) el 27 de mayo.
Jean Paul Brichaux, coordinador de la Comisi√≥n Empresarial de Negociaciones y Comercio Internacional (Cencit), conformada por diversas c√°maras y asociaciones empresariales, expone las principales preocupaciones del sector ante los aranceles del 10% fijados por Estados Unidos a las importaciones de productos guatemaltecos.
La principal preocupaci√≥n es que como pa√≠s perdamos competitividad frente a nuestros principales competidores.
A M√©xico y Canad√° no se les impuso el arancel del 10%.
A medida que otros pa√≠ses a nivel global resuelvan o mejoren su situaci√≥n comercial con Estados Unidos y se les reduzca o elimine ese arancel, Guatemala perder√° competitividad como pa√≠s exportador.
El impacto se estima en alrededor de US$460 millones.
Guatemala export√≥ en 2024 unos US$4,600 millones a Estados Unidos.
Un promedio mensual de exportaciones de US$384 millones y diario de US$12 millones.
El costo se estima en US$1.2 millones.
Seg√∫n informaci√≥n de los principales sectores, ese costo ha sido cubierto por el exportador.
Si Estados Unidos reduce el arancel para otros pa√≠ses y no para nosotros, vamos perdiendo competitividad y nos volvemos m√°s caros.
Las exportaciones totales de Guatemala del primer trimestre crecieron 10.7%.
Jean Paul Brichaux es actualmente el coordinador de Cencit que que agrupa a varias organizaciones empresariales para impulsar acciones en negociaciones comerciales.
Guatemala est√° en la cola junto con otros pa√≠ses que buscan reuniones con EE. UU.
El Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores tuvo un acercamiento inicial.
Desde el 2 de abril, cuando EE. UU. public√≥ la medida, hubo coordinaci√≥n con el Ministerio de Econom√≠a y reuniones con el presidente para dar seguimiento a una hoja de ruta del Ejecutivo.
Se han realizado reuniones interinstitucionales para revisar las barreras comerciales no arancelarias se√±aladas por EE. UU.
El Gobierno ya solicit√≥ la reuni√≥n con USTR, que se celebrar√° pr√≥ximamente, y se ha hablado de una delegaci√≥n p√∫blico-privada.
Pa√≠ses como India, Reino Unido y China ya se reunieron con EE. UU. y establecieron compromisos.
Mineco detect√≥ soluciones a las barreras comerciales y anunci√≥ avances en dos o tres meses.
La reuni√≥n ser√° clave para conocer la opini√≥n del USTR sobre los avances y compromisos.

resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, se√±al√≥ que su Gobierno contempla llegar a acuerdos arancelarios por regiones en la actual negociaci√≥n comercial.

Estados Unidos concedi√≥ a principios de abril una pausa de 90 d√≠as a los grav√°menes considerados rec√≠procos que hab√≠a impuesto a sus distintos socios comerciales y se encuentra inmerso en la negociaci√≥n para llegar a un nuevo pacto.

Bessent recalc√≥ sin citarlos que hay ‚Äú18 socios comerciales importantes, probablemente otros 20 con relaciones s√≥lidas‚Äù, a los que el presidente, Donald Trump, ‚Äúha puesto sobre aviso de que si no negocian de buena fe, volver√°n a los niveles del 2 de abril‚Äù.

Bessent se√±al√≥ que tras haber constatado que Estados Unidos ten√≠a algunas ‚Äúcarencias estrat√©gicas‚Äù, ya fuera en materia de medicamentos, semiconductores, acero y otros productos, el objetivo del Ejecutivo a medio plazo es ‚Äúrecuperar estas industrias lo antes posible‚Äù y seguir comerciando el resto de productos a niveles arancelarios m√°s bajos.

title: Disputa entre Trump y Walmart por aumento de precios debido a los aranceles: el mandatario pidi√≥ no cobrar de m√°s a los clientes
content: El jefe del Tesoro de Estados Unidos dijo el domingo que hab√≠a llamado al CEO de Walmart, un d√≠a despu√©s de que el presidente Donald Trump criticara a la compa√±√≠a por aumentar los precios debido a sus ...
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, est√° en una disputa con Walmart por el aumento de precios debido a los aranceles que impuso a decenas de productos. Trump critic√≥ a Walmart por aumentar los precios y le pidi√≥ que "asumiera" los costos. Walmart, el minorista m√°s grande del pa√≠s con 4.606 tiendas en Estados Unidos, advirti√≥ que algunos de los aranceles se trasladar√°n a los consumidores. El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, dijo que har√≠an todo lo posible para mantener los precios bajos, pero no podr√≠an absorber toda la presi√≥n. Trump respondi√≥ en redes sociales que Walmart y China deber√≠an "COMERSE LOS ARANCELES" y no cobrar a los clientes. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo que hab√≠a llamado a McMillon para entender su postura.

title: Advertencia para Walmart: Trump dice que deben dejar de "tratar de culpar a los aranceles" tras anuncio de aumento de precios
content: Walmart anuncia aumento de precios por aranceles, mientras Donald Trump exige que la empresa no traslade los costos a los consumidores de Estados Unidos.
resumen:
Walmart anunci√≥ que sus precios subir√°n debido al impacto de los aranceles, principalmente sobre productos importados de China.
Donald Trump exigi√≥ a Walmart que no traslade los costos de los aranceles a los clientes.
Walmart tiene m√°s de 4.600 tiendas en Estados Unidos.
Los aumentos de precios afectar√°n a productos esenciales, desde alimentos hasta juguetes y art√≠culos para beb√©s.
Donald Trump critic√≥ que Walmart "trate de culpar a los aranceles" por subir precios y asegur√≥ que la empresa deber√≠a asumir esos costos sin trasladarlos a los clientes.
El CEO de Walmart, Douglas McMillon, explic√≥ que los aumentos de precios son inevitables debido a los aranceles que Estados Unidos impuso, especialmente en productos chinos.
El director financiero, John David Rainey, adelant√≥ que los precios comenzar√°n a subir a finales de mayo y que el impacto se sentir√° a√∫n m√°s en junio.
Entre los productos afectados est√°n frutas y verduras importadas de pa√≠ses como Colombia, Costa Rica y Per√∫, as√≠ como juguetes y art√≠culos electr√≥nicos, muchos fabricados en China.
Los aranceles de Estados Unidos elevan los costos de una amplia variedad de productos:
Alimentos frescos como pl√°tanos, aguacates y caf√© provenientes de Am√©rica Latina.
Juguetes, con aproximadamente el 80% fabricados en China.
Electr√≥nica, como consolas de videojuegos y tel√©fonos m√≥viles, tambi√©n enfrentan alzas que podr√≠an superar el 30%.
Art√≠culos para beb√©s, desde cochecitos hasta leche de f√≥rmula, que en su mayor√≠a provienen de China.

title: China apuesta fuerte por Am√©rica Latina
content: La segunda potencia mundial ve en Am√©rica Latina una gran oportunidad para ampliar su influencia y aprovechar la coyuntura creada por Estados Unidos, que parece abandonar su papel hist√≥rico como el pa ...
resumen: La segunda potencia mundial ve en Am√©rica Latina una gran oportunidad para ampliar su influencia y aprovechar la coyuntura creada por Estados Unidos, que parece abandonar su papel hist√≥rico como el pa√≠s con mayor presencia en la regi√≥n. China ha escalado en la expansi√≥n de su influencia geopol√≠tica de manera global, enfocada ahora en la regi√≥n de Am√©rica Latina. Beijing ve en la regi√≥n latinoamericana m√∫ltiples atractivos: le brinda acceso a recursos naturales estrat√©gicos; es mercado interesante para el comercio; le permite ampliar sus relaciones diplom√°ticas y, con ello, promueve el aislamiento de Taiw√°n; mejora su influencia pol√≠tica en organismos multilaterales; y promueve desarrollo invirtiendo en √°reas sensibles como infraestructura portuaria, ferrocarril y carreteras. China act√∫a con una l√≥gica de seducci√≥n. Ha venido haciendo esto a lo largo del siglo XXI, con bloques como el Foro CELAC‚ÄìChina, el BRICS, la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI), la Organizaci√≥n de Cooperaci√≥n de Shangh√°i (SCO) y el di√°logo creciente entre Mercosur y China, que ya ha provocado acuerdos de libre comercio. Las condiciones han cambiado, pues Estados Unidos ha modificado su estrategia para Am√©rica Latina. La pol√≠tica comercial de Donald Trump ha convertido a Estados Unidos en un pa√≠s proteccionista y m√°s cerrado. Latinoam√©rica no aparece en su agenda m√°s que en materia de seguridad propia, aunque sigue siendo el ‚Äúsocio comercial‚Äù m√°s importante para muchos de los pa√≠ses del √°rea. La visi√≥n de Xi Jinping es ambiciosa: quiere hacer de China una naci√≥n fuerte, autosuficiente, influyente, disciplinada, l√≠der en tecnolog√≠a, con voz fuerte en el plano internacional, bajo un r√©gimen autoritario. La pretensi√≥n de China sobre Taiw√°n sigue siendo la reunificaci√≥n y, solamente tres pa√≠ses ‚ÄìParaguay, Guatemala y Belice‚Äì mantienen relaciones exclusivas con Taip√©i. Trump cerr√≥ para Estados Unidos inversiones √°rabes por US$400,000 millones, China abri√≥ l√≠neas de cr√©dito para Am√©rica Latina por US$10,000 millones. Beijing y Xi Jinping apuestan, por medio del BRI, a construir en Sudam√©rica una red global de infraestructura, comercio y conectividad. China ha sabido aprovechar el momento. Estados Unidos impuso sus pretensiones en los siglos XIX y XX al invadir M√©xico, Nicaragua, Cuba (dos veces), Puerto Rico, Rep√∫blica Dominicana (dos veces), Hait√≠ (dos veces), Panam√° (dos veces) y Granada, o intervenir en Guatemala y Chile para remover gobiernos. China ha irrumpido con fuerza extraordinaria y de forma amistosa.

title: ‚ÄòNeoliberal and authoritarian‚Äô? A simplistic analysis of the Maduro government that leaves much unsaid
content: Gabriel Hetland‚Äôs article ‚ÄúCapitalism and authoritarianism in Maduro‚Äôs Venezuela‚Äù presents a one-sided and decontextualised view of Venezuela under President Nicol√°s Maduro.
resumen: Gabriel Hetland's article ‚ÄúCapitalism and authoritarianism in Maduro‚Äôs Venezuela,‚Äù published in New Labor Forum and reposted at LINKS International Journal of Socialist Renewal, presents a one-sided and decontextualised view of Venezuela under President Nicol√°s Maduro. Hetland claims the Maduro government is virtually devoid of any redeeming characteristics and refers approvingly to the claim made by Maduro‚Äôs harshest critics on the left, that his government and the right-wing opposition are ‚Äútwo sides of the same coin‚Äù. Any serious examination of Venezuela under Maduro needs to incorporate the impact of US-imposed economic sanctions into its analysis. The Washington-engineered economic war significantly undermined the effectiveness of potentially sound policies initiated by Maduro. Hetland‚Äôs black-and-white approach does a disservice to the complex and, in many respects, unique experience of Chavismo. The illegal and semi-legal actions undertaken by Washington and Venezuela‚Äôs right-wing opposition have been numerous and relentless almost since the start of the Hugo Ch√°vez presidency in 1999, including: abortive coups; assassination attempts; recognition of de facto governments; open appeals by top US officials urging Venezuelan military officers to intervene; invasions by paramilitary forces from Colombia; covert and public international campaigns to isolate Venezuela; foreign funding of opposition groups; widespread and protracted street violence aimed at regime change; and sweeping secondary sanctions. The full scope of the war on Venezuela has to be brought into the picture. The impacts of the war on Venezuela are an essential element in the debate over whether the Maduro presidency should be deemed an outright failure. Maduro‚Äôs errors were, in many cases, overreactions to Washington-backed provocations. Washington has systematically countered every initiative undertaken by the Maduro government to address economic difficulties facing the nation. For example, when the Maduro government attempted to renegotiate its foreign debt in response to the sharp decline in oil prices, in August 2017 US President Donald Trump prohibited the trading of Venezuelan bonds in US markets. Maduro then responded to Washington‚Äôs measures against the Venezuelan oil industry by turning to gold exports, but Trump issued an executive order in 2018 banning the purchase of Venezuelan gold. Simultaneously, the Maduro government launched a crypto currency, the Petro, to bypass the US-controlled SWIFT system. Trump responded with another executive order prohibiting the use of Petros under US jurisdiction. The second Trump administration has refused to renew ‚Äúlicenses‚Äù the Biden administration granted Chevron and other corporations to operate in Venezuela. Maduro‚Äôs rapprochement with the private sector should be debated. Maduro, in his 2025 annual Speech to the Nation announced that 85% of the food sold in supermarkets is now ‚ÄúMade in Venezuela‚Äù. This shift is largely due to a ‚Äústrategic alliance‚Äù between agricultural interests and the government, currently coordinated through the Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Industry and National Production. Hetland makes no reference to the government-promoted communes (community production units). Chris Gilbert explores this revitalisation in Commune or Nothing! Venezuela‚Äôs Communal Movement and its Socialist Project. The experience of Angel Prado and the communes is clearly at odds with Hetland‚Äôs interpretation of the Venezuelan government under Maduro. Hetland makes no mention of critical supporters among writers and political figures, Venezuelans and non-Venezuelans, but refers extensively to the recently formed group Comunes. In his discussion of the protests that followed the July 28, 2024 presidential elections, Hetland fails to take into account a viewpoint on the left that runs counter to his own. Attorney General Tarek William Saab presented extensive evidence alleging that on those two days delinquents, in cahoots with the Venezuelan right, carried out attacks on symbols of the state. Hetland accuses the author of justifying political repression in Venezuela. The author‚Äôs statement was: ‚ÄúSome left analysts fault Maduro for taking off the gloves and not abiding by the norms of liberal democracy. In some cases, the criticisms are valid but they have to be contextualised.‚Äù Hetland‚Äôs portrayal of the author‚Äôs views reflect a broader trend in writing on the left that polarises discussion on the Venezuelan government ‚Äî in which Maduro is either demonised or viewed uncritically. The author‚Äôs critique of Maduro ‚Äî and, to a lesser extent, Ch√°vez ‚Äî for failing to seize favourable moments to deepen the transformation process and deliver decisive blows against corruption. The tensions between Maduro and the PCV were initially of a ‚Äúsecondary‚Äù nature, and Maduro‚Äôs sectarianism contributed to the eventual rupture. The errors and shortcomings of the Maduro government cannot be pushed under the carpet or justified, but they nevertheless must be understood in context. There is a direct correlation between the intensity of imperialist aggression and the ability of a government committed to real change to achieve its social, political and economic goals. Criticism that identifies the downsides of the policies of the Venezuelan government and defines political opportunities has been essential. The challenges faced by Maduro are in many ways greater than those Ch√°vez encountered, at least in the years following the regime change attempts of 2002-03. These included the plummeting of oil prices (beginning in 2015), Obama‚Äôs 2015 executive order, and the erosion of public enthusiasm that inevitably occurs in prolonged periods of sacrifices and hardship.
