title: Week ahead: A US debt downgrade and UK CPI
content: This week we should be talking about how in May, US equities have outperformed their European counterparts. However, instead the focus will be on the US credit rating downgrade from Moody‚Äôs that was ...
resumen: This week the focus will be on the US credit rating downgrade from Moody‚Äôs. The US credit rating agency downgraded the US from Aaa to Aa1. The US no longer has the triple A credit rating. The reaction to this news has weighed on US equity futures and knocked the US dollar. Treasury yields are higher across the board, and the 30-year yield breached the key 5% level on Monday morning. The downgrade is to be expected. S&P 500 ditched the US triple A grade back in 2011. Moody‚Äôs expects the current fiscal bill to cost $3.8 trillion over the next decade, and federal deficits to widen. They predict the deficit could balloon to 9% of GDP by 2035, up from 6.4% in 2024, driven mainly by high interest payments. Ahead of the November 2024 Presidential election, the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget reported that President Trump‚Äôs policies would cost $7.75 trillion. The Treasury announced last week that China‚Äôs holdings of US Treasuries had fallen to third place, behind the UK in March. The 10-year yield has surged past the highs reached at the peak of the reciprocal tariff panic in April, while the 30-year yield has breached the 5% level, which is the highest rate since 2023. The dollar was the weakest performer in the G10 FX space last week. In early trading this week, the dollar is weaker. USD/JPY is extending losses after falling though its 50-day sma at the end of last week at 146.10. House Republicans have a new deadline of 26th May to pass the US Budget bill. US equities outperformed their European counterparts last week, and there were big gains for US tech stocks, after President Trump brokered deals with Middle Eastern countries for US AI chips and infrastructure. The S&P 500 ended last week less than 50 points away from the key 6,000 level, and it was closing in on the record high from 19th February at 6,147. The Nasdaq has risen by more than 10% so far in May, and Nvidia‚Äôs share price is higher by more than 30% in the past month. The market is expecting UK inflation to jump to 3.3% in April, from 2.6% in March. Service price inflation is also expected to rise to 4.9% from 4.7%. The Bank of England expects inflation to rise to 3.7% by September. The market is now expecting less than 2 rate cuts for the rest of this year, with the next cut expected in August. GBP/USD is back above $1.33 on Monday morning. Composite PMI readings in the UK, France, Germany and the Eurozone as a whole, are all expected to register increases in sentiment for this month, while the US is expected to register a small decrease. Germany‚Äôs IFO report for May has a close relationship with German GDP. The IFO is expected to register gains for all three categories. EUR/USD is hovering around $1.1180.

title: Desaf√≠os de la pol√≠tica exterior chilena en la era Trump: ¬øEstar en la mesa o ser parte del men√∫?
content: Chile debe responder al desaf√≠o de sentarse a la mesa de las grandes decisiones como un actor relevante, responsable y proactivo ante un panorama internacional, que alcanza s√≥lo para estar en el men√∫.
resumen:
El art√≠culo aborda los desaf√≠os de la pol√≠tica exterior chilena en la era Trump, planteando la necesidad de que Chile se posicione como un actor relevante en la mesa de decisiones internacionales, en lugar de ser parte del men√∫.

El inicio de la segunda administraci√≥n de Donald Trump se caracteriza por un proteccionismo mercantilista, nacionalista y antiglobalizaci√≥n, con iniciativas unilaterales y/o transaccionales. Trump ha utilizado los aranceles como arma, afectando a pa√≠ses como China, Canad√°, M√©xico y Europa.

La econom√≠a internacional est√° experimentando una redirecci√≥n y fragmentaci√≥n, mientras que la pol√≠tica de Trump busca que los capitales se queden en Estados Unidos. La competencia chino-estadounidense se centra en la tecnolog√≠a, con el desarrollo de la inteligencia artificial.

La ofensiva pol√≠tica ultraconservadora afecta derechos y libertades, y las instituciones de la democracia tardan en reaccionar. La alianza con los grandes empresarios tecnol√≥gicos de Silicon Valley confunde el inter√©s de la Naci√≥n con fines particulares.

Am√©rica Latina se encuentra en una dispersi√≥n/fragmentaci√≥n, lo que demanda intensificar el di√°logo y la cooperaci√≥n.

La pol√≠tica exterior chilena debe adaptarse a las transformaciones sociales y complejidades desde el estallido social de 2019. Se debe practicar un no alineamiento activo, con alianzas flexibles que prioricen los intereses nacionales y regionales.

Se propone una diplomacia comercial s√≥lida, que incluya cadenas productivas regionales, pero que no sea la √∫nica herramienta para la proyecci√≥n internacional de Chile. Se debe priorizar la regi√≥n latinoamericana, y se debe elaborar un proyecto de desarrollo fronterizo que incluya a Per√∫, Bolivia y Argentina, junto a los v√≠nculos con Brasil y Uruguay.

El "Sur Global" surge como un espacio para fortalecer el pluralismo mundial, y Chile debiera acercarse a los BRICS+.

Se critica la falta de coordinaci√≥n intraestatal en la pol√≠tica exterior chilena, y se propone una pol√≠tica inclusiva que optimice las capacidades nacionales.

Seis propuestas puntuales:
1.  Diversificar lazos comerciales y pol√≠ticos.
2.  Repensar la integraci√≥n latinoamericana.
3.  Participar en foros internacionales.
4.  Invertir en investigaci√≥n y desarrollo.
5.  Desarrollar una diplomacia proactiva.
6.  Asegurar que Am√©rica Latina sea una zona de paz.

El Grupo de An√É¬°lisis y Seguimiento de la Pol√É¬≠tica Exterior de Chile (GASPE) est√° integrado por los acad√©micos e internacionalistas Cristi√°n Fuentes, Mladen Yopo, Boris Yopo, √Ålvaro Ramis, Carlos Monge, Jaime Ensignia y Carlos Parker.

content: La elecci√≥n del 5de mayo es muy importante porque vamos a elegir los diputados de la AN, uno de los poderes del Estado venezolano, un pilar, que tiene funciones muy importantes, decisivas en ...
resumen:
La elecci√≥n del 5 de mayo es muy importante porque se elegir√°n los diputados de la AN, un poder del Estado venezolano. Con mayor√≠a contundente de los bolivarianos, se garantiza un Gobierno positivo, favorable a la patria. Se deben asegurar los porcentajes necesarios para la aprobaci√≥n de leyes, como 2/3 o 3/5 de los diputados. Si un opositor impide la aprobaci√≥n de un acuerdo internacional, como en los BRICS, causar√≠a un serio tropiezo. Se debe votar ampliamente para tener una mayor√≠a holgada. Se deben desarrollar los planes relativos a las 7 transformaciones. La elecci√≥n del gobernador en cada estado es importante, ya que un gobernador en l√≠nea con el Gobierno nacional beneficiar√° al estado y al pa√≠s. La Asamblea Nacional y los gobernadores en manos bolivarianas ser√°n √∫tiles para la naci√≥n. Se debe dar el voto al Gran Polo Patri√≥tico Sim√≥n Bol√≠var (GPPSB).

LOGROS DE LA PATRIA: Venezuela recibi√≥ 700.000 dosis de vacunas BCG de Ir√°n; Rusia y China apoyar√°n el Plan de las 7 transformaciones; se firm√≥ un acuerdo para exportar frijol mungo a China; se rehabilit√≥ el paseo Juan Manuel Cagigal en Barcelona, Anzo√°tegui; se mostraron m√°s de 200 proyectos en las Olimpiadas de Rob√≥tica 2025.

LEYENDO LA CONSTITUCI√ìN: Art√≠culo 160: El gobierno y administraci√≥n de cada Estado corresponde a un Gobernador o Gobernadora. Para ser Gobernador o Gobernadora se requiere ser venezolano o venezolana, mayor de veinticinco a√±os y de estado seglar. El Gobernador o Gobernadora ser√° elegido o elegida por un per√≠odo de cuatro a√±os por mayor√≠a de las personas que voten. El Gobernador o Gobernadora podr√° ser reelegido o reelegida para un nuevo per√≠odo.

Por circuito: Circuito 1: Yajaira Mel√©ndez, Robetxa Poleo, Jes√∫s Garc√≠a. Circuito 2: Noris Herrera, C√©sar Herrera. Circuito 3: Rigel Sergent, Raquel Fern√°ndez. Circuito 4: Carlos Mogoll√≥n, Alexander Aranguren, Lesbia S√°nchez. Circuito 5: Juan Carlos Alem√°n, Jimmy Gudi√±o, Yasm√≠n Matiz, √Åfrica Vargas.

El enfrentamiento entre Pakist√°n e India realz√≥ la defensa anti a√©rea china y la capacidad t√©cnica y militar de sus aviones.

El presidente Putin dice que Rusia est√° sola frente al Occidente colectivo.

El canciller Lavrov ha declarado que en Rusia hay una sexta columna, que propugna el liberalismo.

Amenazas en Rusia, la 6¬™ columna. M√°s participaciones del imperio estadounidense en el proceso electoral. Sus agentes atacaron el sistema el√©ctrico. Cientos de miles de ataques al sistema inform√°tico del CNE han sido bloqueados. Amenazas de intervenci√≥n de fuerza contra Venezuela por Estados Unidos.

Los agentes pitiyanquis invisibilizan el aporte de Ch√°vez y Maduro al Sistema de Orquestas.

De 4.738 venezolanos regresados desde Estados Unidos, solamente 38 tienen antecedentes.

Los agentes pro imperialistas, como Mar√≠a Machado, hacen lobby en Estados Unidos para que Trump tome medidas contra Venezuela.

Venezuela es referente mundial en pago m√≥vil. Se realizan 260.000.000 pagos m√≥viles al a√±o; cada minuto se realizan 5.000 pagos m√≥viles; mensualmente se mueven 3.000 millones de d√≥lares; hay 20.000.000 afiliados a pago m√≥vil. Venezuela es el pa√≠s No 3 en Am√©rica en bancarizaci√≥n.

Es altamente posible que haya tres candidaturas del sector revolucionario de Bolivia.

El Juzgado 1 de Restituci√≥n de Tierras de C√∫cuta decret√≥ medidas cautelares en favor del Resguardo Ind√≠gena Motil√≥n-Bar√≠.

ESTADOS UNIDOS: Trump busca vender armas obsoletas.

title: Are US assets becoming less desirable?
content: There has been so much commentary, including by us, on the twists and turns of US trade policy ‚Äî notwithstanding the latest 90-day truce with China ‚Äî that what can be said has already been said. For ...
resumen: The article discusses whether US assets are becoming less desirable, given changes in global trade and investment. It notes a shift from globalization to a modern form of mercantilism, where the state intervenes to support industries. This is happening against a backdrop where the US is seemingly abandoning its role as the global system anchor. The article questions the US dollar's status, noting investor disquiet due to disorder and disruption from Washington, and the gap between institutional investors' economic orthodoxy and the US administration's economic philosophy. The article mentions the US dollar weakness, with the greenback estimated to have lost around 10% of its value since Inauguration Day. The article also discusses the dominance of US equities, which has not always been the case, and the potential for share market leadership to shift from the US to the rest of the world. The S&P 500 has outperformed the MSCI EAFE Index since mid-2008, delivering average annual returns of 11.9% versus 3.6% through December 2024. The US market's ROE is 19% versus 12% for EAFE. The US stock market premium versus EAFE on a forward P/E basis was hovering at 55% at the start of 2025. The article also mentions the potential for higher tech-stock volatility, disruption from tariffs, and cresting US consumer confidence. The author's investment approach includes an "underweight" position to the US share market and more funds deployed to non-US markets. The author also maintains exposure to alternative investments and real assets.

title: Global trade war puts climate action under threat
content: This unfolding tariff war is likely to stymie economic growth. An earlier report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) shows that tariff increases are associated with a persistent decline in ...
resumen: President Trump's executive orders to increase tariffs since January 2025 have turned into a global trade war, particularly between the US and China. Average tariffs on Chinese goods now stand at more than 100 percent, while Chinese retaliatory measures on US exports to China exceed those of the US average. The US has imposed more than 10 percent tariffs on almost all goods from most countries across the world. China is now the leader of renewable energy and clean technologies, and these tariffs will greatly impact its production and deployment, having serious impacts on climate change. The US administration has again submitted its application to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. The US is cutting back on its climate commitments, reducing the support for clean technology industries under the Inflation Reduction Act. This unfolding tariff war is likely to stymie economic growth. An earlier report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) shows that tariff increases are associated with a persistent decline in economic growth. Tariffs on green goods, including Chinese exports of solar panels, electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries to the US, are likely to have both direct and indirect impacts globally. The retaliatory measures by China and the European Union (EU) could create space for Europe to attract low-carbon investment and lead in the energy transition. China may redirect its exports toward the relatively open EU market. As clean technology becomes costlier in the US, Chinese companies will likely gain a stronger position beyond the US markets. Exports of Chinese EVs and solar panels to Asia, Latin America and Africa have increased in recent years and will likely continue to expand in markets with lower barriers. The US imports solar panels from other Asian countries, which are often produced by Chinese firms with components made in China. These companies are already responding to US restrictions by relocating parts of their production to new countries. Increased tariffs by 25 percent on Canadian and Mexican steel and aluminium exports are likely to weaken the ability of US automakers to transition to EVs. This will benefit Chinese EV makers. Developing countries will face increasing pressure from tariffs, their debt burden will keep mounting, so they will be forced to relax environmental standards to maintain competitiveness in external trade. The Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) of the United Nations (UN) Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) predicted that trade protectionism goes against ambitious climate action. AR6 developed a global scenario of regional rivalry, called the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways-3 (SSP3), where scientists concluded that under a scenario of rivalry and non-cooperation, challenges to mitigation and adaptation would be high, rendering the goal under the Paris Agreement of limiting the temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius unrealisable. This scenario could lead to four times more emissions than a sustainability-focused pathway with low challenges to mitigation and adaptation. Adaptation as well will meet challenges under this SSP3 scenario, as this will promote deforestation and the intensification of cropping. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was established in 1947, which eventually led to the creation of the World Trade Organization in 1995. The WTO ensures a system of rules-based international trade with checks for discriminatory trade practices and barriers. Unilateralism in the form of only bilateral deals among countries is likely to seriously undermine multilateralism in the global trading system. Trump's tariff policies are likely to harm the US more than others, with higher inflation, joblessness and even a potential recession. This is likely to further strengthen China's leadership in the global green technology supply chain. The trade war could slow the global clean energy transition. China, the world's largest emitter, is also the clean technology leader.

title: Cape Cod small business owner calls absorbing tariff costs 'scary'
content: U.S. Sen. Edward Markey held a listening session with small business owners asking for exemptions to President Trump's tariffs.
resumen: Small business owners on Cape Cod and across Massachusetts are struggling with the impact of tariffs on their businesses. U.S. Sen. Edward Markey introduced the Small Business Liberation Act, aiming to exempt small businesses from tariff payments. The uncertainty caused by tariffs makes planning difficult, especially for seasonal businesses on Cape Cod. Snowy Owl Coffee Roaster co-owner Shayna Ferullo, on Cape Cod, must pay tariffs on all the coffee she imports but Hawaii is the only U.S. state that grows the crop. She is worried that she might be forced to lay off employees, reduce their benefits, and possibly close her business because of tariffs. Ferullo was among a handful of Massachusetts business owners, at the invitation of U.S. Sen Edward Markey, D-Massachusetts, who spoke on May 8 about the impacts President Trump's tariffs were having on their bottom lines. Markey introduced a Small Business Liberation Act on May 5 that would exempt small businesses from paying tariffs. Ferullo and her husband, Manuel Ainzuain, work with coffee growers all over the world. The 10% tariff they have to pay on top of record high prices for green coffee in January is making it a scary time, she said. The Cape's seasonal economy and the uncertainty with tariffs make it harder to plan ahead. The couple started the roasting business ten years ago and have grown it to three cafes with 30 year-round and 70 seasonal employees. They import coffee from small partners in Peru, Nicaragua, Kenya, Ethiopia, Columbia. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a numbers game, a volume game‚Äù Ferullo said. ‚ÄúWe operate on tight margins. Having to absorb these costs is scary. It's a difficult time." There are 700,000 small businesses in Massachusetts, Markey said during the webinar. That translates to about one business for every 10 residents. Small business owners make up about 97% of all importers/exporters. They are Democrats and Republicans, and they suffer more than the big companies ‚Äî some who have gotten exemptions ‚Äî when it comes to paying tariffs, he said. Markey took the opportunity during National Small Business Week, May 4-10, to take aim at what he calls Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúirrational‚Äù tariffs. ‚ÄúSmall businesses are the backbone of the economy, but for small business owners, Trump‚Äôs tariffs are back-breaking,‚Äù he said. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has called for tariff exclusions for small businesses, Markey said. Owners of Boston Pro Sound, 1854 Cycling, Rocheleau Tool and Die and Commonwealth Kitchen also shared how the tariffs impacted them specifically. Brandale Randolph‚Äôs company, 1854 Cycling, in Massachusetts and Connecticut, employs formerly incarcerated individuals, 80% of them women, to build, service and program electronic bicycles. The tariffs could be a death knell for the company, the women he employs, and the communities they live in, he said. ‚ÄúBecause we hire from the communities ... it could destroy entire communities,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the ones who hire the ones that others forgot, the formerly incarcerated, those who don‚Äôt have the technical expertise. Think about us ... those who don‚Äôt have bank loans, who don‚Äôt get venture capital and don‚Äôt get exemptions from tariffs. Without exempting us you‚Äôre crippling families.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe tariffs are an absolute nightmare,‚Äù said Jen Faigel, co-founder and executive director of the nonprofit CommonWealth Kitchen in Dorchester, which represents more than 250 small and emerging food-based businesses.

title: The Miners Who Lost Their Jobs, but Not Their Faith in Trump‚Äôs Tariffs
content: With demand for steel down and a trade war underway, miners in the Iron Range of Minnesota are feeling the hit. But they hope better times are ahead.
resumen: Jon Bird worked 12-hour shifts, four days a week, shoveling rock, hosing mud and operating iron ore crushers at a mine in northern Minnesota. The mines in the state‚Äôs Iron Range sit atop a domestic supply funnel. The ore is extracted, crushed, processed, shipped, smelted in a blast furnace, transformed into steel, and taken to assembly lines. Demand for cars and other metal-filled items slumped in 2024. Cleveland-Cliffs, which owns the mine where Mr. Bird works, reported a $483 million loss for the first three months of 2025, which meant jobs were on the line. Mr. Bird, 33, was laid off. Some 1,200 Cleveland-Cliffs employees were affected, 600 of them in Minnesota. Mr. Bird is a member of the United Steelworkers union. Both Cleveland-Cliffs and Mr. Bird support President Trump‚Äôs tariffs: a 25 percent tax on steel and aluminum imports along with a 25 percent tariff on all imported cars. A wide range of economists think that Mr. Trump‚Äôs global tariff campaign could hasten an economic downturn. The steel companies and the steelworkers‚Äô union believe that tariffs can help protect, and even revitalize, domestic production. Fending off consistently lower-priced Chinese steel is a stated aim of the White House. Mr. Bird said that he didn‚Äôt get why Mr. Trump wanted to tax everything from coffee to mangoes, but that steel tariffs made sense to him because of the availability of homegrown ore. American steel and auto producers are also being hit with higher costs for the imported parts and finished goods that they use. Lourenco Goncalves, the chief executive of Cleveland-Cliffs, told analysts on a recent earnings call that they firmly believe that the Trump administration is spot-on in its push to bring back manufacturing to the United States. Mr. Bird‚Äôs family will ‚Äúhunker down‚Äù with unemployment benefits and a layoff supplement from the steelworkers‚Äô union until Mr. Bird‚Äôs wife, who is finishing nursing school, starts looking for work this summer. If the demand for American steel doesn‚Äôt increase, Mr. Bird might have to leave. The lines between hurting foreign trade adversaries and helping domestic production are blurry in the modern economy. Minnesota legislators are debating proposals to extend the miners‚Äô unemployment insurance benefits until late December, beyond the usual 26 weeks. Keeping skilled miners in the region is a bipartisan priority. Al King, the president of United Steelworkers Local 6115, said during a state legislative committee hearing in April that if they do not get this extension and provide hope to their members, they will not be able to stay. Unionized mining jobs in the Iron Range still pay well. Mr. Bird makes anywhere from $112,000 to $125,000 a year with overtime. The per capita income of St. Louis County is $39,778. Teresa Appelwick, the president of the Laurentian Chamber of Commerce, said that mining is a trickle-down economy. Darrell Gustafson, 50, from Hibbing, Minn., was laid off in March. He is in support of high steel tariffs. Dozens of employers showed up at the 2025 Iron Range Job Fair on April 24. Miriam Kero is a consultant and the coordinator of Hello, Range, a nonprofit group seeking to broaden the economy. Peter Kero, an environmental engineer and author, is also the architect of Redhead Mountain Bike Park. Redhead has hosted the high school state championship for mountain biking in two of the past three years. Food preparation and serving jobs in the area pay around $33,000; grounds cleaning around $41,000. At the entrance to a mining museum in Chisholm is an 85-foot-tall ‚ÄúIron Man‚Äù monument. President Trump has vowed to bring back some of the grand-scale manufacturing. In April, he signed an executive order aimed at bulking up the atrophied U.S. commercial shipbuilding industry. A bipartisan group of senators ‚Äî led by Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, a Democrat, and Senator Todd Young of Indiana, a Republican ‚Äî has pledged to follow up with legislative proposals. The potential for more domestic shipbuilding could mean a greater market for American-made steel. Mr. Bird said he had heard of the shipbuilding proposals and declared himself a fan.

content: En la segunda mitad del siglo XX y en la aurora del siglo XXI las corrientes pol√≠ticas que se disputaban su influencia en Am√©rica Latina ingresaron con m√°s √≠mpetus, sobre todo, nuevas fuerzas pol√≠tica ...

En la segunda mitad del siglo XX y en el siglo XXI, nuevas fuerzas pol√≠ticas globales disputan la hegemon√≠a americana en Am√©rica Latina.

La experiencia de la fracasada corriente comunista sovi√©tica, con Cuba como ejemplo de dictadura, fue asimilada por el r√©gimen comunista chino. China prioriza el comercio y la inversi√≥n, implementando la ‚ÄúRuta de la Seda‚Äù, para incrementar su influencia.

El Foro Celac-China es una muestra de los avances de la influencia de China en el continente americano. China compite con Norteam√©rica, sin interferir en asuntos pol√≠ticos, enfoc√°ndose en comercio e inversi√≥n.

title: Low prices and Trump's trade war are pushing these Northwest farmers to the brink
content: Almost all of the wheat grown in the Pacific Northwest is for export, and even before President Trump's trade war, farmers were dealing with rock bottom prices and slagging global demand.
resumen:
Almost all of the wheat grown in the Pacific Northwest is for export.

Farmers were dealing with rock bottom prices and slagging global demand even before President Trump's trade war.

Jim Moyer's great-grandfather first started growing wheat in eastern Washington in the 1890s.

Typically more than 90% of all the wheat grown here ends up in countries like Japan, Korea and the Philippines.

Wheat prices have been stubbornly low for years while inflation continues to be high.

A combine now is a million dollars, a tractor is 500- to 750,000, a sprayer can be $750,000.

Farmers are still recovering from the first Trump trade war.

Uncertainty is something people across America's heartland are talking about, whether it be wheat farmers in states like Washington or Montana, or corn and soybean growers in North Dakota and Indiana.

The U.S. government spent decades building overseas markets for crops like soybeans and wheat.

In Washington state, Jim Moyer says wheat farmers are still recovering from the trade war in Trump's first term when the popular Trans-Pacific Partnership was torn up.

Byron Behne, a merchandiser with the Northwest Grain Growers, a farmer-owned cooperative in Walla Walla, Wash. says farmers are puzzled by the White House rhetoric, especially after Trump said on his social media platform that farmers should get ready to supply America, and to "have fun."

The Northwest states ‚Äî Washington, Idaho, Montana and Oregon ‚Äî have some of the highest wheat yields in the world.

A lot of things farmers also need, from tractor parts to fertilizer, have to be imported.

Farmer Jim Moyer, who recently retired as a scientist and dean at Washington State University, worries that a lot of his neighbors won't survive if the uncertainty persists.

Paul Reed, 20, is poised to take over his family's wheat, turf and canola farm near La Grande, Ore., when his uncle retires.

Reed is switching more of his operation to grass and lawn turf where he can.

He also hopes to send more grain to local feedlots instead of down to the river for export.

title: Estados Unidos eval√∫a acuerdos arancelarios regionales, incluye a Guatemala
content: Guatemala buscar√° ser incluida en los nuevos acuerdos arancelarios regionales que eval√∫a Estados Unidos, con el objetivo de revertir el arancel del 10% impuesto desde abril a sus exportaciones.
resumen: Estados Unidos eval√∫a acuerdos arancelarios regionales, incluyendo a Guatemala. Guatemala buscar√° ser incluida en los nuevos acuerdos arancelarios regionales que eval√∫a Estados Unidos, con el objetivo de revertir el arancel del 10% impuesto desde abril a sus exportaciones. El secretario del Tesoro de EE. UU., Scott Bessent, confirm√≥ que el Gobierno eval√∫a acuerdos arancelarios regionales como parte de su estrategia de reforma comercial. El Gobierno de Estados Unidos est√° evaluando la posibilidad de establecer acuerdos arancelarios regionales como parte de su estrategia para reformar la pol√≠tica comercial internacional. Bessent afirm√≥ que har√°n muchos acuerdos regionales, incluyendo Am√©rica Central. La propuesta surge en el contexto de las actuales negociaciones comerciales impulsadas por la administraci√≥n del presidente Donald Trump. Estados Unidos tiene actualmente 18 socios comerciales importantes y al menos otros 20 con relaciones s√≥lidas. Bessent destac√≥ que, si no negocian de buena fe, los aranceles podr√≠an retornar a los niveles del 2 de abril. El objetivo actual del Gobierno estadounidense es recuperar industrias como los medicamentos, semiconductores, acero y otros productos esenciales a mediano plazo. Desde el 2 de abril de 2025, Estados Unidos fij√≥ un arancel del 10% para las importaciones de productos guatemaltecos. El Gobierno de Guatemala anunci√≥ que el pr√≥ximo 27 de mayo se llevar√° a cabo una reuni√≥n clave en Washington D.C., en la que se espera discutir posibles ajustes arancelarios y la inclusi√≥n del pa√≠s en un eventual acuerdo regional. La delegaci√≥n guatemalteca estar√° encabezada por la ministra de Econom√≠a, Gabriela Garc√≠a, e integrada tambi√©n por el canciller Carlos Ramiro Mart√≠nez y el embajador de Guatemala en Estados Unidos, Hugo Beteta, seg√∫n confirm√≥ el Ministerio de Econom√≠a (Mineco).

title: China's factory output resists tariff impact, retail sales slow
content: China‚Äôs industrial output growth slows, retail sales expansion misses expectations Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
China‚Äôs factory output slowed in April but showed surprising resilience. Industrial output grew 6.1 per cent from a year earlier, National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) data showed on May 19, slowing from 7.7 per cent in March but beating a forecast 5.5 per cent rise in a Reuters poll.
Retail sales, a measure of consumption, rose 5.1 per cent in April, down from a 5.9 per cent increase in March, and missed forecasts for a 5.5 per cent expansion.
The government‚Äôs push to boost household spending via a trade-in scheme for consumer goods led to a 38.8 per cent gain in home appliance sales.
The NBS data showed the unemployment rate fell to 5.1 per cent from 5.2 per cent in March.
Beijing and Washington reached a surprise agreement last week to roll back most tariffs imposed on each other‚Äôs goods since early April.
China‚Äôs economy expanded 5.4 per cent in the first quarter.
The authorities remain confident of achieving Beijing‚Äôs growth target of around 5 per cent in 2025.
In April, Beijing and Washington escalated tariffs to over 100 per cent in several rounds of retaliatory moves.
The authorities earlier in May announced a package of stimulus measures, including interest rate cuts and a major liquidity injection.

title: LA PIEDRA DE S√çSIFO: La mejor defensa de la soberan√≠a
content: Se tuvo la intenci√≥n de mostrar a los tres l√≠deres latinoamericanos de Brasil, Colombia y Chile junto al l√≠der chino y distante la del representante de M√©xico.
resumen:
El 13 de mayo, la TVE difundi√≥ dos escenas simult√°neamente: la de los presidentes Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Gustavo Pedro y Gabriel Boric junto al presidente chino Xi Jinping, y la del canciller mexicano Juan Ram√≥n de la Fuente en una reuni√≥n China-CELAC.
En la reuni√≥n de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribe√±os (CELAC) y las organizaciones regionales de Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe (ALC), China anunci√≥ destinar diez mil millones de d√≥lares a nuevos cr√©ditos.
A la reuni√≥n en China asistieron el presidente uruguayo Yamand√∫ Orsi Mart√≠nez y otros representantes de la regi√≥n.
La ausencia de la presidenta mexicana Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo en la reuni√≥n fue notoria.
El 9 de abril, Sheinbaum estuvo en Tegucigalpa en una Cumbre de la CELAC donde plante√≥ una cumbre por el bienestar econ√≥mico de la regi√≥n, cooperar en la atenci√≥n a la movilidad humana, critic√≥ la criminalizaci√≥n de los migrantes y se pronunci√≥ contra el bloqueo a Cuba y Venezuela.
La reuni√≥n ministerial de China-CELAC revest√≠a mayor importancia estrat√©gica por la relaci√≥n de M√©xico con el gobierno de Trump.
La historia de las relaciones mexicanas con los gobiernos republicanos y dem√≥cratas ha sido de escaso entendimiento.
En su discurso p√∫blico, Sheinbaum defiende la soberan√≠a nacional.
El presidente Clinton otorg√≥ cr√©ditos al presidente Ernesto Zedillo por la crisis de 1994.
La presidenta Sheinbaum podr√≠a haber estado en dilemas entre las visiones de su secretario de Econom√≠a Marcelo Ebrard y la del secretario de Relaciones Exteriores, Juan Ram√≥n de la Fuente.
Estados Unidos y China son dos relaciones econ√≥micas y pol√≠ticas fundamentales para M√©xico.
En el pasado, el expresidente Ernesto Zedillo trat√≥ con dureza a la entonces presidenta de Nicaragua, Violeta Chamorro.
La pol√≠tica exterior mexicana hacia Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe se basa en la hermandad solidaria y buena vecindad.
La pol√≠tica exterior mexicana se sustenta en la defensa de la soberan√≠a nacional, construida por internacionalistas como Isidro Fabela, Genaro Estrada, L√°zaro C√°rdenas, Adolfo L√≥pez Mateos, Rafael de la Colina, Manuel Tello y Alfonso Garc√≠a Robles.
M√©xico desafi√≥ al imperio al mantener relaciones con la Cuba socialista, condenar el golpe militar de 1973 en Chile y apoyar la pacificaci√≥n de Centroam√©rica con el Grupo Contadora.
La mejor manera de defender la soberan√≠a nacional radica en una pol√≠tica exterior s√≥lida.

title: US tariffs does pose short-term threat, Asean resilience will prevail over long term, say experts
content: Wide-ranging unilateral tariffs imposed by the administration of the US President Donald Trump will cause short-term problems for certain sectors of the export-oriented states for Asean countries.
resumen:
Wide-ranging unilateral tariffs imposed by the administration of the US President Donald Trump will cause short-term problems for certain sectors of the export-oriented states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) grouping, but will lose their bite over time considering the resilience of these countries, according to analysts.

"An immediate impact of the tariffs is higher prices, which in turn lead to lower demand for most goods, resulting in a decline in exports from Asian economies," said Yeah Kim Leng, professor of economics at Sunway University in Malaysia.

"More worryingly, heightened policy uncertainty results in risk aversion and a loss of investor and consumer confidence, thereby leading to reduced business and consumer spending and an eventual economic contraction in a globalized world economy," he added.

Professor Roy Anthony Rogers, deputy executive director at the Asia-Europe Institute of Universiti Malaya, noted that these tariffs will inevitably lead to short-term supply chain and trade disruptions.

"As we live in a global economy, such actions will trigger a domino effect because of the supply chain dependencies and capital flow linkages," he told Xinhua.

ASEAN economies rely on export-dependent industries, which have large capital investments and high gearing, as well as large-scale infrastructure projects with huge foreign borrowings, making them particularly vulnerable to a "tariff war-financial risk" blow-out.

"Semiconductor and high-tech industries, including data centers, are vulnerable to U.S. sanctions on exports of advanced chips.

High-end advanced electronics and their supply chains are also at risk from Trump's reshoring pressures, while other products are confronted with potentially high tariffs that could render them non-tradable or uncompetitive, especially if other exporting countries manage to negotiate lower tariff rates.

The solar photovoltaic sector in Malaysia is already taking a hit.

Asean states have been mobilizing to respond to the economic threats posed by the tariffs.

Malaysia, as the chair of Asean, should call for a special summit among heads of states, ministers of trade, and ministers of finance to meet and negotiate with the Trump administration as a single bloc to maximize their clout.

"Perhaps it is time to revive the East Asia Economic Caucus (EAEC 2.0) to enhance intra-regional trade and reduce over-dependency on the U.S. market. However, it should include Australia and New Zealand to demonstrate that EAEC 2.0 is not against the West, but rather a move to strengthen our resilience," he said.

Southeast Asian states will move to seek alternative markets.

"The industries that have close links with the U.S. may be badly affected, such as semiconductors and technology exports. Therefore, Southeast Asian states should find alternatives," he explained.

The tariffs would undermine the economic position of the U.S. itself, as countries in Asean and worldwide race to de-risk, de-dollarize, and build up insulation against the economic disruptions caused by the U.S., moves that will not favor the country in the long term.

"Financial market volatility has ratcheted up, with US stock and bond markets suffering severe losses in anticipation of the negative tariff impact on the U.S. and global economy, higher inflation and a shift away from US. dollar assets."

"If there is no de-escalation of the tariff conflicts, the US could be the 'ground zero' for a regional financial crisis, which could also envelop highly indebted countries vulnerable to capital flight," he said.

A repeat of the 1997-98 Asian Financial Crisis is unlikely, due to the region's reduced reliance on foreign borrowings, stronger fiscal resilience arising from improved fiscal balances, and low to moderate government debt level.

"Moreover, their trade and investment linkages with China have increased considerably over the decades, which could partially shield the individual countries from U.S. economic or financial shocks," he said.

"What I fear is that if the tariff war continues, it will lead to a global economic recession, and if not resolved, may also lead to war, very much like the situation back in the 1930s," he cautioned.

title: China puts heavy 75% tax on US imports of vital engineering plastic

Las medidas se producen a pesar de una tregua arancelaria de 90 d√≠as entre Estados Unidos y China. El pl√°stico en cuesti√≥n es una alternativa ligera y duradera a metales como el cobre y el zinc y se utiliza ampliamente en piezas de autom√≥viles, electr√≥nica, bienes de consumo, construcci√≥n y materiales farmac√©uticos. title: US-China tariff pause eases trade tension
content: The temporary agreement between the US and China to slash the severe reciprocal tariffs imposed on each other and to cooperate to prevent further disruption to the global economy should have a ...
resumen: The US and China reached a temporary agreement to slash reciprocal tariffs and cooperate to prevent further disruption to the global economy. This should have a positive impact on trade and ease the strain on global supply chains. The agreement has left many countries, including Thailand, feeling relieved and concerned. The relief stems from a clearer stance between the two largest adversaries in the tariff war, while the concern is related to uncertainty about the second round of talks. The agreement helps stabilize the global supply chain and reduces negative impacts on the logistics system. Marketing management should also become easier. The pact also affects transport systems. The US tariffs also affected demand in the US, leading to product shortages on store shelves. In the financial sector, the measures have diminished the US's status as a safe haven. China was also affected, particularly its small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The US tariffs stunted the economy in Yiwu, the world's largest wholesale market located in Zhejiang province. If this downturn drags on, it could result in up to 10 million job losses in China. A key factor driving the US to accelerate negotiations with China is the upcoming summer holiday season in the US. Walmart indicated its current inventory will only last another 2-4 weeks. US budget discussions are expected to continue over the next few months, with the 2026 plan calling for US$7 trillion in expenditure, $5 trillion in revenue and a $2-trillion deficit. This amount does not include $7 trillion in maturing debt that will need to be refinanced and rolled over this year. If the two sides do not reach a resolution in a second round of talks, both positive and negative effects are projected for the global supply chain. If the US and China can reach a resolution before the end of the 90-day pause granted to other countries, it would serve as a benchmark for those nations and help them prepare to manage their own supply chains.

China est√° cortejando a los aliados de Estados Unidos, como la Uni√≥n Europea, Jap√≥n, Corea del Sur, Filipinas y Malasia, aprovechando la p√©rdida de confianza en Estados Unidos.

Estados Unidos impuso aranceles a las importaciones chinas, que llegaron hasta el 145%, y a las ventas estadounidenses, que alcanzaron el 125%, antes de descender a 30% y 10%, respectivamente, como parte de una tregua de 90 d√≠as.

China ha aprovechado la situaci√≥n para acercarse a los aliados de Estados Unidos, ofreciendo cooperaci√≥n y ocupando espacios dejados por Estados Unidos.

title: Laura L√≥pez, gerente de Procomer: ‚ÄòEstamos en los 90 d√≠as de incertidumbre‚Äô
content: Los aranceles del 10% anunciados por Donald Trump generan incertidumbre sobre el futuro de la inversi√≥n extranjera en Costa Rica. Laura L√≥pez, gerente general de Procomer, habla de la estrategia que t ...
resumen:
Laura L√≥pez, gerente de Procomer, se√±ala que el pa√≠s atraviesa un per√≠odo de espera de 90 d√≠as para conocer los efectos concretos y aplicar una estrategia nacional recientemente actualizada.
El Banco Central de Costa Rica (BCCR) advierte que los aranceles impuestos por el gobierno de Donald Trump a sus socios comerciales, incluido Costa Rica, afectar√°n los flujos de inversi√≥n hacia el pa√≠s durante 2025 y 2026.
Procomer tiene una visi√≥n diferente.
En 2024, Estados Unidos aport√≥ el 70% de la inversi√≥n extranjera directa en Costa Rica.
El a√±o pasado hubo 61 proyectos de inversi√≥n; en 2023 hubo 59.
Para este a√±o se ten√≠a una proyecci√≥n de incremento que se defini√≥ desde que se lanz√≥ la nueva estrategia de atracci√≥n de inversi√≥n extranjera en 2023, con metas espec√≠ficas para cada a√±o.
El anuncio de la administraci√≥n Trump ha generado incertidumbre en los mercados internacionales.
El anuncio se dio el 2 de abril.
Durante 90 d√≠as habr√° un proceso de negociaci√≥n que podr√≠a derivar en una tarifa diferenciada por pa√≠s.
Las inversiones y los proyectos con los que se ven√≠a trabajando contin√∫an anunciando su llegada y sus ampliaciones.
Desde Comex y Procomer se ha trabajado para colocar al pa√≠s en una situaci√≥n m√°s ventajosa frente al arancel del 10%.
La Junta Directiva aprob√≥ el fortalecimiento del plan de diversificaci√≥n, aprobado el a√±o anterior, con m√°s de 200 acciones dirigidas a diversificar mercados.
Se incorporaron acciones no solo de prospecci√≥n de nuevos mercados, sino tambi√©n activaciones en m√°s de 125 puntos en Europa.

El Banco Central se√±ala que m√°s del 60% del flujo de inversi√≥n extranjera se concentra en zonas francas.
Con la nueva estrategia de inversi√≥n extranjera directa, se destaca la necesidad de aumentar la inversi√≥n en r√©gimen definitivo, especialmente en los sectores agr√≠cola y comercial.

Europa representa otro 20% y Centroam√©rica otro 20%.

title: Incertidumbre y desaf√≠os de gesti√≥n de la guerra arancelaria
content: El diccionario de la Real Academia de la Lengua Espa√±ola define la palabra incertidumbre como falta de certidumbre; duda, perplejidad. Es sin√≥nimo de falta de ...
resumen: La palabra incertidumbre se define como falta de certidumbre; duda, perplejidad. En econom√≠a, la incertidumbre se refiere a la dificultad para predecir o evaluar el futuro comportamiento de las variables econ√≥micas o de la actividad econ√≥mica en su conjunto, lo que puede conducir a decisiones de consumo e inversi√≥n retrasadas o aplazadas. Acontecimientos disruptivos o inesperados como la pandemia de COVID-19, las draconianas y unilaterales medidas arancelarias de Trump, etc., aumentan la incertidumbre, lo que dificulta la toma de decisiones con efectos directos en la marcha de la econom√≠a. La guerra arancelaria ha marcado un cambio profundo en el comercio internacional, erosionando el multilateralismo y el libre comercio. Al imponer aranceles unilaterales a casi todos los pa√≠ses, incluido China, la Uni√≥n Europea, M√©xico, Canad√°, etc. el presidente Trump ha despertado una ola de proteccionismo que ha contribuido a un clima de creciente incertidumbre econ√≥mica internacional. Se aplazan decisiones sin las cuales la econom√≠a no avanza. Disminuye la confianza de los actores econ√≥micos; aumenta la volatilidad de las variables econ√≥micas; se reduce la inversi√≥n; se pierde la estabilidad macroecon√≥mica y se reduce el crecimiento econ√≥mico. La Reserva Federal de San Luis ha desarrollado un √çndice de Incertidumbre de Pol√≠tica Econ√≥mica que proporciona una visi√≥n cuantitativa de la percepci√≥n de incertidumbre en el entorno econ√≥mico de Estados Unidos. Un aumento del √≠ndice significa mayor incertidumbre y es lo que se observa al cierre del primer trimestre de 2025. La incertidumbre en la econom√≠a estadounidense ha experimentado un notable aumento: pas√≥ de un valor de 167.39, en enero de 2025, a 228.63 (en febrero), escalando hasta 296.92 en el mes de marzo. Este aumento en la incertidumbre es el resultado, adem√°s de la imposici√≥n de aranceles, de una serie de pol√≠ticas implementadas durante los primeros 100 d√≠as del segundo mandato del presidente Trump; entre las que cabe destacar los recortes significativos en el gasto federal y la cancelaci√≥n de m√°s de 275,000 empleados civiles despedidos, cifra que representa aproximadamente el 12% de la fuerza laboral civil federal. El resultado inmediato de todas esas medidas ha sido una ca√≠da del crecimiento econ√≥mico de Estados Unidos a -0.3% en el primer trimestre. La Reserva Federal ha revisado a la baja su pron√≥stico de crecimiento del PIB de Estados Unidos para 2025, reduci√©ndolo del 2.1% al 1.7%. El FMI proyecta ahora un crecimiento de la econom√≠a estadounidense de apenas 1.8%, una reducci√≥n de 0.8 puntos porcentuales con relaci√≥n a la proyecci√≥n anterior de crecimiento de 2.7%. La pol√≠tica arancelaria de Trump no s√≥lo ha alterado las relaciones econ√≥micas entre grandes potencias, sino que ha generado ondas expansivas que amenazan la estabilidad y el crecimiento de las econom√≠as en desarrollo. De prolongarse esta situaci√≥n, se erosionar√°n a√∫n m√°s los cimientos de la estabilidad econ√≥mica, lo que terminar√° afectando la producci√≥n, el consumo, la inversi√≥n, el comercio, el empleo y la cohesi√≥n social. Para la Rep√∫blica Dominicana, con una econom√≠a abierta y peque√±a y fuertemente dependiente del comercio internacional, la inversi√≥n extranjera y la estabilidad del entorno global, el clima de incertidumbre generado por la pol√≠tica de Trump es especialmente perjudicial. Gestionar las amenazas y riesgos que plantea la guerra arancelaria y reducir los impactos sobre el crecimiento en el largo plazo, son grandes desaf√≠os que nuestro pa√≠s tiene por delante. La Rep√∫blica Dominicana tiene que plantearse seriamente un redise√±o de su modelo econ√≥mico hacia una mayor diversificaci√≥n de los destinos de las exportaciones y de la canasta exportadora, reducir la dependencia de un solo mercado y fortalecer el mercado interno. Implica mejorar la competitividad del pa√≠s, desarrollar pol√≠ticas de innovaci√≥n, buscar acuerdos comerciales con nuevos socios, y un rol m√°s agresivo, inteligente y eficiente de la diplomacia econ√≥mica.

title: Temu And Shein Caught In The Crossfire Of Changing Tariff Policy
content: While the Trump administration announced a temporary trade deal Monday slashing tariffs on Chinese goods, the rules on de minimis deliveries still include a $100 charge.
resumen: The U.S. $800 de minimis exemption for goods imported from China has been reduced but not cancelled. The Trump administration announced a temporary trade deal that slashed tariffs on Chinese goods to 30% from 145% for a 90-day period while talks continue. Tariff rules that hit direct to consumer imports have also been cut in half, but a $100 flat-fee option wasn‚Äôt changed. The tariff rate wasn‚Äôt reduced to 54%, but still maintaining the $100 fee option. Many imports of low cost orders from Temu and Shein have still been priced out by the modified rules. The de minimis relates specifically to small packages shipped directly to consumers from abroad. Such packages were shipped in huge quantities to the U.S. by China‚Äôs online discount powerhouses. The $800 ceiling in the U.S. is high compared with many other countries, having been raised in the U.S. by President Barack Obama from $200 in 2016. In neighboring Canada, it is about $40 and in Europe around $150. Around four million small packages claiming de minimis exemptions crossed into the U.S. daily last year. The packages are also thought to be one of the ways in which opioid drugs such as fentanyl being smuggled into the U.S. ‚Äì a huge area of focus for President Trump ‚Äì and former President Joe Biden had also been looking at changing the de minimis rules during his administration. Individual shipments to the U.S. claiming de minimis exemptions annually now exceed more than a billion, up from around 140 million a decade before. Nomura Holdings estimated that around $46 billion of U.S.-bound packages came from China last year, double China‚Äôs own reckonings. In 2024, total annual imports were valued at over $5.3 trillion. The clampdown on the de minimis exemption for imports from mainland China and Hong Kong means products normally using the loophole are now being channeled through customs and are incurring levies. Ecommerce deliveries from China are also likely to become slower and elongate delivery times as exporters switch to shipping over air cargo. India could be the big winner in the post-tariff fall out at the expense of some Southeast Asian production countries. Ken Pilot, founder of Ken Pilot Ventures, said the U.K. has tariffs of 10%, perhaps Vietnam will finish up at 25-30%.

title: Ni√±o Becerra enciende las alarmas: ‚ÄúEn verano podemos llegar a una situaci√≥n Covid de paralizaci√≥n de la econom√≠a mundial‚Äù
content: Esto est√° creando una confrontaci√≥n con China y ha generado una fuerte ca√≠da de las bolsas. Sobre esto se ha pronunciado Santiago Ni√±o Becerra, un reconocido economista espa√±ol y catedr√°tico de ...
resumen: Santiago Ni√±o Becerra, economista espa√±ol y catedr√°tico de Estructura Econ√≥mica en el Instituto Qu√≠mico de Sarri√° de la Universidad Ram√≥n Llull de Barcelona desde 1994, advierte sobre una posible par√°lisis econ√≥mica mundial en verano, similar a la situaci√≥n vivida durante la pandemia de Covid-19. El economista ha mostrado un gr√°fico de Standard's&Poor's, donde el √≠ndice de la bolsa en 2008 era de 735 y en 2025 de 6.101. Ni√±o Becerra ha declarado que la especulaci√≥n es la √∫nica raz√≥n de esta situaci√≥n. El economista ha detallado que si la situaci√≥n empeora con m√°s aranceles y r√©plicas, en verano se podr√≠a llegar a una situaci√≥n de paralizaci√≥n de la econom√≠a mundial. El experto cree que la situaci√≥n Covid puede llegar si se estira mucho la negociaci√≥n entre China y Estados Unidos. El economista cree que China va ganando en esta guerra.

title: Multilateralism without the US?
content: It took only a few months for US president Donald Trump to seriously disrupt a global order that has existed since World War II.
resumen:
The world has spent the past 80 years building the current multilateral system ‚Äì anchored by institutions like the United Nations and the World Bank. This system was largely designed and driven by the United States with the goal of ensuring lasting peace and shared prosperity.

US president Donald Trump seriously disrupted this structure by withdrawing from or weakening key multilateral treaties and organizations.

The pressing question is whether the multilateral world can endure without the active engagement of the United States.

Middle-power countries like South Korea have a role to play in this evolving global landscape.

Seoul must define and assert its role to stay relevant as the international order shifts rapidly under the weight of Trump‚Äôs impulsive and unpredictable trade and security policies.

In a new multipolar system, Korea needs leadership that understands and champions the multilateralism that has underpinned its economic and security gains for decades.

The multilateral system is unlikely to collapse with the withdrawal of its chief architect.

Institutions like intergovernmental organizations and other frameworks of global governance have proven resilient.

The contours of the system will inevitably shift, with new norms and agendas shaped by rising powers such as the EU and the BRICS countries ‚Äì Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.

Trump has pulled the US out of several intergovernmental organizations, including UN cultural and science agency Unesco, the UN Human Rights Council and the World Health Organisation.

He cited alleged anti-Israel and pro-China biases as justifications.

These withdrawals, coupled with the US exit from the Paris Agreement on climate change, have seriously weakened multilateral institutions.

The WHO has reported funding shortfalls that it warns could endanger global health efforts.

Trump imposed or threatened steep tariffs on both allies and rivals.

Product-specific tariffs ‚Äì on steel, automobiles and more ‚Äì were layered on top.

Trump‚Äôs latest move, a proposal for sweeping ‚Äúreciprocal tariffs,‚Äù would impose a 25% blanket tariff on Korean exports to the US.

His agenda is clear: Dismantle the WTO‚Äôs multilateral trade framework and replace it with bilateral deals where American leverage is maximised.

Multilateralism is likely to persist ‚Äì though in a different form.

International mechanisms will be increasingly influenced by multiple major players.

The EU is already stepping up, not just in Europe but globally.

European nations have committed to increased defense spending in response to Trump‚Äôs demands to restructure Nato.

Regional organizations like the African Union and Asean are poised to take on more active roles.

Non-Western powers, especially BRICS nations, will bring new momentum to multilateralism.

China‚Äôs Belt and Road Initiative and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank directly challenge the US-dominated global financial architecture led by the World Bank and the IMF.

Even the supremacy of the US dollar could come under question.

This evolving multilateralism brings real risks, including the infusion of values that challenge the West‚Äôs liberal, rules-based order.

Disillusioned developing countries may be drawn to alternative systems that emphasize state sovereignty over democracy and human rights.

A multilateral order led by authoritarian regimes could prioritize control and coercion over cooperation and fairness.

Middle powers like South Korea must step forward.

Korea should assert its voice to defend and promote a liberal international order from which it has greatly benefited.

UN military support during the Korean War and postwar financial aid from institutions like the World Bank were foundational to Korea‚Äôs security and economic rise.

Korea must help sustain the system in the absence of its original architect.

Korea must take the lead in key areas like digital governance, climate resilience and global health.

Korea should proactively set the agenda and help shape international discourse, following in the footsteps of model middle powers such as Canada or Norway.

Korea must partner with other like-minded nations committed to multilateral cooperation.

Korea must elect a leader who not only understands the value of multilateralism but is also willing to defend it at any cost.

Former journalist Lee Byung-jong is a professor at the School of Global Service at Sookmyung Women‚Äôs University in Seoul.

title: Trump urges Walmart to absorb tariffs after retailer says it could raise prices
content: President Donald Trump scolded Walmart on Saturday after the retail giant warned that his tariffs would force it to raise prices, writing on social media that the discount chain could afford to absorb ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump scolded Walmart on Saturday after the retail giant warned that his tariffs would force it to raise prices. Trump wrote on social media that the discount chain could afford to absorb the costs of the new import taxes without passing them on to customers.

Trump wrote on Truth Social, his social media site, ‚ÄúWalmart should STOP trying to blame Tariffs as the reason for raising prices throughout the chain.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúWalmart made BILLIONS OF DOLLARS last year, far more than expected.‚Äù He called on Walmart, the nation‚Äôs largest retailer, to ‚ÄúEAT THE TARIFFS‚Äù and keep prices down. He wrote, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be watching, and so will your customers.‚Äù

Walmart said Thursday that Trump‚Äôs tariffs, even at their recently reduced levels, would soon force it to start raising prices. Walmart CEO Doug McMillon said on a call with analysts that the company would not be able to ‚Äúabsorb all the pressure‚Äù imposed by the tariffs.

A spokesperson for Walmart, which is based in Arkansas and has more than 4,000 stores in the United States, repeated Saturday that the company would do its best to keep its prices from rising. The spokesperson, Molly Blakeman, said in a statement after Trump‚Äôs post, ‚ÄúWe have always worked to keep our prices as low as possible and we won‚Äôt stop.‚Äù She added, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll keep prices as low as we can for as long as we can given the reality of small retail margins.‚Äù

The company, which says it counts 90% of Americans as its customers, has refrained from projecting profits for its current quarter because of the tariffs. It has said its sales climbed by more than 3%, to $112 billion, in the most recent quarter, which ended last month, and it has projected that its revenue would grow by 3% to 4% this year.

About one-third of Walmart‚Äôs products come from abroad, John David Rainey, the company‚Äôs chief financial officer, has said.

Ryan Sweet, the chief U.S. economist at the advisory firm Oxford Economics, said Saturday that it was no surprise that the tariffs would begin to drive prices up.

title: Qu√© productos se podr√≠an encarecer por los aranceles en Walmart
content: Por Auzinea Bacon, CNN A los compradores de Walmart se les acaba el tiempo para evitar precios m√°s altos. El gigante minorista advirti√≥ el jueves que sus productos se encarecer√°n debido a que los aran ...
resumen:
Los compradores de Walmart se enfrentan a precios m√°s altos debido a los aranceles del presidente Donald Trump, seg√∫n advirti√≥ el gigante minorista.

El CEO de Walmart, Douglas McMillon, declar√≥ que los productos se encarecer√°n debido a que los aranceles son ‚Äúdemasiado altos‚Äù.

Los cambios probablemente entrar√°n en vigor a finales de mayo, y los precios aumentar√°n ‚Äúmucho m√°s‚Äù en junio, seg√∫n el director financiero de Walmart, John David Rainey.

Walmart, con m√°s de 4.600 tiendas en Estados Unidos, recibe mercanc√≠a de Canad√°, China, India, M√©xico y Vietnam, entre otros pa√≠ses. Estos pa√≠ses enfrentan aranceles de al menos el 10 %, y las importaciones de acero, aluminio, autom√≥viles y autopartes enfrentan aranceles del 25 %.

Trump aument√≥ los aranceles sobre la mayor√≠a de los productos chinos a un 145 %, pero esa tasa se redujo al 30 % como parte de una tregua de 90 d√≠as con China.

Los aranceles base no bajar√°n del 10 % durante las negociaciones, seg√∫n el secretario de Comercio, Howard Lutnick.

Los economistas han declarado que los aranceles afectar√°n a los estadounidenses de ingresos bajos y medios, quienes hist√≥ricamente han sido la principal base de clientes de Walmart.

Los pl√°tanos, los aguacates y el caf√© se encuentran entre los productos que provienen de Colombia, Costa Rica y Per√∫. Estados Unidos tambi√©n importa remolacha, repollo, melones y pi√±as de Costa Rica. Las batatas y los c√≠tricos se importan de Per√∫.

Entre febrero y abril, el precio promedio de los pl√°tanos por libra aument√≥ aproximadamente 2 centavos en los minoristas estadounidenses, seg√∫n la Oficina de Estad√≠sticas Laborales.

Walmart se centra actualmente en las compras para la vuelta al colegio, seg√∫n McMillon.

Los aranceles se pagan en cuanto un producto entra al pa√≠s por la aduana, lo que significa que los aranceles m√°s altos ya est√°n afectando los env√≠os.

China representa un gran volumen en categor√≠as como electr√≥nica y juguetes.

Aproximadamente el 80 % de los juguetes vendidos en Estados Unidos se fabrican en China, seg√∫n la Asociaci√≥n de Juguetes.

Compa√±√≠as de juguetes, como Hasbro y Mattel, han anunciado que algunos art√≠culos ser√°n eliminados de su cat√°logo, y han advertido de posibles subidas de precios debido a los aranceles.

El precio de una mu√±eca Barbie con traje de ba√±o vendida en Target subi√≥ un 42,9 % en una semana a mediados de abril, hasta los US$ 14,99.

La Switch 2 de Nintendo podr√≠a costar alrededor de US$ 600, y un iPhone 17 de Apple podr√≠a costar m√°s de US$ 1.000.

Los productos de cuidado infantil, como cochecitos, ropa, sillas de auto y leche de f√≥rmula, tambi√©n podr√≠an experimentar un aumento de precios. Alrededor del 90 % de los productos para ni√±os y beb√©s se fabrican exclusivamente en China.

En 2024, China envi√≥ m√°s de US$ 438.000 millones en bienes a los hogares estadounidenses. Casi el 19 % de ese total correspondi√≥ a maquinaria y electrodom√©sticos. El 4 % de las importaciones chinas del a√±o pasado fueron ropa de cama, muebles e iluminaci√≥n.

Las ventas de art√≠culos generales en Estados Unidos disminuyeron ligeramente durante el primer trimestre, ‚Äúcon una debilidad en los productos electr√≥nicos, los productos para el hogar y los art√≠culos deportivos‚Äù.

title: Donald Trump arremete contra Walmart por subir precios tras aranceles: "gan√≥ mucho m√°s de lo esperado"
content: El expresidente estadounidense acusa a la cadena minorista de lucrar pese a la guerra comercial y exigi√≥ que "se coman los aranceles".
resumen: El expresidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, se lanz√≥ contra la cadena de tiendas Walmart a trav√©s de la red social Truth Social. Trump acus√≥ a Walmart de lucrar pese a la guerra comercial y exigi√≥ que "se coman los aranceles". Walmart report√≥ resultados s√≥lidos en el primer trimestre del a√±o, con ingresos por 165,600 millones de d√≥lares y ganancias por 4,500 millones, cifras por encima de lo estimado por analistas, a pesar de ser 12.1% menores que el a√±o anterior. La empresa advirti√≥ sobre el impacto de la guerra arancelaria impulsada por Trump, que ha elevado los precios de productos como electr√≥nicos, juguetes, frutas y flores importadas de pa√≠ses como China, Costa Rica, Per√∫ y Colombia. El director general de Walmart, Doug McMillon, reconoci√≥ que no son capaces de absorber toda la presi√≥n de los aranceles.

title: Trump tells Walmart to ‚Äòeat the tariffs‚Äô as retailer expects prices to increase
content: U.S. President Donald Trump on Saturday said Walmart needs to stop ‚Äútrying to blame tariffs‚Äù after the retail giant announced its products would become more expensive.
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump said Walmart needs to stop ‚Äútrying to blame tariffs‚Äù after the retail giant announced its products would become more expensive.

Walmart‚Äôs CEO said the price increases were a result of Trump‚Äôs tariffs being ‚Äútoo high,‚Äù particularly when it came to Chinese goods.

Walmart CEO Douglas McMillon said Thursday in an earnings call, ‚ÄúWe will do our best to keep our prices as low as possible. But given the magnitude of the tariffs, even at the reduced levels announced this week, we aren‚Äôt able to absorb all the pressure given the reality of narrow retail margins.‚Äù

Trump responded on Saturday, posting to Truth Social that ‚ÄúBetween Walmart and China they should, as is said ‚ÄòEAT THE TARIFFS,‚Äô and not charge valued customers ANYTHING. I‚Äôll be watching, and so will your customers!‚Äù

Trump‚Äôs comments echoed Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick‚Äôs comments Sunday on CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúState of the Union,‚Äù arguing that ‚Äúbusinesses and the countries primarily eat the tariff.‚Äù

Former U.S. treasury secretary Larry Summers has called such theories ‚Äúludicrous.‚Äù

Economists have told CNN that the tariffs will burden lower- and middle-income Americans, who have historically been Walmart‚Äôs primary customer base.

The changes will likely take effect by the end of May, and prices will increase ‚Äúmuch more‚Äù in June, Walmart‚Äôs finance chief, John David Rainey, told CNBC.

Walmart, which has over 4,600 stores in the United States, gets merchandise from Canada, China, India, Mexico and Vietnam, among other nations. Those countries face at least 10 per cent in tariffs, and imports of steel, aluminum, cars and auto parts face 25 per cent tariffs.

McMillon said, ‚ÄúAll of the tariffs create cost pressure for us, but the larger tariffs on China have the biggest impact.‚Äù

Trump increased tariffs on most Chinese goods to a whopping 145 per cent, but that rate dropped to 30 per cent on Monday as part of a 90-day truce with China.

Trump said the tariffs could become ‚Äúsubstantially higher‚Äù if a trade agreement with China is not reached.

Baseline tariffs will not go lower than 10 per cent during negotiations, Lutnick told CNN on Sunday.

The University of Michigan reported that consumer sentiment fell 2.7 per cent between April and May.

McMillon said, ‚ÄúFood inflation is very much on our mind.‚Äù

Bananas, avocados and coffee are among some of the groceries that McMillon said come from Colombia, Costa Rica and Peru. America also imports beets, cabbage, melons, and pineapples from Costa Rica. Sweet potatoes and citrus are imported from Peru.

Walmart did not say how much prices could increase on fruits and vegetables.

McMillon said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do our best to control what we can control in order to keep food prices as low as possible,‚Äù suggesting that ‚Äúcontrolling the amount of fresh food waste‚Äù could help.

Between February and April, the average price of bananas per pound has increased by about two cents at U.S. retailers, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Ryan Monarch, assistant professor of economics at Syracuse University, told CNN that seasonal and holiday shopping purchases can‚Äôt be delayed for two to three months to wait on the trade war to play out.

Walmart is currently focused on back-to-school shopping, according to McMillon.

McMillon explained that tariffs are paid as soon as a product enters the country through customs, meaning the higher tariffs are already affecting shipments.

McMillon said, ‚ÄúSo I think what we‚Äôre looking at is upward pressure that began in April and plays through the entire year on things that are imported.‚Äù

Estimating tariff costs and order quantities could ‚Äúget more challenging‚Äù further down the line when making ‚Äúdecisions related to things like Halloween and Christmas,‚Äù he said.

McMillon said, ‚ÄúChina, in particular, represents a lot of volume in certain categories like electronics and toys.‚Äù

Roughly 80 per cent of toys sold in the United States are made in China, according to the Toy Association, an industry group.

Toy companies, like Hasbro, the owner of Nerf and Play-doh, said some items will be cut from its portfolio, and Barbie creator Mattel has issued warnings about potential price hikes due to tariffs.

Trump said, ‚ÄúWell, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls, you know? And maybe the two dolls will cost a couple of bucks more than they would normally,‚Äù acknowledging the potential impact tariffs will have on toys.

Product pricing analysis from research firm Telsey Advisory Groups showed that the price of a Barbie doll with a swimsuit sold at Walmart‚Äôs competitor Target rose 42.9 per cent over a week in mid-April to US$14.99.

Gaming products should also see big price hikes. Initially priced at $450, Nintendo‚Äôs Switch 2 could instead cost around $600, according to experts.

An Apple iPhone 17 could cost more than $1,000 instead of $799, according to Daniel Morgan, senior portfolio manager at investment firm Synovus.

Industry experts estimate that about 90 per cent of children‚Äôs and baby gear products are manufactured exclusively in China, and that won‚Äôt change anytime soon.

Syracuse University‚Äôs Monarch said, ‚ÄúCustomers need those things. Even if they were to raise prices on those products, customers are still going to buy them. So you might expect products like that to see prices increasing pretty quickly.‚Äù

In 2024, China sent more than $438 billion worth of goods into American homes. Nearly 19 per cent of that total was machinery and mechanical appliances, according to data from the U.S. International Trade Commission. Meanwhile, four per cent of last year‚Äôs imports from China were bedding, furniture and lighting.

Rainey, Walmart‚Äôs CFO, said general merchandise sales in the United States declined slightly during the first quarter, ‚Äúwith softness in electronics, home products and sporting goods.‚Äù

Monarch said, ‚ÄúConsumers are very worried, and what they‚Äôre doing is they‚Äôre delaying their purchases of durable goods ‚Äî things like cars, things like appliances.‚Äù

Monarch added that Walmart was among companies to increase imports before tariffs took effect.

title: El aporte del sector monetario (OPINION)
content: No se exagera si se afirma que la estabilidad y crecimiento de la econom√≠a se sustentan en las pol√≠ticas monetarias asumidas por el Banco Central y la Junta Monetaria que garantizan tambi√©n el control ...
resumen:
La estabilidad y crecimiento de la econom√≠a se sustentan en las pol√≠ticas monetarias asumidas por el Banco Central y la Junta Monetaria que garantizan el control de inflaci√≥n.

En 2023, el banco emisor asumi√≥ un programa para alcanzar la meta de inflaci√≥n de 4%+-1%, con la reducci√≥n de la TPM, de 8.50% hasta 7.0%, y la Junta Monetaria aprob√≥ un programa de expansi√≥n de liquidez, equivalente al 3% del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB), equivalente a 205 mil millones de pesos.

En 2024, las autoridades monetarias autorizaron una inyecci√≥n de liquidez a la econom√≠a de 175 mil millones de pesos, lo que permiti√≥ que el PIB cerrara en ese a√±o en un 5.0%, en cumplimiento de las metas de inflaci√≥n y estabilidad cambiaria, con una reducci√≥n de 275 puntos b√°sicos en la tasa de inter√©s de referencia.

La incertidumbre ha retornado al sector externo de la econom√≠a a causa de la prolongaci√≥n de la guerra entre Rusia y Ucrania, el conflicto en la Franja de Gaza y la guerra del arancel iniciada por el presidente Donald Trump, lo que obliga al Banco Central a una mayor cautela en el monitoreo del √≠ndice de inflaci√≥n y de la estabilidad en el tipo de cambio.

El sector financiero exhibe gran fortaleza en t√©rminos de liquidez, rentabilidad y expansi√≥n del cr√©dito, con activos netos que a marzo de este a√±o ascendieron a RD$3.9 billones, para un crecimiento interanual de 10.5%.

En enero y febrero de este a√±o, la econom√≠a creci√≥ en 1.7% en t√©rmino interanual, pero en marzo, tuvo una expansi√≥n de 4.5%, lo que permiti√≥ que el trimestre cerrara con un promedio de 2,7%, en perspectivas de alcanzar a finales de 2025, un nivel superior al 4.0%.

La expansi√≥n del cr√©dito bancario, de un 17.5% interanual ha incidido en el crecimiento de sectores como construcci√≥n, manufactura, agropecuaria y exportaci√≥n, aunque tambi√©n la econom√≠a recibe el ox√≠geno de m√°s de 43 mil millones de d√≥lares que ingresan a trav√©s de turismo, remesas, inversiones, exportaciones y zonas francas.

El endeudamiento p√∫blico al 31 de marzo se ubic√≥ en US$59,600.8 millones (47.1% del PIB), d√©ficit fiscal (3.0%) y baja inversi√≥n de capital (2.2%).

Los presidentes Leonel Fern√°ndez, Danilo Medina y Luis Abinader acertaron al nombrar y confirmar a H√©ctor Valdez Albizu, en la gobernaci√≥n del Banco Central.

title: Trump‚Äôs tariffs are undermining the U.S. economy
content: Unless the administration pivots away from its current punitive, protectionist approach and adopts a more stable, globally cooperative economic policy, the U.S. may enter a recession.
resumen: The U.S. economy may be headed toward a recession due to the Trump administration‚Äôs erratic trade policy. In the first quarter of 2025, the economy shrank at an annualized rate of 0.3 percent. Consumer sentiment declined again this month and is now down nearly 30 percent since President Donald Trump took office. Consumer sentiment is now at its second-lowest level on record. Inflation expectations among the consumer sentiment survey respondents soared to multi-decade highs. Nearly 75 percent of respondents in the Michigan survey cited tariffs as a significant concern. The recent 90-day tariff truce between the U.S. and China, which temporarily lowers tariffs on both sides offers a brief and partial reprieve. U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods remain high at 30 percent. Walmart will raise prices to offset the pressure from tariffs. When import costs spike due to tariffs, those costs get passed down the supply chain. Consumer spending, which makes up nearly 70 percent of U.S. GDP, begins to contract. Businesses, especially small and mid-sized ones, are facing growing uncertainty over future input costs and export conditions. Capital investment is already slowing. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon recently said that a U.S. recession remains a possibility. The U.S. has strong underlying indicators: low unemployment, healthy corporate earnings, and a robust innovation ecosystem. According to a recent Echelon Insights poll, 54 percent of Americans now disapprove of Trump‚Äôs handling of the economy. The administration could reinstate predictable trade frameworks, consult with business leaders on supply chain resilience, and roll back harmful tariffs.

title: The RBA‚Äôs war on inflation inflicts $290 billion bill on home buyers
content: Home buyers and investors have paid more than a quarter trillion dollars in interest to help bring down inflation. They may get another rate cut this week.
resumen: The Reserve Bank is poised to bring official interest rates below 4 per cent for the first time in more than two years. The bank‚Äôs monetary policy board starts its two-day meeting on Monday with financial markets expecting the cash rate to be sliced another quarter of a percentage point to 3.85 per cent. Reserve Bank governor Michele Bullock is expected to announce a quarter percentage point interest rate cut this week. The last time it was under 4 per cent was in May 2023 when headline inflation was at 7 per cent and underlying inflation was above 6 per cent. Headline inflation has fallen to 2.4 per cent while underlying inflation is at 2.9 per cent. On a $600,000 mortgage, a quarter percentage point cut would reduce monthly repayments by about $100. Australian home buyers paid out a record $20 billion in interest on their mortgages in the just completed March quarter. Over 12 months to March, they shelled out almost $80 billion in interest ‚Äì a 159 per cent increase on the amount paid in the 12 months before the RBA‚Äôs first rate rise in May 2022. Australian borrowers have paid almost $290 billion in interest on their home loans since 2022. In the three years before that, they paid $157.5 billion. Key data last week which showed unemployment steady at 4.1 per cent and wages growth at 3.4 per cent were largely in line with the Reserve Bank‚Äôs economic forecasts. EY senior economist Paula Gadsby noted that the figures ‚Äì on top of the most recent inflation data ‚Äì would give the Reserve Bank confidence it can cut rates now and in the second half of 2025. Economists at the ANZ said a quarter percentage point rate cut this week was more likely than not. The ANZ had expected three cuts this year, starting in May and followed by further reductions in July and August.

title: Why US-China Trade Talks May Not Lead to a Comprehensive Deal
content: If US pressure China to free-float yuan, increase market access for its companies & go for full capital account convertibility, trade deal is unlikely ...
resumen: US-China trade talks began in Geneva, Switzerland last weekend. After the first round of talks on May 10, President Donald Trump remarked, ‚ÄúA very good meeting today with China, in Switzerland. Many things discussed, much agreed to. A total reset negotiated in a friendly, but constructive, manner.‚Äù. Both sides agreed to suspend tariffs for a period of 90 days. The US cut tariffs to 30 per cent including a 20 per cent tariff aimed at curbing the illegal trade in fentanyl. China will impose a tariff on 10 per cent on US imports. Beijing also agreed to remove or suspend all non-tariff measures against the US. The two sides also agreed to continue talks. According to US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, ‚ÄúThe consensus from both delegations this weekend is neither side wants a decoupling.‚Äù Trade had effectively been shut between the two countries since the imposition of steep tariffs by the US and retaliatory tariffs by China. The number of cargo ships going from China to the US declined by 60 per cent in April 2025. According to Goldman Sachs, an investment bank, up to 16 million jobs in China were threatened by the US tariffs. Service activity in China reached a seven-month low in April and manufacturing activity is at its lowest since December 2023. In April 2025, in a post on his Truth Social platform, Trump released an eight-point ‚Äúnon-tariff cheating‚Äù list, with currency manipulation at the top. On April 8, at a National Republican Congressional Committee dinner, Trump accused Beijing of weakening the yuan to offset the impact of US tariffs. A day before the trade talks were to commence in Geneva, in a post on Truth Social, Trump called on China to open markets to US businesses. In future talks, the US may demand that the yuan be allowed to free-float and its value be determined by market forces. It may also demand that the capital account should be liberalised. President Xi Jinping and the Communist Party of China (CPC) would never agree to such demands. If the yuan is allowed to trade freely and is no longer under the floating rate restrictions of the People‚Äôs Bank of China‚ÄîChina‚Äôs central bank‚Äìthe US trade deficit with China is likely to decline. Chinese exports will become expensive and less competitive relative to exports from other countries. This will lead to a decline in China‚Äôs global exports. It will also result in a decline in China‚Äôs gross domestic product and potentially to a loss of millions of jobs. Beijing will not buckle under US pressure to accept any demand of allowing the yuan to be traded freely. Providing increasing access to US companies to operate in the Chinese economy and expand their operations will also likely lead to closure of Chinese businesses. Increasing access for American companies in China‚Äôs financial sector will curtail, and may lead to the Chinese government‚Äôs right to directly and fully conduct financial and economic interventions in the economy. Capital account liberalisation will allow free movement of capital in and out of China.
