resumen: Am√©rica Latina teme la ca√≠da de las remesas. Las clases populares de Am√©rica Latina temen la dr√°stica ca√≠da de las remesas de los emigrantes. La inflaci√≥n, los cambios econ√≥micos por aplicaci√≥n de nuevos aranceles, la retracci√≥n econ√≥mica, o cualquier otra causa, va a limitar la capacidad de ahorro de esos inmigrantes, preferentemente los hispanos en Estados Unidos. Se sabe de la existencia de remesas y de una potente estructura comercial de casas de env√≠os de dinero; pero no se conoce cuan vital es esa aportaci√≥n para la vida y la estabilidad de tantos pa√≠ses. title: Walmart anuncia que subir√° precios en Estados Unidos desde finales de mayo
content: La cadena trasladar√° el impacto de los nuevos aranceles al consumidor, con alzas visibles en alimentos, juguetes y productos electr√≥nicos. Aumentos por ...
resumen:
Walmart subir√° los precios de varios productos en sus tiendas de Estados Unidos a partir de finales de mayo. El alza se intensificar√° durante junio, empujada por los nuevos aranceles impuestos por el gobierno de Donald Trump, que afectan especialmente a las importaciones chinas con tarifas de entre el 10% y el 30%.

Aunque m√°s de dos tercios de los productos que vende Walmart en el pa√≠s son de origen local, categor√≠as clave como electr√≥nicos y juguetes a√∫n dependen en gran parte de proveedores internacionales. Los nuevos aranceles afectan tambi√©n a productos agr√≠colas de pa√≠ses como Colombia, Per√∫ y Costa Rica, lo que encarece alimentos como aguacates, caf√©, flores y bananas.

El director ejecutivo Doug McMillon y el director financiero John David Rainey aseguraron que Walmart absorber√° parte del incremento de costos, pero advirtieron que los consumidores notar√°n los cambios en sus bolsillos a partir del cierre de este mes.

Seg√∫n la empresa, ya se est√°n aplicando medidas para reducir el impacto: disminuci√≥n del tama√±o de algunos pedidos, b√∫squeda de nuevos proveedores y sustituci√≥n de materiales, como cambiar aluminio por fibra de vidrio en ciertos art√≠culos. La cadena tambi√©n ajusta su oferta para proteger a ciertos productos esenciales de aumentos dr√°sticos y analiza la respuesta de los consumidores ante los nuevos precios.

Walmart mantiene sus previsiones de crecimiento para el a√±o fiscal 2026, con un incremento esperado de entre 3% y 4% en ventas. La empresa se muestra confiada en trasladar la mayor√≠a de los costes adicionales a los clientes sin comprometer sus beneficios.

Walmart opt√≥ por no publicar una gu√≠a clara sobre sus resultados trimestrales, a la espera de c√≥mo evolucionen las tensiones comerciales.

title: Trump hints at expanding trade with ‚Äòbrilliant‚Äô Pakistan
content: WASHINGTON: US President Donald Trump has said that his intervention stopped the India-Pakistan conflict from spiralling into nuclear war by leveraging trade.In an interview with Fox News, Donald ...
resumen: US President Donald Trump said that his intervention stopped the India-Pakistan conflict from spiralling into nuclear war by leveraging trade. In an interview with Fox News, Donald Trump said Pakistan and India were stuck in a tit-for-tat cycle of fighting. Trump termed it a foreign policy success. He said the conflict could have turned ‚Äúnasty‚Äù had he not jumped in to secure a ceasefire. Trump said India and Pakistan were very close to a nuclear war. He said, ‚ÄúAnd I said we‚Äôre gonna talk about trade. We‚Äôre gonna do a lot of trade‚Ä¶don‚Äôt forget Iran wants to trade with us.‚Äù The US president said he had a great conversation with Pakistan and wanted to do trade with them. He also praised products made in Pakistan and said he would be more than happy to do trade which according to him was still not large enough. Previously, the US president told US troops at a base in Qatar during a Gulf tour that Pakistan and India were happy with the ceasefire. He told them that hostilities between Pakistan and India had been settled after he urged the two countries to focus on trade instead of war. The nuclear-armed neighbours halted their worst fighting in nearly three decades after agreeing to a ceasefire on May 10, following diplomacy and pressure from the United States. Pakistan welcomed Trump‚Äôs role in stopping the conflict and said India had approached the US for a ceasefire.

title: China blinked ‚Äî and Trump clearly won the first round of his tariff war
content: The opening round of the tariff war with China is over. And earlier this week, President Trump achieved a very clear win.
resumen: The opening round of the tariff war with China is over. President Trump achieved a win. Trump‚Äôs 145% tariffs on Chinese goods landed a blow to Beijing‚Äôs economy, already staggering under rising unemployment, unsustainable debt, and rising bankruptcies. Trump decided to hit the pause button. Trump has put a 90-day pause on his massive tariffs against China. Xi Jinping was desperate to make a deal. Tens of thousands of Chinese businesses closed and millions of workers laid off. Had the high tariffs continued, over 50% of export companies would have gone under, and 30 million workers would have been on the streets. Americans buy about 16% of the total exports, but because we buy in bulk and pay on time, we provide 50% of that sector‚Äôs profits. China called for a meeting as soon as the tariffs were announced. China‚Äôs finance minister, Lan Fo‚Äôan, traveled to Washington, DC to meet with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. The meeting was held in the basement of the International Monetary Fund and, at China‚Äôs insistence, was kept secret. China made some major concessions, reducing its tariff rate on US goods to 10% and promising to stop the flow of deadly fentanyl into the US. The US has decided to temporarily release its chokehold on China‚Äôs economy. The tariff on China‚Äôs goods will drop to 30%. China has promised to stop flooding the US with fentanyl and the materials used to produce it. Trump has learned three things from the current slugfest with Xi Jinping. China always cheats. China‚Äôs negotiators in Switzerland admitted that they did not honor their original trade agreement with Trump, signed in January 2020, because Biden was weak. The Chinese delegation told us that once President Biden came into office, they just ignored their obligations. Trump‚Äôs tariffs forced Xi Jinping‚Äôs negotiators into a second big reveal when, for the first time, they linked fentanyl to the tariff wars. They would stop the outflow of the deadly drug and its chemical precursors from China, they indicated, in return for tariff relief. The death toll from fentanyl overdoses is approaching half a million. China could have shut down the fentanyl trade with the Mexican cartels at any time. Trump should demand no less. Bessent met with his Chinese counterpart, Finance Minister Lan Fo‚Äôan, in secret talks to reduce China‚Äôs tariffs while still allowing Beijing to save face. Mighty China is a paper tiger. Trump decided not to use America‚Äôs vast leverage to push China into collapse.

title: La crisis energ√©tica afecta la se√±al de radio y televisi√≥n en provincia de Cuba
content: La Habana, 17 may (EFE).- La crisis energ√©tica afecta la se√±al de radio y televisi√≥n en la provincia cubana de Pinar del R√≠o (extremo oeste) donde s√≥lo 7 de los 28 centros de transmisi√≥n cuentan con g ...
resumen:
La crisis energ√©tica afecta la se√±al de radio y televisi√≥n en la provincia cubana de Pinar del R√≠o (extremo oeste).

S√≥lo 7 de los 28 centros de transmisi√≥n cuentan con generadores el√©ctricos para difundir la programaci√≥n.

Radio Guam√° prioriza la programaci√≥n de los fines de semana, as√≠ como eventos deportivos como los campeonatos europeos de f√∫tbol.

Luis Armentero, director de la Divisi√≥n Territorial de Radio Cuba en Pinar del R√≠o, afirm√≥ que la falta de grupos electr√≥genos ha llevado a la optimizaci√≥n de su uso, implementando horarios espec√≠ficos para reducir el desgaste y garantizar su funcionamiento en momentos clave.

Se apaga seis horas al d√≠a: tres en la ma√±ana y tres en la noche.

La escasez de piezas de repuesto para los transmisores de la se√±al tambi√©n ‚Äúlimitan‚Äù el servicio.

Cuba atraviesa una grave crisis energ√©tica reflejada en apagones frecuentes que alcanzan hasta las 20 horas diarias en varias provincias del pa√≠s, mientras que en La Habana alcanzan las cinco horas programadas.

La empresa estatal Uni√≥n El√©ctrica prev√© que los apagones afecten de forma simult√°nea el 45 % del pa√≠s durante el horario de la tarde-noche.

El Gobierno cubano asegura que las principales causas de los apagones son las frecuentes aver√≠as en las centrales t√©rmicas de m√°s de 40 a√±os de explotaci√≥n, el d√©ficit de combustible y las sanciones econ√≥micas de Estados Unidos.

Expertos independientes se√±alan que la crisis energ√©tica responde a una infrafinanciaci√≥n cr√≥nica de este sector, completamente en manos del Estado cubano desde el triunfo de la revoluci√≥n en 1959.

Diversos c√°lculos independientes estiman que el Gobierno necesitar√≠a entre 8.000 y 10.000 millones de d√≥lares para reflotar la red el√©ctrica.

Los frecuentes apagones lastran la econom√≠a cubana, que se contrajo un 1,9 % en 2023 y no creci√≥ el a√±o pasado, seg√∫n estimaciones del propio Gobierno.

El PIB de la isla sigue por debajo de los niveles de 2019 y no lo superar√° este 2025, para el que el Ejecutivo prev√© un avance del 1 %.

title: A rare warning from Walmart during a US trade war: Higher prices are inevitable
content: Walmart, which became the nation‚Äôs largest retailer by making low prices a priority, has found itself in a place it‚Äôs rarely been: Warning customers that prices will rise for goods ranging from ...
resumen: Walmart is warning customers that prices will rise for goods due to tariffs ordered by President Donald Trump. Executives at the $750 billion company told industry analysts that they are doing everything in their power to absorb the higher costs from tariffs. Higher prices are unavoidable, and they will hurt Walmart customers already buffeted by inflation over the past three years. Trump‚Äôs threatened 145% import taxes on Chinese goods were reduced to 30% in a deal announced Monday, with some of the higher tariffs on pause for 90 days. Higher prices began to appear on Walmart shelves in late April and accelerated this month, with a larger sting starting in June and July. Chief Financial Officer John David Rainey said prices are rising not just for discretionary items but for basic necessities as well. The price of bananas, imported from Costa Rica, rose from 50 cents per pound, to 54 cents. Car seats made in China that currently sell for $350 at Walmart will likely cost customers another $100. Baby strollers are also sourced from China. Many Americans are pulling back on spending as they grow increasingly uneasy about the economy. Walmart says that 90% of American households rely on the retailer for a range of products, and more than 150 million customers shop on its website or in its stores every week. Tariffs on China and other countries are threatening the low-price model at the core of Walmart‚Äôs success. Retailers have no choice but to raise prices to offset higher costs from tariffs. They are also bracing for higher shipping costs. Rainey said the retailer did not pause shipments from China as a result of the tariffs because it didn‚Äôt want to hurt its suppliers and wanted to keep merchandise flowing. Two-thirds of Walmart‚Äôs merchandise is sourced in the U.S., with groceries now accounting for roughly 60% of Walmart‚Äôs U.S. business. CEO Doug McMillon said Walmart imports general merchandise from dozens of countries, with China representing a big chunk of volume in certain categories like electronics and toys. Tariffs on countries like Costa Rica, Peru and Colombia are raising costs on groceries like avocados, coffee and roses, in addition to bananas. In some cases, Walmart is absorbing costs on general merchandise within departments or a category and not simply passing on a tariff cost attributable to each item individually. Walmart is also asking suppliers to swap input materials for components if possible. Rainey said there are some goods for which Walmart simply can‚Äôt shift production or produce easily in the United States. McMillon met with Trump at the White House late last month to discuss tariffs and is hoping tariffs would be further reduced. Walmart earned $4.45 billion, or 56 cents per share, in the quarter ended April 30, down from $5.10 billion, or 63 cents per share, in the same period last year. Adjusted earnings per share were 61 cents. Revenue rose 2.5% to $165.61 billion. Walmart‚Äôs U.S. comparable sales rose 4.5% in the second quarter. Business was fueled by health and wellness items as well as groceries. Global e-commerce sales rose 22%. Walmart expects sales growth of 3.5% to 4.5% in the second quarter. The company did not issue a profit outlook for the quarter because of the chaotic environment. The company maintained its full-year guidance issued in February.

title: The on-again, off-again trade war
content: Never mind. President Trump‚Äôs 145% tariffs on China ran smack into Stein‚Äôs law, the late economist Herb Stein‚Äôs famous axiom that ‚Äúif something cannot go on forever, it will stop.‚Äù What was ...
resumen: President Trump‚Äôs 145% tariffs on China ran smack into Stein‚Äôs law. The U.S. and China have mutually agreed to back off a tit-for-tat trade war. During a 90-day pause, the U.S. is taking its tariffs down from 145% to 30%, while China is dropping from 125% to 10%. The problem with tariffs is that they are a way of harming a foreign trade partner via imposing pain on your own businesses and consumers. The 145% tariff was hitting Beijing hard, but also was due to impose severe costs on U.S. concerns dependent on Chinese manufacturing. Small businesses were looking at potential extinction and retailers warning of empty store shelves. A 30% tariff on China, plus the other tariffs that are in play around the globe, mean we still have lurched into the highest U.S. tariff regime since the 1930s. Earlier this year, there was a surge of imports in anticipation of Trump‚Äôs tariffs, in the phenomenon known as front-loading. Then, imports were basically shut off as the 145% tariffs took hold. An on-again-off-again-on-again approach forces U.S. economic actors to deal with wildly gyrating uncertainty for no good reason. Trump hasn‚Äôt gotten anything from the U.K. or China over the last week that he couldn‚Äôt have achieved with much less disruption. The risk is that Trump has, by tariffing everyone, friend or foe, made it harder for us to deepen relationships with our allies and isolate our adversary. As Robert Atkinson of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation points out, the current tack will also hamper the most strategically important, technologically advanced U.S. firms that are all globally integrated. The Trump tariffs will increase their costs by making imported inputs more expensive, while limiting their foreign markets by inviting foreign retaliation for Trump‚Äôs tariffs.

title: APEC Trade chiefs urge sweeping WTO reforms amid US-China tensions
content: Trade chiefs of the 21 member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) issued a joint statement calling for strategic reforms in ...
resumen:
Trade chiefs of the 21 member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) issued a joint statement calling for strategic reforms in international trade as the region grapples with uncertainties driven by two of its members: China and the United States (US).

In a statement issued after the two-day APEC Ministers Responsible for Trade (MRT) meeting in Jeju, South Korea, the regional bloc recognized the importance of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) in advancing trade issues as an integral part of the global trading system.

APEC noted that the WTO is facing challenges that require ‚Äúmeaningful, necessary, and comprehensive reform‚Äù to make it more relevant and responsive in light of recent developments.

Without directly stating tariffs and other trade upheavals, the group said its members are ‚Äúconcerned with the fundamental challenges faced by the global trading system.‚Äù

China and the US are currently engaged in a tit-for-tat trade war that threatens to upend global trade and critical supply chains.

When US President Donald Trump announced last month his new tariff policy, which includes higher reciprocal tariffs on countries with which America has a trade deficit, more than half of APEC‚Äôs 21 member economies were slapped with a higher tax on goods.

The Philippines, a founding member of APEC, was among those hit with reciprocal tariffs, facing 17 percent.

APEC‚Äôs joint statement offered no solution to these concerns, as it primarily focused on global supply chains that are facing ‚Äúcross-sectoral challenges.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe support efforts to ensure that supply chain issues continue to be discussed within APEC to enhance the resilience of supply chains for sustainable economic growth across the APEC region,‚Äù the statement read.

‚ÄúWe recognize the critical role that trade can play in achieving food security, minimizing food supply chain disruptions, and promoting open, fair, transparent, productive, sustainable, resilient, and innovative agri-food systems that benefit all,‚Äù it also read.

APEC appeared to have largely sidetracked the issue of tariffs as its members expressed ‚Äúextreme differences‚Äù in viewpoints, according to a Bloomberg report.

Nonetheless, the bloc expressed interest in deeper economic integration, including through the proposed Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP).

Efforts to enhance experience sharing, capacity building, and technical cooperation were cited as key drivers for this agenda.

The Trade chiefs also discussed the significance of adopting artificial intelligence (AI) in trade facilitation, the benefits of digital transformation, empowering micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs), and a commitment to promoting the cross-border recognition of electronic trade-related documents.

title: Trump advierte a Walmart: No suban precios por aranceles, absorban el costo de esos impuestos
content: El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump arremeti√≥ el s√°bado contra Walmart y public√≥ en las redes sociales que el gigante minorista ...
resumen:
El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump arremeti√≥ el s√°bado contra Walmart y public√≥ en las redes sociales que el gigante minorista deber√≠a absorber los costos adicionales creados por sus aranceles.

Trump ha aumentado los impuestos a las importaciones e intentado asegurar a un p√∫blico esc√©ptico que los productores extranjeros pagar√≠an esos impuestos y que los minoristas y fabricantes de autom√≥viles absorber√≠an los gastos adicionales.

Walmart advirti√≥ el jueves que todo, desde pl√°tanos hasta asientos de seguridad para ni√±os, podr√≠a aumentar de precio.

Trump arremeti√≥ contra el minorista, que emplea a 1,6 millones de personas en Estados Unidos, en una publicaci√≥n en su sitio de redes sociales Truth Social. Dijo que la empresa, con sede en Bentonville, Arkansas, deber√≠a sacrificar sus ganancias por el bien de su agenda econ√≥mica, que seg√∫n √©l eventualmente conducir√° a m√°s empleos dom√©sticos en la manufactura.

Trump public√≥: ‚ÄúWalmart deber√≠a dejar de intentar culpar a los aranceles como la raz√≥n para aumentar los precios en toda la cadena. Walmart gan√≥ miles de millones de d√≥lares el a√±o pasado, mucho m√°s de lo esperado. Entre Walmart y China deber√≠an, como se dice, ‚Äòabsorber los aranceles‚Äô, y no cobrar nada a los valiosos clientes. ¬°Estar√© observando, y tambi√©n lo har√°n sus clientes!‚Äù.

El director financiero de Walmart, John David Rainey, dijo que cree que los asientos para ni√±os de autom√≥vil de 350 d√≥lares fabricados en China pronto costar√°n 100 d√≥lares m√°s, un aumento de precio del 29%.

El gobierno recientemente redujo sus aranceles del 145% sobre China al 30% por un per√≠odo de 90 d√≠as.

Trump ha impuesto aranceles de hasta el 25% a M√©xico y Canad√°.

Existe un arancel base universal del 10% en la mayor√≠a de los pa√≠ses.

Trump ha impuesto impuestos a la importaci√≥n sobre autom√≥viles, acero y aluminio y planea hacerlo sobre medicamentos farmac√©uticos, entre otros productos.

El presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, ha mantenido las tasas de referencia del banco central estables hasta que haya m√°s claridad. Powell ha advertido que los aranceles pueden tanto perjudicar el crecimiento como aumentar los precios.

Trump repiti√≥ sus llamados a Powell para que reduzca las tasas de referencia.

title: Trump tells Walmart to ‚Äòeat the tariffs‚Äô as retailer expects prices to increase
content: U.S. President Donald Trump on Saturday said Walmart needs to stop ‚Äútrying to blame tariffs‚Äù after the retail giant announced its products would become more expensive.
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump said Walmart needs to stop ‚Äútrying to blame tariffs‚Äù after the retail giant announced its products would become more expensive.

Walmart‚Äôs CEO said the price increases were a result of Trump‚Äôs tariffs being ‚Äútoo high,‚Äù particularly when it came to Chinese goods.

Walmart CEO Douglas McMillon said Thursday in an earnings call: ‚ÄúWe will do our best to keep our prices as low as possible. But given the magnitude of the tariffs, even at the reduced levels announced this week, we aren‚Äôt able to absorb all the pressure given the reality of narrow retail margins.‚Äù

Trump responded on Saturday, posting to Truth Social that ‚ÄúBetween Walmart and China they should, as is said ‚ÄòEAT THE TARIFFS,‚Äô and not charge valued customers ANYTHING. I‚Äôll be watching, and so will your customers!‚Äù

Trump‚Äôs comments echoed Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick‚Äôs comments Sunday on CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúState of the Union,‚Äù arguing that ‚Äúbusinesses and the countries primarily eat the tariff.‚Äù

Former U.S. treasury secretary Larry Summers has called such theories ‚Äúludicrous.‚Äù

Economists have told CNN that the tariffs will burden lower- and middle-income Americans, who have historically been Walmart‚Äôs primary customer base.

The changes will likely take effect by the end of May, and prices will increase ‚Äúmuch more‚Äù in June, Walmart‚Äôs finance chief, John David Rainey, told CNBC.

Walmart, which has over 4,600 stores in the United States, gets merchandise from Canada, China, India, Mexico and Vietnam, among other nations. Those countries face at least 10 per cent in tariffs, and imports of steel, aluminum, cars and auto parts face 25 per cent tariffs.

McMillon said: ‚ÄúAll of the tariffs create cost pressure for us, but the larger tariffs on China have the biggest impact.‚Äù

Trump increased tariffs on most Chinese goods to a whopping 145 per cent, but that rate dropped to 30 per cent on Monday as part of a 90-day truce with China.

Trump said the tariffs could become ‚Äúsubstantially higher‚Äù if a trade agreement with China is not reached.

Baseline tariffs will not go lower than 10 per cent during negotiations, Lutnick told CNN on Sunday.

Food:

Bananas, avocados and coffee are among some of the groceries that McMillon said come from Colombia, Costa Rica and Peru. America also imports beets, cabbage, melons, and pineapples from Costa Rica. Sweet potatoes and citrus are imported from Peru.

Between February and April, the average price of bananas per pound has increased by about two cents at U.S. retailers, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Seasonal products:

Walmart is currently focused on back-to-school shopping, according to McMillon.

McMillon explained that tariffs are paid as soon as a product enters the country through customs, meaning the higher tariffs are already affecting shipments.

McMillon said: ‚ÄúSo I think what we‚Äôre looking at is upward pressure that began in April and plays through the entire year on things that are imported.‚Äù

Toys, electronics and baby gear:

McMillon said: ‚ÄúChina, in particular, represents a lot of volume in certain categories like electronics and toys.‚Äù

Roughly 80 per cent of toys sold in the United States are made in China, according to the Toy Association, an industry group.

Toy companies, like Hasbro, the owner of Nerf and Play-doh, said some items will be cut from its portfolio, and Barbie creator Mattel has issued warnings about potential price hikes due to tariffs.

Trump said earlier this month, acknowledging the potential impact tariffs will have on toys: ‚ÄúWell, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls, you know? And maybe the two dolls will cost a couple of bucks more than they would normally.‚Äù

Product pricing analysis from research firm Telsey Advisory Groups showed that the price of a Barbie doll with a swimsuit sold at Walmart‚Äôs competitor Target rose 42.9 per cent over a week in mid-April to US$14.99.

Initially priced at $450, Nintendo‚Äôs Switch 2 could instead cost around $600, according to experts.

An Apple iPhone 17 could cost more than $1,000 instead of $799, according to Daniel Morgan, senior portfolio manager at investment firm Synovus.

Industry experts estimate that about 90 per cent of children‚Äôs and baby gear products are manufactured exclusively in China.

Home goods:

In 2024, China sent more than $438 billion worth of goods into American homes. Nearly 19 per cent of that total was machinery and mechanical appliances, according to data from the U.S. International Trade Commission. Meanwhile, four per cent of last year‚Äôs imports from China were bedding, furniture and lighting.

Rainey, Walmart‚Äôs CFO, said general merchandise sales in the United States declined slightly during the first quarter, ‚Äúwith softness in electronics, home products and sporting goods.‚Äù

title: Trump tariffs seen lowering Chinese firms‚Äô US investment plans
content: After weekend talks in Switzerland, both sides agreed Monday to lower tariffs for 90 days, with US tariffs reduced to 30 per cent and Chinese tariffs to 10 per cent.
resumen:
A China General Chamber of Commerce ‚Äì USA survey released Monday showed half of Chinese companies operating in the United States plan to shift emphasis away from investments in the country in light of Trump administration tariff policies.

The business group conducted the survey of almost 100 Chinese enterprises operating in the US in March and April, finishing shortly before US President Donald Trump‚Äôs so-called ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs on Chinese products of 145 per cent and Beijing‚Äôs retaliatory 125 per cent tariffs.

After weekend talks in Switzerland, both sides agreed Monday to lower tariffs for 90 days, with US tariffs reduced to 30 per cent and Chinese tariffs to 10 per cent.

Respondents to the CGCC survey included companies in 11 sectors, including consumer goods and services, energy, industrial firms, real estate, and communication services, with financial companies taking the largest share.

Among the companies saying they plan to reduce their investment in the US market, 22 per cent said they would ‚Äúsignificantly decrease‚Äù their focus on US investments and plan to suspend or withdraw most investments. Another 28 per cent indicated a ‚Äúslight decrease‚Äù in priority and said they would consider scaling back some investments because of current administration policies.

In contrast, 22 per cent of respondents said they would increase their US investment and 28 per cent said they would maintain investment.

The results revealed widespread pessimism about future investment in the US under the second Trump administration, contrasting with findings showing that Chinese companies‚Äô assessment of the US business environment improved notably during the final year of former president Joe Biden‚Äôs term.

As the survey concluded before Trump announced his new levies on April 2, it added that the tariffs and related policies may have ‚Äúfurther deepened business pessimism ‚Äì beyond what is reflected in this survey‚Äù.

In another survey question, none of the respondents said they think Trump‚Äôs policy will have ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù promotion or limiting effect on their US market expansion, but 50 per cent said it will have ‚Äúmoderate hindering effect‚Äù, compared with 17 per cent saying they expect a ‚Äúmoderate promoting effect‚Äù.

The companies identified a wide range of expected challenges to their US operations this year and next, with 90 per cent citing the stalemate in bilateral political and cultural relations, 73 per cent pointing to frictions in economic and trade ties, and 60 per cent flagging restrictive US foreign investment policies.

US domestic issues also ranked high among Chinese investors‚Äô concerns. According to the survey, 80 per cent of respondents cited inflation and economic instability as major risks. Other frequently mentioned challenges included high compliance and litigation costs, as well as exchange rate volatility.

The chamber urged Chinese firms to adopt flexible strategies incorporating steps to deal with risks, including ‚Äúcore and backup‚Äù investment portfolios prioritising ‚Äúbusiness-friendly‚Äù regions.

The chamber said investors should ‚Äúdecentralise‚Äù research and development, strengthen collaboration with US companies and improve compliance in the face of hi-tech restrictions.

To hedge geopolitical headwinds in particular, it suggested the companies develop local talent recruitment and work with industry alliances to strengthen their voices.

‚ÄúOngoing tariffs and tightening export controls on technology have significantly increased business costs and market pressures. Although the US economy has shown signs of stabilisation, high interest rates, persistent inflation, and labour shortages continue to pose serious uncertainties,‚Äù Hu Wei, the chamber‚Äôs chairman and president and CEO of Bank of China USA, said in the survey.

Chinese direct investment in the US has dropped significantly since Trump‚Äôs first administration, and the trend continued in Biden‚Äôs term amid growing US restrictions on Chinese investment, especially in the hi-tech sector.

That investment was US$28 billion in 2023, down 6.2 per cent from 2022, according to the latest US official data, led by manufacturing, real estate, and banks and similar institutions.

Charlene Barshefsky, former US president Bill Clinton‚Äôs trade representative, and Carla Hills, former President George H.W. Bush‚Äôs top trade envoy, commented on the situation.

title: Franja y Ruta: lo que ense√±an Chile y Venezuela sobre c√≥mo debe Colombia negociar acuerdo con China
content: Casos de √©xito y fracaso demuestran cu√°les son las claves de los pa√≠ses que han sacado mayor provecho del v√≠nculo.
resumen: El presidente chino, Xi Jinping, ofreci√≥ una relaci√≥n m√°s estrecha y cooperativa con Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe. Desde que China lanz√≥ la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI) en 2013, m√°s de 150 pa√≠ses han firmado acuerdos de cooperaci√≥n. La propuesta busca impulsar la conectividad global a trav√©s de infraestructuras. Los riesgos atribuidos a la participaci√≥n en la BRI, como el endeudamiento excesivo o la p√©rdida de soberan√≠a, suelen estar sobredimensionados. El principal riesgo que afronta cualquier pa√≠s al momento de adherirse a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta es la falta de preparaci√≥n. Pa√≠ses como Italia y Panam√° se han salido del acuerdo por razones geopol√≠ticas. Chile, Argentina, Per√∫ y Venezuela se sumaron al proyecto con resultados variables. Venezuela ha mantenido una relaci√≥n centrada en el financiamiento petrolero, sin grandes avances visibles en infraestructura o transferencia tecnol√≥gica y con un endeudamiento por m√°s de una d√©cada. China es el principal socio comercial de Brasil, Per√∫ y Chile y ha desplegado importantes inversiones en el marco del programa de la Franja y la Ruta. El intercambio comercial entre China y la regi√≥n super√≥ los 500.000 millones de d√≥lares el a√±o pasado. Xi propuso un fondo de 9.200 millones de d√≥lares en cr√©ditos para el desarrollo.

content: Los principales √≠ndices anotaron cinco subas consecutivas, impulsados por las esperanzas comerciales ante la tregua arancelaria entre Estados Unidos y China.
resumen: Los principales √≠ndices de Wall Street subieron el viernes por quinto d√≠a consecutivo, impulsados por la tregua arancelaria entre Estados Unidos y China a principios de semana, a pesar de que los datos de las encuestas econ√≥micas mostraron un deterioro en la confianza del consumidor.

title: Tariffs live updates: Trump urges Walmart to 'eat the tariffs' and wants Fed to cut rates 'sooner than later'
content: President Donald Trump, fresh off a trip to the Middle East, renewed his criticism of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on Saturday and called on Walmart to "eat the tariffs" rather than raise ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump renewed his criticism of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on Saturday and called on Walmart to "eat the tariffs" rather than raise prices.

Trump said, "Walmart should STOP trying to blame Tariffs as the reason for raising prices throughout the chain. Walmart made BILLIONS OF DOLLARS last year, far more than expected. Between Walmart and China they should, as is said, 'EAT THE TARIFFS,' and not charge valued customers ANYTHING. I‚Äôll be watching, and so will your customers!!!"

Walmart (WMT) on Thursday warned that rising costs from tariffs could soon lead to higher prices for shoppers.

Trump said the Federal Reserve should cut rates "sooner, rather than later," and continued to express his frustration with Powell.

Trump said Friday that the US will set tariff rates for its trading partners within the next few weeks. He said his administration cannot negotiate trade deals with all countries at once due to limited capacity.

The US effective tariff rate has moved lower over the past month. At 14.4%, the effective US tariff rate is nearly back to its pre-"Liberation Day" level.

President Donald Trump on Saturday said in a social media post the U.S. Federal Reserve should cut rates "sooner, rather than later." Trump also criticized the head of the central bank, Jerome Powell.

Birkenstock (BIRK) will begin raising prices for its sandals and clogs by low single digits in order to pass along tariff costs. The 251-year-old company makes its shoes in Germany, which currently faces a 10% tariff rate for items coming into the US. If the US and European Union haven't struck a new trade agreement before a 90-day tariff pause is up, that rate will shoot up to 20% on July 9.

title: Gold dey boom - but how safe e be for investors?
content: Trade wars and volatile markets don contribute to di gold rush, but expert warn investors say make dem no put all dia eggs inside one basket.
resumen: Emma Siebenborn, strategies director of Hatton Garden Metals, showed a sample of gold scrap, coins, and bars. The largest bar weighed 1kg and was worth about ¬£80,000. Zoe Lyons, the managing director, noted increased demand due to the recent surge in gold prices. The price of gold has increased by more than 40% over the past year, rising to above $3,500 (¬£2,630) per troy ounce in late April, an all-time record. Economists attribute this to changes in US trade policy and geopolitical uncertainty. Louise Street, senior market analyst for the World Gold Council, cited potential inflationary pressure and recessionary risks. Gold is seen as a "safe haven" asset. Russ Mould, investment director for stockbroker AJ Bell, noted that central banks cannot print gold. Exchange Traded Funds have also contributed to the price increase. The recent surge came after US President Donald Trump attacked Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve. Central banks have been net buyers of gold for the past 15 years, with over 1,000 tonnes bought annually since 2022. Daan Struyven, co-head of global commodities research for Goldman Sachs, mentioned the freezing of the Russian Central Bank's reserves as a factor. Simon French, chief economist and head of research at investment firm Panmure Liberum, believes independence from dollar-based banking systems is a major driver for central banks. Goldman Sachs forecasts gold to reach $3,700/oz (¬£2,800/oz) by the end of 2025 and $4,000 (¬£3,000) by mid 2026. Jon Mills, an industry expert for Morningstar, suggested the cost of an ounce of gold might drop to $1,820 over the next few years. Daan Stryven believes prices will generally continue to rise. Russ Mould believes a pause in the upward trend is likely. Simon French believes the peak may be very close. Susannah Streeter, head of money and markets for Hargreaves Lansdown, warns against short-term speculation.

title: Juan Pablo De Luca: ¬´Nos est√°n entregando en medio de una balacera mundial en t√©rminos comerciales¬ª.
content: Rio Grande 17/05/2025.- El Presidente de Rio Grande Activa y doctor en econom√≠a, Juan Pablo De Luca, se refiri√≥ al anuncio del gobierno nacional sobre la quita de aranceles a los celulares, televisore ...
resumen:
Juan Pablo De Luca, Presidente de Rio Grande Activa y doctor en econom√≠a, se refiri√≥ al anuncio del gobierno nacional sobre la quita de aranceles a los celulares, televisores y aire acondicionados importados.

De Luca se√±al√≥ que ¬´nos est√°n entregando en medio de una guerra comercial y es el peor momento, mas una baja de aranceles y, nos van a hundir¬ª.

Seg√∫n De Luca, esto repercute en toda la actividad industrial de Rio Grande, donde la industria interviene en la mitad de la econom√≠a de la ciudad. De concretarse estos anuncios, corren riesgo directo 3000 puestos de trabajo.

De Luca mencion√≥ que la producci√≥n de celulares es el principal producto electr√≥nico y que la baja de aranceles ser√≠a un golpe muy fuerte.

De Luca sostiene que el subr√©gimen tiene que ver con el beneficio directo a ciertos proyectos productivos de las industrias y que el r√©gimen en general beneficia con el no pago de impuestos nacionales, IVA y GANANCIAS, que no solo cubre a Tierra del Fuego, sino tambi√©n, a Malvinas, y Ant√°rtida.

Para De Luca, esto responde a una exigencia del Fondo Monetario Internacional, FMI y neg√≥ que la no adhesi√≥n a RIGI, sea un argumento para que el gobierno nacional haya tomado la decisi√≥n de quitar los aranceles.

De Luca insisti√≥ en que ¬´este no es un modelo que impulse la industria nacional, todo lo contrario, lo que acerca este presidente con lo que hace el presidente Donald Trump, tiene que ver con algo mas ideol√≥gico puede ser mas de derecha, pero en t√©rminos econ√≥micos es totalmente opuesto. Mientras Trump, sube los aranceles a productos chinos, para proteger la industria de su pais, ac√°, Milei pregona el libre mercado, baja los aranceles, impulsa la industria pero de otros paises, no el nuestro¬ª.

De Luca expres√≥ que China y Asia representan el 60 % de la producci√≥n mundial.

De Luca concluy√≥ que ¬´nos est√°n entregando en el peor momento, porque si hay un momento malo para entregar la industria de Tierra del Fuego, es el actual, porque las producciones que no entren en el mercado de Estados Unidos, van a entrar en otros bajando el precio y bajando los aranceles nos van a hundir, con un peso muy apreciado, es decir que nos est√°n entregando en medio de una balacera mundial en t√©rminos comerciales¬ª.

De Luca remarc√≥ que no se tendr√° posibilidad de competir en este marco y que pocos pa√≠ses tienen terminales tecnol√≥gicas como las instaladas en Tierra del Fuego.

title: Jason Furman, former Barack Obama adviser: 'So many of Trump's goals are contradictory'
content: The trade war waged by Donald Trump, although chaotic, is not likely to plunge the United States into a recession, according to Harvard economics professor Jason Furman, speaking in an interview with ...
resumen:
Jason Furman, former Barack Obama adviser, stated that many of Trump's goals are contradictory.
Jason Furman, an economist and professor at Harvard Kennedy School, gave an interview to 'Le Monde.'
Furman is 55 years old.
He is a non-resident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
He served as the chairman of then-president Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers from 2013 to 2017.
The interview was conducted by Arnaud Leparmentier, New York (United States) correspondent.
The interview was published today at 12:34 pm (Paris).

title: Guerra comercial China‚ÄìEstados Unidos: Desaf√≠os para Am√©rica Latina
content: La rivalidad tecnol√≥gica y comercial entre China y USA tambi√©n puede representar una oportunidad. As√≠, Am√©rica Latina podr√≠a atraer parte de esas inversiones si ofrece estabilidad, infraestructura y c ...
resumen:
La rivalidad entre China y Estados Unidos se ha consolidado como uno de los principales ejes del sistema econ√≥mico global. Lo que comenz√≥ en 2018 como una guerra comercial con aranceles rec√≠procos ha derivado en una competencia estrat√©gica m√°s amplia, con implicancias profundas para pa√≠ses de Am√©rica Latina. La regi√≥n, hist√≥ricamente dependiente de ambas potencias como socios comerciales, se encuentra en una posici√≥n delicada: aprovechar las oportunidades que surgen del conflicto sin quedar atrapada en una nueva l√≥gica de Guerra Fr√≠a.

Desde su ingreso a la OMC en 2001, China se ha consolidado como la segunda econom√≠a del mundo y el mayor exportador. La implementaci√≥n de iniciativas como la Franja y la Ruta y ‚ÄúMade in China 2025‚Äù evidencian una estrategia proactiva para consolidar su poder econ√≥mico y tecnol√≥gico. Para USA, esta evoluci√≥n signific√≥ pasar de considerar a China un potencial aliado del orden liberal a verlo como su principal rival estrat√©gico.

Durante el primer Gobierno de Trump, se impuso una agenda proteccionista que incluy√≥ aranceles sobre cientos de miles de millones de d√≥lares en bienes chinos. A nivel global, la confrontaci√≥n exacerb√≥ la incertidumbre econ√≥mica, afect√≥ flujos de inversi√≥n y gener√≥ presiones inflacionarias.

En este contexto, Latinoam√©rica vive con intensidad los efectos de esta pugna. China ha ganado presencia como socio comercial, inversionista y prestamista. Al mismo tiempo, USA sigue siendo una fuente clave de tecnolog√≠a, inversi√≥n e influencia institucional. Los pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n, conscientes de su dependencia econ√≥mica, han optado por un equilibrio pragm√°tico: ampliar v√≠nculos con ambos polos sin comprometerse ideol√≥gicamente.

Chile y Brasil, comparten socios estrat√©gicos, adoptan estrategias muy distintas. Desde los a√±os 90, Chile ha desplegado una diplomacia comercial intensa basada en tratados de libre comercio. Actualmente tiene acuerdos con m√°s de 60 pa√≠ses, incluyendo a China y USA, lo que le da acceso preferencial a buena parte del PIB global. Ante la guerra comercial, ha optado por una postura cautelosa, buscando mantener relaciones positivas con ambas potencias. En 2023, el 38% de las exportaciones chilenas iban a China (principalmente cobre) y un 14% a USA. Chile ha evitado una postura pol√≠tica expl√≠cita, privilegiando el multilateralismo y las reglas del comercio internacional como marco de actuaci√≥n.

Brasil, como potencia regional con m√°s de 210 millones de habitantes y una econom√≠a entre las diez mayores del mundo, ha optado por una estrategia m√°s ambiciosa. Su pol√≠tica exterior hist√≥ricamente ha defendido la autonom√≠a estrat√©gica, participando en bloques como los BRICS y promoviendo un orden multipolar. En el plano econ√≥mico, China se ha consolidado como su principal socio desde 2009. En 2023, el 30% de sus exportaciones fueron a China, y el 23% de sus importaciones provinieron de ese pa√≠s. En contraste, USA represent√≥ solo el 10% de las exportaciones brasile√±as. Con el retorno de Lula en 2023, Brasil reforz√≥ su protagonismo global. Lula firm√≥ acuerdos con China que incluyen cooperaci√≥n tecnol√≥gica y mecanismos de pago en monedas locales, al tiempo que recibi√≥ delegaciones estadounidenses interesadas en inversiones verdes. La clave ha sido la diversificaci√≥n de alianzas sin comprometer su autonom√≠a.

La concentraci√≥n del comercio con China en bienes primarios amenaza con consolidar un modelo extractivista que debilita su base industrial. Para contrarrestar esto, ha promovido inversi√≥n china en sectores industriales y tecnol√≥gicos.

El rol de China en Am√©rica Latina ha evolucionado con la incorporaci√≥n del gigante asi√°tico a la econom√≠a internacional. Entre 2000 y 2020, las empresas chinas realizaron cerca de 480 transacciones por US$ 160.000 millones, enfocadas en energ√≠a, miner√≠a, telecomunicaciones e infraestructura log√≠stica. Paralelamente, los bancos chinos han prestado m√°s de US$ 141.000 millones a la regi√≥n, superando al BID y al Banco Mundial. China muestra inter√©s en invertir en sectores de valor agregado, como autos el√©ctricos, energ√≠as renovables y tecnolog√≠a avanzada.

La diversificaci√≥n no puede limitarse a firmar tratados o cambiar de socio dominante. Se requiere una estrategia integral que incluya diversificaci√≥n productiva; esto es, avanzar hacia exportaciones de mayor valor agregado. Invertir en capacidades tecnol√≥gicas y formaci√≥n de capital humano. Desplegar una pol√≠tica industrial activa que fomente sectores estrat√©gicos y encadenamientos productivos. Y a nivel regional, negociar en bloque para evitar presiones unilaterales de las grandes potencias.

La rivalidad tecnol√≥gica y comercial entre China y USA tambi√©n puede representar una oportunidad. As√≠, Am√©rica Latina podr√≠a atraer parte de esas inversiones si ofrece estabilidad, infraestructura y capacidades laborales adecuadas. En el plano macroecon√≥mico, la persistencia de la guerra comercial podr√≠a requerir pol√≠ticas m√°s activas. Ser√° necesario repensar el balance entre control de inflaci√≥n y crecimiento, incluyendo una pol√≠tica monetaria que privilegie el empleo, y si este primer frente no es capaz de sostener la econom√≠a, se requerir√° un activismo fiscal que acepte mayores niveles de deuda p√∫blica para sostener a las familias y al tejido productivo.

title: Exportaciones de caf√© podr√≠an superar los US$1 mil millones este a√±o, pero arancel en EE. UU. ensombrece buen precio
content: La buena racha de los precios internacionales del quintal de caf√© para los productores y exportadores se ve opacada por las tarifas arancelarias en Estados Unidos, que mantienen incertidumbre en ...
resumen: El precio promedio del quintal de caf√© para Guatemala es de US$330 en los primeros seis meses de la cosecha 2024-2025, seg√∫n Anacaf√©. El auge de los precios internacionales del caf√© para los productores y exportadores guatemaltecos, que ayer en la Bolsa de Nueva York se cotiz√≥ en US$375 por quintal oro, se ve desalentado por las disposiciones de Estados Unidos de gravar en 10% el ingreso de esta materia prima. Hasta el 30 de abril √∫ltimo, el 44% del total de las exportaciones del grano se ha dirigido a clientes en Estados Unidos, y la Asociaci√≥n Nacional del Caf√© (Anacaf√©) report√≥ cinco casos en los cuales hay controversias por la implementaci√≥n de los aranceles en los negocios entre exportadores guatemaltecos y compradores estadounidenses, debido al traslado de esos costos. Se desconoce cu√°ntos son los lotes de caf√© agrupados en esos cinco expedientes que enfrentan dificultades por la aplicaci√≥n de la pol√≠tica arancelaria de EE. UU. La Organizaci√≥n Internacional del Caf√© (OIC) asegura que a√∫n no hay claridad sobre qui√©n asumir√° los cargos, lo que pone en alerta a la industria estadounidense, es decir, los importadores. El sector presentar√° una propuesta en la pr√≥xima visita que realizar√° una delegaci√≥n guatemalteca a la Oficina del Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR, por sus siglas en ingl√©s), a finales de mes en Washington D.C. y plantear√° el impacto que tiene la caficultura en Guatemala como sost√©n de m√°s de 125 mil familias. Ricardo Andr√©s Destarac Bardales, presidente de Anacaf√©, declar√≥ que est√°n trabajando en conjunto con las autoridades involucradas y que ya se tiene claridad sobre las reuniones que se sostendr√°n en el USTR en la visita programada para el 27 de mayo pr√≥ximo. El directivo confirm√≥ que hay cinco reportes a los cuales se les aplic√≥ el cobro del arancel del 10% a los embarques, y se ha confirmado que la cuota se est√° trasladando a los exportadores guatemaltecos. De manera preliminar, se conoce que son 20 contenedores de 22 pies con diferentes calidades de caf√© a los que se les aplic√≥ el cobro del arancel. A su juicio, el arancel lo deben cubrir los importadores estadounidenses, ya que el producto se comercializa FOB, es decir, puesto en puerto. Algunos exportadores de caf√© a√∫n est√°n en negociaci√≥n con los importadores estadounidenses sobre qui√©n asumir√° los cargos de los aranceles. Los registros de Anacaf√© indican que el precio promedio en Guatemala es de US$330 por quintal en la cosecha 2024-2025 (al 30 de abril), y es superior a los US$209.30 de la cosecha 2023-2024 y a los US$241.79 del 2022-2023. Las divisas por las exportaciones de caf√© de octubre a abril suman US$624.60 millones, por lo que se proyecta superar los US$1 mil millones por la exportaci√≥n del grano.

title: Am√©rica Latina teme la ca√≠da de las remesas

resumen: Am√©rica Latina teme la ca√≠da de las remesas. Las clases populares de Am√©rica Latina temen la dr√°stica ca√≠da de las remesas de los emigrantes. La inflaci√≥n, la retracci√≥n econ√≥mica, o cualquier otra causa, va a limitar la capacidad de ahorro de esos inmigrantes, preferentemente los hispanos en Estados Unidos. El Fondo Monetario Internacional advert√≠a de un posible retroceso del crecimiento de la econom√≠a mundial en medio punto, que llegaba hasta un punto de ca√≠da en Estados Unidos por el impacto de las decisiones econ√≥micas de Donald Trump. Se sabe de la existencia de remesas y de una potente estructura comercial de casas de env√≠os de dinero; pero no se conoce cuan vital es esa aportaci√≥n para la vida y la estabilidad de tantos pa√≠ses. Destac√≥ el caso de El Salvador, e incluso el de Hait√≠. Un grupo de venezolanos, perfectamente legalizados, explicaban estos d√≠as como suspendieron una visita concertada al Congreso de los Estados Unidos simplemente por temor. title: China sale a conquistar a Am√©rica Latina con promesas de inversi√≥n y comercio
content: Lo que dej√≥ la cumbre de la CELAC con China en Beijing. Argentina fue el √∫nico pa√≠s que no firm√≥ el documento.
resumen:
China busca fortalecer lazos con Latinoam√©rica y el Caribe, ofreciendo m√°s cr√©ditos, comercio e inversi√≥n, adem√°s de la eliminaci√≥n de visados para algunos pa√≠ses.

En la IV Reuni√≥n Ministerial de la CELAC con China en Beijing, Xi Jinping recibi√≥ a mandatarios como Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva de Brasil, Gustavo Petro de Colombia y Gabriel Boric de Chile.

Argentina, con Javier Milei, no firm√≥ el documento de cierre.

China aumentar√° sus importaciones de productos de alta calidad de la regi√≥n e incentivar√° inversiones.

El documento "Planificando Juntos el Desarrollo y la Revitalizaci√≥n, Construyendo Conjuntamente una Comunidad China-ALC con un futuro compartido" aboga por mayor colaboraci√≥n en inversiones, aumento de la comercializaci√≥n, enfrentar desaf√≠os globales y reformas a instituciones de gobernanza global.

En 2024, el comercio entre China y la regi√≥n super√≥ los 500 mil millones de d√≥lares, frente a los 450.000 del 2023.

China es el segundo socio comercial m√°s grande de Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe, y el primero en algunos casos.

Xi Jinping anunci√≥ una l√≠nea de cr√©dito de m√°s de nueve mil millones de d√≥lares para la CELAC.

Se anunciar√°n nuevas inversiones en infraestructura, con m√°s de 200 proyectos en la regi√≥n que generaron m√°s de un mill√≥n de empleos locales.

China ofrecer√° 3.500 becas gubernamentales, 10 mil oportunidades de capacitaci√≥n, 500 becas internacionales para profesores de chino y 300 lugares de capacitaci√≥n para tecnolog√≠as de reducci√≥n de la pobreza.

Se eliminar√° el visado a Brasil, Argentina, Chile, Per√∫ y Uruguay.

23 pa√≠ses de Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe firmaron el memorando de entendimiento sobre la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI) con China.

El comercio con China debe diversificarse, no solo exportando materias primas e importando bienes de media y alta tecnolog√≠a.

En el foro particip√≥ Dilma Rousseff, presidenta del Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo de los BRICS.

El comercio entre China y la regi√≥n super√≥, por primera vez, los 500 mil millones de d√≥lares, frente a los 450.000 del 2023.

En el marco de la guerra comercial, el gobierno de Xi ya demostr√≥ que quiere negociar con Estados Unidos, pero que tambi√©n est√° dispuesto a tejer otras alianzas, incluso con pa√≠ses que tienen alineamientos m√°s fuertes con Occidente, como puede ser el caso de Jap√≥n o Corea del Sur, con quienes se reunieron los ministros para abogar por el libre comercio.

title: Under Fire From Trump‚Äôs Tariffs, Ammo Makers in a Balkan Valley Hunker Down
content: Companies that make ammunition in the Bosnian city of Gorazde fear they may not survive the tariffs imposed on the goods that they send to their biggest market ‚Äî the United States.
resumen:
Workers producing ammunition parts last month for Ginex and Pobjeda Technology, in Gorazde, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The ammunition makers of Gorazde in eastern Bosnia survived the Balkan wars of the early 1990s.
They face a new menace: the scattershot tariffs announced by President Trump in early April.
The United States‚Äô appetite for guns has long provided a steady market for Gorazde‚Äôs main industry ‚Äî the weapons factories built when Bosnia was part of Yugoslavia.
The tariffs announced by Mr. Trump for almost all of the United States‚Äô trading partners ‚Äî including tiny Bosnia ‚Äî have reverberated around Gorazde.
Ginex, a local company that makes ignition devices used in ammunition, known as primers, has stalled expansion plans.
Demir Imamovic, Ginex‚Äôs marketing manager, said that high tariffs had been especially disruptive for the ammunition industry.
The company has postponed its plans to increase its work force to around 1,100 from 850.
Shooters World, a South Carolina company that sells gunpowder and primers to American ammunition manufacturers, said it imported 20 million primers from Ginex in October but canceled a shipment planned for April, partly because of the tariffs.
Gorazde‚Äôs mayor, Ernest Imamovic, said he worried that the United States had abandoned a faith in free trade and economic development as a path to peace.
Also clouding Gorazde‚Äôs fortunes has been the Trump administration‚Äôs dismantling of U.S.A.I.D., which had financed a now-canceled project to attract investment from the Bosnian diaspora in the United States.
A second U.S.A.I.D. project to support the local government has also been canceled.
Bosnia has over the past five years increased its exports to the United States by more than 250 percent.
Its sales to America last year, according to the trade ministry, only accounted for 1.9 percent of Bosnia‚Äôs total exports, compared to 72 percent to the European Union.
Bosnia once produced more than half of the ammunition used by Yugoslavia‚Äôs military.
The town‚Äôs two biggest companies, the state-controlled Ginex, and Pobjeda Technology, now a private one focused on making ammunition for pistols and sport guns, looked to the U.S. civilian market to help them stay in business ‚Äî and employ more than 2,000 local residents.
More than 100 million Americans own guns.
Business spiked in 2020 when the Covid pandemic in the United States and heightened tensions following the police killing of George Floyd prompted a surge in gun-buying by Americans.
Ginex more than quadrupled its exports to companies in South Carolina, Texas and other mostly southern states.
Mr. Trump‚Äôs election victory in November stirred mixed feelings.
Karen Gerard, Shooter World‚Äôs chief financial officer, said it could make sense to impose high tariffs on imports of low-priced finished ammunition.
America produces only around 2 percent of the primers that domestic companies need to make ammunition.
Bosnia‚Äôs response to the Trump administration‚Äôs tariffs is being led by Trade Minister Stasa Kosarac.
He was appointed to manage trade for the whole country under convoluted power-sharing arrangements mandated by the Dayton accord.
He said he was ‚Äúvery happy‚Äù Mr. Trump was back in the White House and expressed no interest in trying to save Bosnia‚Äôs gun and ammunition companies, mostly located in Muslim towns like Gorazde, from high American tariffs.
He said he was glad to see the back of the Biden administration, which frequently denounced Bosnia‚Äôs more stridently nationalist Serb politicians and sanctioned their leader, Milorad Dodik, the Republika Srpska president.
The trade minister‚Äôs office is decorated with photographs of Mr. Dodik wearing a red Make America Great Again hat.
Mr. Kosarec said he has not reached out to Washington to get a deal on tariffs and was instead waiting for Bosnia‚Äôs fractious, ethnically divided leadership to approve a proposal he said had been made by Mr. Dodik for zero tariffs on both sides.
Bosnia‚Äôs Muslim politicians have no interest in blocking a tariff deal with the United States but are wary of Mr. Dodik exploiting the trade issue to curry favor with President Trump in an effort to get U.S. sanctions against him lifted.
They want Mr. Dodik arrested and jailed following his conviction by a Sarajevo court in February for flouting rulings by the international official responsible for overseeing the Dayton agreement.
Mr. Dodik was given a one-year prison sentence but, protected by armed bodyguards, has resisted arrest.
The risk that the muddle in both Washington and Sarajevo will cost jobs in Gorazde has left the town‚Äôs mayor, Mr. Imamovic, aghast.
Ginex‚Äôs marketing manager said he was still confused by the situation.

title: Republican Hypocrisy Reaches Into the Countryside
content: Some prominent Republicans may see many of these Medicaid recipients as adult layabouts, but it‚Äôs more likely that these cuts will affect low-income children, seniors and Americans with disabilities, ...
resumen:
President Trump won his second term in office with the overwhelming support of rural America. Overall turnout was up in the nation‚Äôs rural counties, and Trump won many of those areas by more than two-to-one. Without this over-performance, his path to victory would have been harder.

Republicans want to cut $700 billion from Medicaid and other federal health programs to pay for their $3.8 trillion tax plan, which includes possibly trillions in tax cuts and extensions for the wealthiest Americans. These cuts could cause as many as 8.6 million Americans to lose their health insurance. Rural areas in particular depend on Medicaid spending. Nearly half of all children in rural areas, 47 percent, receive health insurance through Medicaid. Rural hospitals also rely on Medicaid.

House Republicans also want to slash the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) to reduce so-called waste, fraud and abuse. These cuts will most likely hit children and other vulnerable populations hardest. Roughly one in seven households in rural areas receive SNAP benefits.

House Republicans have proposed other cuts: to programs that provide free meals to children in low-income school districts, to programs that provide care to seniors and to programs that provide rental assistance to at-risk families. This is all on top of Trump‚Äôs trade wars, as well as his unilateral moves to try to slash funding for rural broadband and to try to roll back the production of clean energy, at one point freezing grants for farmers and rural business owners who purchased renewables such as solar panels.

For all of the Republican Party‚Äôs cultural affinity for rural America, its policy agenda is singularly hostile to the material interests of the millions of Americans who live in rural areas.

If Trump and the Republican Party can successfully cut Medicaid and SNAP to pay for upper-income tax cuts, they will almost certainly plunge millions of people ‚Äî including many of their supporters ‚Äî into poverty, possibly made worse by the economic disruption of the president‚Äôs trade agenda.

title: Chinese stock investors strike cautious tone, awaiting further developments in US-China trade talks
content: In the US, markets reacted more positively to the easing of US-China trade tensions, which have roiled global supply chains and stirred fears of higher domestic inflation. The S&P 500 index rose for ...
resumen:
Chinese stock investors took a cautious approach this week to the start of Sino-US trade talks and a 90-day lowering of bilateral tariffs.
Wu Kaida, an analyst with TF Securities, said, "Those who bet Chinese stocks would surge on the news were disappointed," and "The market response was very conservative as investors take a long-term view and await further news."
He added, "People know it is far from being over yet and also know that the US is prone to make sudden and unexpected shifts in policy, as has happened before."
The Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.76 percent this week, while the Shenzhen Component Index rose 0.52 percent.
Both ended lower on Friday after a week of small movements within a narrow 1 percentage point range.
On Thursday, China implemented a 0.5-point cut in the amount of reserves it requires banks to hold.
Wu said he expects sectors like consumption, military equipment and technology to continue as powerhouses of future growth.
Wang Tao, chief China economist of UBS, who is based in Hong Kong, noted a decrease in US-China trade tensions but said "uncertainties remain high."
She said the framework for trade talks announced earlier this week is a starting point for negotiations, "but the weighted average tariff rate still imposed by the US on Chinese goods poses significant pressure on China's exports and economic growth."
Hong Kong's Hang Seng, in a week of wider swings, ended with a weekly gain of 2.1 percent.
The government announced better-than-expected 3.1 percent growth for the first quarter.
In the US, markets reacted more positively to the easing of US-China trade tensions.
The S&P 500 index rose for five consecutive sessions to post a weekly gain of 5.3 percent, while the Dow Jones average was up 3.4 percent.
The Nasdaq surged 7.2 percent.

title: Qu√© productos se podr√≠an encarecer por los aranceles en Walmart
content: A los compradores de Walmart se les acaba el tiempo para evitar precios m√°s altos. El gigante minorista advirti√≥ el jueves que sus productos se encarecer√°n debido a que los aranceles del presidente Do ...
resumen: A los compradores de Walmart se les acaba el tiempo para evitar precios m√°s altos. El gigante minorista advirti√≥ el jueves que sus productos se encarecer√°n debido a que los aranceles del presidente Donald Trump son ‚Äúdemasiado altos‚Äù. El CEO de Walmart, Douglas McMillon, declar√≥ que har√°n todo lo posible para mantener los precios lo m√°s bajos posible, pero dada la magnitud de los aranceles, no pueden absorber toda la presi√≥n. Los cambios probablemente entrar√°n en vigor a finales de mayo, y los precios aumentar√°n ‚Äúmucho m√°s‚Äù en junio, seg√∫n el director financiero de Walmart, John David Rainey. Walmart, que cuenta con m√°s de 4.600 tiendas en Estados Unidos, recibe mercanc√≠a de Canad√°, China, India, M√©xico y Vietnam, entre otros pa√≠ses. Estos pa√≠ses enfrentan aranceles de al menos el 10 %, y las importaciones de acero, aluminio, autom√≥viles y autopartes enfrentan aranceles del 25 %. McMillon declar√≥ que los aranceles m√°s altos sobre China son los que tienen el mayor impacto. Trump aument√≥ los aranceles sobre la mayor√≠a de los productos chinos a un impresionante 145 %, pero esa tasa se redujo al 30 % el lunes como parte de una tregua de 90 d√≠as con China. El secretario de Comercio, Howard Lutnick, declar√≥ que los aranceles base no bajar√°n del 10 % durante las negociaciones. Economistas han declarado que los aranceles afectar√°n a los estadounidenses de ingresos bajos y medios, quienes hist√≥ricamente han sido la principal base de clientes de Walmart. La Universidad de Michigan inform√≥ que la confianza del consumidor cay√≥ un 2,7 % entre abril y mayo. McMillon declar√≥ que la inflaci√≥n alimentaria es una preocupaci√≥n. Los pl√°tanos, los aguacates y el caf√© se encuentran entre los productos que, seg√∫n McMillon, provienen de Colombia, Costa Rica y Per√∫. Estados Unidos tambi√©n importa remolacha, repollo, melones y pi√±as de Costa Rica. Las batatas y los c√≠tricos se importan de Per√∫. Walmart no indic√≥ cu√°nto podr√≠an aumentar los precios de las frutas y verduras. McMillon sugiri√≥ que ‚Äúcontrolar la cantidad de desperdicio de alimentos frescos‚Äù podr√≠a ser √∫til. Entre febrero y abril, el precio promedio de los pl√°tanos por libra aument√≥ aproximadamente 2 centavos en los minoristas estadounidenses, seg√∫n la Oficina de Estad√≠sticas Laborales. Ryan Monarch, profesor adjunto de Econom√≠a en la Universidad de Syracuse, declar√≥ que las compras de temporada y navide√±as no pueden retrasarse dos o tres meses a la espera de que se resuelva la guerra comercial. McMillon explic√≥ que los aranceles se pagan en cuanto un producto entra al pa√≠s por la aduana, lo que significa que los aranceles m√°s altos ya est√°n afectando los env√≠os. McMillon dijo que lo que est√°n viendo es una presi√≥n alcista que comenz√≥ en abril y se mantiene durante todo el a√±o sobre los productos importados. McMillon a√±adi√≥ que calcular los costos arancelarios y las cantidades de los pedidos podr√≠a volverse m√°s dif√≠cil m√°s adelante al tomar decisiones relacionadas con eventos como Halloween y Navidad. McMillon dijo que China, en particular, representa un gran volumen en ciertas categor√≠as como electr√≥nica y juguetes. Aproximadamente el 80 % de los juguetes vendidos en Estados Unidos se fabrican en China, seg√∫n la Asociaci√≥n de Juguetes. Compa√±√≠as de juguetes, como Hasbro y Mattel, han advertido de posibles subidas de precios debido a los aranceles. Trump reconoci√≥ el posible impacto de los aranceles en los juguetes. Un an√°lisis de precios realizado por la firma de investigaci√≥n Telsey Advisory Groups mostr√≥ que el precio de una mu√±eca Barbie con traje de ba√±o vendida en Target subi√≥ un 42,9 % en una semana a mediados de abril, hasta los US$ 14,99. Los productos de videojuegos tambi√©n deber√≠an experimentar fuertes subidas de precio. Con un precio inicial de US$ 450, la Switch 2 de Nintendo podr√≠a costar alrededor de US$ 600, seg√∫n los expertos. Incluso un iPhone 17 de Apple podr√≠a costar m√°s de US$ 1.000 en lugar de US$ 799, seg√∫n Daniel Morgan, gestor de cartera s√©nior de la firma de inversi√≥n Synovus. Los productos de cuidado infantil, como cochecitos, ropa, sillas de auto y leche de f√≥rmula, tambi√©n podr√≠an experimentar un aumento de precios. Los expertos del sector estiman que alrededor del 90 % de los productos para ni√±os y beb√©s se fabrican exclusivamente en China. Monarch de la Universidad de Syracuse dijo que es de esperar que productos como esos vean un aumento de precios bastante r√°pido. En 2024, China envi√≥ m√°s de US$ 438.000 millones en bienes a los hogares estadounidenses. Casi el 19 % de ese total correspondi√≥ a maquinaria y electrodom√©sticos, seg√∫n datos de la Comisi√≥n de Comercio Internacional de Estados Unidos. El 4 % de las importaciones chinas del a√±o pasado fueron ropa de cama, muebles e iluminaci√≥n. Rainey, director financiero de Walmart, dijo que las ventas de art√≠culos generales en Estados Unidos disminuyeron ligeramente durante el primer trimestre, ‚Äúcon una debilidad en los productos electr√≥nicos, los productos para el hogar y los art√≠culos deportivos‚Äù.

title: Moody's rebaj√≥ la calificaci√≥n de Estados Unidos, con el foco puesto en el alto nivel de deuda
content: Es la √∫ltima de las tres grandes agencias calificadoras en hacerlo, y se espera que los inversores acusen recibo en un contexto de mercados vulerables.
resumen: Moody's rebaj√≥ la calificaci√≥n crediticia soberana de Estados Unidos el viernes debido a la preocupaci√≥n por la creciente deuda del pa√≠s, de 36 billones de d√≥lares. Esta medida podr√≠a complicar los esfuerzos del presidente Donald Trump por recortar impuestos y se espera que genere un impacto en los mercados globales.

title: White House‚Äôs approach to tariffs may bring serious consequences
content: As a result of the Trump Administration‚Äôs reckless tariff policies, America‚Äôs hardwood industry has faced a range of consequences, including lost revenues, cancelled orders and the high costs of ...
resumen: As a result of the Trump Administration‚Äôs reckless tariff policies, America‚Äôs hardwood industry has faced a range of consequences, including lost revenues, cancelled orders and the high costs of diverting shipments already in route to China. The 125% tariffs that China applied to U.S. imports in response to the staggering 145% tariffs that the Trump administration placed on Chinese goods on April 2 jolted hardwood producers. Immediately, some hardwood prices plummeted, and many lumber processors halted purchases from sawmills, leaving those mills with limited outlets for their lumber. Many hardwood exporters began laying off workers, closing operations and selling rerouted shipments at distressed prices. For now, the trade war between United States and China has simmered, with tariffs rates on American exports to China now set at 10%. In Pennsylvania, which is the nation‚Äôs leading producer of hardwood lumber, the stakes are especially high. In the Commonwealth alone, the forest-products industry employs over 60,000 people and has a $21.8 billion direct impact and a $39.1 billion indirect impact on the state economy. The livelihoods of foresters, loggers, sawyers, material handlers, lumber graders and many more well-paying jobs hang in the balance. Fewer ancillary workers, such as truck drivers and dock workers, will be needed if high tariffs are reinstated. The future of Pennsylvania‚Äôs global hardwood markets and the environment also remain at risk. Without stable pricing and a reliable supply of U.S. hardwoods, international producers who covet American hardwoods for their beauty, durability, legality and environmental credentials will consider shifting to European, African, South American or Asian hardwoods. When tariffs impair demand from China, the largest importer of American hardwoods, the results are devastating. China is the top destination for Red Oak, the highest-volume species in the Appalachian Forest. Without this market, current East Coast sawmill production capacity, already reduced to its present output of 6 billion board feet annually from over 14 billion annually at its peak ‚Äî partly due to tariffs Trump imposed in 2018 ‚Äî will further decline. The responsible forest management practiced here and respected around the globe requires the full and proper utilization of all hardwood species growing in our forests. Uneven demand across hardwood species resulting from lost markets undermines responsible forest management leading to less wood production. Fewer wood products would also mean less carbon sequestration. Global deforestation rates could also rise if U.S. supplies fewer hardwoods to international markets. These tariffs were implemented by the Trump administration with complete disregard for the Constitutional power granted to Congress ‚Äúto lay and collect taxes, duties, Imposts and Excises.‚Äù Congressional power was circumvented by invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The courts will rule on the tariffs‚Äô constitutionality. Pennsylvania is synonymous with top-quality hardwoods and a paragon of responsible forest management. There are family owned, multi-generational sawmills dotting our Commonwealth providing critical jobs to rural areas. Scott Seyler is vice president for international sales for Northland Forest Products Inc.

title: Las movidas de EE.UU.: aranceles, relaciones con China e impacto en remesas
content: Proteger la industria y los empleos estadounidenses es la prioridad de Washington. El solo anuncio de grav√°menes abri√≥ ruta a negociaciones con varios pa√≠ses.
resumen:
La prioridad de Washington es proteger la industria y los empleos estadounidenses. El solo anuncio de grav√°menes abri√≥ ruta a negociaciones con varios pa√≠ses.

La elevaci√≥n de los aranceles, el cortar la competitividad hace disminuir el comercio exterior, baja el crecimiento econ√≥mico de los pa√≠ses.

Trump se√±ala que la culpa es de la administraci√≥n Biden.

La pol√≠tica actual de Washington es una amenaza para la din√°mica de los intercambios mundiales, atenta contra la complementariedad de ventajas comparativas y competitivas de los diferentes pa√≠ses y puede desembocar en ser factor que har√≠an m√°s lento el crecimiento de producci√≥n, la productividad y la generaci√≥n de empleo globales.

La segunda administraci√≥n de Trump da continuidad a la primera gesti√≥n (2017-2021) en cuanto a promover mayor aislamiento y proteccionismo.

La carencia de competitividad no se compensa con aranceles.

China tiene a su favor factores estructurales tales como (i) tener la mayor cantidad -m√°s de 50%- de las reservas mundiales en d√≥lares; (ii) haber contribuido notablemente -junto a Jap√≥n- de la compra de la deuda estadounidense; y (iii) poseer una posici√≥n estrat√©gica mundial en cuanto a acceso a ‚Äútierras raras‚Äù, componentes indispensables en los dispositivos actuales de alta tecnolog√≠a.

Washington plantea gravar con impuestos de hasta 5%, el env√≠o de remesas familiares. Esto ser√≠a un gran golpe para econom√≠as centroamericanas -especialmente Guatemala-, que tiene un peso de esos env√≠os equivalente a un 20% del producto interno bruto.

Los excesos de proteccionismo, v√≠a el mercantilismo que la administraci√≥n norteamericana trata de establecer ya fueron probados en cuanto a amplios impactos negativos.

Aumentos en los impuestos a la importaci√≥n de bienes puede hacer que estos √∫ltimos evidentemente se encarezcan para los consumidores de la econom√≠a dirigida desde Washington.

En la econom√≠a de Estados Unidos, con mayores aranceles a las importaciones, los precios tender√≠an al alza. La inflaci√≥n es un incremento generalizado de los precios de bienes y servicios en una econom√≠a dada.

Estas medidas muchas veces han sido negativas. No s√≥lo profundizaron la crisis que se trataba de resolver, sino que empujaron a Estados Unidos a una guerra comercial importante con otros pa√≠ses.

La ley Smoot-Hawley se aprob√≥ por el Congreso de ese pa√≠s el 17 de junio de 1930.

Los BRICS (Brasil, Rusia, India, China y Sud√°frica) han empezado a manejar la idea de salirse del patr√≥n d√≥lar.

Washington le pide o casi impone al Viejo Continente que m√°s petr√≥leo y gas provenga de Estados Unidos.

title: The AI arms race gets personal
content: This recalibration of AI export controls is intrinsically linked to the ongoing tariff war, another major front in the US-China battle.
resumen: The U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) rescinded the Biden administration‚Äôs ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence Diffusion Rule‚Äù days before its May 15th effective date. The ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence Diffusion Rule,‚Äù introduced in January under former President Joe Biden, aimed to manage the global proliferation of advanced AI chips and AI capabilities. It established restrictions on exporting U.S.-made AI chips, with closest allies like Japan and South Korea largely spared, while adversaries like China and Russia faced tougher limitations. Nations like Israel and Mexico would have faced caps on AI chip imports. Industry giants like Nvidia opposed the rules. The Trump administration has swept this tiered system aside. The DOC‚Äôs announcement of the revocation included plans for a ‚Äúreplacement rule in the future, likely focusing on direct negotiations with countries as opposed to blanket restrictions.‚Äù Jeffrey Kessler, U.S. Secretary of Commerce for Industry and Security, declared the Biden approach an ‚Äúill-conceived and counterproductive‚Äù imposition. The DOC issued immediate guidance: a reminder that using Huawei‚Äôs Ascend AI chips globally violates U.S. export rules; a caution about using U.S. AI chips in training AI models within China; and recommendations for fortifying chip supply chains. Both administrations share the core goal of cementing U.S. dominance in AI and preventing China from leveraging advanced technology. The Trump administration seems to be gearing up for a more flexible, aggressive and transactional engagement, relying on bespoke agreements and punitive actions against those, like Huawei. The rhetoric of a ‚Äúbold, inclusive strategy with trusted foreign countries‚Äù hints at a different approach to alliance-building in this tech conflict, but the unwavering focus on keeping advanced tech from ‚Äúadversaries‚Äù shows the underlying contest with China remains paramount. Significant tariffs, initiated under the previous Trump administration and largely continued by Biden, were already a defining feature of the economic landscape. The current administration has increased compliance on chipmakers, with Nvidia required to go through a licensing route to ship its H20 GPUs to China. This type of policy shift creates a dual pressure point for the tech industry: restricted access to and movement of AI technology, compounded by the increased financial burden of tariffs. For tech companies and their global supply chains, this integrated battlefront of AI controls and tariffs signals continued turbulence. In the near term adapting to ambiguity will be important as geopolitics move from a defined set of rules to a future that is based on direct negotiations. The intertwined forces of AI export controls and tariffs will likely compel companies to de-risk and diversify their supply chains. China will accelerate its investment in domestic AI capabilities.

title: Chile espera que EE.UU. reduzca los aranceles a cero tal y como lo establece su TLC
content: Conseguir que Donald Trump elimine los aranceles ser√≠a una tarea dif√≠cil para Chile; EE.UU. mantuvo el arancel b√°sico de 10% al Reino Unido ...
resumen:
Chile espera que EE.UU. reduzca los aranceles a cero tal y como lo establece su TLC.

Claudia Sanhueza, subsecretaria de Relaciones Econ√≥micas Internacionales de Chile, declar√≥ que Chile sigue esperando que EE.UU. elimine todos los aranceles y los reduzca a cero, tal y como se establece en el acuerdo de libre comercio entre ambos pa√≠ses.

Se pusieron en marcha las negociaciones para un Acuerdo de Asociaci√≥n Econ√≥mica Integral, Cepa, por sus siglas en ingl√©s, con el fin de abrir nuevos mercados de exportaci√≥n; se estableci√≥ un memorando de entendimiento con importadores de alimentos indios; y se firmaron acuerdos para reforzar la cooperaci√≥n en una serie de √°mbitos, entre ellos la miner√≠a y la tecnolog√≠a.

Las negociaciones con India son ‚Äúla m√°xima prioridad del gobierno y del presidente‚Äù, afirm√≥ Sanhueza, quien a√±adi√≥ que estaba trabajando para cerrar un acuerdo antes de marzo del pr√≥ximo a√±o, cuando finaliza el mandato del presidente.

Su departamento tambi√©n est√° trabajando en un CEPA con Filipinas, que se puso en marcha el a√±o pasado.
