title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq edge higher as US stocks eye a weekly win
content: US stocks rose on Friday, poised for weekly wins after an easing in US-China trade tensions. Investors also eyed President Trump's sweeping tax and spending bill, which failed to clear a key hurdle ...
resumen: US stocks rose on Friday, notching weekly wins across the major averages after an easing in US-China trade tensions. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) moved up nearly 0.7%, extending gains for a fifth day in a row. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) rose 0.8%, while the Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also gained 0.5%. The tech-heavy index outperformed for the week, notching gains of roughly 7%. The S&P 500 has erased all its 2025 losses and is positive for the year. Consumer sentiment fell in May as Americans grew more pessimistic about the inflation outlook. The index came in at 50.8, its second-lowest reading on record, down from 52.2 for April. One-year inflation expectations jumped to 7.8%, the highest since 1981. The president said Friday that the US ‚Äúwill be sending letters out essentially telling" countries the tariff rate set for their imports within the coming weeks. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) extended gains for a fifth straight session, up more than 5% for the week. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also rose more than 7% over the past five days. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) also rose on Friday, gaining more than 3% for the week. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) was hovering above $104,000 on Friday. Gold futures (GC=F) pulled back more than 1% on Friday. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) was up more than 4% for the week, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) rose more than 6% over the past five days. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) was up more than 2.5% over the same five-day period. Consumer sentiment tumbled further in May. The index slid to a reading of 50.8. One-year inflation expectations jumped to 7.3% ‚Äî the highest since 1981. Tesla (TSLA) stock rose 1% in premarket trading. Novo Nordisk (NVO) announced that CEO Lars Fruergaard J√∏rgensen would leave his post. Novo Nordisk stock is down 22% year to date. Charter Communications (CHTR) stock rose more than 6% premarket Friday. The deal would value Cox Communications, which is privately held, at $34.5 billion. UnitedHealth (UNH): The health insurer's stock turned higher, up about 3%. Applied Materials (AMAT): Its stock slid roughly 6%. Take-Two Interactive (TTWO): Shares in the games maker slipped 2%. Constellation Brands (STZ): The drinks company's stock rose over 3%. Cava Group (CAVA) stock fell 3% in premarket trading Friday. Japan‚Äôs economy contracted an annualized 0.7% for Jan-March. The Nikkei 225 (^N225) edged down 0.5%. South Korea‚Äôs Kospi (^KS11) traded flat. Australia‚Äôs S&P/ASX 200 (^AXJO) advanced 0.8%. In Hong Kong the Hang Seng Index (^HSI) opened 200 or 0.9% down from previous close.

title: Por qu√© son peligrosos los aranceles de Trump
content: Primero, anal√≠tica y emp√≠ricamente se sabe que los aranceles (impuestos ad valorem a los productos comprados en el exterior) ...
resumen:
La imposici√≥n de aranceles por parte de Trump est√° generando efectos negativos en la econom√≠a estadounidense, con proyecciones de reducci√≥n en el crecimiento econ√≥mico y aumento de la inflaci√≥n. La Reserva Federal ajust√≥ a la baja su estimaci√≥n de crecimiento, mientras el FMI prev√© una disminuci√≥n del PIB. Los precios de los mercados alimentarios tambi√©n se ven afectados por los grav√°menes. Trump utiliza esta pol√≠tica como medida de negociaci√≥n, buscando atraer inversionistas y cuestionar la globalizaci√≥n. La incertidumbre se extiende en la econom√≠a mundial, con proyecciones a la baja del PIB en 2025.

Los aranceles (impuestos ad valorem a los productos comprados en el exterior) afectan negativamente a las econom√≠as que los aplican, generando presiones inflacionarias porque suben directamente los precios de los bienes de consumo que se importan de otros pa√≠ses. Tambi√©n, aumentan los precios de los insumos de los productores del pa√≠s que los aplica, lo que sube sus costos y suma presiones inflacionarias en ese pa√≠s. Los precios m√°s altos reducen el poder adquisitivo de los sueldos y, por consiguiente, se reduce la demanda interna de bienes y servicios de esa econom√≠a y, finalmente, se contrae la actividad productiva (PIB) del pa√≠s que sube sus aranceles.

La Reserva Federal (FED) de Estados Unidos ajust√≥ a 1,7 % su proyecci√≥n de crecimiento econ√≥mico para 2025, reduciendo en 0,4 puntos porcentuales su estimaci√≥n anterior (diciembre 2024). El FMI, ajust√≥ su estimaci√≥n del PIB de EE.UU en casi un punto porcentual, desde 2,7% (estimado en enero) a 1,8%. EE.UU baj√≥ su PIB en 0,3 puntos porcentuales en el primer trimestre de 2025, respecto del cuarto trimestre 2024, en que hab√≠a tenido una tasa de crecimiento trimestral anualizada de 2,4%. La inflaci√≥n de EE.UU muestra una tendencia a aumentar. Estimaciones recientes proyectan tasas de 3,0% para este a√±o, aument√°ndola en 0,3 puntos porcentuales.

En Bloomberg se informa que los precios de los mercados alimentarios mundiales se han visto afectado por los grav√°menes.

Trump utiliza la pol√≠tica arancelaria como medida de negociaci√≥n. En lo econ√≥mico, seg√∫n √©l, lo que hace es retomar el potencial econ√≥mico de Estados Unidos en el mediano plazo, atrayendo a los inversionistas hacia la econom√≠a norteamericana y, simult√°neamente, avanza en poner en cuesti√≥n la actual globalizaci√≥n de los mercados. En lo geopol√≠tico, establece un punto de poder en la negociaci√≥n de aranceles, al menos con el conjunto de pa√≠ses que han aceptado sentarse a la mesa de negociaci√≥n, los cuales son, de partida, todos los pa√≠ses a los cuales, Chile entre ellos, les aplic√≥ una tarifa de 10% para las producciones que los norteamericanos les compran. A los cuales tambi√©n se agregaron Jap√≥n y la Zona Euro, con poco √©xito inicial. Recientemente, se estar√≠a sumando China a las negociaciones de los aranceles ‚Äúcompensatorios‚Äù de Trump.

La lucha entre Estados Unidos y China por la primac√≠a en los desarrollos cient√≠ficos y tecnol√≥gicos, fue el fundamento de la guerra comercial anterior entre estas naciones, entre marzo 2018 y fines de 2019, que signific√≥ reducir el PIB mundial desde 4% en 2017 a 3,3% en 2019.

Los aranceles que en estos meses Trump ha estado aplicando (10% desde el 4 de febrero a China y Canad√°, los que subi√≥ a 20% el 4 de marzo); o que, ha estado anunciando que va a aplicar (por ejemplo, en marzo avis√≥ que aplicar√≠a un 25% al cobre, el acero y el aluminio); o que, anunci√≥, el 02 de abril, aplicar√≠a a 90 pa√≠ses y que unos d√≠as despu√©s suspendi√≥ por noventa d√≠as en su aplicaci√≥n, para negociar; o que, simplemente ha dejado en suspenso (como el cobre y otros metales); o que, aumenta, el 8 de abril, a 145% para la mayor√≠a de los productos chinos y que frente a la respuesta china vuelve a aumentarlos a 245%.

El FMI estima (19 de abril), ca√≠das en el PIB de las principales econom√≠as y, para Estados Unidos pronostica una ca√≠da desde 2,7% a 1,8%, para China una ca√≠da desde 4,6% a 4,0%, para la Zona Euro una reducci√≥n desde 1,0% a 0,8% y, en el caso de Chile, estima una ca√≠da desde 2,2% a 2,0%.

title: La tasa de desempleo en Paraguay se situ√≥ en el 5,6 % en el primer trimestre de 2025
content: Asunci√≥n, 16 may (EFE).- La tasa de desocupaci√≥n en Paraguay se situ√≥ en el 5,6 % entre enero y marzo de 2025, por encima del 4,6 % registrado en el per√≠odo precedente, el cuarto trimestre de 2024, in ...
resumen:
La tasa de desempleo en Paraguay se situ√≥ en el 5,6 % entre enero y marzo de 2025, por encima del 4,6 % registrado en el cuarto trimestre de 2024, seg√∫n el Instituto Nacional de Estad√≠sticas (INE).

El desempleo baj√≥ en 1,3 puntos si el resultado de los tres primeros meses de 2025 se compara con el mismo periodo de 2024, cuando la tasa se ubic√≥ en el 6,9 %.

La poblaci√≥n desempleada totaliz√≥ 171.634 personas, de las cuales, cerca de 79.845 fueron hombres (46,5 %) y 91.789 mujeres (53,5 %), en un pa√≠s de 6,1 millones de habitantes, seg√∫n la Encuesta Permanente de Hogares Continua correspondiente al primer trimestre de 2025, elaborada por el INE.

La tasa de ocupaci√≥n se ubic√≥ en el 66,1 %, que representa a alrededor de 2.911.705 personas.

La ocupaci√≥n registr√≥ un leve aumento de 0,4 puntos, si se compara con el 65,7 % del primer trimestre de 2024, lo que implica 41.838 nuevas personas ocupadas, seg√∫n el INE.

Los sectores econ√≥micos con mayores incrementos en la mano de obra ocupada fueron el sector primario (que abarca la agricultura, ganader√≠a, pesca, entre otros), en alrededor de 13.392 personas, y el sector terciario o de servicios, en 29.301 trabajadores.

La subocupaci√≥n subi√≥ al 3,1 % (96.726 ocupados), frente al 2,9 % (88.971 ocupados) del primer trimestre de 2024.

La fuerza de trabajo sum√≥ el primer trimestre de 2025 aproximadamente 3.083.338 personas, que representa al 70 % de la poblaci√≥n de 15 y m√°s a√±os de edad.

title: Impuesto del 5% a las remesas: c√≥mo afectar√≠a a los inmigrantes
content: El impuesto del 5% a las remesas afectar√≠a a millones de inmigrantes y a sus familias en sus pa√≠ses de origen: aqu√≠ te decimos qui√©nes ser√°n los m√°s afectados ...
resumen: Una nueva propuesta fiscal impulsada por legisladores republicanos en la C√°mara de Representantes plantea un impuesto del 5% a las remesas enviadas desde Estados Unidos. Esta medida, incluida en un paquete m√°s amplio que refleja las prioridades del presidente Donald Trump, podr√≠a tener consecuencias significativas para millones de inmigrantes que viven y trabajan legalmente en el pa√≠s. El proyecto afectar√≠a a m√°s de 40 millones de personas, incluyendo titulares de tarjetas de residencia permanente y quienes cuentan con visas temporales como H-1B, H-2A y H-2B. Todos ellos quedar√≠an sujetos al nuevo impuesto. Los ciudadanos estadounidenses estar√≠an exentos. Seg√∫n sus impulsores, el impuesto tiene un doble objetivo: frenar la inmigraci√≥n ilegal y generar ingresos para el gobierno federal. El vicepresidente JD Vance declar√≥ que el impuesto ayudar√≠a a ‚Äúdesincentivar actividades ilegales como el narcotr√°fico y la trata de personas‚Äù. Sin embargo, expertos advierten que esta medida podr√≠a tener efectos contrarios a los esperados. Los trabajadores migrantes contribuyen activamente a la econom√≠a estadounidense. Muchos de ellos env√≠an parte de sus ingresos a sus pa√≠ses de origen para apoyar a sus familias. El nuevo impuesto reducir√≠a el dinero disponible para esos env√≠os, afectando directamente a comunidades en pa√≠ses como M√©xico, Guatemala, Honduras y Hait√≠, donde las remesas representan una fuente vital de ingresos. En municipios como Cajol√°, en Guatemala, gran parte de la econom√≠a local depende de las remesas. Una disminuci√≥n significativa de estos flujos podr√≠a provocar el cierre de negocios, aumento del desempleo y m√°s presi√≥n migratoria hacia Estados Unidos. Miguel D. Ram√≠rez, economista y cr√≠tico de la propuesta, alert√≥ sobre una posible consecuencia no deseada. De acuerdo con el analista, los migrantes podr√≠an recurrir a canales no autorizados para evitar el impuesto, lo que debilitar√≠a la fiscalizaci√≥n y aumentar√≠a el uso de sistemas informales de env√≠o. La presidenta de M√©xico, Claudia Sheinbaum, calific√≥ la propuesta como injusta y contraria a los principios de libertad econ√≥mica. En 2023, las remesas globales alcanzaron los $656 mil millones de d√≥lares. M√©xico, India y China fueron algunos de los principales receptores. El dinero enviado ayuda a financiar educaci√≥n, salud y consumo b√°sico en comunidades vulnerables. Esta medida forma parte de un paquete legislativo que tambi√©n contempla la extensi√≥n de los recortes fiscales aprobados en 2017, que favorecen principalmente a los contribuyentes con mayores ingresos. La Oficina Conjunta de Tributaci√≥n estima que este paquete podr√≠a incrementar la deuda nacional en $5.3 billones de d√≥lares. Para compensar este aumento, los republicanos han propuesto recortes dr√°sticos en programas sociales como Medicaid y SNAP, que benefician a millones de personas en situaci√≥n vulnerable. Esto ha generado preocupaci√≥n entre legisladores moderados y activistas comunitarios. Aunque la propuesta ya fue aprobada en el Comit√© de Medios y Arbitrios de la C√°mara, su futuro es incierto. El presidente de la C√°mara, Mike Johnson, pretende someterla a votaci√≥n antes de que termine mayo. No obstante, enfrenta tensiones entre quienes exigen m√°s recortes al gasto p√∫blico y quienes temen las consecuencias sociales y econ√≥micas de estas medidas. Los intentos previos por establecer impuestos similares a nivel estatal han fracasado en casi todos los casos. Solo Oklahoma aplic√≥ una medida de este tipo en 2009. En aquel a√±o, el estado aprob√≥ un impuesto a las remesas: una tasa de $5 d√≥lares sobre cualquier transferencia bancaria inferior a $500 d√≥lares y del 1% sobre cualquier monto superior a $500 d√≥lares.

title: 'We need USMCA': Auto suppliers face distress from Trump tariffs
content: "For the U.S. to be globally competitive, we need USMCA," Paul McCarthy, president-elect of MEMA and president of its aftermarket suppliers group, said before the Automotive Press Association.
resumen: Working to have the U.S. government honor conditions of the United States-Mexico-Canada trade agreement is a top priority for the vehicle suppliers' lobbying trade group. "For the U.S. to be globally competitive, we need USMCA," Paul McCarthy, president-elect of MEMA and president of its aftermarket suppliers group, said before the Automotive Press Association. Supplier outlooks are down among MEMA's more than 1,000 members. Three quarters are expecting worse financial performances in 2025 than they had anticipated coming into 2025. With their median break-even point expected to be North American production of 14.5 million vehicles this year, up from 14 million because of tariffs, the industry is in a precarious position. Data firm S&P Global Mobility was predicting production at 13.9 million to 14.3 million ahead of President Donald Trump offering some relief measures late last month. "This is an industry under pressure, and our strategies, our investments are on hold, and that's not a good thing for what is the largest manufacturing sector in the U.S.," McCarthy said, noting suppliers contribute 2.5% of U.S. economic activity. President Donald Trump has instituted import taxes of 25% on steel and aluminum, 25% on certain auto parts and at least 10% on imports from most countries around the world with some of the heaviest on Canada and Mexico. About 71% of imported materials and components used by MEMA's members are USMCA-compliant, and MEMA is providing resources to help more become compliant to avoid 25% tariffs. "We've all invested for the last 20 or 30 years into the North America supply chain," said Collin Shaw, president of MEMA's original equipment suppliers group, "and every country in USMCA offers something unique and has something to bring to the table to ensure that, from a competitiveness standpoint, we can compete with the rest of the world." Suppliers have added 61,000 U.S. manufacturing and salaried jobs in the years since Trump signed USMCA in 2020. "That is aligned with the administration's goals," McCarthy said, "that a strong U.S. requires a strong region to be competitive again." More than half of MEMA members report they are less competitive because of the tariff situation, and 53% are worried about sub-tier supplier distress as tariffs raise costs and are expected to increase vehicle prices. "New orders are down, and costs remain elevated," said Mike Jackson, MEMA's executive director of research and insights, "and this is a very tough situation for the supplier industry." Of MEMA members, 7% said they have implemented furloughs, 5% have instituted temporary wage reductions, 43% have delayed capital expenditure spending, 38% have restricted travel and 15% have taken other actions because of tariffs. Some suppliers, though, say they are moving forward with investments. Paul Thomas, president of major auto supplier Robert Bosch GmbH in North America and of Bosch Mobility America, this week said the German manufacturer isn't holding off investing and is moving forward with $6 billion in announced U.S. investments since 2023. Honoring USMCA and making tweaks as needed would help to offer the industry the stability it needs to make long-term decisions. MEMA also is urging certainty on regulations of greenhouse tailpipe emissions. Trump has ordered a reevaluation of rules finalized by the Biden administration and is seeking to remove California's waiver allowing it to have stricter standards that 13 other states and Washington, D.C., have adopted. MEMA also urges permitting reforms to increase the speed of U.S. expansion, retaining the Inflation Reduction Act that former President Joe Biden signed in 2022 that granted incentives to manufacturers of U.S. batteries, a "pro-business" tax environment, incentives for research and development and support to increase skilled tooling talent in the country, McCarthy said. The ability to deduct R&D spending proposed in the Ways and Means Committee's budget is a good step forward.

resumen: El cierre de empresas en Ju√°rez ha venido creciendo desde que el Gobierno de Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador subi√≥ el salario m√≠nimo en la frontera, seg√∫n Marcelo V√°zquez Tovar, delegado de la Asociaci√≥n Nacional de Exportadores e Importadores de la Rep√∫blica Mexicana (Anierm). La imposici√≥n de aranceles por parte de Donald Trump ha agravado la situaci√≥n. En abril, el Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social (IMSS) report√≥ el cierre de dos empresas m√°s en la frontera. Ya suman 451 empresas cerradas en a√±o y medio, de octubre de 2023 a la fecha. En octubre de 2023, Ju√°rez ten√≠a 12 mil 5 empresas; para abril de 2025 la cifra baj√≥ a 11 mil 554 patrones. El sector Comercio ha perdido 134 empresas, seguido por el sector Servicios para Empresas con 118 y el sector de la Transformaci√≥n con 91. La mayor√≠a de los que cierran son peque√±os y medianos empresarios. Anierm ofrece sus servicios a estos empresarios, incluyendo asesor√≠as en comercio exterior, capacitaci√≥n y certificaciones, y misiones comerciales a Centroam√©rica. El sector industrial de pa√≠ses como Honduras, Guatemala, Belice y El Salvador est√° creciendo, y los proveedores locales podr√≠an ofrecer su experiencia y aprovechar la mano de obra de aquellos lugares.

title: Stock market today: S&P 500 notches 5-day win streak, Nasdaq gains 7% for week as Wall Street shakes off trade war worries
content: US stocks rose on Friday, notching weekly wins across the major averages after an easing in US-China trade tensions. Investors also eyed President Trump's sweeping tax and spending bill, which failed ...
resumen: US stocks rose on Friday, notching weekly wins across the major averages after an easing in US-China trade tensions. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) moved up nearly 0.7%, extending gains for a fifth day in a row. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) rose 0.8%, while the Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also gained 0.5%. The tech-heavy index outperformed for the week, notching gains of roughly 7%. The S&P 500 has erased all its 2025 losses and is positive for the year. Consumer sentiment fell in May as Americans grew more pessimistic about the inflation outlook. The index came in at 50.8, its second-lowest reading on record, down from 52.2 for April. One-year inflation expectations jumped to 7.8%, the highest since 1981. The president said Friday that the US ‚Äúwill be sending letters out essentially telling" countries the tariff rate set for their imports within the coming weeks. Republicans voted to oppose the bill, which promises big tax cuts. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) extended gains for a fifth straight session, up more than 5% for the week. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also rose more than 7% over the past five days. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) also rose on Friday, gaining more than 3% for the week. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) was hovering above $104,000 on Friday. Gold futures (GC=F) pulled back more than 1% on Friday. Gold was on pace to close out the week down more than 4% this week, trading near $3,170 an ounce. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) was up more than 4% for the week, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) rose more than 6% over the past five days. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) was up more than 2.5% over the same five-day period. Consumer sentiment tumbled further in May. The index slid to a reading of 50.8. One-year inflation expectations jumped to 7.3% ‚Äî the highest since 1981. Tesla (TSLA) stock rose 1% in premarket trading. Novo Nordisk (NVO) announced that CEO Lars Fruergaard J√∏rgensen would leave his post. Novo Nordisk stock is down 22% year to date. Charter Communications (CHTR) stock rose more than 6% premarket Friday. UnitedHealth (UNH): The health insurer's stock turned higher, up about 3%. Applied Materials (AMAT): Its stock slid roughly 6%. Take-Two Interactive (TTWO): Shares in the games maker slipped 2%. Constellation Brands (STZ): The drinks company's stock rose over 3%. Cava Group (CAVA) stock fell 3% in premarket trading Friday. Japan‚Äôs economy contracted an annualized 0.7% for Jan-March. The Nikkei 225 (^N225) edged down 0.5%. South Korea‚Äôs Kospi (^KS11) traded flat. Australia‚Äôs S&P/ASX 200 (^AXJO) advanced 0.8%. In Hong Kong the Hang Seng Index (^HSI) opened 0.9% down.

title: Brasil refuerza su alianza comercial y diplom√°tica con China
content: El presidente de Brasil, Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva, concluy√≥ el martes despu√©s de una serie de reuniones de alto nivel en Beijing.
resumen: El presidente de Brasil, Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva, concluy√≥ el martes su √∫ltima ronda de diplomacia internacional despu√©s de una serie de reuniones de alto nivel en Beijing. Su viaje a China sigui√≥ a una visita a Rusia, lo que pone de relieve los esfuerzos de Brasil por profundizar los lazos con actores globales clave en medio de un orden mundial cada vez m√°s fragmentado. El gobierno brasile√±o anunci√≥ que la visita de Lula gener√≥ aproximadamente R$ 27 mil millones (4,8 mil millones de d√≥lares) en inversiones chinas planificadas en los sectores automotriz, energ√©tico y alimentario de Brasil. Las dos naciones tambi√©n firmaron 36 acuerdos comerciales que abarcan √°reas como energ√≠a, tecnolog√≠a, agronegocios y finanzas. China ha sido el mayor socio comercial de Brasil durante m√°s de una d√©cada, con un comercio bilateral que alcanz√≥ los 188 mil millones de d√≥lares en 2024, un aumento de 3,5% respecto al a√±o anterior. Brasil exporta principalmente productos agr√≠colas a China, como soja, ma√≠z, carne de res y caf√©. A cambio, importa maquinaria, productos electr√≥nicos, repuestos y veh√≠culos el√©ctricos de la potencia asi√°tica. En Pek√≠n, Lula particip√≥ en el IV Foro de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribe√±os (Celac) y realiz√≥ una visita de Estado por invitaci√≥n del presidente Xi Jinping. Ambos l√≠deres se reunieron en privado para abordar la cooperaci√≥n bilateral y los desaf√≠os geopol√≠ticos. En una conferencia de prensa posterior a su encuentro, Lula destac√≥ la importancia estrat√©gica de la relaci√≥n de Brasil con China. ‚ÄúLa relaci√≥n entre Brasil y China nunca ha sido tan necesaria‚Äù, afirm√≥. ‚ÄúEn los √∫ltimos meses, el mundo se ha vuelto m√°s impredecible, inestable y fragmentado. China y Brasil est√°n decididos a alzar la voz contra el unilateralismo y el proteccionismo‚Äù. Al referirse a los aranceles impuestos por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump a los bienes importados de pa√≠ses de todo el mundo, Lula reiter√≥ su apoyo al comercio basado en las directrices de la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio. ‚ÄúLas guerras comerciales no tienen ganadores‚Äù, afirm√≥. ‚ÄúAumenta los precios, deprime las econom√≠as y erosiona los ingresos, especialmente entre los m√°s vulnerables. El presidente Xi Jinping y yo abogamos por un comercio justo en el marco de la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio‚Äù. Lula tambi√©n abord√≥ los conflictos globales, incluida la guerra en Ucrania y la crisis humanitaria en Gaza. ‚ÄúLos puntos en com√∫n entre Brasil y China sientan las bases para un di√°logo integral que restablezca la paz en Europa‚Äù, afirm√≥. Hablando sobre Oriente Medio, a√±adi√≥: ‚ÄúLa humanidad se ve mermada por las atrocidades cometidas en Gaza. No puede haber paz sin un Estado palestino viable e independiente que coexista con el Estado de Israel‚Äù. Poco despu√©s de los comentarios de Lula, el ministro de Asuntos Exteriores de Ucrania, Andrii Sybiha, recurri√≥ a las redes sociales para solicitar la asistencia de Brasil para instar al presidente ruso, Vladimir Putin, a asistir a las negociaciones de alto nivel en Estambul y presionar por un cese del fuego de 30 d√≠as. Sybiha escribi√≥ que habl√≥ con su hom√≥logo brasile√±o, Mauro Vieira, y ‚Äúllam√≥ a Brasil a usar su voz autorizada en su di√°logo con Rusia para hacer realidad esta reuni√≥n directa al m√°s alto nivel‚Äù. La delegaci√≥n de Lula a China incluy√≥ a 11 ministros, miembros del Congreso brasile√±o y un contingente empresarial de unos 200 ejecutivos. Esta fue la segunda visita oficial de Lula a China desde su regreso a la presidencia en enero de 2023.

title: Consorcio chino pide a trabajadores en huelga que vuelvan a sus labores en Canal de Panam√°
content: Ciudad de Panam√°, 16 may (EFE).- El consorcio para construir el cuarto puente sobre el Canal de Panam√°, integrado por dos empresas chinas, pidi√≥ este viernes a la "fuerza laboral paname√±a" reincorpora ...
resumen: El consorcio para construir el cuarto puente sobre el Canal de Panam√°, integrado por China Communications Construction Company LTD y China Harbour Engineering Company LTD, pidi√≥ a la ¬´fuerza laboral paname√±a¬ª reincorporarse a los puestos de trabajo, en medio de una huelga obrera que se cumple desde hace semanas. El consorcio exhort√≥ a ¬´toda la fuerza laboral paname√±a -personal operativo, divisiones t√©cnicas y subcontratistas- a retomar sus funciones a la brevedad¬ª. El retorno a la actividad laboral es para cumplir ¬´con los protocolos de seguridad, la disciplina laboral y el nivel de compromiso que demanda una infraestructura de esta magnitud¬ª. El consorcio chino respeta la decisi√≥n individual de cada trabajador de presentarse o no a laborar, sin coacci√≥n alguna, pero reafirma su derecho, como contratista del Estado, de continuar con el desarrollo del proyecto conforme a lo establecido en la normativa legal vigente. El trabajo es un derecho humano fundamental que el consorcio defiende y promueve, al igual que el respeto a la legislaci√≥n laboral paname√±a, los convenios colectivos y los derechos adquiridos de todos los trabajadores. El cuarto puente sobre el canal aliviar√° el congestionado tr√°fico de la capital paname√±a agilizando el movimiento diario de 70.000 veh√≠culos y beneficiando a 1,7 millones de personas. El proyecto original, con coste de 1.420 millones de d√≥lares, fue adjudicado en 2018 al consorcio chino por el Gobierno de Juan Carlos Varela (2014-2019) y deb√≠a estar listo en cinco a√±os (2023) pero ahora las proyecciones indican que ser√° culminado en 2028. Algunos sindicatos de docentes del sector p√∫blico iniciaron el pasado 23 de abril una huelga indefinida para pedir al Gobierno la derogatoria de una reforma a la seguridad social. Se han sumado el sindicado de la construcci√≥n, Suntracs, y tambi√©n el de la industria bananera, as√≠ como grupos ind√≠genas. Tambi√©n protestan contra un acuerdo de seguridad entre EE.UU. y Panam√° y contra la miner√≠a. Hay a diario protestas callejeras en la capital y algunas otras ciudades. Los manifestantes obstruyen parcialmente la v√≠a Interamericana. Se registran enfrentamientos entre la polic√≠a y los manifestantes con epicentro en Veraguas y Bocas del Toro. La transnacional Chiquita registra p√©rdidas millonarias, ante lo cual anunci√≥ el cierre definitivo de una finca y una empacadora y traslad√≥ a la vecina Costa Rica a su personal administrativo.

title: Oil posts weekly gain but remains under supply hike pressure
content: HOUSTON] Oil settled higher on Friday (May 16), notching a second straight week of gains on easing US-China trade tensions, although prices were held back by expectations of higher supply from Iran ...
resumen:
Oil settled higher on Friday (May 16), notching a second straight week of gains on easing US-China trade tensions.

Brent crude futures settled up 88 US cents or 1.4 per cent at US$65.41 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures closed 87 cents or 1.4 per cent higher at US$62.49.

The benchmarks posted a weekly rise of 1 per cent and 2.4 per cent, respectively.

The contracts fell by more than 2 per cent in the previous session on the prospect of an Iranian nuclear deal.

US President Donald Trump said on Thursday the US was nearing a nuclear deal with Iran.

ING analysts wrote in a note that a nuclear deal lifting sanctions would allow Iran to increase oil output, resulting in additional supply of around 400,000 barrels per day.

The US and China agreed to a 90-day pause on their trade war.

Oil rigs fell by 1 to 473 this week.

title: Trump‚Äôs polling numbers have stabilized. Will it last?
content: With all of that in mind, it remains to be seen whether Trump can continue building on the improving sentiment.
resumen:
After what could be considered a turbulent first 100 days in office, President Trump may be beginning to hit his stride.

Trump‚Äôs approval ratings dropped 14-points between inauguration day and his 100-day mark, his numbers appeared to have stabilized in recent weeks.

From a second term record low approval rating of net-negative-7 points in late April (52% disapprove vs. 45% approve), there has been a 3-point improvement in recent weeks.

Now, one-half of voters (50%) disapprove and 46% approve, per RealClearPolitics polling aggregator.

At the same time Trump‚Äôs overall job approval hit its lowest point, an Economist/YouGov poll reported that a majority (54%) of Americans felt the country was on the ‚Äúwrong track‚Äù compared to 36% saying the country was on ‚Äúthe right direction.‚Äù

The same poll, conducted just days ago, shows that 18-point spread narrowing to 7-points. Slightly less than one-half (49%) of Americans now say the country is on the wrong track, versus 42% who say we‚Äôre heading in the right direction.

Trump‚Äôs approval on the economy (47%) was 4-points above water two weeks after inauguration day.

In the days following ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù it had fallen to net-negative-10 points (43% approve vs. 53% disapprove), per Economist/YouGov tracking polls.

Now, as the stock market recovers from its tariff-induced sell off and an end to the trade war with China is in sight, 45% of Americans approve of Trump‚Äôs handling of the economy compared to 51% who disapprove, per the latest tracking poll.

After a 14-point drop in approval on the economy (+4 to -10), Trump has recovered virtually half of the decline.

Trump‚Äôs imposition of sweeping global tariffs threw financial markets into a tailspin, and introduced so much uncertainty that many economists predicted an imminent recession.

After a 90-day pause and then the signing of a preliminary deal with the United Kingdom and progress on a new trade deal with China, much of that pessimism has abated.

The tariffs had turned into a ‚Äúpolitical tax‚Äù on Trump‚Äôs ratings, but pausing them, along with progress on trade deals, significantly lowers the political risks.

The chaos caused by Elon Musk‚Äôs Department of Government Efficiency has been considerably reduced.

With Musk stepping away from the government to focus more on Tesla, the constant stream of headlines announcing widespread firings has calmed nerves in Washington and throughout the country.

Early in his term, he repeatedly forced himself into the spotlight with provocative statements and actions that gave the appearance of a president determined to blow up the system without any clear or coherent strategy.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has taken the lead on trade negotiations, sidelining hardline ideologies like Peter Navarro.

The improving economic outlook is the real driver of Trump‚Äôs improving numbers.

Despite Americans becoming slightly more approving of his handling of the economy, his approval on inflation ‚Äì a direct byproduct of the tariffs ‚Äì remains deeply underwater.

The aforementioned Economist/YouGov poll ‚Äì conducted after reports of a breakthrough in China talks ‚Äì shows that nearly 6-in-10 (57%) of voters disapprove of how Trump has handled inflation.

Two polls, one from CBS News and another from CNN, both show an identical 62% disapproval with the President‚Äôs handling of inflation, versus 38% who approve in both polls.

content: El gigante minorista ceder√° ante los aranceles y subir√° sus tarifas Walmart no resisti√≥ m√°s. La mayor cadena minorista de ...
resumen:
Walmart anuncia alza de precios.

Los precios subir√°n, y lo har√°n pronto.
El director ejecutivo de la corporaci√≥n, Doug McMillon, admiti√≥: ‚ÄúNo podemos absorber toda la presi√≥n‚Äù generada por los nuevos aranceles impuestos por el expresidente Donald Trump, en especial sobre productos importados desde China.
Los aumentos comenzar√°n a finales de este mismo mes, y se intensificar√°n durante junio.
El director financiero, John David Rainey, se mostr√≥ visiblemente preocupado por las repercusiones en el bolsillo del pueblo estadounidense: ‚ÄúLos consumidores ver√°n precios m√°s altos. Eso es inevitable.‚Äù.
Los nuevos grav√°menes, del 10% sobre todos los productos importados, afectan de lleno a art√≠culos esenciales como colchones, juguetes, cochecitos y otros bienes de consumo familiar.

En diez estados con gran presencia latina, operan 1.748 de sus 4.613 tiendas ‚Äîes decir, el 38% de toda su red nacional.
Entre estos estados destacan Texas, California, Florida y Nueva York, donde tambi√©n vive la mayor√≠a de los dominicanos en EEUU.
Las comunidades dominicanas ‚Äîfuertemente asentadas en Nueva York, Nueva Jersey, Florida y Massachusetts‚Äî ver√°n c√≥mo los productos esenciales se encarecen.
Walmart, consciente de la importancia del consumidor latino, ha intentado acercarse con campa√±as en espa√±ol y productos culturales espec√≠ficos.
Muchas empresas trasladan los costos al consumidor m√°s vulnerable.

title: Stocks rally thanks to pause on China tariffs, decent inflation data
content: Economists have pared back their original estimates for tariff-driven stagflation, but they still warn pain from increased prices will be felt this summer.
resumen:
Wall Street has recouped all of its losses for 2025, as investors rallied once the White House announced a potential trade deal with China this week.

President Donald Trump said he had reached an understanding with China to unwind most of the tariffs between the two countries.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average had gained 1,405 points for the week. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also had good weeks, increasing 299 points and a whopping 1,283 points, respectively.

Retail sales for April were about what was expected, coming in at 0.1%. Economists had predicted retail sales excluding automobiles would rise to 0.3%, and the metric missed, echoing the 0.1% retail sales increase.

The consumer price index increased just 0.2% in April, despite decreasing in March. The CPI gained 2.3% year-over-year, the smallest increase seen since early 2021. Gasoline prices led the way, dropping 10% year-over-year, while grocery prices declined 0.1% even as egg prices remain up sharply from a year ago.

The producer price index also showed a 0.5% decrease last month, greater than expected, with prices increasing 2.9% year-over-year. So-called ‚Äúsupercore PPI‚Äù ‚Äî which excludes food, energy and trade services ‚Äî fell 0.1%, the first decline seen since April 2020.

Walmart CEO Doug McMillon said ‚Äúwe aren‚Äôt able to absorb all the pressure‚Äù of tariffs and that ‚Äúthe higher tariffs will result in higher prices.‚Äù

The National Federation of Independent Business‚Äôs monthly small optimism index dropped again, this time by 1.6 points and remaining below the index‚Äôs average of 98 for the second consecutive month.

More than one-third of surveyed business owners said they could not fill certain job openings, while labor quality remains the most important problem for small businesses.

title: US Stock Market Highlights: S&P 500 marks 5th straight gain, up 5% as China tensions cool
content: The S&P 500 rose for a fifth straight session on Friday, closing the week up 5.3%, despite weak consumer sentiment data and inflation concerns. The Nasdaq jumped 7.2%, while the Dow gained 3.4%. Tech ...
resumen: The S&P 500 closed higher on Friday, extending its winning streak to five sessions and posting a strong weekly gain of 5.3%. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.52% to end at 19,211.10, surging 7.2% for the week, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 331.99 points, or 0.78%, to finish at 42,654.74‚Äîbringing the 30-stock index into positive territory for 2025. Gains were driven by optimism over easing US-China trade tensions. Technology stocks led the market higher, with Nvidia climbing 16%, Meta advancing 8%, Apple rising 6%, and Microsoft gaining 3%. Consumer sentiment declined in May, with inflation concerns weighing on households. The University of Michigan‚Äôs consumer sentiment index dropped to 50.8 from 52.2 in April. Expectations for inflation over the next year rose to 7.3% from 6.5%. The Federal Reserve has announced plans to reduce its workforce by 10% over the coming years.  Nvidia is planning to set up a research and development centre in Shanghai.  American retails chains are experiencing a resurgence as American consumers shift away from Chinese e-commerce platforms Temu and Shein.  President Donald Trump‚Äôs flagship tax and spending proposal has been rejected by the House Budget Committee in a 21‚Äì16 vote. Coinbase shares rose more than 9% on Friday.  The Dow Jones Industrial Average futures are up around 100 points, while S&P is around 15 points. The Nasdaq Composite Index futures around around 60 points a few minutes before the opening bell. Barclays has increased its price target for chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) from $110 to $130. Novo Nordisk has removed Chief Executive Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen.  Trump‚Äôs tariffs on Chinese goods are expected to remain in place at levels likely to significantly restrict Chinese exports to the United States, even after the current 90-day truce.

title: Texas businesses feel the pinch from Trump‚Äôs tariffs, Fed survey finds
content: The higher taxes on imports will shrink Texas businesses‚Äô profits and raise costs for consumers, business owners say.
resumen:
Texas business owners told the Dallas Federal Reserve that they expect higher prices and a slowdown amid uncertain policies from the Trump administration.

Nearly 60% of Texas business owners say the Trump administration‚Äôs back-and-forth on tariffs, a tax on imported goods, has already harmed their business, recent survey results by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas show.

Once those tariffs are in full swing, a majority of business owners said they expect the new levies to bite into profits, raise costs for businesses, and harm their business in the long run.

More than 75% said they would pass increased costs from tariffs on to the consumer. Most said they‚Äôd do so within three months of tariffs taking effect.

The April survey results come from the Dallas Fed, an arm of the Federal Reserve System. The Dallas Fed regularly surveys hundreds of Texas business owners across a range of industries to gauge their feelings about the economy, their business outlook and what effects policies have on their business.

Trump enacted a 10% baseline tariff on all countries in April, but initiated a 90-day pause on many additional tariffs targeted at specific countries he announced in April after global markets panicked.

More than two-thirds of business owners said they expect the cost of doing business to rise owing to higher material and equipment costs. A plurality expects revenue to fall and that they‚Äôll pull back on hiring, production and investment.

Some 44% of businesses surveyed by the Dallas Fed said they‚Äôd absorb higher costs. Another 14% said they‚Äôd scale back their operations or shutter their business entirely.

About 29% said they plan to find new domestic suppliers should they face higher duties on foreign goods. But less than 6% said they‚Äôd relocate production or services stateside.

title: President Donald Trump said cargo slowdown at U.S. ports is a ‚Äúgood thing.‚Äù Economists say it‚Äôs not
content: Economists say a cargo slowdown at U.S. ports would result in job losses for people employed at ports, in transportation and at warehouses. Those employees‚Äô economic losses will radiate outward into ...
resumen:
Donald Trump stated on May 8, 2025, in an event in the White House: "Declining cargo traffic at U.S. ports ‚Äúmeans we lose less money. ‚Ä¶ When you say it's slowed down, that's a good thing.‚Äù"

Economists say a cargo slowdown at U.S. ports would result in job losses for people employed at ports, in transportation and at warehouses. Those employees‚Äô economic losses will radiate outward into the economy, harming consumer spending and prompting layoffs in other sectors. Consumer goods shortages could result as well.

Trump‚Äôs assertion that spending less on imports means the U.S. loses less money also draws skepticism from economists. They say trade enables affordable consumer products, and that consumers will pay higher prices ‚Äî and potentially buy less ‚Äî if foreign imports are slashed, which would have spiraling effects through the economy.

title: Illinois food businesses in the crosshairs of trade war Trump says will boost U.S. manufacturing
content: Produce from warm climates can‚Äôt be reshored to the U.S. for year-round consumption, like some industrial and consumer goods.
resumen:
President Donald Trump says his tariffs will reshore U.S. manufacturing, yet food businesses, including those in Illinois, are especially hard hit by his trade war since supply chains are tied to local agricultural conditions and can‚Äôt easily be shifted, say business leaders and officials.

Produce such as bananas, pineapple, mangoes, lemons and oranges grow in certain climates and seasons.

Peter Testa, CEO of Testa Produce, a Chicago food distributor founded in 1912, said his company supplies restaurants, schools and hospitals in Illinois, Wisconsin and Indiana.

Testa Produce‚Äôs massive warehouse in the Back of the Yards neighborhood stores and distributes products from across the U.S. and around the world, including fresh produce, dairy, canned and dry goods and frozen foods.

Shelves in its 91,300-square-foot facility are stacked high with boxes of pineapple, oranges, cantaloupe, apples, coconut water, hominy, refried beans, pasta and more.

Produce from warm climates can‚Äôt be reshored to the U.S. for year-round consumption, like some industrial and consumer goods.

U.S. Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi, D-Ill., who represents the 8th Congressional District, said last month, during visits to Illinois food businesses, including Testa Produce, ‚ÄúIt shouldn‚Äôt be used as a weapon, especially when everybody needs it.‚Äù

The International Fresh Produce Association said last month in a statement that broad application of tariffs as a ‚Äúblunt tool disrupts markets, raises consumer costs and places unnecessary strain on growers and producers across the supply chain.‚Äù

On April 2, Trump announced tariffs on about 60 countries but then paused them for 90 days after global financial markets plunged.

Despite the reprieve, most imports from those countries to the U.S. face a 10% tariff.

After the pause lifts in July, tariffs on other countries could soar again.

In April, Trump exempted many goods under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement from tariffs.

Testa Produce sources food from other countries that face tariffs, including Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, El Salvador, Brazil and Venezuela, as well as Asian nations.

Food buyers such as Testa Produce are unsure whether to buy now or to wait, in case Trump rolls back his tariffs.

Testa said during Krishnamoorthi‚Äôs visit to the food distributor, ‚ÄúMany customers are wondering how this will all end. I don‚Äôt have answers for them. There‚Äôs mass confusion.‚Äù

In April, Trump ordered 145% tariffs on goods from China.

On Monday, U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said the U.S. agreed to drop the tariffs to 30%, while China agreed to lower its rate on U.S. goods from 125% to 10%.

Mark Williams, chief Asia economist at Capital Economics, warned, ‚ÄúThere is no guarantee that the 90-day truce will give way to a lasting ceasefire.‚Äù

Dani Rodrik, an economist at Harvard University, said the two countries had stepped back ‚Äúfrom a needless trade war‚Äô‚Äô but that U.S. tariffs on China remain high at 30% ‚Äúand will mainly hurt U.S. consumers.‚Äô‚Äô

Elliot Richardson, president of Chicago-based Small Business Advocacy Council, said last month that in general, small businesses bear the brunt of tariffs and their ‚Äúdevastating impact.‚Äù

Richardson, who also joined Krishnamoorthi‚Äôs visit to Testa Produce, said, ‚ÄúTheir margins will be smaller, or they will pass costs on to customers. Larger companies have the means to absorb lower margins. Small businesses do not. I don‚Äôt want to see small businesses fail because of a trade war they have no control over. Small businesses should not be collateral in a trade war.‚Äù

Tariffs also affect U.S. farmers when other countries place retaliatory tariffs on the crops they export.

Illinois is the nation‚Äôs second-leading exporter of both soybeans and feed grains and related products, according to the Illinois Department of Agriculture.

On Krishnamoorthi‚Äôs tour of food businesses last month, he also visited Kindred Farms in Atlanta, about two hours south of Chicago.

Owner Ron Kindred is busy planting this year‚Äôs soybean crop at his 1,700-acre farm.

Krishnamoorthi timed his visits to Illinois food businesses nearly two weeks ahead of his May 7 announcement to run for the U.S. Senate to replace Sen. Dick Durbin.

Tariffs create extreme uncertainty about the price soybeans will fetch later this year, whether $10 per bushel or $7, Kindred said.

Market prices for soybeans have dropped from $16 per bushel two years ago to about $10 now, he added.

Kindred said, ‚ÄúIf it goes down to $8, there‚Äôs no way we can re-coup our costs.‚Äù

Soybean farmers might not break even at $10 per bushel, he said.

Last fall, Kindred fertilized about 850 acres for soybeans on his farm, so it‚Äôs too late to make any big changes to his crop.

Kindred, who is also chairman of the Illinois Soybean Association, said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just out here, caught in the crossfire.‚Äù

Across the U.S., farmers export 60% of their soybeans and China is their largest market, Kindred said.

Farmers will likely pause spending on new equipment and other investments, said Kindred, who had been thinking of buying new tractors for his farm.

Tariffs also raise prices on potash fertilizer from Canada.

Kindred said, ‚ÄúThey drive the prices of everything up.‚Äù

China‚Äôs retaliatory tariffs on U.S. imports particularly hurt American food producers, the American Farm Bureau Federation said.

The Washington, D.C.-based group said in February, ‚ÄúWe know from experience that farmers and rural communities will bear the brunt of retaliation.‚Äù

In response to this week‚Äôs truce between the U.S. and China, American Farm Bureau Federation President Zippy Duvall said in a statement, ‚ÄúChina is one of the top three export destinations for America‚Äôs farmers and ranchers, so word of the 90-day pause was welcomed news.‚Äù

The International Fresh Produce Association said in a statement: ‚ÄúWe are encouraged by the recent progress between the U.S. and China to ease reciprocal tariffs and reduce trade barriers. As one of the largest global markets, China plays a critical role in the produce and floral industry‚Äôs international supply chain, and this agreement marks a positive step toward creating a more stable trade environment. But the 90-day reprieve provides temporary relief, and uncertainty remains.‚Äù

Kindred said, ‚ÄúThe long-range impact of tariffs makes our soybeans uncompetitive in the world marketplace. That‚Äôs our big concern.‚Äù

When Trump ordered tariffs on China in 2018, U.S. soybean farms ‚Äúlost market share to counterparts in South America, who expanded production,‚Äù he added.

Between 2018 and 2019, tariffs resulted in about $2

title: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs All About Trump‚Äôs Tariffs‚Äô: Asia Flocks to U.S. Trade Official
content: Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation nations, staring down U.S. tariffs, jockeyed for time with U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer at a gathering in South Korea.
resumen: The gathering of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) trade ministers offered intrigue and urgency as countries scrambled to engage the United States in talks before a 90-day pause on tariffs expires in July. The meeting, which took place this week on South Korea‚Äôs resort island of Jeju, was the first opportunity for the group of mostly Asian economies and the United States to meet collectively since President Trump announced ‚Äî and then suspended ‚Äî what he called reciprocal tariffs on dozens of trading partners. The heaviest duties were applied to imports from trading partners in Asia. The main attraction at the meeting was Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative and one of the two main negotiators who reached an agreement for a temporary truce on tariffs with China last weekend. Cheong Inkyo, South Korea‚Äôs minister of trade, said many participating countries had originally planned to send vice ministers to the meeting but then changed their minds and sent ministers to push for meetings with Mr. Greer. David Boling, a director of Japan and Asia trade at the Eurasia Group and a former U.S. trade negotiator, said that most countries were eager to meet with American officials at meetings of APEC, but that such discussions were even more critical this time because of the looming deadline on July 9. Last month, Mr. Trump imposed tariffs on goods from dozens of countries. A week later, after blowback in the financial markets, he suspended the tariffs for 90 days to allow time for negotiations. He kept a 10 percent ‚Äúbase-line‚Äù tariff on all imports. In setting the reciprocal tariffs, Mr. Trump reserved some of the most punishing duties for longtime allies such as South Korea and Japan and countries in Southeast Asia like Vietnam, Thailand and Cambodia. Britain is the only trading partner that has reached an agreement with the Trump administration so far. Mr. Cheong said he had been able to speak with Mr. Greer about the progress that the countries had made since the start of discussions in early May. Mr. Trump hit South Korea, a longtime U.S. ally, with a 25 percent tariff. Mr. Greer also met with the vice chairman of HD Hyundai, the heavy-industry arm of South Korea‚Äôs Hyundai conglomerate, to discuss opportunities for cooperation in shipbuilding. According to South Korean media reports, Mr. Greer also met with Li Chenggang, China‚Äôs trade envoy. Under the agreement, the United States reduced tariffs on Chinese imports to 30 percent from 145 percent, and China cut levies on American goods to 10 percent from 125 percent. The reprieve is set to expire in early August. APEC slashed its economic outlook for the region from projections made two months earlier, before Mr. Trump announced the reciprocal tariffs, which affect more than half of APEC‚Äôs 21 members. The group, which accounts for around half of global trade and about 60 percent of economic output, cut its forecast for growth this year to 2.6 percent from its previous projection of 3.3 percent. Carlos Kuriyama, who leads economic and trade research at APEC, said a reduction in trade with the United States would be difficult to overcome.
